President #Ramaphosa: It must be emphasised that this remission excludes those sentenced for violent, aggressive and sexual offences, as well as people declared dangerous criminals in terms of section 286A of the Criminal Procedure Act of 1977.

President #Ramaphosa: The Minister of Justice and Correctional Services @RonaldLamola will provide the relevant details and specific circumstances with regard to relevant offenders. #ReconciliationDaypic.twitter.com/vuyxEihA8R
President #Ramaphosa: The process will be done in various phases, starting with special categories, including women, children, the elderly, youth and inmates with disabilities. #ReconciliationDay
President #Ramaphosa: There have been previous remissions of this nature granted to coincide with important national days. #ReconciliationDay

President #Ramaphosa: Remissions of sentences are always carefully considered, taking into account interests of the public and the administration of justice. We recognise that incarceration has followed a judicial process & that sentences have been duly imposed after conviction.

President #Ramaphosa: In celebrating the 25 years of democracy, and in line with established international practice, I have decided, in terms of the Constitution, to grant a special remission of sentence to specific categories of sentenced offenders, probationers and parolees.pic.twitter.com/5tWWMhJkpu

President #Ramaphosa: We have reached across the divide and embraced each other, and in this month and every month we must continue to do so. Despite our backgrounds, cultures and beliefs and political affiliations, we are one nation.

President #Ramaphosa: Let us make an effort to learn each other’s languages and to teach our own to others. We will not allow the prophets of doom to tell us that we are worse off than before 1994, or that race relations have deteriorated. #ReconciliationDay

President #Ramaphosa: We see it on our TV screens, where programming reflects the diversity of cultures of this country, but most especially the diversity of language. Let us not see language as a barrier to coexistence, but as a means to reach out to those of different cultures.
President #Ramaphosa: We see it in our Parliament, where young and old, black and white represent the interests of their communities and give voice to their concerns.
President #Ramaphosa: We see it in universities that are becoming ever-more inclusive, where students graduate in traditional attire and their families break out into ululation and dance.

President #Ramaphosa: We see it in our schools, where black children and white children learn and play side by side. And when the newspapers carry stories of the top performing matriculants they are African, white, Indian and coloured.

President #Ramaphosa: For the first time, our national rugby team is captained by a black man, Siya Kolisi. Our most famous athlete is a black woman from Ga-Masehlong, Mokgadi Caster Semenya, and our most famous swimmer, Chad le Clos, is a white man. #ReconciliationDaypic.twitter.com/LySbb2Ebb1

President #Ramaphosa: We saw South Africans of all races take to the streets, proudly waving the national flag, and proclaiming their pride in their country. We need only look around us to see just how far we have come.pic.twitter.com/9Z9Gz5P8Sq

President #Ramaphosa: We witnessed this clearly with the outpouring of joy when the Springboks won the Rugby World Cup in Japan last month, and when our Zozibini Tunzi was crowned Miss Universe last week. #ReconciliationDaypic.twitter.com/Faywvqgz6D

President #Ramaphosa: Reconciliation must mean that South Africans must reach out to one another through language, cultural appreciation, sports & through daily life activities. Although there may be pockets of intolerance, we remain a people prepared to see each other as equals.

“Let us speak out against violence wherever we see it, whether it involves our brothers, our uncles, our sons or our friends. Let us say enough is enough. Sekwanele. Leligazi’ el’chithekile selanele.” #ReconciliationDaypic.twitter.com/tw24GMV3NX

“Reconciliation is not only about race, but also about the human condition. It is about bridging the divide between women and men. This means that the empowerment of women and the achievement of gender equity is one of our most important tasks.” President @CyrilRamaphosapic.twitter.com/0M2loh76Xq

“Reconciliation is therefore also about healing the wounds of the past by restoring the land and the wealth to all the people, and realising the rights of all South Africans to dignity, security and comfort.” President @CyrilRamaphosa #ReconciliationDaypic.twitter.com/7vlZVWsHUW

“Reconciliation is about acknowledging that South Africa belongs to all who live in it, united in our diversity. It makes us all equal citizens of this country, with an equal claim to being South African.” President @CyrilRamaphosa #ReconciliationDaypic.twitter.com/s4gKJw6sWK

President #Ramaphosa: This day, once symbolising domination of one group over another, is now an occasion to celebrate the pact we made to start on a clean slate & strive towards realising a society founded on reconciliation, non-racialism, non-sexism, equality, peace & justice.

President #Ramaphosa: When we attained our democracy in 1994 we took a conscious decision that the 16th of December would be a day we commemorate both historical events, and in doing so, reconcile our nation. #ReconciliationDay

President #Ramaphosa: It is therefore significant that this day of the year also marks the day in 1961 on which Umkhonto we Sizwe, the military wing of the ANC, was formed to resist the savagery of apartheid dispossession and oppression. #ReconciliationDaypic.twitter.com/e5y1ArSnWP

President #Ramaphosa: In that historic battle, brave Zulu warriors with assegais succumbed in large numbers to the firepower of the Voortrekkers, and, it is said, the Ncome River ran red with the blood of these freedom fighters. #ReconciliationDay

President #Ramaphosa: This day of the year was proclaimed as the Day of the Vow by our apartheid rulers to remember the fierce battle in 1838 at the Ncome River between the Voortrekkers and the Zulu people under His Majesty King Dingane. #ReconciliationDay

President #Ramaphosa: That we have been able to overcome a bitter past and stand here today to proclaim ourselves proud South Africans, black and white, is testimony to the strength and resolve of a great people.
President #Ramaphosa: A celebration of the triumph of reconciliation over retribution, of goodwill over animosity, and of fellowship over hatred. #ReconciliationDaypic.twitter.com/1JqL3U3l36

President #Ramaphosa: This is a place of immense beauty, lying at the foot of the majestic Drakensberg. But like many parts of this province it has been in the grip of drought. So we were all immensely pleased last week when the heavens opened to give some relief to Bergville.

President #Ramaphosa: The design of our national coat of arms pays homage to our Khoisan forebears, and every time it is displayed we are reminded of the deep and enduring links between us and our ancient past. #ReconciliationDay

President #Ramaphosa: Bergville is also the gateway to the uKhahlamba-Drakensburg Park where the San rock art at this World Heritage Site gives us a glimpse into the lives of our ancestors who lived here thousands of years ago. #ReconciliationDay

President #Ramaphosa: From the founding of Ezintabeni ZoKhahlamba by Inkosi uZikhali, to the establishment of the Bergville Mountain Village in the late 1800s, to the South African War of 1899, this area has been witness to a past of both turbulence and progress.

President @CyrilRamaphosa will address today’s gathering under the theme: “The Year of Indigenous Languages: Supporting National Reconciliation Through the Promotion, Development and Preservation of Indigenous Languages” #ReconciliationDaypic.twitter.com/bx3SeK6iRI

#ReconciliationDay is commemorated each year on December 16, in tribute to the progress we have made towards building a society that is rooted in unity, non-racialism and non-sexism.pic.twitter.com/jVKCKxJEQv

The President is also expected to visit #Tembisa on Gauteng's East Rand that has been severely impacted by the recent rains, leading to wide scale flooding.

With South Africa assuming the Chair of the African Union in 2020, President Ramaphosa and President El-Sisi, who is the outgoing AU Chair, also discussed matters around deepening continental integration, peace, security and development.

The President was accompanied by the Ministers of International Relations and Cooperation, Dr Pandor, Defence and Military Veterans, Ms Mapisa-Nqakula, Minister of Trade and Industry Mr Patel, Minister of State Security, Ms Dlodlo and Minister of Tourism Ms Kubayi-Ngubane.

The focus of the Egypt visit was to strengthen bilateral & economic relations with the largest export market in North Africa for South African goods. The leaders of both countries further discussed new avenues of cooperation in trade and investments.

President Ramaphosa was slated to participate in a high-level panel at the Inaugural Aswan Forum for Sustainable Peace and Development on the 11th of December 2019 but has returned to South Africa to attend to urgent domestic priorities.

President Ramaphosa will also visit the operations centre at Eskom headquarters at Megawatt Park in Gauteng. The President departed the Egyptian capital Cairo on Tuesday, where he held official talks with President Abdel Fatah El-Sisi.

President @CyrilRamaphosa will on Wednesday, 11th of December 2019, meet with the Board and Management of the national power utility #Eskom - where he will be briefed on plans to mitigate and resolve the current electricity crisis affecting most of the country.

President Ramaphosa will on Wednesday the 11/12/19 meet with the Board and Management of the national power utility Eskom - where he will be briefed on plans to mitigate and resolve the current electricity crisis affecting most of the country. https://bit.ly/35jkF8V

President @CyrilRamaphosa has arrived in Cairo, Egypt where is undertaking an Official Visit. South Africa and Egypt enjoy cordial bilateral relations underpinned by strong historical and fraternal bonds dating back to the era of the liberation struggle. #BetterAfricaBetterWorldpic.twitter.com/dWANVC5tdW

The President has directed the Ministry of Public Enterprises as well as Eskom to continue to give regular updates and communication on the progress being made to restore the units back to full capacity. #Eskom

“The energy challenges in this country will not be resolved overnight. We have set out on a bold path of restructuring and rebuilding. Despite the setbacks of the past week, we are making progress and will steadily begin to see the fruits of these efforts.” #Eskom

“Government has taken far-reaching and necessary decisions to ensure the sustainable security of energy supply. As we confront the immediate challenges, we are working to put these long term solutions in place.” #Eskom

“The anger & frustration that load shedding has caused is understandable. It is essential at this time that all stakeholders work together to restore adequate supply of electricity in the shortest time. We call on all South Africans to reduce consumption at this time.” #Eskom

“Our immediate priority is to get as much generating capacity back on line within the shortest possible time. Eskom’s emergency response command centre and technical teams are working around the clock to fix multiple breakdowns.” #Eskom
“The extreme weather in several parts of the country over the last week has compounded the problems of an electricity grid that was already under great strain”. #Eskom
President Ramaphosa said: “The ongoing load shedding is devastating for the country. It is causing our economy great harm and disrupting the lives of citizens”. #Eskom

The President has been in constant communication with the Minister of Public Enterprises and the leadership of the electricity utility on the state of the national grid and the work being done to address the current crisis. #Eskom

President @CyrilRamaphosa this afternoon (Monday 9 December 2019) received an update on the most recent developments at #Eskom’s power stations, which resulted in the escalation of load shedding to stage 6.

President Ramaphosa is undertaking an Official Visit to Egypt taking place on 10/12/19. Whilst in Egypt, President Ramaphosa will participate in the Inaugural Session of the “Aswan Forum for Sustainable Peace and Development” on 11/12/19 in Aswan. https://bit.ly/2YwSNLH

#Togo is the world’s 4th largest phosphate producer. Lomé, the capital city of Togo, is a major harbour and a major trade centre in West Africa. President #Ramaphosa: Be comforted in the knowledge and pride that he has left behind a great legacy. Akwehlanga lungehlanga. Ah Zwelonke! Ah Zwelonke! Ah Zwelonke!

President #Ramaphosa: I pray that God may assuage the pain and anguish of your bereavement and leave you only with the cherished memory of his Majesty, your loved son, husband, brother, and uncle. #RIPKingSigcawu

President #Ramaphosa: To the Sigcawu Royal Family this is a difficult time for you. It may well be that all our words and speeches here today and in the past few days since his passing may be weak and fruitless attempts to comfort you from a grief of a loss so overwhelming.
President #Ramaphosa: I once again convey my deepest condolences to the entire AmaXhosa nation for your loss. #RIPKingSigcawupic.twitter.com/fkWN7Ni9r2

President #Ramaphosa: True to this legacy, His Majesty promoted harmony between the AmaRharhabe and AmaGcaleka. He was an advocate for traditional leadership playing a greater role in national affairs. #RIPKingSigcawu
President #Ramaphosa: In seeking to define itself and its identity, the amaXhosa nation has never shied away from the principle of inclusivity, tolerance and coexistence. #RIPKingSigcawu

President #Ramaphosa: We know that the mother of iKumkani uNgubengcuka yaba Thembu was birthed by the daughter of Khawuta, who was from AmaXhosa. And that the mother of Mhlontlo, the King of amaMpondomise was the daughter of Sarhili, a King yamaXhosa. #RIPKingSigcawu
President #Ramaphosa: One notes for example how marriages between different groups led to the forging of new alliances and the cementing of ties. #RIPKingSigcawu
President #Ramaphosa: This was not done by conquest but by voluntary association and assimilation, resulting in unity among different peoples.
President #Ramaphosa: The history of amaXhosa kingdom bears witness to the acceptance and embrace of other groups in the region, united by a common language, isiXhosa. #RIPKingSigcawu
President #Ramaphosa: He further believed that none of these should be used as a means of exclusion, or that the amaXhosa kingdom should become a citadel of ethnic or racial purity. #RIPKingSigcawu

President #Ramaphosa: Across the expanses of this very land of the Xhosa live AmaBomvana, OoGaba and many others. His Majesty, like his forebears believed that among the duties of kingship was to promote inclusivity through culture, language and custom. #RIPKingSigcawu

President #Ramaphosa: King Sigcawu was a unifier. With his progressive views he was following in the footsteps of his illustrious predecessors. The Xhosa nation has throughout history distinguished itself as a home and a refuge for many groups fleeing persecution. #RIPKingSigcawu

President #Ramaphosa: Through his projects - the King Zwelonke Legacy Project and the King Zwelonke Foundation, he fervently championed community development, moral regeneration, education and agricultural projects. #RIPKingSigcawu

President #Ramaphosa: He was vocal about the need for increased constitutional responsibilities for traditional leaders and critical about government’s pace of service delivery, but remained a patriot and a proud South African. #RIPKingSigcawu

President #Ramaphosa: During his short reign, His Majesty distinguished himself in various ways. He was an outspoken champion of transformation and development, and always forthright with his views. #RIPKingSigcawu

President #Ramaphosa: This province produced freedom fighters such as Nelson Mandela, Winnie Mandela, Water Sisulu, Albertina Sisulu, Oliver and Adelaide Tambo, Govern Mbeki, Raymond Mhlaba, Chris Hani, Steve Tshwete and many others. #RIPKingSigcawu
President #Ramaphosa: During apartheid, the people of this province fought the brutality of the system that deprived our people of land, and political and economic rights. #RIPKingSigcawu
President #Ramaphosa: The role of AmaXhosa leaders in resisting colonialism inspired generations of freedom fighters who eventually led this country to freedom and democracy in 1994. #RIPKingSigcawu

President #Ramaphosa: On behalf of the people of South Africa I extend my deepest condolences to the Royal family & to AmaXhosa people. We are saddened, but we know that no matter how much we wish to, we cannot hold back the hand of fate. It was His Majesty’s time to leave us.

President #Ramaphosa: The Sigcawu family has lost a husband, a father, a brother and a friend. As a nation we have lost a respected leader who was a pillar of the community and a solid partner of our government. Si ngatsho ukuthi Uwile umthi omkhulu.

President #Ramaphosa: Amakhosi noKumkani are the repository, guardians, keepers, custodians, promoters and protectors of our customs, languages and culture. They are the great umbilical link that connects us to our past, keeps us rooted to our present and guides us to our future.

President #Ramaphosa: We have lost a great leader. His majesty’s passing is a reminder of the shortness of our life on this earth. It is a reminder to us to spend our time wisely, in performing good acts, and in being of service to others as His Majesty did. #RIPKingSigcawu

President #Ramaphosa: A cloud of sadness has descended upon the AmaXhosa nation and on the entire South African nation. It was for this reason & out of respect of His Majesty that we declared that our nation’s flag be flown at half-mast throughout the country. #RIPKingSigcawu

His Majesty became King of amaXhosa in 2006 and led his people until his passing. He was the first King in South Africa to be crowned in 2015 after the democratic recognition of traditional leadership. President @CyrilRamaphosa will deliver the eulogy. #RIPKingSigcawupic.twitter.com/eiAaLvNUNM

#Medupi is the first base load station to be built in 20 years by #Eskom after Majuba Power Station. This base-load power station was formerly known as Project Alpha and has since been named Medupi which means “rain that soaks parched lands, giving economic relief”. #Khawulezapic.twitter.com/x2zjCvM5Ic

The President was briefed on the status of the project - #Medupi will be the world’s fourth largest coal-fired power station and once completed, it will be able generate enough electricity to power almost the whole of the Gauteng provincepic.twitter.com/pszBXrlj8a

President #Ramaphosa: We will not be defeated by this scourge. We will turn the tide. Let us move together, a nation resolute and above all united, to end gender-based violence and femicide forever.pic.twitter.com/qQ5jgd7AHW

President #Ramaphosa: Let us remember the words of German playwright Bertolt Brecht: “Those who stay at home when the battle begins and leave others to fight for a cause must be aware: because those who did not share the fight will share the defeat.” #16DaysofActivism
President #Ramaphosa: We know that gender-based violence affects and impacts us all. None of us can be impartial or indifferent. #16DaysofActivism #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: The success we have registered so far in implementing the #EmergencyActionPlan is the fruit of collaboration between government, civil society and the private sector. It demonstrates what we can do if we work together. #16DaysofActivism #EnoughIsEnough
President #Ramaphosa: It is to the good and decent men and boys out there, who would not even dream of hurting, disrespecting or abusing a woman that I direct my message today.

President #Ramaphosa: I will say it again – violence against women is not a problem of women, it is a problem of men. Our message to those who abuse women has been abundantly clear: there is no place in our society for you. #16DaysofActivism #EnoughIsEnoughpic.twitter.com/fQkBCnFyTF

President #Ramaphosa: This campaign will complement a wider 365-day, year-round education, awareness and #prevention campaign that government will roll out in partnership with civil society. #16DaysofActivism #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: Far too many men and boys believe women are inferior, that they are the property of their husbands and fathers, and worse yet, that women and girls ‘deserve’ to be raped because of how they dress, the places they visit, and the friends they keep.

President #Ramaphosa: At the root of gender-based violence are sexist and patriarchal attitudes. The national campaign that we are launching here today is aimed at raising awareness around the rights of women and girls, but also at changing the #attitudes of men and boys.

President #Ramaphosa: To ensure that those found guilty of gender-based violence receive punishment proportionate to the seriousness of their crimes, we are in the process of reforming existing laws around #bail and #sentencing.

President #Ramaphosa: Government employees who work with children and mentally disabled persons are being vetted against the #NationalRegister of Sex Offenders. To date, over 1,200 officials have been vetted, including prosecutors and members of the SAPS. #16DaysofActivism

President #Ramaphosa: We are working to address this problem, and the Department of Health is currently conducting an #audit of forensic health nurses in Limpopo and Mpumalanga. #16DaysofActivism #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: I encourage members of the public to contact the #GBVCommandCentre to alert us to stations that do not have them. Many communities, including the Lephalale community, have told us about personnel shortages at health care facilities. #16DaysofActivismpic.twitter.com/61vfpMEl2n

President #Ramaphosa: To date 7000 rape evidence collection kits have been distributed to police stations countrywide and Limpopo received 700 #rapekits in the first week of this month. #16DaysofActivism #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: The SAPS has allocated 312 new recruits currently undergoing basic #training to the Family Violence, Child Protection and Sexual Offences Units. Nearly 4,500 SAPS members have also received training on the provision of survivor-centered services.
President #Ramaphosa: A project to reopen #unresolved murder and sexual offences cases has already begun in the Eastern Cape and will soon be operational nationally. #16DaysofActivism #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: National and provincial #24HourCallCentres to deal with complaints against SAPS and legal officers in matters of gender-based violence are up and running, and we have achieved our target of attending to all complaints within seven days.

President #Ramaphosa: We are also working to reduce the gender-based violence #casebacklogs at forensic laboratories and are developing a tracking mechanism that will be rolled out in January next year. #16DaysofActivism #EnoughIsEnough
President #Ramaphosa: It will be piloted at a number of courts with significant backlogs in the #NorthWest, #EasternCape and here in #Limpopo. #16DaysofActivism

President #Ramaphosa: Four properties in Pretoria have already been refurbished and will open as #shelters in the first week of December. A 100-day rapid results approach to speed up case #turnaround times was launched in the Eastern Cape last Friday. #16DaysofActivism

President #Ramaphosa: An audit of the country’s 281 designated health facilities is underway to prepare some to adopt the #Thuthuzela model. Provinces are identifying underutilised buildings that can be refurbished and used as shelters. #16DaysofActivism #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: The #ThuthuzelaCareCentres are being expanded, with three new centres planned. Of the four in Limpopo, only two are fully operational, and we will be working with the NPA to ensure they are all capacitated. #16DaysofActivism #EnoughIsEnough
President #Ramaphosa: New #CCTVsystems that allow survivors to testify in privacy have been upgraded at 38 regional courts. #16DaysofActivism #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: In September, a new #SexualOffencesCourt was opened right here in Limpopo in Sibasa and eleven regional courts across all provinces have been identified for upgrade. #16DaysofActivism #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: Since the plan was rolled out, I have been receiving regular weekly updates on our progress. Key aspects of the plan are being implemented and we are on schedule to meet the six month target. #16DaysofActivism #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: It focuses on improving access to justice for survivors, prevention campaigns to change attitudes and behaviour, measures to strengthen the criminal justice system, and the creation of economic opportunities for women who are vulnerable to abuse.

President #Ramaphosa: Two months ago, we announced an #EmergencyActionPlan that has seen R1.6 billion of government funding reprioritised towards programmes to tackle gender-based violence. #16DaysofActivism #EnoughIsEnoughpic.twitter.com/ZjQz8pcgH9

President #Ramaphosa: We remember 2-year-old Samson Sithole from Seraheng village, who was kidnapped, raped and murdered in December last year, and his tiny body thrown into the bush. #16DaysofActivism #EnoughIsEnoughpic.twitter.com/7zJKAdFnbh

President #Ramaphosa: We remember 59-year-old Mama Mphephu Sophie Vukeya, a grandmother from Muswana village, who was attacked while collecting firewood and who died in hospital in June after being raped and beaten. #16DaysofActivism #EnoughIsEnoughpic.twitter.com/fDvPAXF9pV

President #Ramaphosa: We remember 11-year-old Thandi Mampane from Ga-Marishane village who went missing from her home in September and whose body was found a week later. #16DaysofActivism #EnoughIsEnoughpic.twitter.com/Suoe1NKgTj

President #Ramaphosa: We remember 6-year-old Boitumelo Matsekoleng from Serageng village who we buried last month: her young life cut short by a man who raped her and left her for dead. #16DaysofActivism #EnoughIsEnoughpic.twitter.com/cfm59WJ2rY

President #Ramaphosa: Our communities are in the grip of violence against those we are supposed to protect. As I stand before you, I invoke the memories of the many women & girls in this province and throughout the country who have suffered from the brutality of men.pic.twitter.com/k51izoJnRQ

President #Ramaphosa: We grew up being taught that as men and boys we must respect women and protect children. We were taught to never, ever raise your hand against a woman. But we have lost our way. #16DaysofActivism #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: This crisis of violence against women and children is a great shame on our nation. It goes against our African values and everything we stand for as a people. #16DaysofActivism #EnoughIsEnoughpic.twitter.com/IsRg2saYbw

[WATCH]: His Excellency President @CyrilRamaphosa addresses the #BRICS Heads of State & Government Dialogue with the see BRICS Business Council and the New Development Bank #BRICS2019 #BetterAfricaBetterWorldhttps://twitter.com/CyrilRamaphosa/status/1195000181663490048 …

President #Ramaphosa: As he concludes a sterling term, we wish President Kamath and his management team greater success for the future. It gives us as leaders of BRICS countries enormous pride to see the commitment and the spirit of the Fortaleza Agreement is alive & thriving.

President #Ramaphosa: The NDB has demonstrated great leadership since it opened its doors in 2015, bringing it on par with and, in some instances, surpassing other regional development banks. We trust that the NDB will maintain this good momentum.
President #Ramaphosa: We call on the NDB to ensure that its financing policies support infrastructure development in all our countries. #BRICS2019

President #Ramaphosa: Institutions like the New Development Bank should consider innovative financing instruments to crowd-in private sector participation. As we grow and strengthen the NDB as an institution, we must not lose sight of its developmental mandate. #BRICS2019
President #Ramaphosa: In this slowing growth environment, where fiscal and monetary policy is limited, public and private role players need to collaborate to support growth. #BRICS2019

President #Ramaphosa: We are confident that the NDB’s activities on the continent will assist in addressing the large infrastructure financing gap that has been impeding economic growth and development in Africa. #BRICS2019
President #Ramaphosa: We stand ready to support the Bank in this process, particularly with regard to reaching out to Africa. #BRICS2019

President #Ramaphosa: South Africa supports the Bank’s flexible approach to membership and the composition of the list of countries to be considered as prospective members for the first phase of expansion. #BRICS2019
President #Ramaphosa: South Africa is particularly impressed with the Bank’s efforts to ensure that it becomes a global financial institution by 2021. #BRICS2019

President #Ramaphosa: As founding members, we made a commitment that the Bank should benefit not only BRICS countries but should extend its horizon to other emerging markets and developing countries. #BRICS2019
President #Ramaphosa: Today, we proudly acknowledge the significant achievements made by the Bank, and for this we commend the stewardship of President Kamath. #BRICS2019

President #Ramaphosa: We must contribute to our own prosperity as we position ourselves to be the critical cog in the rebalancing of the global economy. Investment is a fundamental basis for sustained economic growth. #AfricaInvestmentForum

President #Ramaphosa: Through innovative and ambitious platforms like the Africa Investment Forum, we are able to collaborate to enable Africa to industrialise and achieve greater heights of regional integration. #AfricaInvestmentForum

President #Ramaphosa: We want to produce our own goods for our own domestic markets and for export. We want to be able to stitch, stamp & chisel the words ‘Proudly made in Rwanda’, ‘Proudly made in Ghana’ and ‘Proudly made in Togo’ onto garments, mobile phones, computers & cars.

President #Ramaphosa: We want to reverse this. We want to produce our own food to feed our people. We want to generate our own energy. We want to see greater local beneficiation in our mining and minerals industries. #AfricaInvestmentForumpic.twitter.com/WQMByoLA45

President #Ramaphosa: Today we are faced with a new challenge, of being net importers of products and goods that could be produced domestically. This puts pressure on national balance sheets and diverts economic priorities away from vital social spending. #AIF2019 #InvestSA
President #Ramaphosa: Under colonial rule, Africa’s rich resources were plundered and shipped off to foreign destinations, leaving countries impoverished and under-developed. #AfricaInvestmentForum

“The coming into operation of the #AfCFTA will connect over 1.2bn people & solidify a consumer market that will be worth over $3 trillion by 2030, bringing into being the largest free trade area since the formation of the WTO.” President @CyrilRamaphosa #AfricaInvestmentForumpic.twitter.com/AMYnwhcwhB

“Africa has come into its own, is pursuing growth and development in the interests of its people, and is charting its own course. And now we stand on the cusp of a new era of African integration.” President @CyrilRamaphosa #AfricaInvestmentForum #InvestSApic.twitter.com/sfsEmpOqGk

“If the success of last year’s event is any indication, this forum’s unique focus on dealmaking through the highly impactful boardroom sessions is yielding tangible results. Last year 350 investors from 53 countries participated.” President @CyrilRamaphosa #AfricaInvestmentForumpic.twitter.com/tEShdFixNG

President @CyrilRamaphosa signs the #25YearReview Report. The report is launched for public reflection and debate amongst citizens on the 25 years of democracy in South Africa. The launch took place at the Mpumalanga University, in Mbombela. #Democracy25 #GrowSouthAfricapic.twitter.com/kDSMjaPtuZ

“The 25 Year Review Report will stimulate intense and, at times, ferocious debate about South Africa’s 25 year experience of democracy. This is what it is intended to do.” President @CyrilRamaphosa Launch of #25YearReview Report University of Mpumalangapic.twitter.com/kiYJdLaU8Y

“Eighty percent of South Africans now living in formal dwellings, 14 million households now have piped water, 16 million households have sanitation, and 84% of all households have electricity.” President @CyrilRamaphosa Launch of #25YearReview Report University of Mpumalangapic.twitter.com/BEZdiSt3Xz

President #Ramaphosa: Poverty alleviation grants have now been extended to over 17 million beneficiaries, covering the aged, children and people with disabilities. These measures have improved the standard of life of millions of South Africans and reduced poverty. #25YearReview

President #Ramaphosa: To cushion the most vulnerable members of our society against socio-economic adversity, we have provided social security support in areas such as health, education, housing, water and sanitation, and electricity. #25YearReview #Democracy25 #GrowSouthAfrica

President #Ramaphosa: While significant interventions have been implemented by government aimed at redress and pro-poor policies, South Africa remains the most unequal society in the world. #25YearReview #Democracy25 #GrowSouthAfrica

President #Ramaphosa: In 1994, democratic South Africa inherited an economy in crisis. Yet the size of the South African economy has doubled over the past 25 years. The number of people in employment has also doubled in 25 years, from 8 million to 16 million.pic.twitter.com/mqIVjSZv5F

President #Ramaphosa: Black direct ownership on the JSE still stands at around 3%, and black people still account for only 25% of top management in the private sector. Furthermore, women still account for only 20% of top management across the public and private sectors.

President #Ramaphosa: Over the past 25 years, we have introduced a range of policies, including broad-based black economic empowerment, employment equity, affirmative policies in our procurement and industrial strategies, and land restitution and redistribution. #25YearReview

President #Ramaphosa: The 25 Year Review Report notes that notwithstanding all the legal and policy instruments of redress, poverty and inequality persist. This is largely the result of skewed ownership and participation patterns in our economy. #25YearReview #Democracy25pic.twitter.com/bK016iHvPv

President #Ramaphosa: However, evidence points to a rising burden of non-communicable diseases, which will require dedicated focus from health and other sectors responsible for social determinants of health. #25YearReview #Democracy25

President #Ramaphosa: Life expectancy has improved, while child & infant mortality rates have been significantly reduced. Access to antiretroviral therapy in the public health sector has grown from 45,500 patients in 2004 to over 4.7 million in 2019. #25YearReview #Democracy25

President #Ramaphosa: Access to health care has been significantly improved since the democratic government introduced the policy of free primary health care for children under 6 and pregnant and lactating women in 1996. #25YearReview #Democracy25 #GrowSouthAfricapic.twitter.com/3GRWMTqaSo

President #Ramaphosa: Our reform of the education system has been notable. There is now almost universal school enrolment of children aged 7 to 15. There are more than 800,000 learners below the age of 6 in Grade R. #25YearReview #Democracy25 #GrowSouthAfricapic.twitter.com/UcTs03XLfq

President #Ramaphosa: The matric pass rate has increased from 58% in 1994 to 78.2% in 2018. We have almost doubled the number of special schools for children with disabilities and special needs. Total university enrolment has also doubled, and now stands at over a million.

President #Ramaphosa: Despite this progress, our country still experiences high levels of violence and gender-based crimes committed against women and girls. The economic empowerment of women remains one of the most significant challenges after 25 years.

President #Ramaphosa: There has been a substantial increase in the representation of women in the judiciary, Parliament and legislatures, Cabinet and the public service. #25YearReview #Democracy25 #GrowSouthAfrica

President #Ramaphosa: Since 1994, government has enacted legislative reforms, approved progressive policies and implemented programmes that give expression to the constitutional rights of women and girls to equality, human dignity, freedom and security of the person.pic.twitter.com/D2VH9qfKpI

President #Ramaphosa: The report reflects that our democratic dispensation unleashed creative energies in sport, arts, music, literature, film and dance, as well as science, technology and innovation. Gender equality has been a central part of our struggle for emancipation.

President #Ramaphosa: It now occupies its rightful place in the global community, and is a member of multilateral institutions such as the UN Security Council, the Non-Aligned Movement, the G20, BRICS, the G77+China, and the African Union, among others. #25YearReview

President #Ramaphosa: The 25 Year Review reports a basic, but profound truth, that democratic South Africa is a nation at peace with itself and the world. #25YearReview #Democracy25 #GrowSouthAfricapic.twitter.com/NWYePvPIdD
Launch of the #25YearReview Report at the University of Mpumalanga #Democracy25https://www.pscp.tv/w/cJVKvTFyYVFab3lnemVNS3p8MVlwSmtZZGd5TWpLake_QJI-dEOYbaogkpnzI4_1r_mjVPuvz_sxCme2oeH- …

[PICTURES]: Official opening of the #MpumalangaHighCourt in Mbombela towards the promotion of #AccesstoJusticeForAllpic.twitter.com/WBWxXOMZU8
Address by President Cyril Ramaphosa at the official opening of the Mpumalanga High Court, Mbombela, Mpumalanga https://bit.ly/2pSbMDB

“This is indeed a historic day for the people of Mpumalanga, as we officially open the first provincial High Court right here in Mbombela. This court represents a new era for the citizens of this province who have travelled a long and difficult road to get access to justice.”

Following today’s successful official opening ceremony of the #MpumalangaHighCourt, President @CyrilRamaphosa will this afternoon launch the 25-Year review report at the University of Mpumalanga’s Mbombela Campus. #25YearReview #Democracy25pic.twitter.com/jHzHJQo5NA

President @CyrilRamaphosa with Acting Deputy Chief Justice Sisi Khampepe, Minister of Justice and Correctional Services Ronald Lamola, MP Premier Refilwe Mtshweni-Tsipane and Judge President Francis Legodi during the official opening of the #MpumalangaHighCourt in Mbombela.pic.twitter.com/KZVgm0g8Eq

President #Ramaphosa: It must set the bar for jurisprudence high, and make its mark not just in Mpumalanga but throughout the country. In this the land of the rising sun, a new day has dawned. I declare this court open. Let justice reign.pic.twitter.com/9x1Dq30drN
President #Ramaphosa: It must be an agent of transformation and issue progressive judgments that advance the rights of our people, especially their socio-economic rights. #MpumalangaHighCourt

President #Ramaphosa: It must become a centre of excellence that advances justice and redresses the wrongs of the past, especially through the Land Claims and Labour Courts. #MpumalangaHighCourtpic.twitter.com/THLHX7H83F
President #Ramaphosa: It must inspire the young who want to follow in the footsteps of our great jurists like former Chief Justice Pius Langa, a son of this province. #AccesstoJusticeForAll

President #Ramaphosa: It is not mere bricks and mortar. It must empower every man, woman and child of this province. It must be a beacon of hope for all who have suffered prejudice, victimisation, injustice or harm. #MpumalangaHighCourt

President #Ramaphosa: As we strive to maintain the rule of law, and at the same time give effect to the rights of our citizens, it is critical that public confidence in the courts is maintained. The impact of this court must extend beyond its magnificent structure.pic.twitter.com/0Lvf5FfZJf

“We are working tirelessly to implement our strategy to combat gender-based violence, to restore law & order, and to strengthen the work of our law-enforcement officials.” President @CyrilRamaphosa Official opening of the #MpumalangaHighCourt #AccesstoJusticeForAllpic.twitter.com/M6GduFRBGl

“Never and never again will the rights of our people be undermined by the courts.” President @CyrilRamaphosa Official opening of the #MpumalangaHighCourt #AccesstoJusticeForAllpic.twitter.com/0IHRLtrlxH

President #Ramaphosa: And where court orders are issued against them, there must be compliance. Failure to do so leads citizens to lose confidence in the integrity of the judicial process, which in turn erodes the rule of law. #AccessToJusticeForAllpic.twitter.com/fUEfxvkSgj

President #Ramaphosa: They must deliver health care, education, housing, water, sanitation and electricity without being compelled to do so by the courts. The services must be of quality and respect our people’s dignity. #MpumalangaHighCourt

President #Ramaphosa: Our municipalities and government departments must do their jobs. They must implement government decisions, manage their budgets prudently, and deliver the services that it is our people’s right to access. #AccessToJusticeForAll

President #Ramaphosa: At a time when the public purse is severely constrained, it should not be that claims against the State continue to soar, particularly cases of medical negligence in our public health facilities, but also against the South African Police Service.

President #Ramaphosa: It should not be, indeed it should never be, that the time and resources of our courts are being used to fight legal battles when local, provincial and national government departments fail to meet their obligations to our citizens. #MpumalangaHighCourt

President #Ramaphosa: Our courts face significant resource challenges and are already burdened with huge caseloads and backlogs as they strive to uphold the rights of our citizens. #AccessToJusticeForAll

“Today we are opening a court that will administer justice without fear or favour, in an open and accessible process that reflects the ethos of our Constitution.” President @CyrilRamaphosa Official opening of the #MpumalangaHighCourt #AccesstoJusticeForAllpic.twitter.com/EVZzzwqOlU

“As government we promised that every province will have a fully-fledged, well-resourced and capacitated High Court in line with the provisions of the Superior Courts Act of 2013. We are here today to fulfill that promise.” President @CyrilRamaphosa #AccesstoJusticeForAllpic.twitter.com/H0vie2J0K5

“This court represents a new era for the citizens of this province who have travelled a long and difficult road to get access to justice.” President @CyrilRamaphosa Official opening of the #MpumalangaHighCourt #AccesstoJusticeForAllpic.twitter.com/swtaickgyD

President @CyrilRamaphosa arrives in Mbombela for the opening of the #MpumalangaHighCourt and is received by Minister Ronald Lamola, Acting Deputy Chief Justice Sisi Khampepe and Premier Refilwe Mtshweni-Tsipane.pic.twitter.com/0HQyGA5hzv

President @CyrilRamaphosa delivers the keynote address at the official opening of the Mpumalanga High Court.https://www.pscp.tv/w/cJUl1TFyYVFab3lnemVNS3p8MWpNSmd3WWVkdmpKTMWTi-rhrCidCj7w1NZZxusnllwT8HOkKuHGY5qQQ1WB …

The court building in Mbombela consist of 12 court rooms, of which currently 5 are being utilised. Three for Civil and Two for Criminal cases. One additional Civil Court and one additional Criminal court room will also be utilised in the near future. #MpumalangaHighCourtpic.twitter.com/OYbBssi7l9

President @CyrilRamaphosa is conducted on a tour of the High Court by Judge President Francis Legodi, accompanied by MP Premier Mtshweni-Tsipane, Acting Deputy Chief Justice Sisi Khampepe, Minister Ronald Lamola and Executive Mayor of Cllr J Sidell. #MpumalangaHighCourtpic.twitter.com/zqAcxAEGCW

The #MpumalangaHighCourt was proclaimed on 1 May 2019 with Mbombela as the main seat and Middelburg as the local seat. These permanent seats signify a historic occurrence, as Mpumalanga is the last province to get its own provincial seat of the High Court.pic.twitter.com/VqQ1AjOi5Q

President @CyrilRamaphosa cuts the ribbon during the official opening ceremony of the #MpumalangaHighCourt. The Superior Courts Act of 2013 states that the High Court should have divisions in all nine provinces in the Republic of South Africa.pic.twitter.com/v1Uci07fzb

The official opening of the #Mpumalanga High Court is a milestone towards promoting access to justice. It also means the people of Mpumalanga no longer have to incur travel costs to the Pretoria High Court in Tshwane.pic.twitter.com/VdVk5J4AQ5
President @CyrilRamaphosa will this morning officially open the Mpumalanga High Court in Mbombela. The court started operating earlier this year in May.pic.twitter.com/E4htDqt7jY

Closing Remarks by President Cyril Ramaphosa at the Second South Africa Investment Conference, Sandton Convention Centre, Johannesburg http://bit.ly/2PTrEk0 #InvestSA #SAIC19pic.twitter.com/pAQ7Rj0HuJ

President #Ramaphosa: This is an outstanding achievement and reflects the determination of those companies and associations that have made commitments to invest or further invest in our economy. #InvestSA #SAIC19pic.twitter.com/kjgYlL6VhU

President #Ramaphosa: This commitment of investments amounting to R371 billion if you add the R 8 billion that is still subject to regulatory and board approval processes is 17% higher than the commitments that were made last year.

President #Ramaphosa: It has been estimated that these investments will conservatively lead to the creation of around 412,000 direct jobs over the next 5 years. This doesn’t include the hundreds of thousands of indirect jobs that will be created through allied linkages.

President #Ramaphosa: We have received indications of a further R8 billion in planned investments that are subject to either regulatory or company board approvals and therefore we have not named the companies here today. #SAIC19 #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: I am immensely pleased to announce that the total value of investment commitments made today at our Second South Africa Investment Conference is R363 billion. #SAIC19 #InvestSApic.twitter.com/CvOc736Hkn

President #Ramaphosa: Our investment drive is taking place in tandem with a range of economic developments – from the opening up of special economic zones, to reviving industrial parks, to supporting community business centres, to creating digital hubs & small business incubators
President #Ramaphosa: At the end of our first investment conference last year we had a sense that we carried away many of the small stones from the mountain. #InvestSA #SAIC19

President Ramaphosa: The commitments made at last year’s conference and those made today have placed us firmly on the path to achieve our ambitious target of securing $100 billion – R 1.2 trillion over five years.

President #Ramaphosa: You, like us, are excited by the sheer breadth of opportunities South Africa offers and the potential returns they can deliver. There is a Confucian proverb that goes: “The man who moves a mountain begins by carrying away small stones.” #InvestSA
President #Ramaphosa: The fact that you have come to this conference, and in such numbers, shows the great faith you have in our country and its potential. #InvestSA #SAIC19

President #Ramaphosa: We are all aware that the global economic environment is weakening, and that you as investors have a vast array of choices on where to take your business, and that we are competing with other emerging markets.

President #Ramaphosa: I know that companies that made announcements here are ready to move ahead with a renewed sense of determination to turn the investment commitments made here into new business, new jobs and new opportunities.

President #Ramaphosa: But more importantly, we are immensely encouraged as South Africans by the commitments that have been announced here for it is these investments that will have the effect of boosting our country’s economic growth and create much-needed jobs.

President #Ramaphosa: We are also encouraged by the honest and direct statements that have been made by all the participants who spoke either in the plenary sessions or in the breakaway sessions. #InvestSA #SAIC19

President #Ramaphosa: As the second South Africa Investment Conference draws to a close, I believe I am speaking on behalf of everyone here when I say we are immensely encouraged by the attendance of so many of us here. #InvestSA #SAIC19pic.twitter.com/PwVbbO6Jgi

President #Ramaphosa: Investors are offered a preferential corporate tax regime, building support, employee tax incentives, favourable customs regulations and support for capital investment and training.pic.twitter.com/GRvpafOEAs

President #Ramaphosa: To this end, we have established 10 special economic zones in strategic locations around the country where investors are able to produce and export value-added products. #SAIC19 #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: Labour is committed to improve productivity levels. We have identified special economic zones as platforms that can attract investors and enhance economic growth. #SAIC19 #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: Today we will witness the signing of master plans for the poultry and the clothing, textile and footwear industries. This will lead to the giant retailers in our economy increasing local procurement, investment and job creation. #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: Master plans for each of these sectors will ensure that infrastructure, skills, incentives and other resources are directed towards where they have the greatest impact. #SAIC19 #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: It prioritises growth in important sectors such as automotive, clothing and textiles, gas, chemicals and plastics, tourism, renewable energy, oceans economy, agriculture, mining and beneficiation, the digital economy and the high-tech industries. #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: Central to our efforts to ignite growth and create jobs is an ambitious execution oriented industrial strategy founded on partnerships between government, labour and industry. #SAIC19 #InvestSApic.twitter.com/e4TR1xJPN6

President #Ramaphosa: We are on a path of removing impediments and constraints to inclusive growth. We have embarked on a path that is illuminated by policy consistency and regulatory certainty, fiscal responsibility, and decisive interventions to stimulate economic activity.pic.twitter.com/nncBsJHqST

President #Ramaphosa: We have been steadily working to create a business environment that is competitive and conducive to investment. As a government and as a country, we are clear about what we need to do & we are marshalling our every resource & our every capability to do it.

President #Ramaphosa: We have acted decisively to end state capture and are rebuilding the capacity of the state. We have fostered greater policy coherence and are improving alignment across the different spheres and entities of government. #SAIC19 #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: Working together, we have made much progress in implementing the policy reforms that I spoke about at last year’s Conference, creating policy certainty, consistency and predictability for investors and for citizens. #SAIC19 #InvestSApic.twitter.com/QOlvdh1E4O
President #Ramaphosa: We have determined that we will move forward, effect far-reaching reforms and undertake the detailed work required to turn our economy around. #SAIC19 #InvestSA
President #Ramaphosa: And it was through this collaboration that we identified several major issues we must address to achieve to the economic recovery that we all seek. #SAIC19 #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: We will not falter on our path to improve the condition of our people. It is for this reason that, as a government, we reached out to our social partners to forge a new compact for growth and development. #SAIC19 #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: But, even in the face of such great challenges, hope continues to spring eternal in the hearts of South Africans who are determined that they will not yield to despair. As a nation, we have determined that we will not be defeated by challenges we face.

President #Ramaphosa: Today, we are still feeling the effects of several years of state capture and corruption, the erosion of important public institutions and the resultant policy malaise. #SAIC19 #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: In navigating our way from the horrible past of apartheid misrule into a democratic future, we have made mistakes along the way. Over the last decade, our economy has barely grown, investment has dwindled and the rate of unemployment has increased. #SAIC19pic.twitter.com/2dWzwG0bu5

President #Ramaphosa: Despite significant progress over the last 25 years, the legacy of our divided past has left many of our people without skills, without assets and without jobs. All these factors have combined to exacerbate poverty and inequality. #SAIC19 #InvestSApic.twitter.com/7HGG1LqdiL
President #Ramaphosa: We are also a country which carries the scars of a sad and horrible past, where the colour of one’s skin determined one’s livelihood and future. #SAIC19 #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: Our democracy is strong, robust and wonderfully noisy and our institutions are durable, confirming the political stability of our body politic over the past 25 years and into the future. Yet, we are also a country with many challenges. #SAIC19 #InvestSA
President #Ramaphosa: We have a vibrant civil society, a progressive labour regime and an independent and robust media. #SAIC19 #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: There is the rule of law in this country, our judiciary is independent and our legal framework is strong, especially around commerce, taxation, maritime issues, competition law, intellectual property, property rights and other basic human rights. #SAIC19pic.twitter.com/gok4tizjy7

President #Ramaphosa: Indeed we have a lot to offer, in the form of our people, in natural and mineral resources, with a young and able workforce, world class infrastructure, sophisticated telecommunications systems, and a well-regulated financial and banking sector. #SAIC19
President #Ramaphosa: It is pleasing to see that investors continue to consider South Africa as a country with much to offer and a viable and profitable investment destination. #SAIC19 #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: I have had occasion to be present at some of these factory and facility openings and have seen the optimism and commitment of the business owners, management teams and workers at all these establishments.

President #Ramaphosa: It is gratifying to see the commitments that were made at this Conference last year materialising in the form of new factories, new production lines, new products, new services and new jobs. #SAIC19 #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: Of the 31 projects announced last year eight projects have been realised and completed. 17 are in construction or at implementation stage. In total, this represents R238 billion of the investments that were announced last year. #SAIC19 #InvestSApic.twitter.com/TXwsOF3Hqt

President #Ramaphosa: It is now exactly year since the inaugural South Africa Investment Conference, where local and international investors responded to our call and stood on this platform to make investment announcements totalling nearly R300 billion. #SAIC19 #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: Last year, we announced our objective to raise $100 million – or R1.2 trillion – in new investments over five years with a view to addressing low economic growth and reducing unemployment.
President #Ramaphosa: It is a particular privilege to welcome all our international guests to South Africa, the home of the champions of world rugby. #SAIC19 #InvestSApic.twitter.com/rj5F6PPdml

President #Ramaphosa: The Industrial Development Corporation will assist with the development of business cases for SEZs, securing private investors and conducting due diligence processes on prospective investors. The #TshwaneAutoSEZ will be developed under this new approach.

President #Ramaphosa: Project management units at the Development Bank of Southern Africa will assist in accelerating the roll-out of infrastructure, including bulk infrastructure, factories and warehouses. #TshwaneAutoSEZ #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: Investors will need to be signed up before an area is approved as a Special Economic Zone. All three spheres of government will be involved with the private sector in the planning and development of infrastructure. #TshwaneAutoSEZ #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: It includes resolving regulatory hurdles that have been obstacles to investors. Processes such as securing environmental impact authorisations, water use licenses and the like will be fast-tracked. #TshwaneAutoSEZ

President #Ramaphosa: This excludes construction jobs, indirect jobs and additional jobs from confirmed investments where projects are still under construction. We are introducing a new approach in the implementation of SEZs to enhance their impact. #TshwaneAutoSEZ #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: In early 2018 we announced our intention to mobilise over R1.2 trillion in new investments over the next 5 years. Many of these investments will be located in special economic zones across the country, which to date have created over 16,000 direct jobs.

President #Ramaphosa: Once operational it will support SMMEs, especially black owned businesses, to perform value-added sub-assembly to Tier 1 suppliers of the Ford Motor Company. #TshwaneAutoSEZ #InvestSA

“I am encouraged by the decision of the @FordSouthAfrica Motor Company to work with government to establish the first automotive incubation centre adjacent to the Tshwane Automotive SEZ.” President @CyrilRamaphosa #TshwaneAutoSEZ #InvestSApic.twitter.com/YGntuAiSdZ

President #Ramaphosa: The agreements reached and the partnerships forged at these Summits make an important contribution to economic growth, development and job creation here in South Africa.pic.twitter.com/RPo7EZfKvs

President #Ramaphosa: They also provide an opportunity to advance South Africa’s position on a range of issues like the reform of multilateral institutions to international support for African development. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: They provide a platform for the South African government and business to promote the investment opportunities in the country, to explore new markets and to forge strategic partnerships. #RamaphosaQandA
President #Ramaphosa: While these international summits do not directly create jobs, they can contribute to an improved environment for investment, trade and cooperation. #RamaphosaQandA
President #Ramaphosa: These gatherings provided an opportunity for South Africa to advance its foreign policy and promote its economic interests.

President #Ramaphosa: These included: - G20 Summit in Japan - African Union Extraordinary Summit in Niger - SADC Summit in Tanzania - Tokyo International Conference on Africa’s Development in Japan - Russia-Africa Summit in Sochi, Russia #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: Since the start of the 6th democratic administration in May 2019, I have attended six international summits, covering both political and economic issues. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/C0FwwbJQqb
Closing Remarks by Deputy President David @DDMabuza as Co-Chair of the Plenary Session of the 7th South Africa-China Bi-National Commission, Beijing, China http://bit.ly/2oyVVJz
President #Ramaphosa: This is necessary not only to address the plight of the landless, but to boost the economy, create jobs and reduce poverty, particularly in rural areas.

President #Ramaphosa: Cabinet is therefore determined to shortly finalise its consideration of the recommendations so that the land reform process can proceed at a faster rate and have a greater impact. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/0i1GqSlFkH
President #Ramaphosa: The report of the Advisory Panel has provided the country with a comprehensive, just and sustainable approach to land reform. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/MXy7j7NGXG
President #Ramaphosa: The Inter-Ministerial Committee, which is chaired by the Deputy President, is tasked with coordinating and providing political leadership to accelerate land reform.

President #Ramaphosa: It further proposed circumstances in which such expropriation could be considered. The Panel’s recommendations complement and reinforce the work being done by the Inter-Ministerial Committee on Land Reform and Agriculture.

President #Ramaphosa: The Advisory Panel found that the mechanism of land expropriation without compensation is one of a range of methods that could be used to acquire land for the purposes of land reform. #RamaphosaQandA
President #Ramaphosa: In line with this recommendation, Cabinet has already taken decisions on the release of land for human settlements. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: The Panel has called on government to immediately identify well-located and unused or under-utilised land and buildings for the purposes of urban settlement and to prioritise poor tenants for upgrading their rights.
President #Ramaphosa: This report recommends legal mechanisms to recognise, register, record and enforce a continuum of land rights, so that all our people become rights holders.

President #Ramaphosa: The Advisory Panel has produced several far-reaching recommendations to ensure that we correct the skewed distribution of land in the country, a necessary precondition to our objective of reducing inequality in our country. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/cPWRaFXfEc
President #Ramaphosa: Cabinet still needs to finalise its deliberations on the findings and recommendations of the Advisory Panel. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: As I indicated in this House on 22 August, the report of the Presidential Advisory Panel on Land Reform and Agriculture has been presented to Cabinet and has been made available to the public. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/0gn0YcSy9P
Opening Remarks by Deputy President David @DDMabuza as Co-Chair of the Plenary Session of the 7th South Africa-China Bi-National Commission, Beijing, China. http://bit.ly/36lCSDG
President #Ramaphosa: Given the breadth of interventions, this is a challenging undertaking, but we are confident that – working together – we will succeed. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/eGfnpUEdQ2

President #Ramaphosa: To ensure that the reallocation of resources has the necessary impact, government is working with civil society and other partners to ensure that all of these measures are implemented with urgency.

President #Ramaphosa: The budget for this intervention is still to be finalised through the ongoing reprioritisation process; as is the approximately R20 million still needed to strengthen accountability measures. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: It will also be used to support social services for survivors at local and district municipality level. The plan furthermore calls for the creation of more economic opportunities for women who are vulnerable to abuse because of poverty.

President #Ramaphosa: Two hundred social workers will be appointed to provide targeted services to survivors at various social services centres, including at the national network of Thuthuzela Care Centres. #RamaphosaQandA
President #Ramaphosa: An amount of R517 million will go to care and support for survivors of gender-based violence. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/S6AEUhQOxz
President #Ramaphosa: This funding will ensure that legislation that has been pending is finalised, and, where necessary, that capacity is made available for new laws to be drafted.
President #Ramaphosa: This includes bail and sentencing reform to ensure that perpetrators face justice and that the law acts as an effective deterrent. #RamaphosaQandA
President #Ramaphosa: Work is being done to enhance our current legal and policy framework to make it more responsive to the needs of survivors of gender-based violence. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: The Department of Social Development will drive the roll-out of programmes that will engage men’s formations, traditional leaders, student organisations, youth groups, offenders inside prisons, officials working in the criminal justice system & communities.

President #Ramaphosa: We know that gender-based violence often has its roots in social, cultural and other norms that perpetuate patriarchy and chauvinism. We also know we have to focus on prevention as the first point of intervention. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/ZYI9Bg5YlY

President #Ramaphosa: It will, among other things, review, monitor and evaluate progress, and ensure there is adequate budgeting and resourcing to support the 5 key pillars of the plan. An amount of R179m has been allocated to education, awareness raising & prevention programmes.pic.twitter.com/24NLHyIudq

President #Ramaphosa: The multisectoral interim steering committee established after last year’s Presidential Summit on Gender-based Violence and Femicide will continue to play a key role in driving implementation of this plan.
President #Ramaphosa: Accountability for the expenditure on the reprioritised funds lies with the respective departments. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: Departments must be commended for readily and swiftly responding to this call. We are now in a position to allocate more than R1.6 billion from the 2019/20 financial year baseline spending allocation.

President #Ramaphosa: Since I announced that government would commit R1.1 billion towards the implementation of the plan, National Treasury has written to key departments and entities asking them to urgently identify funds that can be reprioritised. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: It was also a response to mounting calls from our people to match our condemnation of such violence with the commitment of the necessary human, financial and other resources to tackle this crisis. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: When I asked this House to approve the emergency action plan to combat gender-based violence and femicide two months ago, it was in response to a national crisis. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/4StV87st1b

President #Ramaphosa: The measures and interventions we are embarking upon are aimed at ensuring that we reduce the level of unemployment among young people. It is the biggest challenge we face. We must work together to address this challenge. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/OLMSoNCLOT

President #Ramaphosa: That is why we have directed public resources towards the poor, why we have implemented employment equity and broad-based black economic empowerment, why we have massively expanded access to education, and why we have introduced a National Minimum Wage.

President #Ramaphosa: As I have said in this House before, nation building requires that we take measures to advance those South Africans who have been disadvantaged by unfair discrimination. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: We need to encourage our young people to rather than just merely look for jobs, they should be the ones who, through enterprise innovation, create jobs and be the ones who employ other young people. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: As Government we are committed to reducing equality through measures that include diversified job creation, strengthening our manufacturing and productive sectors, attracting investment, and encouraging entrepreneurship especially targeting our young people.pic.twitter.com/QKjIQgc1KG

President #Ramaphosa: The second South Africa Investment Summit will take place from 5-7 November 2019. The Conference will once again seek to mobilise R1,2 trillion in new investments over the next five years and promote the country as a preferred investment destination.pic.twitter.com/0I6HwpdAyZ

President #Ramaphosa: With our relatively established manufacturing base, our developed road, rail, port and energy infrastructure, and our deep financial markets, South Africa is well-placed to make use of the opportunities a free trade area could provide. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: It is for this reason that we have embraced the African Continental Free Trade Area. The #AfCFTA will be a game-changer, both for South Africa and the rest of the continent. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/oRsLQ3dSxg

President #Ramaphosa: The economies of the African continent are together growing at a rate far greater than our own, and we need to see the opportunity that such growth presents for our economy and for our people.

President #Ramaphosa: It is expected that over the next few decades there will be a massive increase in investment in infrastructure across Africa, which should benefit South African construction companies, manufacturers and banks.
President #Ramaphosa: The African marketplace is where our companies will increasingly find trading and investment opportunities. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/MXQjLgFKLr

President #Ramaphosa: On the economic front, we acknowledge that while the economy is driven largely by international demand, growth over the last decade can be disproportionately attributed to the expansion in capital-intensive industries, retail trade, and financial services.
President #Ramaphosa: Develop and implement spatial planning that deliberately breaks the geography and inequalities of apartheid to reflect a non-racial, non-sexist and prosperous society for all.
President #Ramaphosa: Accelerate key social and economic transformation initiatives such as land reform to correct the fault lines in our society.
President #Ramaphosa: These should complement campaigns and programmes such as Proudly South African, and Brand SA.

President #Ramaphosa: In order to foster economic inclusion, the current Medium Term Strategic Framework will seek to stimulate local industries and direct public procurement as well as domestic consumer behavior towards supporting localisation.
President #Ramaphosa: Implementing the summit declaration on Gender Based Violence and Femicide (GBVF) including the development of a National Strategic Plan to combat GBVF and related intolerance.

President #Ramaphosa: There must be full and effective implementation of laws and policies adopted in our country. Greater emphasis should be placed on women’s economic emancipation, which remains a fundamental requirement in transforming unequal gender relations.

President #Ramaphosa: Policy priorities required to address these challenges over the next five years and in the medium to long term include the implementation of the country’s gender mainstreaming policy across all sectors of society.

President #Ramaphosa: As the incoming chair of the African Union next year, South Africa will put great emphasis on giving effect to the agreement on the Continental Free Trade Area. #FTAfrica

President #Ramaphosa: The #AfCFTA will also have a broader international impact as Africa will be able to deal with other trade blocs from a position of greater strength, able to demonstrate economies of scale.
President #Ramaphosa: The borders drawn up in the palaces of Europe will gradually become less significant than the infrastructure matrix that will link African economies together.

President #Ramaphosa: As African countries become more connected to each other through highways and railway lines, through regional power grids and water infrastructure, the continent will undergo a infrastructural transformation.

President #Ramaphosa: From a social perspective, it is likely to result in a more cosmopolitan Africa as the greater movement of people and skills brings more people of diverse backgrounds and nationalities together. #FTAfrica

President #Ramaphosa: On the political front, the #AfCFTA will help to consolidate the union among all African states. It will reduce the potential for conflict because there is no benefit in waging wars with countries that you trade with.

President #Ramaphosa: These include easing customs controls, developing regulations on the cross border movement of people, reforming taxation and intellectual property regimes and improving anti-corruption legislation.

President #Ramaphosa: Business costs will be reduced and business efficiency will be raised. African governments are hard at work putting regulations and mechanisms in place to ensure that the free trade area is a success.

President #Ramaphosa: This treaty will unleash the manufacturing and industrial capability of the continent as companies will seek to make products for the burgeoning African market. The removal of trade barriers will lower prices and benefit consumers. #FTAfrica

President #Ramaphosa: The free flow of goods and services will enable African businesses and entrepreneurs to expand their horizons. It will lead to the creation of a huge number of both big and small businesses.
President #Ramaphosa: On the economic front, it will improve access to existing markets and lead to the creation of new ones. #FTAfrica

President #Ramaphosa: By some estimates the new free trade area could increase the value of intra-African trade by 15 to 25% by 2040. In addition to its economic impact, the #AfCFTA will have far-reaching political, social, physical and international effects.

President #Ramaphosa: We share a common vision to see greater levels of investment directed into Africa and to see higher volumes of intra-African trade. President #Ramaphosa: Their interest extends beyond the borders of their countries to promoting greater economic development within the respective economic regions on the continent. As we pursue economic integration, these regions are taking on a greater significance.

President #Ramaphosa: Unemployment remains stubbornly high. On the narrow definition, the unemployment stood at 29 percent in the second quarter. Our economy has lost its competitiveness, ranking 82nd among 190 countries in the World Bank’s Ease of Doing Business Index.

President #Ramaphosa: It is highest in Limpopo and the Eastern Cape, and lowest in the Western Cape and Gauteng. Poverty is overwhelmingly black. It also has a disproportionate impact on children, those living in rural areas, and people with little or no education.

President #Ramaphosa: Poverty is rife, with nearly half of the population considered chronically poor at the upper bound national poverty line. Poverty tracks the patterns of our past closely. #GrowSouthAfrica

President #Ramaphosa: This is due to the uneven distribution of income and wealth in our economy, inherited from our difficult past. On measures such as the under-five child mortality rate, life expectancy and school completion rate, we lag behind our peers. #GrowSouthAfrica

President #Ramaphosa: Our country has made great strides in improving the lives of South Africans since 1994. However, our country does not perform at the same level as other upper middle-income countries. #GrowSouthAfrica

President #Ramaphosa: It is clear that we meet at a difficult time for our economy, when many key indicators confirm the extent of the economic malaise that had set in in the aftermath of the Great Recession. #GrowSouthAfrica

President #Ramaphosa: As we reflect on the Terms of Reference of the Council and discuss its working arrangements, it is our hope that the Council will direct its efforts towards practical solutions to the complex and pressing challenges our country faces. #GrowSouthAfrica

President #Ramaphosa: I said this Council would “ensure greater coherence and consistency in the implementation of economic policy and ensure that we are better equipped to respond to changing economic circumstances”. #GrowSouthAfrica

President #Ramaphosa: We have sought individuals who have done work in South Africa, on the African continent and in other parts of the world. I announced my decision to establish such a Council in my first State of the Nation Address in February 2018. #SONA2018 #GrowSouthAfrica
