President #Ramaphosa: Working together, we can be a nation at peace with each other, and with our neighbours. We can be a nation that confronts it challenges and overcomes them. Working together, we can heal our nation and unite its people. #EnoughIsEnoughpic.twitter.com/QKTCIKP5HB

President #Ramaphosa: It is time to restore the hope and faith of our people. Working together, we can turn this moment of crisis into an opportunity to renew ourselves and return to the values of respect for the rule of law and of human rights for all. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: We must remove the cancers of gender-based violence and xenophobia, so that we can hold our heads up high among the community of nations. The time for talk is over.pic.twitter.com/dXN9KIEzdC

President #Ramaphosa: At the same time, we need to continue our work through the African Union to strengthen democracy and good governance across the continent and silence the guns of war and conflict.

President #Ramaphosa: Many of them have fled war and persecution in their own countries, and see South Africa as a safe place for them and their children. Let us show them the spirit of ubuntu and show empathy for their situation. #EnoughIsEnough
President #Ramaphosa: I call upon all our citizens to extend the hand of friendship to the immigrant community who just want to make a better life for themselves and their families. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: I call upon this Parliament to consider these and other emergency measures without delay so that all government departments, agencies and civil society formations can begin with implementation. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: Violence against women is not the problem of one province, one community or one political party. It does not wear a green and yellow doek, a smart suit or a red uniform. #EnoughIsEnough
President #Ramaphosa: Our nation is at a crossroads. Our actions now will determine whether we rise or sink into the abyss. #EnoughIsEnoughpic.twitter.com/ObleX6dXeb
President #Ramaphosa: Everyone must see it as their duty to speak out against crime and to report misdeeds. Criminals must have no nowhere to hide.
President #Ramaphosa: This needs to be dealt with as a law-enforcement matter, irrespective of the nationality of the individuals involved.
President #Ramaphosa: But we also have to acknowledge that there are certain parts of the country where specific foreign nationals have been identified as the main dealers and pedlars.

President #Ramaphosa: One of the issues raised, quite genuinely by communities, is the proliferation of drug trafficking in various localities, in urban and rural areas. Both South Africans and foreign nationals are involved in this.

President #Ramaphosa: We should consider, as many other countries have, the regulation of how foreign nationals can own and participate in certain types of businesses within the small and medium enterprise sector.

President #Ramaphosa: South African employers, be they in the trucking industry, hospitality or agriculture, must obey the law. All who operate businesses in this country must be registered and meet the requirements of the law.
President #Ramaphosa: Police and immigration officials who take bribes in return for making cases go away, for releasing impounded goods or for issuing fraudulent documents must be dealt with firmly.
President #Ramaphosa: That is why government has prioritised border control and security, and ensure that we tighten up regulations to deter illegal immigration. #EnoughIsEnough
President #Ramaphosa: We proceed from the principle, as does every other sovereign state, that all who live in South Africa must be legally permitted to do so. #EnoughIsEnough
President #Ramaphosa: We share your frustration that some South African employers are employing foreigners over locals to undercut wages, turning worker against worker. #EnoughIsEnough
President #Ramaphosa: We understand the concerns of local businesses struggling to compete against counterfeit goods being sold at prices they cannot match. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: They destabilise communities and inhibit economic activity. At the same time, we must attend to the concerns that our people have. We know that our people are concerned about illegal immigration, and about some foreign nationals being involved in crime.

President #Ramaphosa: Violent service delivery protests, the destruction of public facilities, cable theft, illegal electricity connections, truck hijackings and construction site invasions disrupt essential services and put lives and livelihoods at risk. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: As we tackle racism and xenophobia, so too must we reinvigorate our efforts to grow an economy that is inclusive and build a state that is capable and developmental. We must deal firmly with any and all acts of criminality. #EnoughIsEnough
President #Ramaphosa: In responding to these acts of violence and criminality, we must address both the intolerance and the frustration. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: The recent public violence directed against both foreign nationals and South Africans exposed not only the levels of intolerance in our society but also the extent to which so many of our people are frustrated about their social and economic conditions.
President #Ramaphosa: We must realise the spirit of our Constitution. The rights of women and men alike must be protected. This time must be different. We, South Africans, must be different.

President #Ramaphosa: There was clear commitment from leadership, funds were mobilised and there was solidarity across society. We have the means to end violence against women and children. Now is the time to unite to turn the tide.

President #Ramaphosa: Protests driven by women, and particularly by our young people, these past few weeks, have broken a spell. Less than a decade ago we were able to turn the tide on the Aids pandemic because we were able to work together. #EnoughIsEnough
President #Ramaphosa: I believe we are living through another such a revolution in consciousness today, but this time it concerns the injustices under which women have long laboured. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: It changed how we viewed the world and our place in it. No longer would we accept injustice inflicted on us because of the colour of our skin. This revolution is incomplete and it is still living.

President #Ramaphosa: Many years ago, South Africa was swept by a revolution in how black people thought about themselves and about their place in society. Like many others, I was involved in black consciousness politics, championed by Steve Biko and others.
President #Ramaphosa: When we witness acts of violence against women we must not look away. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: As men we must play an active role in the movement against gender-based violence. We must lead by example in showing women respect and decency. We must be positive role models to our sons and our daughters.
President #Ramaphosa: The perpetrators of these crimes are the products of a brutalised society, a society still suffering the effects of centuries of dehumanisation. We must break this cycle.

President #Ramaphosa: The phenomenon of absentee fathers means that boys often grow up without positive role models and positive expressions of masculinity, leaving them at the mercy of the streets, and susceptible to involvement in crime and gangs.
President #Ramaphosa: No man is born a rapist, a woman-batterer or a murderer. Men and boys are being exposed to violence at a young age, some becoming victims of violence themselves. #EnoughIsEnough
President #Ramaphosa: The private sector should come on board to fund and capacitate rape crisis centres at hospitals and clinics, and victim support centres at our police stations.
President #Ramaphosa: We could, for example, harness the Youth Employment Service initiative to recruit young South Africans to boost staffing at police stations, shelters and counselling centres.
President #Ramaphosa: Gender-based violence is a societal problem, and as such all sectors of society must become involved.

President #Ramaphosa: As part of this a national gender-based violence prevalence study will be commissioned in the general population as well as a specific survey to monitor gender-based violence in the LGBTQI+ community.

President #Ramaphosa: All government departments will be expected to adhere to gender-responsive planning, budgeting, monitoring and evaluation. We are also going to improve collection and analysis of data to monitor our GBV programmes.
President #Ramaphosa: We will continue to prioritise support and training for women engaging in small business and informal sector activity, and call on established business to be part of this effort
President #Ramaphosa: The landscape of South African business would fundamentally change if the private sector made a similar commitment.

President #Ramaphosa: We call upon the private sector to do the same. Government is committed to reach its target to set aside 30% of the value of its procurement for women-owned businesses, and to progressively increase that to 40%.

President #Ramaphosa: By tackling unequal economic power dynamics we can reduce the vulnerability of women to abuse. Government will continue to prioritise women when it comes to access to employment, training opportunities and procurement of services.

President #Ramaphosa: Women are often hostages in abusive relationships because of poverty and unemployment. Young women in particular are vulnerable to exploitation from older men with financial resources. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: The Vice Chancellors of our universities have asked to meet the President to discuss violence against women on campus. We will be having a meeting to come up with initiatives that are focused on what we should do at institutions of higher learning.

President #Ramaphosa: We are therefore going to resource the gender-based violence framework in universities and colleges, which will include the establishment of gender equity offices in these institutions.

President #Ramaphosa: Institutions of higher learning require a particular focus. They are important sites of socialisation of young people, but they are also places where sexual harassment, victimisation of women students and rape are rife.

President #Ramaphosa: Drug and alcohol abuse fuel gender-based violence pandemic. The Department of Social Development has therefore been tasked with increasing the visibility of substance abuse awareness and education, and prioritising funding for more treatment facilities.

President #Ramaphosa: We are planning to meet with representatives of the private sector to discuss the establishment of a Gender-based Violence and Femicide Fund to increase support to survivors, including persons with disability and the LGBTQI+ community.
President #Ramaphosa: As part of taking initiatives to address the challenges in the district, we have decided to establish a further five #Thuthuzela Care Centres in the district.

President #Ramaphosa: During our visit to the OR Tambo District yesterday to launch the district development model we found that there are only three such centres serving a population of 1.5 million people. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: We will work with the private sector, concerned individuals and other institutions to substantially increase the number of Thuthuzela Care Centres across the country from the current 54 to over 100 by 2025.

President #Ramaphosa: Through our Emergency Action Plan, we provide post-rape training for health care providers and lay counsellors who provide care and support to victims and survivors. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: As part of our fourth area of intervention – care, support and healing for victims of violence – we will standardise the framework for funding civil society organisations working with survivors of gender-based violence. #EnoughIsEnough
President #Ramaphosa: We call on all Parliamentary committees to prioritise these areas of legislative reform and ensure that we have effective legislation in place without delay.
President #Ramaphosa: It is also important that legislation like the Victim Support Services Bill is finalised as it will strengthen support for GBV programmes and services.

President #Ramaphosa: Those who are found guilty of such crimes should not be eligible for parole. A life sentence must mean just that – life in prison. We are also going to give urgent attention to strengthening programmes to rehabilitate offenders and youth at risk.

President #Ramaphosa: Abusers, rapists and murderers must know that they will be caught and that they will face the consequences of their actions. We affirm our position that the state should oppose bail for suspects charged with the rape and murder of women and children.

President #Ramaphosa: We need to engage with the Judiciary to ensure that the exercise by presiding officers of their discretion does not undermine the national effort to end gender-based violence. #EnoughIsEnough
President #Ramaphosa: We need to engage with the Judiciary on the role that it can play in supporting the national effort to end gender-based violence.
President #Ramaphosa: We will propose to Parliament the necessary legislative changes to ensure that all crimes against women and children attract harsher minimum sentences. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: We will therefore, as our third area of intervention, be proposing a range of legal and regulatory reforms to this Parliament to strengthen the response of the State to gender-based violence. #EnoughIsEnough
President #Ramaphosa: In many respects, however, these measures have fallen short of what is needed to confront the severity of the challenges we face.

President #Ramaphosa: Government has launched many, many interventions over the past decade. They have been well-intentioned, but they have not delivered the outcomes we have hoped for. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: We have a Ministry in the Presidency for Women, Youth and Persons with Disabilities. We have a Commission for Gender Equality. In this Parliament, there is a Portfolio Committee and a Select Committee on Women, Youth and Persons with Disabilities.

President #Ramaphosa: Since the advent of democracy, we have enacted several laws and undertaken a number of programmes to tackle gender inequality in our society, to promote human rights and to enable effective action against gender-based violence. #EnoughIsEnough
President #Ramaphosa: These measures include the establishment of special courts, hiring additional court staff and clearing the backlog at forensic labs. #EnoughIsEnough
President #Ramaphosa: The Department of Justice and Constitutional Development is already working on measures to clear the backlog of criminal cases for rape and other forms of gender-based violence.
President #Ramaphosa: Funding has already been approved for the establishment of an additional eleven Sexual Offences courts over the next financial year.

President #Ramaphosa: We will therefore be directing resources to improve the functioning of Sexual Offences Courts, Thuthuzela Care Centres, and the Family Violence, Child Protection and Sexual Investigation Units of the SAPS.

President #Ramaphosa: The second part of our response is to strengthen the criminal justice system. This is to ensure that justice is served, perpetrators are held to account, survivors do not suffer secondary victimisation, and the law acts as a deterrent. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: We will undertake a mass mobilisation programme to train and deploy prevention activists to all of our 278 municipalities. They will engage in household visits and community interventions focused on changing harmful social norms. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: As part of this campaign, we are going to provide gender sensitivity training to law-enforcement officials, prosecutors, magistrates and policy makers & ensure that those who are found in breach of their responsibilities in this regard are held to account.

President #Ramaphosa: A focus will be on men’s groups and formations, youth at risk and offenders inside prisons. This must be matched with prevention education in schools. Women’s rights and gender power relations will be part of Life Orientation in the school curriculum.

President #Ramaphosa: We are, as part of our emergency response and with a view of embarking on prevention measures, going to launch a mass media campaign that will target communities, public spaces, workplaces, campuses and schools, as well as recreational spaces like taverns.

President #Ramaphosa: Our young men and boys are daily exposed to patriarchal attitudes and practices, and are often encouraged to prove their masculinity through domination and violence. #EnoughIsEnough
President #Ramaphosa: In implementing our prevention measures, we must recognise that violence against women is not a problem of women. It is a problem of men. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: As we have done with our response to HIV and AIDS, we should establish appropriate structures in the offices of Premiers and Mayors to work with social partners to drive and coordinate our efforts to end gender-based violence.

President #Ramaphosa: The Steering Committee will coordinate rapid response at national level. In this way, problems at police stations and courts, and challenges such as availability of rape kits or delays in DNA testing, can be channeled to the relevant authorities quickly.
President #Ramaphosa: This emergency action plan will be driven by an Interim Steering Committee located in the Presidency and co-chaired by government and civil society organisations.

President #Ramaphosa: Thirdly, the steps we should take to enhance the legal and policy framework; fourthly, what we should do to ensure adequate care, support and healing for victims of violence; and, fifthly, measures to improve the economic power of women in South Africa.

President #Ramaphosa: The Plan strengthens existing measures and introduces new interventions in five principal areas: firstly, how to prevent gender-based violence; secondly, how we should strengthen the criminal justice system;
President #Ramaphosa: Given the urgency of the situation, we have developed an Emergency Action Plan, which will be implemented over the next six months.

President #Ramaphosa: In line with those decisions, and following consultation between government, business, traditional leaders, the media, Chapter Nine Institutions and civil society, we have developed a draft National Strategic Plan, which will be finalised shortly.

President #Ramaphosa: In line with those decisions, and following consultation between government, business, traditional leaders, the media, Chapter Nine Institutions and civil society, we have developed a draft National Strategic Plan, which will be finalised shortly.

President #Ramaphosa: We will make substantial additional funding available for a comprehensive package of interventions to make an immediate and lasting difference. We will complete the implementation of the decisions of last year’s #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: To enhance the safety of women we will, as a matter of urgency, make the necessary amendments to our laws and policies to ensure that perpetrators of gender-based violence are brought to book. #EnoughIsEnough
President #Ramaphosa: Women should not have to protect themselves from men. They should feel safe and secure with us as men. They have the right to feel safe.
President #Ramaphosa: We feel their pain as fathers, as mothers and as grandparents. We affirm right here, right now, Sekwanele – Enough is enough. The people of this country want action now.

President #Ramaphosa: Outside of this Parliament, on the streets of this country, we have heard the demands of women to be safe. We cry with the parents who have lost their daughters, the children who have lost their mothers, and the friends who have lost their classmates.
President #Ramaphosa: In this Parliament there are leaders who are both women and men; the voices of men and women alike must be heard. Let us all work together to turn the tide. #EnoughIsEnough
President #Ramaphosa: We need to restore the human rights of others, a principle that so many South Africans fought for, and a cause for which so many gave their lives. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: There are many who have lost respect for the values that define our very essence as Africans – the protection of women and children, tolerance and the accommodation of difference. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: There are many in our country who have increasingly shown scant regard for the state, for the police and the rule of law, for community and religious leaders and institutions, for our elders, and for each other. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: This week I despatched envoys to a number of African countries to address concerns that have been raised by reports of their citizens being attacked. Lawlessness is corroding the fabric of our society. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: Over the past two weeks, we have witnessed acts of violence against both foreign nationals and South Africans, a situation worsened by the circulation of fake and incendiary messages designed to sow panic. #EnoughIsEnough
President #Ramaphosa: While it has its own specific causes and features, gender-based violence reflects a broader crisis of violence in our society.
President #Ramaphosa: South Africa is one of the most unsafe places in the world to be a woman, with levels of violence that are comparable to countries that are at war. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: This does not count the many more cases of rape and sexual assault that are not reported. Research by Statistics South Africa shows that one in five South African women older than 18 has experienced physical violence by a partner. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: There is a very violent and brutal war underway against the women of South Africa. Last year, 2,700 women and over 1,000 children died at the hands of another person. Every single day the police receive over 100 cases of reported rape.

President #Ramaphosa: I have called this special joint sitting of the houses of Parliament because there is a dark and heavy shadow across our land. The women and children of this country are under siege. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: We have therefore called for a Joint Sitting of Parliament this Wednesday to address the issue of gender-based violence and femicide. We will be calling on Parliament to consider emergency measures that can be undertaken to respond to this crisis.

President #Ramaphosa: Given the extent of the crisis, government has embarked on immediate and concrete action to make a real difference in the lives of women in our country. We have heard the calls of the women of our country for action and for justice. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: Violence against women is never the fault of women. It is men who rape and kill women, and it is therefore an obligation on the men of this country to speak out against violence, harassment and abuse. #EnoughIsEnough
President #Ramaphosa: And just last week, we heard about a subject advisor in Lusikisiki who allegedly raped a six year old child. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: According to the World Health Organisation, South Africa has the fourth-highest interpersonal violence death rate in the world, at 12.5 per 100 000 adult women. #EnoughIsEnough

President #Ramaphosa: According to the South African Police Service, 2 700 adult women were murdered in 2018/2019. Although a decrease of 5% from the previous year, this means that a woman is murdered every three hours on average. #EnoughIsEnough

President @CyrilRamaphosa: In recent weeks, our country has been deeply traumatised by acts of extreme violence perpetrated by men against women and children. #EnoughIsEnough

President Ramaphosa has expressed his confidence that Justices Tshiqi and Majiedt will further enrich jurisprudence at the apex Court which has served the nation with distinction throughout the democratic dispensation.

He is the current Chairperson of the Rules Board for the Courts of Law and also a Council Member of the South African Judicial Education Institute (SAJEI). Additionally, he is the Chancellor of the Sol Plaatje University.

In December 2010, Judge Majiedt was appointed as a permanent Judge of the Supreme Court of Appeal. He acted at the Constitutional Court from February to May 2014. He also served as a member of the National Association of the Democratic Lawyers (NADEL) from 1986 to 2000.

In January 2000, Judge Majiedt returned to private practice as an advocate and this culminated in his appointment as an Acting Judge of the Northern Cape Division of the High Court. It was during that year that he was appointed as a permanent Judge of this Court.

Judge Majiedt, 58, holds the BA Law and LLB degrees from the UWC. He was admitted as an advocate in 1984 and practised as such until 1995 when he was appointed as a Chief Provincial State Law Adviser in the Northern Cape Office of the Premier from 1996 to 1999.pic.twitter.com/GT0rYDOhVF

She acted at the Competition Appeal Court from 2007 to 2009. She was later appointed at the Supreme Court of Appeal in 2009. She has an acting stint at the Constitutional Court from November 2014 to May 2015.

Prior to her permanent appointment, Judge Tshiqi served as a mediator, facilitator, and arbitrator under the Independent Mediation Service of SA (IMSSA), and at the Commission for Conciliation, Mediation and Arbitration (CCMA) as well as a Mediator in the Land Claims Commission.
She served her articles from 1989 to 1991 and practised as an attorney until 2005 when she was appointed as a Judge of the Gauteng Division of the High Court, Johannesburg.

Judge Tshiqi, 58, holds a B Proc degree and a Postgraduate Diploma in Labour Law. She started her legal career as a Legal Coordinator at the South African Council of Churches from 1986 to 1989.pic.twitter.com/8HpmYagqiu

President Ramaphosa appointed Judges Tshiqi & Majiedt from a list of 5 nominees prepared by the Judicial Services Commission. The Commission conducted interviews in April 2019 following the discharge from active service of former Deputy Chief Justice Moseneke & Justice Nkabinde.

In terms of section 174(4) of the Constitution, the President, as head of the National Executive, appoints Judges of the Constitutional Court following consultation with the Chief Justice and leaders of political parties represented in the National Assembly.
The President has made these appointments after consulting the Chief Justice of the Republic of South Africa and the leaders of the parties represented in the National Assembly.

President @CyrilRamaphosa has in terms of Section 174(4) of the Constitution appointed Judge Zukisa Laura Lumka #Tshiqi and Judge Stevan Arnold #Majiedt as Judges of the Constitutional Court with effect from 1 October 2019.pic.twitter.com/Fb24GN9wlW

President #Ramaphosa: Let us once again, as a nation, work together to end the violence against the women and children of our country. Let us build the South Africa we want, and which all our people so richly deserve. I thank you.
President #Ramaphosa: Now, as a nation, let us once again work together to end the violence that has engulfed our streets, and damaged our economy and confidence in our country.
President #Ramaphosa: As a nation, we have endured moments of uncertainty before. As a nation, we have overcome conflict and achieved peace.

President #Ramaphosa: We call on all religious leaders and communities to lead the country in prayer and contemplation this Friday, Saturday and Sunday. In all churches, mosques, synagogues and temples, let us humble ourselves and bring healing to our nation.
President #Ramaphosa: It is a time for all of us who live in this country to confront our challenges directly and earnestly, not through violence, but through dialogue.
President #Ramaphosa: Let us not be provoked by those who want to sow mistrust and fuel conflict. This is a time for calm.
President #Ramaphosa: This misinformation is also being disseminated in neighbouring countries and throughout the world, causing panic and putting lives in danger. Let us not be misled.

President #Ramaphosa: We must act responsibly and stop disseminating fake videos, photographs and messages, especially on social media, with an intention of negatively portraying our country and its people.

President #Ramaphosa: Since Sunday, 423 people have been arrested for violence-related offences in Gauteng and 21 suspects have been arrested in relation to truck violence in KwaZulu-Natal. I am calling upon each one of us to desist from fueling a climate of fear and confusion.
President #Ramaphosa: The criminal justice system is ready to deal with perpetrators of violence, looting and lawlessness.
President #Ramaphosa: The violence has largely subsided and police have increased reinforcements and visibility in priority areas to ensure the safety of all within South African borders.
President #Ramaphosa: We commend our law enforcement and security agencies who have moved swiftly to restore stability in Johannesburg, Ekurhuleni, Tshwane and parts of KwaZulu-Natal.

President #Ramaphosa: Where communities have genuine grievances these must be addressed through engagement and dialogue. But where people act with criminal intent, irrespective of their nationality, we will not hesitate to act to uphold the law and ensure order and stability.
President #Ramaphosa: We value our relations with other African countries and need to work to strengthen political, social and trade ties if we are to develop our economy and those of our neighbours.

President #Ramaphosa: We worked together to destroy apartheid and overcome the divisions it created, where we feared each other & our differences were exploited. Thanks to the people of Africa, we have now achieved democracy and must use this platform to live together in harmony.

President #Ramaphosa: Equally, there is no justification for the looting and destruction of businesses owned by South Africans. The people from other countries on our continent stood with us in our struggle against apartheid.
President #Ramaphosa: There can be no excuse for the attacks on the homes and businesses of foreign nationals, just as there can be no excuse for xenophobia or any other form of intolerance.

President #Ramaphosa: We know that at least 10 people have been killed in this violence, two of whom were a foreign nationals. No amount of anger and frustration and grievance can justify such acts of destruction and criminality.

President #Ramaphosa: As I speak to you, the debris of several days of violence and looting continues to litter many of the streets of our country. People have lost their lives and many have been injured. Families have been traumatised. Livelihoods have been destroyed.
President #Ramaphosa: Over the past few days, our country has been deeply traumatised by acts of violence and criminality directed against foreign nationals and our own citizens.

President #Ramaphosa: As South African men, let us take responsibility for our actions. We must treat the women & girls of our country with care and respect. It is only when we do that that we will end violence against women and children. Let us declare that enough is enough.

President #Ramaphosa: We acknowledge the men and boys who have heeded the call to respect women by participating in the Takuwani Riine Men and Boys Campaign. We also acknowledge others who are championing change towards a South Africa that is free of violence by 2030.
President #Ramaphosa: Let us, as families, make sure that we raise boys to respect women, to respect themselves, to value life and human dignity.

President #Ramaphosa: There is therefore an obligation on the men of this country to act to end such behaviour and such crimes. As men, let us speak out. We must not look away. We must face gender-based violence head-on.

President #Ramaphosa: Violence against women is not a women’s problem. It is not a problem of what a woman said or did, what a woman was wearing, or where she was walking. Violence against women is a men’s problem. It is men who rape and kill women.
President #Ramaphosa: I will therefore be asking Parliament to discuss and identify urgent interventions that can be implemented without delay.

President #Ramaphosa: The Minister of Finance will be asked to allocate additional funding to the national machinery to coordinate our campaign against gender-based violence. The women of our country are calling for emergency measures to end this violence.
President #Ramaphosa: We will implement a national multi-faceted plan to prevent gender-based violence through school programmes, community initiatives and workplace policies.

President #Ramaphosa: We will use every means at the disposal of the state – from the police service to the justice system, from social development programmes to our school curriculum – to strengthen all parts of our national response to gender-based violence.
President #Ramaphosa: We will address other systemic challenges such as the backlog of cases, delays in DNA testing and the availability of rape test kits in our police stations.

President #Ramaphosa: These emergency response teams will focus in particular on violence directed at women, children and other marginalised groups including the LGBTQIA Plus community and people with disabilities.

President #Ramaphosa: We will strengthen the emergency teams at a provincial level – which bring together the police, social development, health, justice and education – to continue providing rapid and comprehensive responses to all forms of violence against women.
President #Ramaphosa: All gender-based violence cases that have been closed or that were not properly investigated must be reviewed.

President #Ramaphosa: Many women’s organisations have complained that there aren’t enough rehabilitation programmes in our prisons. These programmes will be increased and reconfigured to reduce the number of repeat offenders.

President #Ramaphosa: I will propose to Cabinet that all crimes against women and children should attract harsher minimum sentences. We agree with the women of our country that the state should oppose bail and parole for perpetrators of rape and murder against women and children.

President #Ramaphosa: This National Register of Offenders will list all the men convicted of acts of violence against women and children. I will ask Parliament to consider amending the legislation to make the register public.

President #Ramaphosa: I wish to enumerate some of the additional measures we will be taking. We are going to overhaul and modernise the national register of gender-based violence offenders provided for in the Sexual Offences Act to ensure it is effective in combating GBV.

President #Ramaphosa: We have established 92 dedicated Sexual Offences Courts since 2013, with a further 11 to be opened this year to improve conviction rates & provide comprehensive & appropriate services to ensure survivors of sexual offences are not subject to further trauma.
President #Ramaphosa: We are reviewing laws on domestic violence and sexual offences to prioritise the needs and interests of survivors.

President #Ramaphosa: Working together, government and civil society formations, have already made much progress towards establishing and resourcing a national machinery to coordinate our campaign against gender-based violence.
President #Ramaphosa: We have recorded progress on the implementation of the decisions of the Presidential Summit on Gender-Based Violence last year.

President #Ramaphosa: We have heard the calls of the women of our country for action and for justice. The collective anger, the pain and the fear that these killings have caused must strengthen our resolve to end all forms of violence and abuse perpetrated by men against women.

President #Ramaphosa: Women have every right to expect that they be free from harassment and violence on the streets, in schools and campuses, on buses, taxis and trains, at places of work and worship, and in their homes.
President #Ramaphosa: Like millions of men across this country, I am appalled at the war being waged on our sisters, our mothers, our wives, our partners and our daughters.
President #Ramaphosa: Today I speak to you as your President, and as a citizen of our country. But I also speak to you as a husband and a father to my daughters.

President #Ramaphosa: These killings have caused great pain and outrage because acts of such brutality have become all too common in our communities. Violence against women has become more than a national crisis. It is a crime against our common humanity.

President #Ramaphosa: We know the names of Uyinene Mrwetyana, Leighandre Jegels, Janika Mallo, Ayakha Jiyane and her three little siblings, but we also grieve for many others who have died at the hands of men.

President #Ramaphosa: As we have done before in times of great difficulty and strife, this is the time to come together as a nation to confront our problems directly. The nation is mourning the deaths of several women and girls who were murdered by men.
President #Ramaphosa: These acts of violence have made us doubt the very foundation of our democratic society, our commitment to human rights and human dignity, to equality, to peace and to justice.

President #Ramaphosa: My Fellow South Africans, our nation is in mourning and pain. Over the past few days, our country has been deeply traumatised by acts of extreme violence perpetrated by men against women and children.

”We all want to see a South Africa that is thriving and prosperous. We all want to see a South Africa where all our citizens enjoy equal opportunity to make a better life for themselves.” President @CyrilRamaphosa #InvestSA #WEFAfrica19 #af19pic.twitter.com/Ft8BEclaMq

“I call on all investors present here today, particularly local investors, to be part of this new momentum. We want and need foreign direct investment, and scaled up domestic investment is the necessary catalyst.” President @CyrilRamaphosa #InvestSA #WEFAfrica19 #af19pic.twitter.com/LbmFdYHhiN

“An economy that is fertile ground for companies and businesses who are prepared to invest in human capital to take advantage of the opportunities presented by the 4th Industrial Revolution.” #InvestSA #WEFAfrica19 #af19 #4IR

“It is also about staking a claim in the future of a great nation that has the means and the drive to become one of the world’s most vibrant economies.” President @CyrilRamaphosa #InvestSA #WEFAfrica19 #af19pic.twitter.com/1pktT1nLxw

“We continue to pursue economic growth together with our developmental aspirations. Investing in South Africa is not just about securing decent returns.” President @CyrilRamaphosa #InvestSA #WEFAfrica19 #af19pic.twitter.com/HOxqIFXGxH

“Some of the economic measures we have put in place may take some time to demonstrate returns, but they have nevertheless been impactful. We are resolute that what we have done so far is both correct and necessary.” President @CyrilRamaphosa #InvestSA #WEFAfrica19 #af19pic.twitter.com/VuRpxdgb7u

“All of us in this room share a common goal, to make South Africa the destination of choice for ease of doing business. We all want to build an economy that is more equitable and from which all South Africans can benefit.” President @CyrilRamaphosa #InvestSA #WEFAfrica19 #af19

”South Africa currently ranks 82nd among 190 economies in the World Bank’s Ease of Doing Business Index. While we may not see the results of our efforts immediately, this administration has set itself the ambitious goal of being in the Top 50.” President @CyrilRamaphosa #InvestSApic.twitter.com/yFLGftEIQd

“We are hard at work to stimulate growth, ensure economic stability and restore the credibility of state institutions. We recognise the urgency with which we need to reform our investment promotion architecture to remove policy, regulatory and other impediments.” @CyrilRamaphosa

“And while the economy is creating new jobs, they are not nearly enough to bring down the overall rate of unemployment. We are dealing with the challenges of the present while working to undo the devastating legacy of our past.” President @CyrilRamaphosa #InvestSA #WEFAfrica19

President #Ramaphosa: South Africa belongs to all of us equally & we must all feel that we belong to this South Africa, regardless of the various differences that we may have along the lines of language, region or colour. We are all one nation & let us begin to act as one nation.pic.twitter.com/Kq7bXipbFm
Whatever our individual backgrounds or circumstances, we are all part of the majority. #GrowSouthAfrica #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: It is indeed true that South Africa is made up of people of different races, ethnicities, language groups and religions, but we are all part of the greater South African people. #GrowSouthAfrica #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: We have sought to advance the constitutional principle that everyone has the right to use the language and to participate in the cultural life of their choice. #GrowSouthAfrica #RamaphosaQandA
President #Ramaphosa: Since 1994, we have put in place policies and programmes to safeguard these rights and advance these opportunities. #GrowSouthAfrica #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: All South Africans must have the same rights and opportunities regardless of race, gender, sex, ethnic or social origin, colour, sexual orientation, age, disability, religion, conscience, belief, culture, language & birth. #GrowSouthAfrica #RamaphosaQandA
President #Ramaphosa: The achievement of national unity depends on the advancement of equality in all spheres of public and private life. #GrowSouthAfrica #TheSouthAfricaWeWant #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: Among other things, it calls on all of us to heal the divisions of the past, establish a society based on democratic values, social justice and fundamental human rights, ensure every citizen is equally protected by the law & free the potential of each person

President #Ramaphosa: In undertaking my responsibility as President of the Republic, I am guided in the main by the Preamble to our Constitution. #GrowSouthAfrica #TheSouthAfricaWeWant #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: While the Constitution enjoins the President to promote the unity of the nation, it is the role and the responsibility of all South Africans to build a country that belongs to all who live in it. #GrowSouthAfrica #TheSouthAfricaWeWant #RamaphosaQandA
President #Ramaphosa: Cabinet still needs to consider the findings and recommendations of the panel, after which it will be able to pronounce on their implementation. #GrowSouthAfrica #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: It is intended that, together with the work already underway, the Panel’s recommendations will inform the finalisation of a comprehensive, far-reaching and transformative land reform programme. #GrowSouthAfrica #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: Progress is being made in the development of an integrated model for farmer support. The model entails the provision of financial and non-financial support through the value chain. #GrowSouthAfrica #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: The Department of Public Works and Infrastructure has released 100 parcels of land for land restitution purposes. For the remaining parcels of land, land use studies are being finalised, which include land identified for human settlements. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: The IMC is making progress in the development of the National Spatial Development Framework, which will guide our efforts to ensure land use and planning is developmental and transforms people’s lives. #GrowSouthAfrica #RamaphosaQandA

The Panel’s recommendations complement and reinforce the work being done by the Inter-Ministerial Committee on Land Reform chaired by the Deputy President. #GrowSouthAfrica #TheSouthAfricaWeWant #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: This report recommends legal mechanisms to recognise, register, record and enforce a continuum of land rights, so that all our people become rights holders. #GrowSouthAfrica #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: The report of the Advisory Panel has been presented to Cabinet and has been made available to the public. The report provides a detailed and critical assessment on progress since 1994 and outlines some of the weaknesses in our policies and programmes.

President #Ramaphosa: Through providing poor South Africans with land on which to farm, to live and to run businesses, we will be able to break the cycle of poverty in which many people are trapped. #GrowSouthAfrica #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: The Presidential Advisory Panel on Land Reform & Agriculture had produced several far-reaching recommendations to ensure that we correct the skewed distribution of land in the country. This is necessary to reduce inequality. #GrowSouthAfrica #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: The acceleration of land reform is essential for the transformation of society, for tackling poverty and growing the economy. #GrowSouthAfrica #TheSouthAfricaWeWant #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: Through the #NHI, we will be closer to achieving the demand of the Freedom Charter that: “Free medical care and hospitalisation shall be provided for all.” Working together, we are determined to achieve this goal. #GrowSouthAfrica #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/EPZZu1ZnBQ

President #Ramaphosa: The NHI provides an opportunity to fundamentally transform health care in this country to ensure greater fairness, improved health outcomes and a more productive workforce. #GrowSouthAfrica #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: The quest for universal health coverage is probably one of the most significant public-private partnerships that we will undertake, and it is essential that all social partners are involved in its design and implementation.

President #Ramaphosa: It is for this reason that we are pursuing an ambitious programme to address the problems in our health system alongside the introduction of National Health Insurance. #NHI #GrowSouthAfrica #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: Furthermore, the World Health Organisation is greatly supportive of our efforts to introduce universal health coverage, which has been a fundamental demand of the Freedom Charter for over 50 years. #GrowSouthAfrica #RamaphosaQandA
President #Ramaphosa: The Elders Group, established by the Former President Nelson Mandela, has issued a statement in support of our efforts towards NHI. #GrowSouthAfrica #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: We are on track to do this in our country through the National Health Insurance. We have global support in moving towards Universal Health Coverage. #GrowSouthAfrica #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: As part of our global commitment, we attended and contributed our input to the #G20 Summit in Osaka in June this year. At the summit, we, together with the low and medium income countries were urged to move towards universal health coverage.

President #Ramaphosa: We are heading out to New York at the United Nations to join other countries who are moving towards the implementation of their verson of Universal Health Coverage. #UNGA #GrowSouthAfrica #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: This is essential for the achievement of a better quality of life, social justice, for equity & for a more productive economy. We have also signed as a country the Sustainable development agenda which calls for the introduction of Universal Health Coverage.

President #Ramaphosa: Therefore, one of our greatest priorities as a nation must be the achievement of universal health coverage, where all our people have equal access to quality health care. #GrowSouthAfrica #TheSouthAfricaWeWant #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/u5WmShpmU5

President #Ramaphosa: South Africa has massive inequalities that require policy change. We are one of the countries with the highest inequality. The health sector contributes significantly to the country’s inequality status. #GrowSouthAfrica #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: I would therefore like to suggest that this Parliament take responsibility for ensuring that the same standards of accountability and transparency are applied to all parties and leaders. #GrowSouthAfrica #TheSouthAfricaWeWant #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/vCS7FWMVnl

President #Ramaphosa: While this Act does not extend to the funding of internal party leadership contests, this is perhaps the appropriate time for this House to consider whether it is necessary & desirable for funding of internal party contests to be regulated. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: The Political Party Funding Act, which I signed into law earlier this year, does regulate public and private funding of political parties and requires the disclosure of donations accepted. #GrowSouthAfrica #TheSouthAfricaWeWant #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: Nor is there a provision for the disclosure of such information in the Executive Ethics Code or in the Code of Ethical Conduct & Disclosure of Members’ Interests for Assembly & Permanent Council Members. #GrowSouthAfrica #TheSouthAfricaWeWant #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: As things currently stand, therefore, there are no rules or regulations in place for the disclosure of donations for internal party leadership contests. #GrowSouthAfrica #TheSouthAfricaWeWant #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: If there were members of the Executive who were part of the campaign and were involved in fundraising, they did so as individual party members exercising their democratic and Constitutional right. They owe no apology for what they did. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: Those who contributed to the campaign – whether as organisers, volunteers, service providers or donors – did so out of a genuine concern for the future of the country. #GrowSouthAfrica #TheSouthAfricaWeWant #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: In its funding and its activities, there was no wrongdoing, no criminality and no abuse of public resources. #GrowSouthAfrica #TheSouthAfricaWeWant #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/TQ4iqpRPmv

President #Ramaphosa: The CR17 campaign was a legitimate, forward-looking and necessary effort to promote the renewal of the governing party and broader society, undertaken under difficult conditions. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ranaphosa: As for the report of the Public Protector, Honourable Members may know that this matter has been taken on urgent judicial review. We should allow the courts to make a determination on this matter. #GrowSouthAfrica #TheSouthAfricaWeWant #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: We need also to support and equip the National Prosecuting Authority to pursue investigations and prosecutions where there is evidence of criminality. #GrowSouthAfrica #TheSouthAfricaWeWant #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: As a country, and as leaders, we should direct our efforts towards supporting the Zondo Commission of Inquiry and urging all those with information relevant to its mandate to make themselves available to the Commission. #GrowSouthAfrica #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: Growing our economy requires hard work, commitment and close cooperation between all social partners. Are you playing your part? #GrowSouthAfrica #TheSouthAfricaWeWant #RamaphosaQandA
President #Ramaphosa: #TheSouthAfricaWeWant needs durable partnerships between government, business, labour, communities and civil society. #GrowSouthAfrica #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: The @IDCSouthAfrica will provide R11 billion in support to women-empowered enterprises alone, and further funds will be made available for youth-enterprises. #GrowSouthAfrica #TheSouthAfricaWeWant #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: In partnership with the private sector the DTI and IDC will provide support of over R40 billion to black-industrialists over the next five years. #GrowSouthAfrica #TheSouthAfricaWeWant #RamaphosaQandA
President #Ramaphosa: @GovernmentZA is stepping up support for black industrialists and women- and youth-owned enterprises. #GrowSouthAfrica #TheSouthAfricaWeWant #RamaphosaQandA

Summit noted that the next Summit will take place in Maputo, Mozambique in August 2020. #40SADCSummit #SADCSummit2020

Summit extended its appreciation to the Government and people of the United Republic of Tanzania for successfully hosting the 39th Ordinary Summit and the hospitality they provided to the delegates during the Summit period.
His Excellency President Dr. John Pombe Joseph Magufuli thanked all the Heads of State and Government for attending the 39th Ordinary Summit of SADC Heads of State and Government.
Summit commended H.E. Edgar Chagwa Lungu, President of the Republic of Zambia for his leadership during his tenure as the Chairperson of the Organ on Politics, Defence and Security Cooperation.
...on the signing of the peace and reconciliation agreement on the 06th August 2019, paving the way for sustainable peace and revamping of economic and social development.
Summit commended H.E. President Filipe Jacinto Nyusi, President of the Republic of Mozambique, and Honourable Ossufo Momade, the leader of the opposition political party, RENAMO...
Summit commended the Republics of Angola and South Africa for providing financial and material assistance for the conduct of the 2018 Presidential Elections in the Republic of Madagascar.
...for the role played that contributed to the peaceful elections and peaceful transfer of power, while maintaining the territorial integrity of the DRC.

Summit commended the Outgoing Chairperson of SADC, H.E. Dr. Hage G. Geingob, President of the Republic of Namibia, and the Outgoing Chairperson of the Organ on Politics, Defence and Security Cooperation, H.E. Edgar Chagwa Lungu, President of the Republic of Zambia...

Summit noted progress made on the construction of the SADC Standby Force Regional Logistics Depot and mandated the Chairperson of the Organ to engage further the African Union on the support required for the construction of the Regional Logistics Depot.
...and develop a Roadmap towards the transformation of the SADC Parliamentary Forum into a SADC Parliament;

Summit directed the SADC Secretariat in collaboration with the Parliamentary Forum Secretariat to develop the model that the proposed SADC Parliament would assume, in terms of mandate, powers and functions;
Summit congratulated the Comoros, Democratic Republic of Congo, Eswatini, Madagascar, Malawi and South Africa for holding peaceful and successful elections

Summit directed the Secretariat to notify the African Union Commission to notify the Government of Japan on the SADC Position regarding the exclusion of SADR participation in the forthcoming meeting of TICAD in August 2019.

Summit expressed solidarity with Saharawi Arab Democratic Republic/Western Sahara (SADR) by urging African Union Member States and other partners to ensure that the SADR is not excluded from participating in continental and international events;

Summit called for the unconditional implementation of all UN resolutions and AU decisions on Western Sahara, which will lead to a positive, peaceful and permanent solution that meets the aspirations of the people of Western Sahara.

Summit noted the resolutions of the SADC Solidarity Conference with the Saharawi Arab Democratic Republic (SADR)/Western Sahara and urged SADC Member States, the African Union, and the United Nations to implement the Conference resolutions

Summit commended the outgoing Chairperson of SADC, H.E. Dr. Hage G. Geingob (Namibia), and H.E. Cyril Ramaphosa (South Africa) for their outstanding leadership during the SADC Solidarity Conference with the Saharawi Arab Democratic Republic;

Summit noted the acts of gravity of maritime security threats such as Piracy, and Maritime terrorism; Drug Trafficking and; illegal carrying and trafficking of Weapons and Ammunition and agreed to jointly address them as part of SADC Maritime Security Strategy.

Summit noted the Act of extremism and terrorism in the DRC specifically in Beni area and agreed to continue collaborating with the Internationals Conference of the Great Lakes Region & consolidate efforts towards on the political & security stabilization of the Great Lakes Region

Summit noted the gravity of security challenges, especially of terrorism activities and transnational crime and urged Member States to prioritize the implementation the SADC Regional Counter Terrorism Strategy and its Action Plan.

Summit welcomed the enactment of legislation to establish the National Reforms Authority (NRA) in the Kingdom of Lesotho, called upon all stakeholders in #Lesotho to remain committed to the reforms process, and commended the SADC Facilitator for the effective facilitation.
Summit noted the withdrawal of South Africa's signature from the Protocol on the Tribunal in the Southern African Development Community of 2014 in compliance with the Constitutional Court ruling.
Summit also approved the Protocol on Inter-State Transfer of Sentenced Offenders, whose objective is to allow for the transfer of sentenced offenders to serve their sentences in their home countries.

Summit noted that #Burundi met some of the eligibility criteria for admission of new members into SADC and that she will submit a progress report based on which a verification Mission will be undertaken.
Summit approved Kiswahili as the Fourth SADC Official Working Language. This is in recognition of its contribution and Mwalimu Julius Kambarage Nyerere’s role during the liberation struggle.

Summit declared the 25th October as the date on which SADC Member States can collectively voice their disapproval of the sanctions through various activities and platforms until the sanctions are lifted.

Summit noted the adverse impact on the economy of Zimbabwe & the region at large, of prolonged economic sanctions imposed on Zimbabwe & expressed solidarity with Zimbabwe, and called for the immediate lifting of the sanctions to facilitate socio-economic recovery in the country.
...including the application of Article 5 of the SADC Protocol on Gender and Development on Special Measures.

Summit noted the good progress towards representation of women in politics and economic decision making and urged Member States to translate laws and policies into concrete actions, such as legislative quotas on women’s representation in politics...
and directed the SADC Secretariat to expedite the operationalization of the SADC Disaster Preparedness and Response Mechanism as part of the regional measures to respond to effects of climate change.

Summit expressed sympathy and noted the effects of tropical cyclones in the Union of Comoros, Madagascar, Malawi, Mozambique, South Africa, and Zimbabwe and commended all Member States for humanitarian support...
To this effect, Summit agreed to accelerate the implementation of the industrialization strategy.

Summit noted with great concern the slow growth in the intra-SADC trade levels, and that the region continues to export unprocessed raw material to the rest of the world, thereby forfeiting the potential benefits of the resource endowments.

Summit noted progress made on the implementation of the SADC Industrialization Strategy, and approved the Protocol on Industry, which aims to promote the development of a diversified, innovative and globally competitive industrial base.

Summit noted the overall decline in food production in the Region, for the 2018/19 crop season, and urged Member States to implement comprehensive multi-year response plans to tackle the recurrent droughts and food insecurity to boost agricultural production.

Summit endorsed the Theme of the #39SADCSummit of Heads of State and Government, “A Conducive Environment of Inclusive and Sustainable Industrial Development, Increased Intra-Regional Trade and Job Creation”, which takes forward the #SADC industrialization agenda
Summit commended the Outgoing Chairperson of SADC, H.E. Dr. Hage G. Geingob, President of the Republic of Namibia for his exemplary leadership during his tenure.

Summit also elected H.E. Emmerson Mnangagwa (Zimbabwe) as Chairperson of the Organ on Politics, Defence and Security Cooperation, and H.E. Dr. Mokgweetsi E.K. Masisi (Botswana) as Incoming Chairperson of the Organ on Politics, Defence & Security Cooperation.

Summit elected H.E. Dr. John Pombe Joseph Magufuli, President of the United Republic of Tanzania as Chairperson of SADC, and H.E. Filipe Jacinto Nyusi, President of the Republic of Mozambique as Incoming Chairperson of #SADC.

Summit expressed deep condolences to His Excellency Dr. President John Pombe Joseph Magufuli, the Government and the people of the United Republic of Tanzania and the families of the deceased following the deadly fuel tanker accident in #Morogoro.

The 39th Ordinary Summit of the Heads of State and Government of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) was held at Julius Nyerere International Convention Centre in Dar es Salaam, United Republic of Tanzania, on the 17th and 18th August 2019.

Remarks by President @CyrilRamaphosa during his visit to the Soikone University of Agriculture, Solomon Mahlangu campus (formerly known as Solomon Mahlangu Freedom College - #SOMAFCO) in Morogoro, Tanzania http://bit.ly/2ZcXrRI #SAinTanzania pic.twitter.com/7aryl80mtC
President #Ramaphosa: It is our task now, as the heirs of this great heritage, to deepen these ties through economic cooperation and development. #SAinTanzania

President #Ramaphosa: Through these efforts, the ties between Morogoro and South Africa have been sustained although a quarter of a century has passed since most of our people went back home. #SAinTanzania

President #Ramaphosa: It is work that serves to remind young people of the importance of this place in the history of our country and of the contribution that Tanzania and several other African countries made to the attainment of our freedom. #SAinTanzania

President #Ramaphosa: That is why we are encouraged by initiatives like the #SOMAFCO Future Africa Precinct, which aims to remember & celebrate our past while investing in infrastructure & economic opportunities that make a tangible difference in the lives of the people here.
President #Ramaphosa: Together with the people of Tanzania, we want this place to have a future that is as glorious as its past. #SAinTanzania

President #Ramaphosa: We return here because we desire – like the people of this area and all the people of Tanzania – to see this as a place of development, of commerce, of learning and of prosperity. #SAinTanzania

“Today, we return to feel with our own hands the soil that sustained our freedom fighters over the many dark years of oppression, the soil in which the remains of several of these freedom fighters are now interred.” President @CyrilRamaphosa in Morogoro, Tanzania #SAinTanzania pic.twitter.com/Ehme0urbsE
President #Ramaphosa: For this, Tanzania paid a heavy price as the colonial and apartheid rulers of neighbouring states sought to destabilise the country and undermine its economy. #SAinTanzania
President #Ramaphosa: In elaborating this selfless support for liberation movements, Tanzania encouraged and promoted African unity and solidarity. #SAinTanzania

President #Ramaphosa: Tanzania welcomed and housed large numbers of freedom fighters and refugees from struggles across Southern and sub-saharan Africa, providing an escape for those endangered by colonial oppression, wars of liberation and natural disasters. #SAinTanzania

President #Ramaphosa: Guided by his conviction, Tanzania offered itself as a base for several liberation movements from across the region, including the ANC, PAC, FRELIMO, MPLA, ZAPU, ZANU and SWAPO. #SAinTanzania

President #Ramaphosa: It was made possible, in particular, by the courageous leadership of Mwalimu Julius #Nyerere, who had a vision of a free and independent Africa in which all its people could exercise their right to self-determination. #SAinTanzania
President #Ramaphosa: The #Morogoro Conference was made possible by the generosity of the government and people of the newly-independent Tanzania. #SAinTanzania

President #Ramaphosa: Although we now wage a new struggle – for economic emancipation – under very different conditions, the ‘1969 Strategy & Tactics document’ adopted here in #Morogoro remains, to this day, an important and enduring point of reference. #SAinTanzania
President #Ramaphosa: In fact, the frank, sometimes heated, discussions held here in Morogoro continue to echo through the liberation movement half a century later. #SAinTanzania

President #Ramaphosa: The Conference was a pivotal moment in the struggle for our liberation, a moment of renewal and revitalisation. The Morogoro Conference effectively defined the course of our struggle for the next two decades. #SAinTanzania

President #Ramaphosa: A number of important meetings were held here, and among those was the ANC’s landmark consultative conference, which was held here in #Morogoro in 1969. This year we mark its 50th anniversary. #SAinTanzania

“Tanzania will forever be remembered as the heart of the Southern African liberation struggle, and the people of our countries will remain forever grateful.” President @CyrilRamaphosa in #Morogoro, Tanzania (16 August 2019) #SOMAFCO #SAinTanzania pic.twitter.com/a5tp8rzCN3

“No account of the anti-apartheid struggle is complete without Tanzania and in particular Morogoro’s chapter in that inspiring human narrative.” President @CyrilRamaphosa in #Morogoro, Tanzania (16 August 2019) #SOMAFCO #SAinTanzania pic.twitter.com/o4s2LX4LwK

“Today, we have come home. We have returned to the place which, for three decades, provided shelter, comfort, nourishment and knowledge to thousands of South African freedom fighters.” President @CyrilRamaphosa in Morogoro, Tanzania (16 August 2019) #SOMAFCO #SAinTanzania pic.twitter.com/vx3eKQ4aye

President @CyrilRamaphosa signs the visitors book during his visit to the Solomon Mahlangu Campus at the Soikone University of Agriculture in Morogoro, Tanzania. #SOMAFCO #SAinTanzania pic.twitter.com/eyALBw8kaU

It aimed to produce a new type of South African dedicated to non-racialism, non-sexism and social justice. It was to be accessible to all, irrespective of age, colour, creed, race or sex. #SOMAFCO #SAinTanzania

In contrast to Bantu education, which sought to prepare students for a lifetime of servitude, education at #SOMAFCO was meant to empower students to lead the process of building a democratic South Africa. #SOMAFCO #SAinTanzania

The Solomon Mahlangu Freedom College #SOMAFCO, was established by the exiled ANC in 1978. It is situated in Mazimbu, Morogoro. The college provided educational & vocational skills to young South Africans who had fled the country after the 1976 Soweto uprising. #SAinTanzania pic.twitter.com/Q6T5vMwRQD

President @CyrilRamaphosa and Dr Tshepo Motsepe on a tour of the Solomon Mahlangu Campus at the Soikone University of Agriculture, formerly known as the Solomon Mahlangu Freedom College. #SOMAFCO #SAinTanzania pic.twitter.com/bOb3IpcJ95

It was this Consultative Conference that adopted the Strategy and Tactics document, which determined the direction of the ANC's struggle against the apartheid regime for several decades. #SAinTanzania pic.twitter.com/dboeIGn2Hf

President @CyrilRamaphosa’s visit coincides with the 50th Anniversary of the African National Congress’s Morogoro Consultative Conference convened under the stewardship of President Oliver Tambo. #SAinTanzania pic.twitter.com/3UZt5TOvbd

President @CyrilRamaphosa and Dr Tshepo Motsepe arrive at the Morogoro Airport and are received by Prime Minister of Tanzania, Mr Kassim Majaliwa. President Ramaphosa’s visit to #Morogoro is the first by a sitting President of the Republic of South Africa. #SAinTanzania pic.twitter.com/6RcaNQGP5E
