President #Ramaphosa: I have made a call for all sectors of society to come together and develop a social compact to help us resolve our country’s challenges.pic.twitter.com/XVSrZxntF0

President #Ramaphosa: As traditional leaders, let us educate our people against child marriage and discriminatory practices that prevent women from owning property and land. #WomensDay2019pic.twitter.com/mNlTBKHakL

President #Ramaphosa: As sexual partners, let us care enough for each other to practice safe sex. As all South Africans, let us condemn violence against the LGBTQI+ community, including the abominable crime of so-called ‘corrective’ rape.

President #Ramaphosa: As men, let us step up and become better fathers to our children, and play an active role in their lives. Let us support great initiatives like #TheBestAManCanBe, a male mentorship programme being run by the creators of the Gogo Nozizwe commercial.

President #Ramaphosa: I have seen the beautiful Women’s Day tribute to #GogoNozizwe that is trending on social media; and it moved me greatly. Hers is the story of millions of our hardworking mothers and grandmothers who raise children alone and in great hardship. #WomensDay2019pic.twitter.com/qN1LwRfmr3
President #Ramaphosa: As parents, as grandparents, as uncles and aunts, let us rid ourselves of old attitudes that value boys over girls. #WomensDay2019pic.twitter.com/RC6CiygHZ5

President #Ramaphosa: We all have a responsibility to end gender-based violence. As men we become partners in abuse when we remain silent as other men use money or violence to dominate their girlfriends and wives. #WomensDay2019

President #Ramaphosa: We are reviewing the Domestic Violence Act to strengthen its provisions around domestic homicide and the enforcement of protection orders. The proposed amendments will also include previously marginalised victims such as members of the LGBTQI+ community.

President #Ramaphosa: A GBV steering committee will soon begin provincial consultations on the National Strategic Plan to end gender-based violence. The Department of Justice is in the process of amending the National Policy Framework on the Management of Sexual Offences.

President #Ramaphosa: Since government and civil society adopted a Declaration against Gender-Based Violence and Femicide last year, we have made a number of advances. #WomensDay2019pic.twitter.com/CTlOauhufu

President #Ramaphosa: All of these interventions are to ensure the women of this country are healthy, that their needs are responded to, and that the doors of opportunity are opened to them. #WomensDay2019
President #Ramaphosa: We are going to ensure that women and girls are direct beneficiaries of the National Health Insurance once it is implemented. #WomensDay2019pic.twitter.com/Pl94NlrAkT

President #Ramaphosa: Just over two weeks ago, we signed a Presidential Health Compact with stakeholders across the health sector on a series of measures to significantly improve the quality of the health care our people receive. #WomensDay2019

President #Ramaphosa: We have heard your concerns, here in North West, about the poor quality of service at our hospitals & clinics. Under Premier Mokgoro’s leadership we are working to turn this around, to ensure women and girls receive the best primary & secondary health care.
President #Ramaphosa: We will also correct whatever is standing in the way of this nation’s women and girls enjoying quality and accessible #health care, including reproductive health care.
President #Ramaphosa: Let us agree here that we will realise the economic liberation of women in our lifetime. Re tlo e etsa. Ro etsa ka Pele! Ro itlhaganela! Sizakukhawuleza! #WomensDay2019

President #Ramaphosa: Where there are deficiencies in our laws, and with their implementation we will correct them. The #FreedomCharter promised that the land shall be shared amongst those who work it, and this includes boMme, boSisi, bo Mama, all of you. #WomensDay2019

President #Ramaphosa: To the women of North West and around the country – in our villages, on our farms and in our cities – I have a message for you today. We will respect and enforce your rights to land. #WomensDay2019pic.twitter.com/yrHSTvy1Ib
President #Ramaphosa: These commitments will be written into the Performance Agreements of Ministers, Premiers, Directors-General and all senior managers in the public service. #WomensDay2019

President #Ramaphosa: Cabinet recently approved the Gender-Responsive Planning, Budgeting, Monitoring, Evaluation and Auditing Framework. Under this new framework, all government plans and budgets will have to include gender-specific delivery targets. #WomensDay2019pic.twitter.com/9favq82jlM
President #Ramaphosa: In the last year, state-owned companies enrolled over 2,700 female learners in training programmes to become artisans, technicians and engineers. #WomensDay2019

President #Ramaphosa: Over the last four years, our SOCs have spent a total of R100 billion on goods and services from women-owned businesses. These SOCs also have a crucial contribution to make in providing young women with the skills they need to succeed in a changing economy.

President #Ramaphosa: This programme, although only five years old, has already achieved its five year target for women entrepreneurs. It has approved R6.6 billion for women-owned businesses against a target of R4.4 billion. #WomensDay2019pic.twitter.com/OEVoluVrTO

President #Ramaphosa: As we expand our work in special economic zones, we will have a specific programme to support women’s participation across the value chain, and bring more women into the Black Industrialists Programme. #WomensDay2019

President #Ramaphosa: As we implement the agreements of last year’s #JobsSummit, we are working to ensure that we overcome the disadvantages that confront women in the world of work. #WomensDay2019pic.twitter.com/hXmHUOKr51

President #Ramaphosa: It is therefore critical that as we implement measures to address the jobs crisis in this country, we give special attention to the economic position of women. #WomensDay2019pic.twitter.com/FilccToaj1
President #Ramaphosa: We are working to expand the number of small businesses and improve their success rate, through greater support and creating space for new market entrants. #WomensDay2019
President #Ramaphosa: We are implementing a range of interventions to ease the cost of doing business, and making South Africa a competitive investment destination. #WomensDay2019

President #Ramaphosa: We are finalising the establishment of a new #InfrastructureFund with a clear plan to revive investment in infrastructure, which will drive economic activity and boost manufacturing. #WomensDay2019

President #Ramaphosa: According to the figures released last week by Statistics South Africa, the expanded unemployment rate among women stands at 42.5%, while it stands at 35% among men. #WomensDay2019
President #Ramaphosa: Women are disproportionately affected by unemployment and are in the lowest earning categories, making them most vulnerable to poverty. #WomensDay2019pic.twitter.com/vXS0185kdA
President #Ramaphosa: We are implementing a revitalised industrial strategy in support of key growth sectors in the economy with the greatest potential to create jobs. #WomensDay2019

President #Ramaphosa: Working together with partners in business and labour, in communities and across civil society, we are taking measures to restore our economy and create economic opportunities, especially for women and youth. #WomensDay2019

President #Ramaphosa: But we know there can be no true liberation of women unless they are economically empowered. For generations, black women in particular have carried the greatest burden of apartheid dispossession and deliberate underdevelopment. #WomensDay2019
President #Ramaphosa: 47% of MPs are women. This year, we achieved 50/50 gender parity among Cabinet Ministers for the first time. #WomensDay2019pic.twitter.com/mJrzAfRvR2

President #Ramaphosa: We have implemented policies & programmes to give practical expression to women’s rights to education, health care, basic services and social support. Today, women comprise 58% of all students enrolled at universities and colleges around the country.
President #Ramaphosa: As we mark 25 years of democracy, we can say with certainty that we have made a real difference in the lives of women. #WomensDay2019pic.twitter.com/aYGJFwLahw
President #Ramaphosa: They are shining examples of the strides our country has made since democracy, and of the even greater heights we are yet to attain. #WomensDay2019

President #Ramaphosa: They are the women of @BanyanaBanyana who are on a winning streak and have just scored their way into the COSAFA finals. All these women, and many, many more like them, are changing South Africa for the better. #WomensDay2019pic.twitter.com/OZuS521wrK

President #Ramaphosa: They are tech industry leaders like Zandile Keebine, whose organisation GirlCode hosts coding clubs and workshops for high school girls, and teaches basic computer literacy skills to unemployed women. #WomensDay2019pic.twitter.com/5DRB588Hve

President #Ramaphosa: They are researchers like UWC graduate student Shireen Mentor, who grew up witnessing the ravages of drug abuse in her community of Mannenberg, and is now conducting ground-breaking research into the effects of substance abuse on the brain.pic.twitter.com/r8idxn3dIl

President #Ramaphosa: They are entrepreneurs like nuclear scientist Nomso Kana whose company manufactures fibre-optic cables that are critical for the rollout of broadband infrastructure. #WomensDay2019pic.twitter.com/w9Qy85lSSI

President #Ramaphosa: They are farming specialists like Mmabatho Morudi from right here in North West, whose farm in Winterveld offers free bee pollination services to rural farmers. #WomensDay2019pic.twitter.com/GjOqHIkhSL

President #Ramaphosa: They are pathfinders like Dr Mary-Jane Bopape, the chief scientist for weather research at the South African Weather Service, who is leading a specialist team to produce this country’s first ever weather and climate change modelling system. #WomensDay2019pic.twitter.com/H5WK7ZhvfC
President #Ramaphosa: They are blazing a trail: in the workplace and in the boardrooms, in our factories and on our farms, in our Parliament and in our civil society organisations. #WomensDay2019
President #Ramaphosa: Today, we also pay tribute to the present generation who have taken up the baton of struggle towards a truly non-sexist and egalitarian society. #WomensDay2019

President #Ramaphosa: Those who participated in the march of 1956 described is as a moving and an emotional experience. It is in their honour that today we commemorate their historic contribution that has led to us enjoying the freedoms that they fought for. #WomensDay2019pic.twitter.com/G48Ye4gH1U

President #Ramaphosa: I once met an old woman who was a domestic worker who went to the march of 1956. She told me she had to take the children of her then employer to the march. Such was the dedication of those women. #WomensDay2019

President #Ramaphosa: She was one of the women of which our young star poet Koleka Putuma wrote: ‘I said a lineage of greatness is born. Women who have stood on the front lines of battlefields. Yielded their present for the future of others.” #WomensDay2019
President #Ramaphosa: She was among the great leaders of her generation. She answered to a higher calling to be of service to humanity, without expectation of recognition or reward.

President #Ramaphosa: It is an honour to commemorate #WomensDay2019 in the birthplace of one of our greatest heroes, Isithwalandwe/Seaparankoe Dr Ruth Segomotsi Mompati. Mama Ruth was a stalwart of the liberation movement, a freedom fighter and a committed gender activist.pic.twitter.com/BHLKejlaNh

Address by President Cyril Ramaphosa at the signing of the Presidential Health Compact, Dr George Mukhari Academic Hospital, Ga-Rankuwa, Tshwane https://bit.ly/2Z9Ueix

President #Ramaphosa: We are working together towards the achievement of redress. We are working for the public good, for social cohesion, for economic progress and, as Madiba said, for peace. We are working towards building the South Africa we want. #PresidentialHealthCompactpic.twitter.com/ophWkUGH8r

President #Ramaphosa: With the signing of this #PresidentialHealthCompact, we are closer to the fundamental transformation of our health care system. Through our actions, we are bringing our collective energies to bear to be of service to our people.pic.twitter.com/8DoY8EEhaE
President #Ramaphosa: Working in partnership, we have developed action plans with key interventions aligned to nine pillars. #PresidentialHealthCompactpic.twitter.com/cu8oV6PQmO

President #Ramaphosa: Under One Health System, all our hospitals, clinics and doctors’ rooms are appropriately staffed and resourced; there are adequate medicines, equipment and supplies; and infrastructure is suitable for the services to be provided. #PresidentialHealthCompact

President #Ramaphosa: Under One Health System, patients are treated with dignity and respect, regardless of their social circumstances. This is what we expect not just in the health care sector, but across the public service. #PresidentialHealthCompact

President #Ramaphosa: The #PresidentialHealthCompact has as its stated goal: One Country, One Health System. This means quality of care must be the same regardless of whether you have money or not, and regardless of where you live.pic.twitter.com/bmbtu9iL82

President #Ramaphosa: Cabinet recently adopted the National Health Insurance Bill, and it will soon be tabled in Parliament. As we move towards universal health coverage, the steps we are taking today will aid us in our efforts. #NHI #PresidentialHealthCompactpic.twitter.com/JHs12VldmA

President #Ramaphosa: Following the Summit, social partners turned their focus to developing the Compact that we will be signing today. We have already seen, and must applaud, the broad commitments our various social partners have made to strengthen the public health system.

President #Ramaphosa: We convened the Presidential Health Summit to address failures that have hampered our progress towards an integrated & unified health system. I was encouraged at by high level of participation in terms of the no. of delegates & the quality of their input.

President #Ramaphosa: A healthy nation is a successful nation. The transformation and effective resourcing of our health system is fundamental to our plans for building a just, equitable and prosperous society. #PresidentialHealthCompactpic.twitter.com/UyxPvSFbPP

President #Ramaphosa: Our mission to reform health care, to make it better suited to the needs of an ever-growing population, is part of a global movement towards equitable health care access that was given new impetus when the Sustainable Development Goals were adopted in 2015.pic.twitter.com/lKaOGFl7MB

President #Ramaphosa: By working in a collaborative way, we will be able to reach our goals faster and implement them efficiently and with the best use of resources. In fixing what is wrong with the public health care system we are mindful of the impact of our past.pic.twitter.com/zDcB4zBu41

President #Ramaphosa: The signing of the #PresidentialHealthCompact is the culmination of a long journey we have travelled together since we convened the Presidential Health Summit last year to find solutions to the crisis facing our health system.pic.twitter.com/n7asNYIvS1

The oncology facility brings advanced oncology care to cancer patients with a state-of the-art oncology diagnostics facility that allows for more accurate diagnosis, staging & monitoring of response to therapy. It’s also be used in Neurology, Cardiology & Infection/Inflammation.pic.twitter.com/RHnDUQXYiV

The Presidential Health Compact being signed today is a culmination of a process of consultation and collaboration between various stakeholders, aimed at strengthening the healthcare system towards ensuring a long & healthy life for all South Africans. #PresidentialHealthCompactpic.twitter.com/RmkcoutmAD

President @CyrilRamaphosa is conducted on a guided tour of the hospital as follows where he is visiting the Positron Emission Tomography Unit at the George Mukhari Hospital in Tshwane. #PresidentialHealthCompactpic.twitter.com/IufGUF9ZOG

Address by President Cyril Ramaphosa at the 25 Years of Democracy Conference, University of Johannesburg, Auckland Park https://bit.ly/32CV0H4
President #Ramaphosa: We need to ensure, in this context, that our academic output helps us sharpen our response to some of our most pressing challenges. #Democracy25pic.twitter.com/qwDv2vGSQx
President #Ramaphosa: We need to work together to improve the current state of affairs, to aid in nation building and the forging of a common national identity. #Democracy25
President #Ramaphosa: It necessitates active and ongoing engagement. We are first and foremost citizens, and the national interest demands that we each do our part. #Democracy25

President #Ramaphosa: In the end, we all have a stake in the stability and prosperity of our country. Our elected representatives must be held to account, yes, but true nation-building requires collaboration across society. #Democracy25pic.twitter.com/rI0osVASVj

President #Ramaphosa: In order to rebuild our public service and to have a corps of men & women who are ethical and skilled, our academic institutions have a similarly important role to play in the provision of training programmes, working with the National School of Government.

President #Ramaphosa: As part of ensuring that public policy is both coordinated and evidence-based, the new unit will be working with think-tanks and research institutions, including many of those represented here. #Democracy25
President #Ramaphosa: That is why we have decided to re-establish a Policy Unit in the Presidency to ensure that policy coordination across government is aligned. #Democracy25
President #Ramaphosa: However, crucial policy missteps have taken place. There are instances where we failed to implement coherent policy or delayed doing so. #Democracy25

President #Ramaphosa: This has resulted in millions more of our people being brought into the economy – and we will continue to advance policies such as BBBEE, employment equity and the Black Industrialists Programme as key levers of transformation. #Democracy25

President #Ramaphosa: In driving this country’s development over the past quarter century, we have made policy decisions and choices that have made a real difference. We have pursued an economic path of growth, of redress and of transformation. #Democracy25

President #Ramaphosa: While our objective was clear, to build a country with equal rights and opportunities for all, there were sharp points of divergence on how to achieve it. Today, 25 years later, we are reaping the consequences, both good and not so good, of those choices.pic.twitter.com/8aSu0kK6QS

President #Ramaphosa: It needed to respond to the legitimate expectations of our people within a global reality – and under local circumstances – that were not conducive to a rapid improvement in the conditions of the majority of our people. #Democracy25
President #Ramaphosa: It needed to give practical expression to the vision of the Freedom Charter while ensuring that our new country was integrated into the global economy. #Democracy25
President #Ramaphosa: Progress requires that we make choices. As the new democratic government took office in 1994, it was faced with a number of stark and difficult decisions. #Democracy25

President #Ramaphosa: This administration has identified key tasks within a defined set of focus areas that are realistic and achievable within the next five years. Growing an inclusive economy is by far our greatest focus. #Democracy25pic.twitter.com/qVTtLQPnkb

President #Ramaphosa: We have to reflect as government on whether our implementation model in its current iteration has effectively met our development needs. In attempting to do too much, in not coordinating our actions within & between departments, we have been found wanting.

President #Ramaphosa: We have to ask ourselves very profound and tough questions about our democracy beyond holding regular, free and fair elections and strengthening public institutions. #Democracy25
President #Ramaphosa: If democracy is to mean more than just securing the franchise, if it is to make a material difference in people’s lives, we have to arrest the decline. #Democracy25

...and the cultural patterns that preserve the power relationships created by colonisation. So long as they are not remedied, poverty and inequality will continue to deepen. It is our actions now that will determine the path the country takes. #Democracy25

President #Ramaphosa: As Professor Steven Friedman notes in a recently published paper, although we have exceeded expectations insofar as democratic consolidation is concerned, we have yet to transform the economic patterns that exclude millions from the economy’s benefits...
President #Ramaphosa: These material conditions have had an impact of the formation of a common national identity. #Democracy25

President #Ramaphosa: However, this progress has been undermined, particularly since the global financial crisis, by stagnant growth, declining investment, maladministration and corruption, among others. #Democracy25

President #Ramaphosa: There are several indicators of social progress, from the growth in the size of the black middle class to an improvement in educational attainment, from a massive improvement in access to basic services to a decline in levels of poverty. #Democracy25

President #Ramaphosa: The substantial investment we have made in economic and social infrastructure, in providing houses, water and electricity, in expanding access to education and health care has undoubtedly improved people’s lives. #Democracy25pic.twitter.com/ivgOV0iAVL

President #Ramaphosa: Despite significant economic progress in the years leading up to the global financial crisis, unemployment has increased over the last decade, poverty levels have begun to rise again, and millions of South Africans remain excluded. #Democracy25
President #Ramaphosa: Over the course of the last 25 years, however, we have been less successful in addressing the structural faults in our economy. #Democracy25

President #Ramaphosa: Through sound macroeconomic management and, to some extent, the benefits of a democratic dividend, we succeeded in turning around public finances and setting the country on an improved growth path. #Democracy25
President #Ramaphosa: These challenges were underpinned by an economy that was in its design and structure simply unable to satisfy the needs of the South African people. #Democracy25

President #Ramaphosa: In the very first years of democracy, we were called upon to address an immediate economic crisis, characterised by a substantial fiscal deficit, a huge apartheid debt bill and stagnant growth. #Democracy25pic.twitter.com/3pQLI1jq0o

President #Ramaphosa: This conference provides an opportunity to assess progress towards the achievement of our vision of a non-racial, non-sexist, democratic, prosperous & free society. It is a platform to identify challenges, opportunities and tasks of the present & the future.pic.twitter.com/O4iMHVxj4R
President #Ramaphosa: Such engagement is essential if we are to forge durable and lasting social compacts across society to attain our developmental objectives. #Democracy25

President #Ramaphosa: This conference forms part of a broader social dialogue that should enrich our understanding of the last 25 years and that contributes to a common vision and programme for the next 25 years. #Democracy25

President @CyrilRamaphosa pays his final respects and presents the Stone flag to a member of the Maphoto family as Ntate Lesibe Isaac “Bra Ike” Maphoto is laid to rest during his Special Official Funeral service at the Silikon cemetery in Polokwane, Limpopo.pic.twitter.com/Vj0JOAq1c7
Eulogy by President Cyril Ramaphosa at the funeral of Comrade Lesibe Isaac ‘Ike’ Maphoto, Polokwane, Limpopo Province https://bit.ly/2O5QzkN

President #Ramaphosa: To the family I say, we share in your sorrow, and we join you in celebrating a life well lived in the service of others. He has run the race, he has fought the good fight. And so we say farewell, Son of the Soil. Robala ka khutjo Mokone wa ntshi dikgolo.pic.twitter.com/DlWfbDaXAb

President #Ramaphosa: Theirs was a battle against the forces of racism. Let us strive and fight with equal measure to overcome the ills of our society today. The ills of poverty & injustice, of violence against women & children, against disease, and against racism & inequality.

President #Ramaphosa: In bidding farewell to a giant of the liberation struggle, I call on the people of this country, especially our young people, to pick up the spear that has fallen.pic.twitter.com/DHFt2AW7S5

President #Ramaphosa: Let us emulate his commitment to and love of education – and encourage our children to take advantage of all the educational opportunities at their disposal and study particularly subjects that respond to the rapidly changing nature of work.pic.twitter.com/98UIkipfXs

President #Ramaphosa: In his honour, we must double our efforts and intensify the fight against corruption and hold accountable all those who facilitated the capture of the state by private interests.

President #Ramaphosa: Bra Ike abhorred corruption and the abuse of the movement to enrich oneself. I am certain that Bra Ike would have been in the forefront of those against the beneficiaries and defenders of state capture.pic.twitter.com/FNop0fnSjC

President #Ramaphosa: To carry on this legacy we must sharpen our revolutionary conviction to contribute to the ongoing transformation of our country. And that we do so without any motive of material advantage or personal gain.

President #Ramaphosa: Though he is no longer with us, the ideas for which Bra Ike stood will not die. We are confident that he has left behind men and women determined continue the fight for a non-racial, non-sexist, democratic and prosperous South Africa.

President #Ramaphosa: They are stories of advancing deep into hostile territory under cover of darkness; of hiding along crocodile infested riverbanks; of encountering locals who did not speak their language and being unable to determine who was friend or foe.

President #Ramaphosa: The Luthuli Detachment distinguished itself in the famous Wankie and Sipholilo Campaigns, also known as the Western Front and Eastern Front campaigns. As we read the historical accounts, we are astonished by their bravery.

President #Ramaphosa: The men and women of MK, and of the Luthuli Detachment were able to advance, confront and defeat the enemy because they worked together, because they did not descend into infighting, and because they saw the bigger picture.

President #Ramaphosa: It is here that we learn about some of the virtues that epitomized Bra Ike. Respect, for the leadership of the movement and for his fellow soldiers. Discipline – an understanding that their mission was difficult, and would take time.pic.twitter.com/GBpL2rdm8Q

President #Ramaphosa: When he completed his training he was sent to an ANC military base in Kongwa in Tanzania. Life in the camp was difficult, and the conditions grueling, especially for young men like Bra Ike who were rearing to go to the frontline to fight.

President #Ramaphosa: Before Bra Ike took part in the many campaigns of the Luthuli Detachment, he was amongst those sent by MK for military training, which he completed in Lebanon and the then Soviet Union.
President #Ramaphosa: The story of his life offers many lessons to us today. Lessons in courage, lessons on the virtue of discipline, and on the limitless capacity for endurance of the human being.

President #Ramaphosa: Bra Ike was a soldier of the revolution. He joins the glorious ranks of George Nene, of Archie Sibeko, of Chris Hani, of Thandi Modise, and of the many legions of men and women whose actions lit the path to our liberation.

President #Ramaphosa: Like Comrade Maphoto, they were young, and their entire lives stretched before them. But they were of uncompromising revolutionary morality, and understood that a life that was not lived in freedom, was no life at all.

President #Ramaphosa: The men and women who joined Umkhonto we Sizwe at such a time were amongst the bravest of the brave. It was a time when any association with the liberation movement risked imprisonment, and even death.

President #Ramaphosa: They took up arms in the cause of freedom at a time when the liberation forces were in the crosshairs of the racist Pretoria regime at a time like no other. Our people’s demands for freedom were being responded to with bloodshed and brutality.

President #Ramaphosa: He was from the legion of umgwenya – the detachment of Luthuli, and the standard-bearers of the politically conscious & revolutionary army of Umkhonto we Sizwe. Bra Ike and the veterans we have from the detachment here with us today, answered history’s call.

President #Ramaphosa: He suffered the pain of exile. He survived incarceration in a foreign land. He forsook the comforts of ordinary life to pick up a backpack and a rifle in the cause of the liberation struggle.
President #Rmaphosa: A man of distinction, of resolve, of immense courage, and of selflessness. A man who devoted his life to the liberation of our people.

President #Ramaphosa: For the past four days, the national flag has been flown at half-mast around the country in tribute to this great soldier, who was also an unwavering patriot, a mentor and friend, a philanthropist, and a much loved father and grandfather.

President #Ramaphosa: On behalf of the government and the people of the Republic of South Africa, and on behalf of the African National Congress (ANC), I would like to convey my deep condolences to the family, comrades & friends of Comrade Maphoto, whom we all knew as ‘Bra Ike’.pic.twitter.com/HP7u6XQPFI

President #Ramaphosa: We will be championing the agenda of peace and development on the continent both at an #AU and #SADC level. We continue to support the people of #Lesotho as they move forward with the reforms to which they have committed themselves.

President #Ramaphosa: Once implemented, #Africa will become the world’s largest free trade area; merging 55 countries of 1.2 billion people with a combined GDP of USD 2,5 trillion. #AfCFTA #BudgetVote2019
President #Ramaphosa: With the signing of the Africa Continental Free Trade Area ( #AfCFTA), the nations of Africa took a decisive step that will deepen the integration of our continent.

President #Ramaphosa: We are also concerned about growing reports of planned retrenchments by some of our big firms and we are engaging stakeholders and will be considering all available options to help our firms to retain as many jobs as possible without compromising viability.

President #Ramaphosa: I have directed Ministers Gordhan & Patel to intervene & get our goods to their destinations urgently. We can’t aim to grow an economy on the basis of exporting value-added products and then fail to meet our obligations to get goods to international markets.
President #Ramaphosa: Fellow South Africans, Cabinet is concerned at reports of a go-slow a some of our ports, particularly in the Eastern Cape where operations have nearly ground to a halt.

President #Ramaphosa: I have said before that we are speeding up our agrarian reform programme, including rapid land release for development. The DP is overseeing this work. In addition our SMME support programme is fully operational and notable progress is being registered.

President #Ramaphosa: Infrastructure development remains at the centre of our economic growth efforts, and we will continue with the process of budget reprioritisation in order to revitalise our infrastructure build programme, which is led by Minister De Lille.

President #Ramaphosa: Our roadmap to achieve Top 50 status in the World Bank’s Ease of Doing Business index is already being presented to key stakeholders as it seeks to remove the barriers to success for business, including small business.
President #Ramaphosa: In the coming weeks we will also give a progress report on the implementation of the stimulus package that we announced last year as we move towards its first anniversary.

President #Ramaphosa: The Presidency will continue to lead the national investment drive, and to meet our goal of raising R1.3 trillion in the next five years. President #Ramaphosa: Minister Patel in his Budget Vote elaborated on Reimagining our Industrial Strategy. We have a framework in place and expect Master Plans for each of the identified sectors before we host the second Investment Conference in November. #BudgetVote2019

President #Ramaphosa: The Ministers in the economic cluster have elaborated on urgent steps to be taken to refuel the engine room of the economy, from growing small businesses, to attracting higher tourism numbers, to the potential of recent offshore oil and gas discoveries.

President #Ramaphosa: We expect to finalise these performance agreements by the first week of September when the #MTSF, with clear deliverables for each department, is approved by Cabinet. #BudgetVote2019

President #Ramaphosa: We must be a learning government, a machinery that learns from its mistakes and take decisive steps to correct the situation.pic.twitter.com/X81VzllyGH

President #Ramaphosa: The New Dawn requires that we implement more of such interventions in order to improve our performance as government. Where there is best practice in other spheres, we will benefit from them, identify and replicate them. #BudgetVote2019

President #Ramaphosa: Because implementation will be tracked more closely under this new integrated district-based system, we will be able to pinpoint with precision our level of intervention to make local government more effective. #BudgetVote2019
President #Ramaphosa: When our municipalities are dysfunctional it doesn’t just negatively impact our citizens, it deters investment. #BudgetVote2019

President #Ramaphosa: When an automotive manufacturer or a soft drinks company sets up shop here, they don’t do so on the lawns of the Union Buildings – they go to our provinces and municipalities. #BudgetVote2019pic.twitter.com/CN3LOgZq9J
President #Ramaphosa: Local government is the engine room of service delivery and the incubator of investment, and plays a critical role in determining land use for development. #BudgetVote2019
President #Ramaphosa: This approach will underpin the work that Minister Dlamini Zuma will be doing in her portfolio as Minister of Cooperative Governance and Traditional Affairs.

President #Ramaphosa: In time to come, special #Khawuleza Provincial Coordination Forums will be set up for the purposes of oversight and implementation monitoring. Through the programme of izimbizo the President and Deputy President will participate in these forums.

President #Ramaphosa: These plans must be spatially referenced to indicate what projects will be implemented in which districts, why, how and by when.pic.twitter.com/y5UNx7RKJM

President #Ramaphosa: This means targeted development – development that localises procurement and job creation, that promotes and supports local businesses, and that involves communities instead of foisting it on them. #BudgetVote2019

President #Ramaphosa: Considering the successes we have already achieved in doing so on a smaller scale, we will be rolling out a new integrated district based approach to addressing our service delivery challenges. #BudgetVote2019
President #Ramaphosa: As the sixth administration, we are going to do away with a fragmented approach to development. #BudgetVote2019pic.twitter.com/nRtcXQxZIL

@CyrilRamaphosa Now is the time for all of us to work together to implement it. Let us always remember what Proverbs 29:18 instructs: “Where there is no vision, the people perish.” #SONAReply #SONA2019pic.twitter.com/OaHnsFvrxD

@CyrilRamaphosa "We will not succeed in either addressing the economic crisis of the present or building an inclusive future unless all South Africans play their part." #SONAReplypic.twitter.com/6gd15jcs7x
@CyrilRamaphosa "The future must be built now." #SONAReply #SONA2019pic.twitter.com/VkE6VYcPPI

@CyrilRamaphosa "I want to pay tribute to the national teams representing South Africa in the Women’s Football World Cup, the Cricket World Cup and the African Cup of Nations" #SONADebate #SONA2019 #SONAReplypic.twitter.com/HG3qyOe0qW
@CyrilRamaphosa "The country’s largest urban economies must play a far greater role in job-intensive growth and poverty reduction." #SONADebate #SONA2019 #SONAReplypic.twitter.com/WATqJOwPdI

@CyrilRamaphosa "If we are to improve the lives of South Africans, particularly the poor, and if we are to foster economic development, we need to make local service delivery work." #SONADebate #SONA2019 #SONAReplypic.twitter.com/NgR1ucQYpY

@CyrilRamaphosa "It is the most fundamental right of our citizens to live in safety in their homes, in the streets, and in their communities." #SONADebate #SONA2019 #SONAReplypic.twitter.com/dFu0VuFFlA

@CyrilRamaphosa "We are investing in the National Health Insurance so that we can not only contribute to economic growth by keeping the population healthy, but ensure universal access to quality health care." #SONADebate #SONA2019pic.twitter.com/Yc9pI0mwMD

@CyrilRamaphosa "The 26 road building projects that form part of the Economic Stimulus and Recovery Plan will unlock total investment of R13 billion, delivering roads in rural areas and townships over the next 3 to 5 years and producing a total of 22,000 jobs." #SONADebatepic.twitter.com/BqX75OwNTC
@CyrilRamaphosa "We are working to increase the proportion of public spending that goes to infrastructure development." #SONADebate #SONA2019 #SONAReplypic.twitter.com/McybQBdt2J
@CyrilRamaphosa "We are determined that land should be distributed to those who work it and those who need it." #SONADebate #SONA2019pic.twitter.com/yqXEtm9RGK

@CyrilRamaphosa "A significant part of our efforts to unleash growth while advancing transformation is our accelerated programme of land reform." #SONADebate #SONA2019 #SONAReplypic.twitter.com/Y4Lky3KG5u

@CyrilRamaphosa "The successful takeover of the distribution of SASSA grants by the Post Office is a clear demonstration that government institutions do have the capacity and capability to effectively implement projects of this magnitude." #SONADebate #SONA2019 #SONAReplypic.twitter.com/Yq84cOwAeK

@CyrilRamaphosa "We are also working towards a new SOE landscape in which state owned companies have the expertise, leadership and appropriate financial models to fulfil their respective mandates." #SONADebate #SONA2019 #SONAReplypic.twitter.com/UqRIPH7JzY
@CyrilRamaphosa "We see the greatest growth in jobs coming from small and medium sized businesses" #SONADebate #SONA2019 #SONAReplypic.twitter.com/0XynBt26p3
@CyrilRamaphosa "We must look forward to a time when the goods that we import do not come across the ocean, but from across the Limpopo." #SONA2019 #SONAReplypic.twitter.com/tRxiwcahmG

@CyrilRamaphosa "Our revitalised industrial strategy has a focus on expanding our trade and investment links with the rest of the SADC region and the continent at large." #SONA2019 #SONAReplypic.twitter.com/Ru3i0Xrkx7

@CyrilRamaphosa "We are determined to achieve our goal of being among the top 50 global performers in the World Bank’s annual Doing Business Report within the next 3 years." #SONA2019 #SONAReplypic.twitter.com/tMSiQzFcVS
@CyrilRamaphosa "This SONA was about setting out the seven priorities of the administration" #SONAReply #SONA2019pic.twitter.com/IDDjWkmaHj
@CyrilRamaphosa A few days ago, my attention was drawn to a tweet that said ...pic.twitter.com/Ci1KuhKa0p
@CyrilRamaphosa "We are seeking through our investment drive not only to generate foreign direct investment, but also to encourage local businesses to invest." #SONAReplypic.twitter.com/bT94fTJS9g
@CyrilRamaphosa "There are no short cuts and there are no quick fixes." #SONAReplypic.twitter.com/gv7GCqk7m9
@CyrilRamaphosa "Building the South Africa we want starts now – and it involves all of us." #SONAReplypic.twitter.com/Ur4zEafnfq

@CyrilRamaphosa "More than half a century after it was adopted, the Freedom Charter remains the foundation of our shared vision of a just and equitable South Africa." #SONAReplypic.twitter.com/kHt0mv686k

@CyrilRamaphosa "It is our experience, over a long and difficult history, that it is only through dialogue, through the frank exchange of views, that we can arrive at inclusive solutions".pic.twitter.com/EqcWFcSaf6

President #Ramaphosa: Working together there is nothing we cannot be, nothing we cannot do, and nothing we cannot achieve. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/fOo7sZrbqp
President #Ramaphosa: We are committed to building an ethical state. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/Ju1fsccquN
President #Ramaphosa: It is essential that we strengthen our SOEs #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/WycmqQhQd5
President #Ramaphosa: We are stepping up the fight against drug syndicates. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/68r2jj5IGs
President #Ramaphosa: We are working towards the establishment of the Gender-Vased Violence and Femicide Council. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/3cAMM9BZBo
President #Ramaphosa: We want a South African where all people are safe and feel safe. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/I0dRXVsz19
President #Ramaphosa: We have to prepare our young people for the jobs of the future. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/pKDcFftZ5T
President Ramaphosa: We will mobilise the entire nation behind a massive reading campaign. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/lZZ1dlfvZg
President #Ramaphosa: We have to support the fire of entrepreneurship. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/sdjP8RZ6ck
President #Ramaphosa: We will expand the National Youth Service to take on 50 000 young people a year. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/AP71gLEUYJ

President #Ramaphosa: The growth of our economy will have little value unless it creates employment on a far greater scale. The fact that the unemployment rate among young South Africans is more than 50% is a national crisis that demands urgent, innovative & coordinated solutionspic.twitter.com/98elF5NO69

President #Ramaphosa: In the immediate term, government will accelerate efforts to identify and release public land that is suitable for smart, urban settlements and for farming. In the stimulus & recovery package, we promised to prioritise funding for emerging farmers. #SONA2019pic.twitter.com/alphvE5tYx

President #Ramaphosa: We have the opportunity to be at the forefront of green growth, of low-carbon industrialisation, of pioneering new technologies and of taking quantum leaps towards the economy of the future. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/hamn8sMzvi
President #Ramaphosa: We must address the high cost of doing business. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/d2pqGissGc
President #Ramaphosa: Today we reaffirm this constitutional mandate, which the Reserve Bank must pursue independently, without fear, favour or prejudice. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/qPl9BWu9Un
President #Ramaphosa: We call on all South Africans to consistently buy locally made goods. #BuyLocal #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/5VhoOZP6cL

President #Ramaphosa: We are intensifying our investment drive. Of the R300 billion of investments announced at our inaugural Investment Conference last year, just over R250 billion worth of projects has entered implementation phase. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/IAoA7CYJ1v

President #Ramaphosa: We call on the telecommunications industry to further bring down the cost of data do that it is in line with other countries in the world. #DataMustFall #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/ubP8IkfzDC
President #Ramaphosa: We will bring economic development to local areas. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/k4TUsHJXfY
President #Ramaphosa: We will rebuild the foundations of our economy. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/Q8REgZ9Fgf
President #Ramaphosa: We will appoint a Chief Restructuring Officer to reposition #ESKOM. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/2hMTAWAAb7
President #Ramaphosa: Within the next decade, it is our ambition that our economy should be growing a rate far greater than our population. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/UKdS10msWE
President #Ramaphosa: We need to provide skills and create economic opportunities for persons with disability. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/xFrKsq7FS0
President #Ramaphosa: We are far advanced in revising the #NHI detailed plan of implementation. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/266e1dMWzo
President #Ramaphosa: We must attend to the capacity of our hospitals and clinics. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/XLxP22Pdx0
President #Ramaphosa: In the next five years, we will accelerate the provision of well-located housing and land to poor South Africans. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/VYX5aRP6OL

President #Ramaphosa: We set these ambitious goals not despite the severe difficulties of the present, but because of them. We set these goals so that the decisions we take now are bolder and we act with greater urgency. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/2sBScEcJH0

President #Ramaphosa: Let us make these commitments now – to ourselves and to each other – knowing that they will stretch our resources and capabilities, but understanding that if we achieve these five goals, we will have fundamentally transformed our society. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/blNXX6EWRg

President #Ramaphosa: To ensure that our efforts are directed, I am suggesting that, within the priorities of this administration, we agree on five fundamental goals for the next decade. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/TNNfvNcw49
President #Ramaphosa: Let is agree that within the next 10 years we will have made progress in tackling poverty, inequality and unemployment. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/FVD6OH5IG7
State of the Nation Address by President Cyril Ramaphosa, Parliament, Cape Town. #SONA2019 http://bit.ly/2WVVo4j
President #Ramaphosa: Now is the time to focus on implementation. #SONA2019pic.twitter.com/CwJ5bWWiwi

President #Ramaphosa: We need to focus on those actions that will have the greatest impact, actions that will catalyse faster movement forward, both in the immediate term and over the next 10 years. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/uk7r0BpLoy

President #Ramaphosa: We have heard you, and many others. Sinizwile. Hi twile. To zwi pfa. Re itlwile. Through the elections held in May, you provided all of us with a clear mandate for growth and renewal. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/W0WHkumKvd
President #Ramaphosa: Working together, we have laid a firm foundation on which we can build a country in which all may know peace and comfort and contentment. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/9g9tCBbuPY
President #Ramaphosa: We gather here at an extremely difficult and challenging time in the life of our young democracy. #SONA2019 pic.twitter.com/GtM4fq9AEy

President #Ramaphosa: Our people suffered gravely and endured untold hardships as a result of the implementation of the Natives Land Act. The effect of that law are still present with us. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: We recall the words of Sol Plaatje on that tragic event, when he said: “Awakening on Friday morning, June 20, 1913, the South African native found himself, not actually a slave, but a pariah in the land of his birth.” #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: We gather here at the start of the 6th Democratic Parliament, 106 years to the day after the Natives Land Act – one of the most devastating acts of dispossession, pain and humiliation – came into force. #SONA2019

Address by President Cyril Ramaphosa at the 2019 Youth Day Celebration, Peter Mokaba Cricket Club, Polokwane http://bit.ly/31yhsk8

President #Ramaphosa: A new tomorrow is on the horizon, bringing with it the promise of a South Africa of shared prosperity, of equal opportunity for all, and a South Africa where you, the youth, are its greatest asset. Let us grow South Africa together.pic.twitter.com/FnSV7AJuG0

President #Ramaphosa: You are born of a people who experienced one of the greatest tragedies in modern human history, but who triumphed. You, like me, believe in the greatness of this country. This country is yours to inherit, so rise and take charge of your destiny. #YouthDaypic.twitter.com/2kbdznEw0G
President #Ramaphosa: Your schools, libraries and centres of learning are not just for your benefit, but for the benefit of future generations. Be proud of them and protect them. #YouthDay

President #Ramaphosa: In taking advantage of the opportunities this government has made available to you to improve your lives – like enrolling in a TVET college or volunteering to do community work – you are keeping their legacy of civic activism alive. #YouthDay

President #Ramaphosa: You are the sons and daughters of a great people, and inheritors of the spirit of Peter Mokaba, of Nelson Mandela, of Hector Pieterson and of the generation of 1976. #YouthDaypic.twitter.com/5f6v8hR8l0

President #Ramaphosa: To you, the youth, we salute your resilience. Many of you are too young to have experienced the injusice of apartheid, but many of you live with its effects. Do not lose hope. Do not let the sun set on your ambition, your plans and your dreams. #YouthDaypic.twitter.com/Y43JzivnxU

President #Ramaphosa: We also have to deal with gender-based violence among young people and encourage them to conduct healthy relationships, and to dismantle deeply ingrained sexist attitudes towards women and girls. #YouthDay

President #Ramaphosa: The high incidence of HIV among young people indicates that we also need to step up prevention campaigns directed at youth to raise awareness around risky sexual behaviour. #YouthDay

President #Ramaphosa: We will therefore work to mobilise the whole of society behind the National Drug Master Plan. Once implemented, it is hoped this plan will reduce the demand for drugs, cut off their supply and ultimately free our youth from the harm they cause. #YouthDay

President #Ramaphosa: We know that alcohol and substance abuse is taking its toll on young lives across our nation. The average age of a drug user is getting younger. Drugs are fueling violence, crime, suicide and risky sexual behaviour. #YouthDay

President #Ramaphosa: In its efforts to break barriers for young people in the job market, the NYDA has trained almost 400,000 young people on job preparedness and life skills. Around 25,000 of these young people have now been placed in permanent jobs. #YouthDaypic.twitter.com/jhsJnScEZ7

President #Ramaphosa: The National Youth Development Agency continues to provide interventions to support young entrepreneurs & has over the past five years disbursed development finance to more than 6,000 start-up youth entrepreneurs and helped create more than 18,000 new jobs.

President #Ramaphosa: We welcome the work being done through the Youth Employment Service. In a few months, the YES initiative has placed over 18,000 young people in employment opportunities & is providing business infrastructure & support through its community hubs. #YouthDay

President #Ramaphosa: This year we have also set aside over R900 million to settle the historical debts of continuing NSFAS-funded students. Despite these efforts, however, youth unemployment remains a national crisis. #YouthDaypic.twitter.com/3eUo3DWLEz

President #Ramaphosa: It is for this reason that the budget of the National Student Financial Aid Scheme has grown exponentially from R70 million in 1994 to nearly R15 billion in 2018. We are phasing in free tertiary education for children from poor and working class backgrounds.pic.twitter.com/cIY3SUGy15
President #Ramaphosa: We are determined that no young person in this country should be denied a decent education because of the financial circumstances of their family. #YouthDay

President #Ramaphosa: These are all productive and growing areas of the economy into which our young people can be absorbed. We are continuously strengthening our TVET colleges so young people can gain the technical skills our country needs to industrialise & develop our economy.
President #Ramaphosa: But we don’t just need software engineers. We also need car mechanics, electricians, plumbers, hydroponics specialists, tour guides and aquaculture farmers. #YouthDay

President #Ramaphosa: At last year’s Presidential Jobs Summit, we agreed on a number of initiatives to accelerate the skilling of our young people to take advantage of jobs in the tech sector, as well as in installation, maintenance and repair jobs. #YouthDaypic.twitter.com/MdFVjsnJ8C

President #Ramaphosa: We are therefore prioritising science, technology, engineering, arts and mathematics in our education system. Coding and data analytics are being introduced as school subjects. #YouthDay
President #Ramaphosa: We are committed to provide our young people with all the opportunities possible to enable them to reach their potential. This begins with education. #YouthDay
President #Ramaphosa: Despite their hardships and daily struggles, millions of young people in this country still believe they have a place in the South African sun. #YouthDay
President #Ramaphosa: These positive stories are a reminder that the flame that burned bright in the youth of 1976 has not been lost to the history books. #YouthDay
President #Ramaphosa: Like our shining star and the daughter of this province, Mokgadi Caster Semenya, who has overcome challenges both off and on the track. #YouthDaypic.twitter.com/8xAAEHswrc

President #Ramaphosa: They are blazing a trail across the worlds of arts, culture and sport – like the young women of Banyana Banyana who participated for the very first time in the Women’s FIFA World Cup in France. #YouthDaypic.twitter.com/iWnqFof96K
President #Ramaphosa: They are serving as clinical directors in our hospitals, and entering Parliament and provincial legislatures in their numbers. #YouthDay

President #Ramaphosa: They are building aircrafts in Cape Town, inventing water purification systems in Gauteng and spending their afternoons building circuits and prototypes in coding clubs in townships from Langa to Ivory Park. #YouthDay

President #Ramaphosa: They are just some of the young people who are making a difference in ways both big and small. This country’s young people are far from being the lost generation. They are seizing the future with both hands. #YouthDay

President #Ramaphosa: There is Gabriella Mogale who invented fire-proof shack construction material, and Portia Mavhungu who invented a mechanism to assist people with disability to use the toilet with dignity. #YouthDay
President #Ramaphosa: There is Tinashe Chipako, a young engineering student who pioneered a water-saving fertiliser project on the campus of the University of Cape Town. #YouthDay
[WATCH LIVE]: President @CyrilRamaphosa delivers the #YouthDay keynote address 25 Years of Democracy: A Celebration of Youth Activism”https://twitter.com/CyrilRamaphosa/status/1140214906869833729 …
President #Ramaphosa: There is Sifiso Ngobese whose company provides safe trolleys for waste pickers. #YouthDay
President #Ramaphosa: There is Thato Kgatlhanye, whose company designs and manufactures solar-charged schoolbags made from recycled plastic bags that can be used as reading lights. #YouthDay

President #Ramaphosa: Across this country there are stories of young people who have used their talents, imagination and creativity to solve some of our country’s most pressing challenges. #YouthDaypic.twitter.com/aVeEuGZ0FF
President #Ramaphosa: I speak of 27-year-old Precious Malatji from Dennilton who runs a thriving accounting practice. #YouthDay
President #Ramaphosa: I speak of 34-year-old Faith Dowelani from Thohoyandou who runs a successful one stop beauty shop, Tshavhudi House of Beauty. #YouthDay

President #Ramaphosa: I speak of 22-year-old Mahlatse Matlakana from Senwabarwana who runs a fresh produce company that supplies large retailers in Limpopo and the Johannesburg Fresh Produce Market. #YouthDay

President #Ramaphosa: Amidst all this, I also encountered voices of hope. I met young men and women who share my optimism for this country’s future. Young people determined to succeed against the odds, and to go out into the world and carve a space for themselves. #YouthDaypic.twitter.com/kWYWToxXCj

President #Ramaphosa: Theirs are the stories of many young people around the country who have become increasingly frustrated. Their stories are a harsh reminder that the social and economic marginalisation of our youth is a stain on this country’s conscience. #YouthDay

President #Ramaphosa: They told me of their despondency at having to sit at home despite having a degree because they do not have work experience. They told me of having to stretch a grant or a pension to put food on the table. #YouthDay

President #Ramaphosa: They told me of the indignity of waking up each morning hoping that today will be the day they find work, or some opportunity to change their lives, only to be disappointed. #YouthDay

President #Ramaphosa: Over the last few months, I have travelled the country listening to the voices of our people, young and old, men and women. They shared with me their frustrations and their fears. #YouthDay

President #Ramaphosa: It is you, the youth of this country, who remind us that our liberation is not complete as long as millions of our people live in poverty, are jobless and remain on the margins of society. #YouthDay

President #Ramaohosa: It is you who are the voice of our national conscience as we build a South Africa free of racism, of sexism, of xenophobia and other forms of discrimination. #YouthDaypic.twitter.com/qX4hfT5Bmx
President #Ramaphosa: And it is you, the youth, who have taken up the struggles of a new generation – for economic opportunity, for access to land and for education. #YouthDay2019

President #Ramaphosa We pay tribute to all the progressive student movements – from NUSAS, SASO, AZASO, SANSCO and SASCO – for their contribution to the struggle for our liberation. Young people have been the vanguard of our democratic revolution. #YouthDay #YouthDay2019pic.twitter.com/MWM8iUXU2S

President #Ramaphosa: The police responded with teargas and live ammunition. Many students were wounded and many lost their lives. Today we salute you: Hector Peterson, Mbuyisa Makhubu, Tsietsi Mashinini and all the youth of 1976, whose sacrifices ensured we could be free today.pic.twitter.com/p8c71bm0kx

President #Ramaphosa: In their school uniforms, their fists in the air, and their faces bright with the fire of resistance, they confronted the heavily armed police singing: “Senzeni na? What have we done?” #YouthDay #YouthDay2019pic.twitter.com/nTW2cd6M1B

President #Ramaphosa: Today we remember the young men & women who were on the frontline of the school boycotts of June 16th 1976. 43 years ago, thousands of students around the country – from Soweto to KwaMashu, Gugulethu to Port Elizabeth, to Makhado – rose up against oppressionpic.twitter.com/Be2t0y0Mun

President #Ramaphosa: It is my honour to address this Youth Day celebration in a place named after one of our country’s greatest sons, Peter Ramoshoana Mokaba, the Lion of the North. #YouthDay2019pic.twitter.com/fNaSospraj

This year’s Youth Month coincides with the commemoration of 25 years of Freedom and Democracy and it takes place under the theme “25 Years of Democracy: A Celebration of Youth Activism”. #YouthDaypic.twitter.com/vLLb69pmlp
The month of June has been declared Youth Month and it is a period set aside to pay tribute to the youth of 1976 for their activism. #YouthDaypic.twitter.com/Dciv14nuy9

President @CyrilRamaphosa and Deputy President @DDMabuza have today received the report of the Presidential Advisory Panel on #LandReform and Agriculture. http://bit.ly/2X6Nfco #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/B2KowTEU32

President @CyrilRamaphosa has thanked DP @DDMabuza, the IMC and all advisory panel members for their hard work over an 8 month period which included hours of consultation with various sectors of society and also very deliberate and sometimes dissenting and difficult engagement.pic.twitter.com/ry1Yj3I1Z7

The Advisory Panel was chaired by Dr Vuyo Mahlathi and composed of the following members: Professor Ruth Hall, Professor Mohammed Karaan, Advocate Tembeka Ngcukaitobi, Ms Bulelwa Mabasa, Dr Thandi Ngcobo, Mr Wandile Sihlobo, Mr Daniel Kriek,Ms Thato Moagi & Mr Nick Serfonteinpic.twitter.com/kBdBI9uNJz

The panel was appointed in September 2018 to support the Inter Ministerial Committee (IMC) on Land Reform chaired by the Deputy President & advise the IMC on policy matters associated with land reform, including restitution, redistribution, tenure security & agricultural support.pic.twitter.com/08FMBCSQuL
President @CyrilRamaphosa and Deputy President @DavidMabuza receive Report of the Presidential Advisory Panel on Land Reform and Agriculture. #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/6dS94EPKwu

President @CyrilRamaphosa pens his message of support in the International Labour Organisation’s Golden Book on the occasion of the Centenary International Labour Conference at the United Nations Palais Des Nations in Geneva, Switzerland. #ILO100pic.twitter.com/AOAiZzK9PF

President #Ramaphosa: Let us seize all the opportunities brought about by the changes in the world of work to deliver greater economic security, equal opportunities and social justice. #ILO100pic.twitter.com/k5rxyoFcNw

President #Ramaphosa: We must renew our commitment to fundamental workers’ rights. Let us be reminded that before us, behind us, above us, beneath us and all around us, social justice remains a central aspiration for all the workers of the world yearning for a better future.pic.twitter.com/HiTSu2Wp37

President #Ramaphosa: The progress that has been made is the result of a deliberate and conscious recognition that decent employment is intricately linked to peace, prosperity and progress in the world. #ILO100
President #Ramaphosa: As we collectively strive to achieve the 2030 Sustainable Development Goals, particularly Goal 8 on decent work and economic growth, we look to the ILO for leadership. #ILO100
President #Ramaphosa: We must continue to reform the governance of the ILO so that it promotes inclusivity, fairness and equality. #ILO100

President #Ramaphosa: The prospect of looming trade wars & other disagreements seem to signal greater global tension & polarisation. If we are to remain a trusted & credible vehicle through which social justice will be achieved, organisational unity & cohesion will be paramount.pic.twitter.com/jTdwk3v89k

President #Ramaphosa: Although the ILO retains its unique character within the UN system as the only organisation that has governments, business and trade unions as equal partners, the global multilateral framework remains fragile. #ILO100pic.twitter.com/Kpncp4Si0P
President #Ramaphosa: For the ILO to continue with its valuable work, we need to reaffirm our commitment to multilateralism. #ILO100pic.twitter.com/fTKymLdDLk

President #Ramaphosa: That is why the Global Commission on the #FutureofWork has said that we need to invest in the capabilities of people, we need to invest in the institutions of the world of work, and we need to invest in decent, sustainable work. #ILO100

President #Ramaphosa: Yet we know that the changing world of work also presents new opportunities. If we are to harness these changes for our benefit, rather than be shaped by them, we need a new approach. #ILO100pic.twitter.com/hB319szjeh

President #Ramaphosa: Whether it is an underpaid worker in a factory, a taxi driver who’s been made redundant by the spread of online platforms, or a female football player of a national team demanding the same pay & benefits as her male counterpart, there is a common experience.pic.twitter.com/Wu05fIuKeU

President #Ramaphosa: The youth and women are at the bottom of most, if not all, socio-economic indicators. The change in work processes is leading to an increase in casualisation of labour. #ILO100pic.twitter.com/zLWF1yzYij
President #Ramaphosa: Unemployment and working poverty have trapped hundreds of millions of people across the globe. #ILO100pic.twitter.com/Jj60S14vCs

President #Ramaphosa: Both the workforce and the workplace are being rapidly transformed by the technological advances of the 4th Industrial Revolution, as the growth of artificial intelligence, automation and robotics threatens jobs. #ILO100 #FutureofWorkpic.twitter.com/fUpGwrymur

President #Ramaphosa: Comprising leading global figures from business, trade unions, think tanks, governments and NGOs, the Commission took the view that rapid and unprecedented change in the world of work required a human-centred response. #ILO100 #FutureofWorkpic.twitter.com/jwpMvKN6X6
President #Ramaphosa: It also provides guidance on how best to embrace the opportunities that this change presents. #ILO100 #FutureofWorkpic.twitter.com/8t2Iq6KIpk

President #Ramaphosa: The work undertaken, the insights shared and the recommendations put forward will be of immense benefit for many countries and for my own country, South Africa, as we grapple with the challenges of change. #ILO100pic.twitter.com/og03NoU4JA

President #Ramaphosa: It has been my singular privilege to co-chair the Global Commission with PM Stefan Löfven. This is an inspired initiative that places the #ILO at the centre of global efforts to shape the world of work in a tomorrow that is constantly changing and uncertain.pic.twitter.com/vVEsJrcC5Y

President #Ramaphosa: In addressing this question – which poses both a challenge and an opportunity – the ILO has been a standard-bearer. It is in fulfilment of its founding purpose that the ILO established the Global Commission on the #FutureofWork. #ILO100pic.twitter.com/1sgEq4kZqD
President #Ramaphosa: Now, the world must confront the question of how to enhance the rights of workers in the face of rapid industrialisation, climate and technological change. #ILO100
President #Ramaphosa: It was a vastly different world back then, emerging from the ravages of war, but the challenges it faced are similar to those we face today. #ILO100

President #Ramaphosa: They sought to lay the foundations for a new world of social justice, where governments, employers and workers would strive together in pursuit of a common goal. #ILO100pic.twitter.com/JSUVg6ipQM
President #Ramaphosa: It is for workers like these, for the protection and promotion of their rights, that the ILO was formed one hundred years ago by a group of visionary men and women. #ILO100
President #Ramaphosa: This settlement, and the class action that preceded it, is unique in our history and covers compensation for workers as far back as 1965. #ILO100
President #Ramaphosa: Mineworkers around the world work under extremely dangerous and difficult conditions, and are often exploited and denied adequate benefits. #ILO100
President #Ramaphosa: It is a victory for social justice and brings redress for one of the most vulnerable workers in not just our country but around the developing world. #ILO100
President #Ramaphosa: This case has dramatic and far-reaching implications for the way workers health and safety are treated in our country. #ILO100

President #Ramaphosa: They asked the court to approve a multi-million dollar settlement for mineworkers who had contracted illnesses like silicosis and tuberculosis while working on the mines. #ILO100

President #Ramaphosa: Earlier this month the principle of social justice which was one of the founding principles of the ILO was so well played out in our South African courts when lawyers representing mineworkers and five mining houses appeared side by side.
President #Ramaphosa: Throughout our struggle for democracy, justice and workers’ rights, the ILO has been a constant source of support, encouragement and guidance. #ILO100

President #Ramaphosa: This is an occasion to reflect on the profound impact that the ILO has had on the world of work and the lives of workers over the last 100 years. For South Africans, the ILO has played a particularly important role in giving form to the country we are today.pic.twitter.com/koWRc1A5Er

Address by President Cyril Ramaphosa on the occasion of the Presidential Inauguration https://bit.ly/2JZHwyg
President #Ramaphosa: A brighter day is rising upon South Africa and upon our beloved continent, Africa. Nkosi Sikelel’ Afrika.pic.twitter.com/2LKMo30vmV

President #Ramaphosa: And I pledge here today that I will serve you, I will work with you, side by side, to build the South Africa that we all want and deserve. A new era has dawned in our country. #PeoplesInauguration pic.twitter.com/5RAFWiTCiO
President #Ramaphosa: You, the people of South Africa, have sent them, and you have sent me, as your President. Having taken the oath of office I am saying yes, South Africa #ThumaMina.
President #Ramaphosa: You have chosen them to safeguard your rights, to improve your lives and to build a country that is united, strong and truly free. #PeoplesInauguration

President #Ramaphosa: These 490 men and women whom you have sent to Parliament seem to have heard the same call that the Lord made to Isaiah when He said: “Whom shall I send, and who will go for us?” They have now said, send us. They have said #ThumaThina. #PeoplesInaugurationpic.twitter.com/HTwZUHFbKs
President #Ramaphosa: With your votes you have placed your confidence and your trust in the men and women who now sit in our sixth democratic Parliament. #6thParliament #PeoplesInauguration

President #Ramaphosa: It is to this brighter day that we now turn our eyes, to a vista rich with the hues of hope and promise. It is you, the people of South Africa, who have spoken. #PeoplesInauguration pic.twitter.com/JQOJbLvV79

President #Ramaphosa: We are not unaware of the debilitating legacy of our past, nor the many difficulties of the present. To achieve the South Africa we want will demand an extraordinary feat of human endeavour.

President #Ramaphosa: Every school child will be able to read, and every person who wants to work will have a reasonable opportunity to find employment. As we make this bold declaration, we are not unaware of the depth of the challenges we must confront. #PeoplesInauguration pic.twitter.com/Kr2K43YLCq

President #Ramaphosa: Let us declare that when we gather to celebrate the 50th year of our freedom there shall no longer be any person in this land who is unable to meet their basic needs. That there should be no child who goes hungry. #PeoplesInauguration

President #Ramaphosa: Today, let us declare before the esteemed witnesses gathered here that such a South Africa is possible. Let us declare our shared determination that we shall end poverty in South Africa within a generation. #PeoplesInauguration

President #Ramaphosa: It is our shared will – and our shared responsibility – to build a society that knows neither privilege nor disadvantage. It is a society where those who have much are willing to share with those who have little.

President #Ramaphosa: Our Constitution – the basic law of our land – continues to guide our way even at the darkest hour. As a nation we can no longer abide the grave disparities of wealth and opportunity that have defined our past and which threaten to imperil our future.

President #Ramaphosa: They yearn for a society in which our worth is determined by how we value others. It is a society guided by the fundamental human principle that says: Umuntu ngumuntu ngabantu. Motho ke motho ka batho. #PeoplesInauguration pic.twitter.com/L5GtReek2U

President #Ramaphosa: It is through our actions now that we will give form to the society for which so many have fought and sacrificed and for which all of us yearn. All South Africans yearn for a society defined by equality, by solidarity, by a shared humanity.

President #Ramaphosa: This is a defining moment for our young nation. Today is the choice of history. It is through our actions now that we will determine our destiny. South Africans want action and not just words. #PeoplesInauguration
President #Ramaphosa: The challenges that we face are real. But they are not insurmountable. They can be solved. And we are going to solve them.pic.twitter.com/0ZdMCWgA9K

President #Ramaphosa: In recent times, our people have watched as some of those in whom they had invested their trust have surrendered to the temptation of power and riches. They have seen some of the very institutions of our democracy eroded and resources squandered.

President #Ramaphosa: Despite our most earnest efforts, many South Africans still go to bed hungry, many succumb to diseases that can be treated, many live lives of intolerable deprivation. Too many of our people do not work especially the youth. #PeoplesInauguration
President #Ramaphosa: They have felt the cold shadow of a past so cruel and iniquitous that it has at times threatened to eclipse the very achievement of their hard-won freedom. #PeoplesInauguration

President #Ramaphosa: As the shackles of oppression have fallen away, they have felt their horizons widen and their lives improve in a myriad ways. But they have also known moments of doubt. #PeoplesInauguration

President #Ramaphosa: Our people have felt the warm embrace of liberty. They have rejoiced at the affirmation of their essential and equal humanity. They have found shelter and sustenance. They have found opportunity and purpose. #PeoplesInaugurationpic.twitter.com/lwY7hkE4VO

President #Ramaphosa: Twenty-five years have passed since that glorious morning on which Nelson Rolihahla Mandela was sworn in as the first President of a democratic South Africa. In the passage of that time, our land has known both seasons of plenty and times of scarcity.pic.twitter.com/HWMSjQKLYk
President #Ramaphosa: Today, we declare that our progress as South Africa depends on – and cannot be separated from – the onward march of our beloved continent Africa. #PeoplesInauguration

President #Ramaphosa: To forge a free trade area that stretches from Cape Town to Cairo, bringing growth and opportunity all African countries. To silence the guns and let peace and harmony reign. #PeoplesInauguration

President #Ramaphosa: Today, we reaffirm our determination to work with our sisters and brothers across the continent to realise the African Union’s vision of #Agenda2063. To build the Africa that we all Africans want. #PeoplesInauguration pic.twitter.com/9IWbuoZKyu

President #Ramaphosa: We also recognise those countries from other continents who have joined us today. We remain eternally grateful to all nations represented here for the sacrifices and tireless contributions by your people and governments to the liberation of our land.pic.twitter.com/NelRAaDjNt

President #Ramaphosa: We are profoundly grateful to you for choosing to celebrate #AfricaDay among us, giving further poignancy to South Africa’s transformation from a pariah state to a full and valued member of the family of African nations. #PeoplesInauguration
President #Ramaphosa: As South Africa, we are honoured and deeply humbled by the presence here of leaders from across the African continent. #PeoplesInauguration

President #Ramaphosa: It is a day on which we reaffirm our common commitment to an Africa that is at peace, that is prosperous and that promises a better existence for its people. #PeoplesInauguration
President #Ramaphosa: We gather here on the day that the people of our continent celebrate the unity of Africa. It is a day of friendship, solidarity and cooperation. #PeoplesInauguration

President #Ramaphosa: I am humbled by the trust you have bestowed upon me, aware of the challenges our country faces, but also alive to the fact that our people are filled with hope for a better tomorrow. #PeoplesInauguration
President #Ramaphosa: I stand before you having just taken the oath to be President of our beautiful country South Africa. #PeoplesInauguration
