President #Ramaphosa: As for me, I will work day and night, to the best of my ability, to deliver on our mandate and in the best interests of our people. I am truly humbled with the honour to be President of the people of the Republic of South Africa.pic.twitter.com/dHtkBHN7fw

President #Ramaphosa: Lastly, allow me to congratulate the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker on their election, and all those representatives of the people who have taken up their seats today. #6thParliamentpic.twitter.com/5WP0pZOFRf

President #Ramaphosa: I thank the leaders who have congratulated me. Our people want hope, but they must see that this is a government that will work for them. We will work together to build the South Africa of our dreams. We must address our past to plot our way to a new future.pic.twitter.com/cKbyhZvGoC

President #Ramaphosa: I wish to thank the leaders of all political parties for the manner in which the election was conducted and look forward to a constructive relationship. #6thParliamentpic.twitter.com/XOl8jairWH

President #Ramaphosa: Madiba is smiling down on all of us. He worked so hard to put this Parliament together and I know he is pleased with this #6thParliament. I know that O.R. Tambo is smiling. Mama Albertina Sisulu is smiling. Mama Winnie Madikizela Mandela is smiling.pic.twitter.com/TAKlBmiB4d
President #Ramaphosa: I wish to express my gratitude to the Chief Justice for presiding over the establishment of this new Parliament. #6thParliamentpic.twitter.com/9e4mjzbcNe

President #Ramaphosa: Please be assured of our commitment to work with Parliament and all the parties represented here to create the conditions for meaningful social and economic transformation. #6thParliament

President #Ramaphosa: As we enter the 6th democratic administration, please be assured of my personal commitment and the commitment of the incoming Executive to fulfil these obligations. #6thParliamentpic.twitter.com/YvBG9o603F

President #Ramaphosa: Certainly, they expect a robust exchange of views, they understand that we may often differ, but they expect that we will always honour their wishes and remain true to our mandate. Their house must never degenerate into chaos and disorder #6thParliamentpic.twitter.com/D6F3AThs8E
President #Ramaphosa: The people of this country expect us to work together, to collaborate, to seek consensus and to effect change. #6thParliamentpic.twitter.com/KE4Dy4YaXt

President #Ramaphosa: We have a mandate to build a nation founded on the principles of social justice, solidarity and equality; a nation at peace with itself and the world. We have been given a responsibility to revive our economy, to rebuild our institutions and to restore hope.pic.twitter.com/lRUOUuAwaj

President #Ramaphosa: Together, despite our different party affiliations, we carry a common mandate – to build a new nation in which all may be free, secure and equal. Free from poverty, hunger and unemployment. #6thParliament

President #Ramaphosa: Our people have spoken clearly and they have spoken quite emphatically. In its composition, this House is a reflection of the will of the people. Together, we are their representatives and we must regard ourselves as their champions. #6thParliamentpic.twitter.com/CEWRJPIVqp

President #Ramaphosa: They did so in peace, with pride and with dignity. I applaud all South Africans who took part in the voting process. After a hotly contested and often discordant election campaign, the people of South Africa have had their say. #6thParliament

President #Ramaphosa: It is a responsibility that I undertake mindful of the needs, aspirations and expectations of the people of this land. It has been two weeks since the people of South Africa went to the polls to elect the Honourable Members now gathered in this House.

President #Ramaphosa: I am truly honoured and humbled to have been elected to serve as President of the Republic of South Africa. It is a responsibility that I will discharge with the greatest of care and to the best of my ability. #6thParliamentpic.twitter.com/XzfxnOIrKY

President #Ramaphosa: Lastly, I wish to thank the religious leaders of all faiths who prayed for a peaceful election. I salute each & every one of you and I thank you for making it possible for this election to be a resounding expression of the will of the people of South Africa.pic.twitter.com/vvbjBSesNB

President #Ramaphosa: I must also thank the media, which continues to play a vital role in our democracy and which was so important in ensuring that the South African people were well informed as they went to vote. #SAElections2019
President #Ramaphosa: I wish to thank all the observer teams, both local and international, who gave their time and effort to ensure a free and fair election. #SAElections2019

President #Ramaphosa: I also wish to extend my gratitude to the leaders and members of the various political parties that participated in the elections. In both your conduct and your words, you contributed to the peace and calm which characterised the entire election season.pic.twitter.com/oEYTnTmE4d

President #Ramaphosa: We pay tribute to the men and women of the @SAPoliceService and the #SANDF for ensuring peace and stability during voting & to Home Affairs staff who ensured that as many voters as possible had their identity documents on election day. #SAElections2019
Remarks by President Cyril Ramaphosa at the IEC election results announcement, Results Operation Centre, Tshwane https://bit.ly/2VZdh0W

President #Ramaphosa: We thank the staff and leadership of @IECSouthAfrica, who worked tirelessly to ensure the success of these elections. Often under difficult conditions, you conducted yourselves professionally, impartially and with the dedication we have come to expect.pic.twitter.com/lawvQDoqXo

President #Ramaphosa: They have voted for a united South Africa in which all may realise their potential. They have voted for a more equal society, free from poverty, hunger and want. They have voted for a country at peace with itself and the world. #SAElections2019

President #Ramaphosa: I was encouraged to observe the hive of activity on social networks where young people were encouraging each other to go and vote. Our people have spoken – and they have done so clearly and emphatically. #SAElections2019

President #Ramaphosa: We applaud the young people – especially the first time voters – who participated in the elections and took responsibility for their future and that of our country. #SAElections2019pic.twitter.com/K9ldRSDwjn

President #Ramaphosa: We send our sincere condolences to the families and friends of Ms Susan Matona from Vanderbijlpark and Mr Dirk Osche from Elandspoort. We must honour their memories by deepening our democratic culture and defending, with all we have, the right to vote.

President #Ramaphosa: We salute the elderly for coming out in their large numbers to vote as they have done in every election since 1994. We were deeply saddened by the passing away of two of our elderly compatriots at voting stations on Wednesday. #SAElections2019

President #Ramaphosa: Many of our people braved the rain and cold to cast the ballots that will determine the future of our country. In doing so, they reaffirmed the vibrancy of our democracy in an environment of diverse opinions. #SAElections2019pic.twitter.com/uqrSvqDDz0

President #Ramaphosa: We pay tribute to the millions who went to the polls to choose the public representatives who will champion their collective interests and help them realise their shared dreams and common aspirations. #SAElections2019

President #Ramaphosa: This election confirms that freedom does indeed reign in South Africa. It gives us the assurance that our people are the true custodians of our freedom and democracy. #SAElections2019

President #Ramaphosa: we now have a greater appreciation of what President Nelson Mandela meant during his inauguration on 10 May 1994 when he said: “Let freedom reign. The sun shall never set on so glorious a human achievement.” #SAElections2019pic.twitter.com/tYi3ZLVFU6

President #Ramaphosa: Today – 25 years later – we are here at the invitation of the Independent Electoral Commission to witness the announcement of the official results of the sixth democratic general election. #SAElections2019

President #Ramaphosa: That first vote was a tribute to the heroic struggles waged by successive generations of gallant men and women, to the hardships they endured and to the sacrifices they were prepared to make for our freedom. #SAElections2019pic.twitter.com/5hox4vtXYQ

President #Ramaphosa: Their actions represented the fulfilment of a solemn pledge made decades before in the Freedom Charter, which said that: “No government can justly claim authority unless it is based on the will of all the people.”pic.twitter.com/EXdea0NwVe

President #Ramaphosa: Twenty five ago, millions of our people exercised their democratic right to vote for the very first time – and in doing so set our country firmly on a path of freedom and progress. #SAElections2019

President @CyrilRamaphosa and @AfricanUnion’s Head of Observer Mission, Former President of the United Republic of Tanzania, His Excellency Mr Jakaya Kikwete and guests observe a moment of silence at the Official Announcement of the 2019 National and Provincial Elections Results.pic.twitter.com/CDfwh17d5S

President Ramaphosa launched YES in 2018 as an initiative to place the needs of and opportunities for young people at the centre of inclusive economic growth. #SayYES to #AFutureThatWorks #http://yes4youth.co.za (2/3)pic.twitter.com/LLcgZE4IAw

President Ramaphosa receives update on the Youth Employment Service (YES). YES is a business-led collaboration with government and labour to create work opportunities for youth. #SayYES to #AFutureThatWorks #http://yes4youth.co.za (1/3)pic.twitter.com/EuVUh6FEAo
WATCH LIVE: President @CyrilRamaphosa receives update in the Youth Employment Service #Yes4Youthhttps://twitter.com/CyrilRamaphosa/status/1123860511387521024 …

Register as a #YES Youth by logging onto http://www.yes4youth.co.za/youth-registration … where you can register as a #YES Youth. Registration is open to candidates between the ages of 18 and 34, who are currently unemployed and black (as per the B-BBEE codes definition). #Yes4Youth #UzoytholaKanjanipic.twitter.com/FeySnXO1KQ

#Yes4Youth Community Hubs bring investment and technology into the heart of communities. Hubs build local capabilities and opportunity, where young people are. Nearly 100 more hubs will be rolled out to communities throughout South Africa. #Yes4YouthZApic.twitter.com/Avo92PQeId

Corporates who meet their #YES target can place the youth in their own business or at a host SMME through a sponsored host placement, at no cost to the host. The young person will work in the host business for 12 months and will be paid by the sponsor company. #Yes4Youthpic.twitter.com/wYm1xYAUtk

Through the #YES initiative, 1 million young South Africans will be offered paid work experience over the next 3 years. These young people will be exposed to the working environment which will increase their chances of finding employment. #Yes4Youthpic.twitter.com/rKLmPQVfIg

The Youth Employment Service (YES) is a partnership between business, government, labour and civil society aimed at addressing youth unemployment. It prioritises and targets young women, unemployed youth, out of school youth and youth in rural areas. #Yes4Youthpic.twitter.com/6RgJ8oKODn

President @CyrilRamaphosa launched #YES in 2018, placing the needs of and opportunities for young people at the centre of inclusive economic growth. #YES is aimed at all unemployed black youth between the ages of 18-34 years, regardless of the level of education. #Yes4Youthpic.twitter.com/VURfdjgLK6

President @CyrilRamaphosa will today receive an update on the Youth Employment Service (YES) - a business-led collaboration with government and labour to create work opportunities for youth. #Yes4Youthpic.twitter.com/ne7m7eSiGa

The Order of the #Baobab in SILVER is bestowed on: CONSTANCE MIRRIAM THOKOZILE KOZA (Posthumous): For her excellent contribution and commitment to education and community development. Her selfless giving to society enriched and empowered many lives. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/CQpmt22fT9

The Order of #Luthuli in SILVER is bestowed on: YOSUF VERIAVA: For his brilliant contribution to the medical profession. He has personified medical ethics and progressiveness. He also courageously pushed back the frontiers of the unjust laws of apartheid. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/bkuwWXkKTy

The Order of the Companions of OR Tambo in GOLD is bestowed on: His Excellency Admiral Didier Ignace Ratsiraka (Madagascar): He offered the liberation movement a platform to operate #RadioFreedom in the battle of ideas between apartheid propaganda & non-racial democratic values.pic.twitter.com/p87773Uw2o

The Order of the Companions of OR Tambo in SILVER is bestowed on: LUCIA RAADSCHELDERS (The Netherlands): Over many years, she was a reliable friend of our country and, post-liberation, played a critical role in supporting our democracy & archiving our history. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/XsddBekc7f

The Order of the Companions of OR Tambo in SILVER is bestowed on: AMII OMARA-OTUNNU (Uganda): For his excellent contribution to the global fight for democracy and social justice. He has beeen a reliable tried and tested friend of South Africa. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/DNWI18wpGT

The Order of the Companions of OR Tambo in SILVER is bestowed on: PAULETTE PIERSON-MATHY (Belgium): She has been a prolific author of original reports & publications providing deep insights into realities of apartheid and the struggle for liberation in Africa. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/pETRuLDxbI

The Order of the Companions of OR Tambo in SILVER is bestowed on: KHOTSO MAKHULU (United Kingdom): For his courageous contribution to the fight for liberation. He provided refuge, comfort & family to young activists arriving in exile to join the South African liberation strugglepic.twitter.com/HUlppHt8Q3

The Order of the Companions of OR Tambo in SILVER is bestowed on: KLAAS DE JONGE (The Netherlands): For his contribution to the fight for the liberation of South Africa. With little regard for his own life, he was part of the armed resistance to apartheid. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/lA05X0R7pm

The Order of the Companions of OR Tambo in BRONZE is bestowed on: Riccardo Sarra (Italy): For his consistent contribution to the fight for the liberation of the people of South Africa and the Southern African region. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/cOvXieQilh

The Order of the Companions of OR Tambo recognises eminent foreign nationals and other foreign dignitaries for friendship shown to South Africa. It is therefore an order of peace, co-operation and active expression of solidarity and support. #ORTambo #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/2gfTXkJEv5

The Order of #Mapungubwe is bestowed in GOLD on: BOMO EDNA MOLEWA: For her exceptional contribution to the fight to save our planet. Through her tireless efforts, South Africa is recognized as one of the global leaders in matters of environment of justice. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/YvZ2zpoQ53

The Order of #Mapungubwe in SILVER is bestowed on: ARI SITAS: For his excellent contribution to social science scholarship and progressive policy-making. He is a talented social scientist who moves effortlessly between profound knowledge production & the arts. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/sJm5ccw471

The Order of #Mapungubwe in SILVER is bestowed on: MALIK MAAZA: For his outstanding contribution to the field of nanoscience and nanotechnology. A pioneer, his work has improved our knowledge and made headway in the development of cutting edge modern technology #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/3Q5b3YACFx

The Order of #Mapungubwe in BRONZE is bestowed on: THOKOZANI MAJOZI: For his outstanding contribution to science, particularly the development of a novel mathematical technique for near-zero-effluent batch chemical facilities which enables re-use of wastewater. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/dyYmxcUHIx
The Order of Mapungubwe recognises South Africans who have accomplished excellence and exceptional achievement to the benefit of South Africa and beyond. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/FF3vGuzKD9

The Order of #Luthuli is bestowed in SILVER on: ANTONY ANDREW TREW: For his contribution to the attainment of democracy and reconstruction of a post-apartheid society. His meticulous application of language is imprinted in dossiers of government where he served. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/iEHxlnoedI

The Order of #Luthuli is bestowed in SILVER on: MOYISILE TYUTYU: For his shining contribution to the fight for the freedom of all South Africans. As an operative of Umkhonto we Sizwe, he proved to be a man of courage, living by his conviction that all are equal. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/SBfThnHNQI

The Order of #Luthuli is bestowed in SILVER on: VELAPHI MSANE: For his excellent contribution to the liberation struggle and his steadfast conviction in the equality of all. His courage allowed him to put his people first, with scant regard for his own safety. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/ipuRVh0AFy

The Order of #Luthuli in SILVER is bestowed on: THANDI LUJABE-RANKOE: For her excellent contribution to fight for South Africa’s liberation. She raised awareness on repression & mobilised support for those who were facing the apartheid security forces inside SA. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/jDaemtdZPg

The Order of #Luthuli recognises South African citizens who have contributed to the struggle for democracy, nation-building, building democracy and human rights, justice and peace as well as for the resolution of conflict. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/x1vJmH69z1

The Order of the #Baobab is bestowed in SILVER on: WILLIAM SMITH: For his superb contribution to the teaching and demystification of mathematics and science. Through TV, he made mathematics and science accessible even to the most marginalised in our society. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/I4lHqpBI9b

The Order of the #Baobab is bestowed in SILVER on: RAY & DORA PHILLIPS: For their contribution to the first social work network designed to improve the living conditions of the oppressed being brought to the Rand to work in the mines. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/oNEphUKpU9

The Order of the #Baobab is bestowed in SILVER on: BONGANI MKHWANAZI (Posthumous): For his excellent contribution to the upliftment of black business. He was a doyen and one of the foremost champions of economic transformation in post-apartheid South Africa. #NationalOrders

The Order of the #Baobab in SILVER is bestowed on: BRAAM JORDAAN: For his brilliant efforts at raising awareness on the importance of sign language and the human rights of deaf people around the world through his colourful spectrum of films and books. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/8Eths4XjrD

The Order of the #Baobab recognises South African citizens who have contributed to community service, business and economy, science, medicine and technological innovation. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/V2oZ1QgI5q

The Order of #Ikhamanga is bestowed in SILVER on: MARY MHLONGO TWALA: For her excellent contribution to the performing arts & raising awareness on women’s health issues through storytelling. Her sense of humour & humility have endeared her to the nation at large. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/ab7MHL5kD4

The Order of #Ikhamanga is bestowed in SILVER on: JACQUES KALLIS: For his contribution to the sport of cricket and for placing South Africa on the world sporting map. His stellar career & commitment to the sport inspired many young people to aim for excellence. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/aL1KEKh3HY

The Order of #Ikhamanga is bestowed in SILVER on: MATHATHA TSEDU: For his excellent contribution to South African journalism and to journalism on the African continent, as well as his selfless contribution to the liberation of our country and continent. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/RQIaaxispQ

The Order of #Ikhamanga will be bestowed in GOLD on: JOHAAR MOSAVAL: For his exceptional contribution to the performing arts through ballet dancing. His talent led him to be the first black South African to become a senior principal dancer at the Royal Ballet. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/nTYKcjglQR
Address by President Cyril Ramaphosa on the occasion of the bestowal of the 2019 #NationalOrders, Sefako Makgatho Guest House, Tshwane. https://bit.ly/2DwzPvy

The Order of #Ikhamanga is bestowed in SILVER on: BENJAMIN POGRUND: For his excellent contribution to journalism and to scholarship on the liberation struggle. His informative writing shone the light on our country during some of the darkest days in our history. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/K4dtB5g7Yt

The Order of #Ikhamanga is bestowed in SILVER on: NOMHLE NKONYENI: For her brilliant contribution to the performing arts. She has graced national and international stages and her mastery of her craft has moved many audiences locally and around the world. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/Y6FoLu0Xtu

The Order of Ikhamanga is bestowed in SILVER on: YVONNE CHAKA CHAKA MHINGA: For her excellent contribution to the field of music & her contribution to social cohesion. Her melodic voice reverberated and found resonance across our continent and around the world. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/Cda1JPuAdM

The Order of #Ikhamanga in SILVER is bestowed on: ACHMAT DAVIDS: For his excellent contribution to literature and the preservation of history through storytelling. His work enriched our understanding of the Cape Muslims’ contribution to the development of the Afrikaans language.pic.twitter.com/12flircsHx
The Order of #Ikhamanga recognises South African citizens who have excelled in the fields of arts, culture, literature, music, journalism and sport. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/JSp6BHM2QD

The Mendi of Decoration Bravery in SILVER is bestowed on: THAPELO TAMBANI: For his selfless act of saving a life, which led to his unfortunate demise. His courageous act remains his legacy to all who knew him & got to know of him after his courageous sacrifice. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/gRuw1Q0Tob
The Order of #Mendi for Bravery recognises South African citizens who have performed acts of bravery. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/yCDEMqxjae

In his capacity as Grand Patron, HE President @CyrilRamaphosa bestows on recipients the Order of Mendi for Bravery, the Order of Ikhamanga, the Order of the Baobab, the Order of Luthuli, the Order of Mapungubwe, and the Order of the Companions of OR Tambo. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/dMNvsCzTqA

President #Ramaphosa: Under the powers vested in me by the Constitution of the Republic of South Africa, I now confer the Order of Mendi, the Order of Ikhamanga, the Order of the Baobab, the Order of Luthuli, the Order of Mapungubwe and the Order of the Companions of O R Tambo.pic.twitter.com/Yuq0FJH085

President #Ramaphosa: You have exerted yourselves to the best of your respective abilities, and excelled. You give us further cause to believe that South Africa’s future is bright. You have done your duty. You have made your country proud. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/jG3hTKkHXD

President #Ramaphosa: You have shown that as South Africans we can render service to the Republic in many different ways. I wish to congratulate you, as well as the families of those who are being recognised posthumously.pic.twitter.com/TKsMAJbToi

President #Ramaphosa: Today your country has honoured you, but it is an honour that should inspire you to set even greater goals, driven by a commitment to lifelong learning and to a constant betterment of the self. #NationalOrders

President #Ramaphosa: A citizen enters fully into the social contract, binding themselves into a collective for the greater good. A citizen is an agent for change. We have among us today the very best of such citizens. #NationalOrderspic.twitter.com/jCW1yMfpZV

President #Ramaphosa: A citizen, by contrast, assumes the duties of membership of society. A citizen embraces the concept of civic virtue – of dedication to the common welfare of their community and their country. #NationalOrders

President #Ramaphosa: A member of society merely exists. A member of society, though they enjoy the rights afforded by our Constitution, does not take an active part in the political, social and cultural life of the nation. #NationalOrders

President #Ramaphosa: Recipients of the #NationalOrders, In your commitment to the betterment of yourselves and your communities, you have shown that indeed a fundamental difference exists between being a member of society and being a citizen.
President #Ramaphosa: We are also joined by the families of those who have unfortunately passed away, to receive on their behalf the recognition they so richly deserve. #NationalOrders

President #Ramaphosa: We have among us here today South Africans who have excelled in a number of fields, who have made an invaluable contribution to enriching public life: whether it is in the academic, social, cultural, technological, music, artistic, political & other spheres.pic.twitter.com/Hr0eZjgxug

President #Ramaphosa: It was out of the need to give practical effect to the values of our Constitution – the achievement of equality, the advancement of human rights and freedom, non-racialism, non-sexism and human dignity – that the national honours were reconfigured in 2002.

President #Ramaphosa: Although they are conferred by the President, the recipients are nominated by members of the public. These Orders celebrate individuals who have excelled; whose actions and works represent the triumph of the human spirit. #NationalOrders
President #Ramaphosa: The National Orders are the highest honour that this country can bestow on its citizens and eminent foreign nationals. #NationalOrders

President #Ramaphosa: Together, the distinguished recipients of the National Orders represent the values, the ideals and the aspirations of the millions of South Africans who stood in line to vote for freedom on the 27th of April 1994. #NationalOrders
President #Ramaphosa: It is fitting that we recognise also the contribution of eminent foreign nationals who contributed to the achievement and advancement of our freedom. #NationalOrders

President #Ramaphosa: It is fitting that we hold this #NationalOrders ceremony – to bestow our country’s highest honours on those who have so faithfully discharged their duty to their communities, their fellow citizens & to their country – on the eve of such a momentous occasion.
President #Ramaphosa: We gather here as South Africa prepares to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the achievement of freedom and democracy. #NationalOrders

#NationalOrders are the highest awards that our country, through the President, bestows on our citizens and eminent foreign nationals who have contributed towards the advancement of democracy and who made a significant impact on improving the lives of South Africans.pic.twitter.com/uxYiBmxLsm

Address by President Cyril Ramaphosa at the official handover of Enhlanhleni, Lembe and Ingweni Phaphama Primary Schools. #QualityEducationForAll http://www.thepresidency.gov.za/speeches/address-president-cyril-ramaphosa-official-handover-enhlanhleni%2C-lembe-and-ingweni-phaphama …

President #Ramaphosa: Working together as government, teachers, parents, unions and the community at large, let us make this official handover of three primary schools be the beginning of an exciting and meaningful journey of learning for all our children. #QualityEducationForAllpic.twitter.com/n3c6tTkW0H

President #Ramaphosa: They must produce citizens that are conscious of and committed to the ideal of a truly united nation defined by non-racialism, non-sexism, democracy and shared prosperity. #ASIDI #QualityEducationForAllpic.twitter.com/pHVvgtyxeV

President #Ramaphosa: These schools must be defined by an embedded culture of teaching and learning. They must nurture a cohort of children who are ever ready for higher forms of learning. #ASIDI #QualityEducationForAllpic.twitter.com/ZI4qnYAOBW

President #Ramaphosa: To the people of KwaZulu-Natal, we are handing over to you these primary schools so that you can use them to nurture the talents of our children and equip them with the knowledge and skills for a changing world. #ASIDI #QualityEducationForAllpic.twitter.com/tJxwTATV5j

President #Ramaphosa: I call on learners – our greatest & most valuable asset – to be ambitious, have a dream, be disciplined, come to school on time, listen to the instructions of your teachers, do your homework, participate in sports, and study hard and progress. #ASIDIpic.twitter.com/NGtYx7a8tS

President #Ramaphosa: The investment that made in education since the advent of democracy has resulted in a steady improvement in educational outcomes. Higher education enrolment has increased from 150,000 in ‘94 to around a million students enrolled for university studies today.pic.twitter.com/JBXg8BH2pO

President #Ramaphosa: In addition to demolishing the mud structures and constructing new facilities for all three schools, @AdoptASchoolSA has also been running advocacy and strategic planning workshops. #ASIDI #QualityEducationForAllpic.twitter.com/i4FzRUMxNR

President #Ramaphosa: Having been involved with @AdoptASchoolSA over the last 17 years, I have seen how this holistic model has been developed, tested and reviewed – and has produced impressive results in over 500 schools. #ASIDI #QualityEducationForAllpic.twitter.com/gDWNp8tEy1

President #Ramaphosa: Over the last two decades, we have added around 39,000 additional classrooms and over 1,200 new schools. We know that appropriate infrastructure is necessary for an effective schooling environment, but that it is not buildings that define a school. #ASIDIpic.twitter.com/7bHMQNo9qj

President #Ramaphosa: Today, around 17 percent of the consolidated government budget – more than R230 billion – is spent on basic education alone. We have made significant progress in making education accessible to the poor. #ASIDI #QualityEducationForAllpic.twitter.com/Ef8oB4d33u

President #Ramaphosa: For hundreds of learners, for their families, for their communities, this is a moment of renewal and of hope. For this province and for the country more broadly, this is a celebration of the potential of partnership in meeting our development needs. #ASIDIpic.twitter.com/FkghLQ4EEV

[WATCH LIVE]: President @CyrilRamaphosa delivers the keynote address at the official handover ceremony of the three primary schools currently underway in KwaZulu-Natal. #ASIDI #QualityEducationForAllhttps://twitter.com/CyrilRamaphosa/status/1118472174229004288 …

President @CyrilRamaphosa on a guided tour of the new Enhlanhleni primary school in Dannhauser in the KwaZulu-Natal. To date, #ASIDI has completed the construction of 216 schools across the country. #QualityEducationForAllpic.twitter.com/CnwJXyh8jj

President @CyrilRamaphosa arrives in Dannhauser, KwaZulu-Natal, for the official handover ceremony of three primary schools:- Lembe, Ingweni Phaphama & Enhlanhleni where the ceremony takes place. #ASIDI #QualityEducationForAllpic.twitter.com/L6oMk3CPaG

Mud structures have been replaced with modern brick and mortar structures with additional design elements that allow for a positive learning environment. The designs comply with current & future school requirements and complement the environment in which they are situated. #ASIDIpic.twitter.com/fG7NxWdVwi

The partnership is in response to the President @CyrilRamaphosa’s call for collaboration between government and civil society to realise the right of children to safety and dignity in educational facilities. #ASIDI #QualityEducationForAllpic.twitter.com/217BmLIRfb

In partnership with the @AdoptaSchoolSA, the schools were built under @DBE_SA ’s Accelerated School Infrastructure Delivery Initiative with the objective of eradicating schools without water, sanitation & electricity and replace schools constructed from inappropriate material.pic.twitter.com/FYQskPQniu

President Cyril Ramaphosa has welcomed the establishment by interfaith religious leaders of a values-based initiative to engender social cohesion, nation-building and societal renewal. https://bit.ly/2I9uu11
President @CyrilRamaphosa signs the Statement of Intent for Societal Renewal, towards achieving a South Africa, we want to live in. #SocietalRenewalpic.twitter.com/M64Gpu1E4n
Opening Remarks by President Cyril Ramaphosa at the meeting with Interfaith Leaders, CSIR Convention Centre, Tshwane https://bit.ly/2KnU1FD

Interfaith religious leaders engage President @CyrilRamaphosa on the Presidential Declaration. The meeting is held under theme "The South Africa we want to build: a framework to harnessing the potential of faith leaderstowards social cohesion, nation building & #SocietalRenewal.pic.twitter.com/vWypVssm5p

[PICTURES]: President @CyrilRamaphosa delivers his remarks at an engagement with the interfaith religious leaders. The engagement seeks to forge pathways of collaboration between religious community, the Presidency and government at large. #SocietalRenewalpic.twitter.com/8mLvCNu92L

President #Ramaphosa: Let us forge ahead in the spirit of partnership and mutual understanding, for we share a common responsibility and a common goal – to realise a better South Africa for ourselves, for our children, and for the children of tomorrow. #SocietalRenewal

President #Ramaphosa: We must do all we can to ensure our democracy remains sturdy and resilient, that those who come after us will continue to be able to rely on it, to lean in its shade, and to enjoy its benefits and protection. #SocietalRenewalpic.twitter.com/kmiXAwlxzF
President #Ramaphosa: We remember the words of Chris Hani, a great hero of our people who was cruelly murdered on this day 26 years ago. #SocietalRenewalpic.twitter.com/S86hnOepFw

President #Ramaphosa: We cannot afford to have its roots wither away through intolerance and disrespect – for ourselves, for each other, and for the worth and dignity of every human being. #SocietalRenewal
President #Ramaphosa: We are a relatively young democracy. The tree of liberty was planted by our forbearers. Over the past 25 years it has been watered and nurtured. #SocietalRenewal

President #Ramaphosa: Today, we will be committing ourselves to a declaration for societal renewal. This Declaration represents our concern at the rise of social problems in our society that, if not effectively addressed, will reproduce themselves in coming generations.pic.twitter.com/mQDlA5xIe3

President #Ramaphosa: As we embark on this endeavour, we want to listen to you, to hear and understand your concerns and for you to spell out your vision. We want you to tell us what more we can do to assist you in your mission. #SocietalRenewalpic.twitter.com/JiF9CjDtRF

President #Ramaphosa: As our faith community stood at the forefront during our days of struggle, so now too do we want you to be at the forefront of a new social movement to renew our society. #SocietalRenewal

President #Ramaphosa: For the betterment of their congregants, yes, but also for the betterment of communities, and for the country as a whole. It is the excellent work you are already doing in our communities that we want to harness and build upon. #SocietalRenewal

President #Ramaphosa: And now you have an equally important role to play in the renewal of our society, and in using your positions to restore basic human values in our society. The men and women of the faith community have never faltered in their willingness to do their part.pic.twitter.com/PtEaeGZTC3
President #Ramaphosa: As government, we have always appreciated the role of faith communities in guiding us when we have strayed from our mission to unite and develop our country. #SocietalRenewal

President #Ramaphosa: This is not the South Africa we fought for. It is not the South Africa for which many people were jailed and killed. It is certainly not the South Africa we want to live in. We are here to explore avenues of collaboration to renew South Africa.

President #Ramaphosa: Racism and intolerance, the abuse of women and girls, the absence of common decency in how we interact with others, the use of violence to settle disputes or grievances – all tell us that we have strayed from our country’s founding values. #SocietalRenewal

President #Ramaphosa: Today, more than ever before, the vast majority of South Africans, and in particularly the poor and the vulnerable, have access to education, to health care and to basic services. #SocietalRenewal

President #Ramaphosa: In the past 25 years we've made significant progress in improving the lives of South Africans. From an oppressive state machinery that had scant regard for the lives of millions, we now have a democratic state where all enjoy equal rights & protection.

President #Ramaphosa: In this, the year that we mark 25 years since the founding of our democracy, we have a great deal to be thankful for, and an even greater deal of which we can be proud. #SocietalRenewal #Democracy25

President #Ramaphosa: In being here today you have responded to the call from your government to join us to bring healing to our nation, at a time when it is confronted by intolerance, racism, violence and other social ills. #SocietalRenewal

President #Ramaphosa: Dr King said: “The nation is sick. Trouble is in the land; confusion all around... But I know, somehow, that only when it is dark enough you can see the stars. And I see God working in this period of the 20th century in a way that men are responding.”pic.twitter.com/Yu8bkhtnDp
President #Ramaphosa: It was a dark time, when black men, women and children were being brutalised for demanding their rights to be treated equally. #SocietalRenewal

President #Ramaphosa: In preparing for this meeting I recalled the impact on me personally of one of Dr King’s greatest speeches. In 1968 he delivered his memorable address in Memphis, Tennessee, in which he declared “I’ve been to the mountaintop”. #SocietalRenewalpic.twitter.com/a3l3ybESdp

President #Ramaphosa: Last week marked 50 years since the assassination of Dr Martin Luther King Jnr. Dr King was a towering figure in the US civil rights movement, and his ideas on non-violent resistance to oppression had a great bearing on our own liberation struggle.

President #Ramaphosa: They are anchored by the imperative that has driven communities of faith since the dawn of time – to advance social justice. We are meeting soon after another occasion of historical significance. #SocietalRenewal

President #Ramaphosa: They are consistent with the founding values of our Constitution: those of human dignity, of the achievement of equality, of non-racialism and non-sexism; and of the advancement of human rights and freedoms for all. #SocietalRenewalpic.twitter.com/enI7OTbDsH

President #Ramaphosa: That these dates are so important to three of the world’s great faiths coincide every year reminds us all of the commonality of our humanity. And that although there may be doctrinal and other differences among us, we ultimately share the same values.

President #Ramaphosa: We will soon enter the Easter period, which coincides with the Jewish festival of Pesach or Passover, and soon afterwards, the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan will begin. #SocietalRenewal

President #Ramaphosa: It is my honour and privilege to welcome you to this critical and timely dialogue. It is taking place as we approach a period of deep religious significance for people of the Christian, Jewish and Muslim faiths. #SocietalRenewal

President #Ramaphosa: Now in my capacity as President of the Republic, therefore proclaim that this Presidential Summit Declaration against Gender-Based Violence and Femicide is hereby assented to and signed on behalf of the government of South Africa. #GBVFDeclaration

President #Ramaphosa: Through this Declaration, we aim to ensure that our economic development model takes into consideration non-gender conforming people and other marginalised groups such as people with disabilities. #GBVFDeclaration

President #Ramaphosa: To prevent gender-based violence requires that we implement social behaviour change programmes in our communities to tackle patriarchal values &norms. We must target people who influence attitudes, behaviours and practices that promote gender-based violence
President #Ramaphosa: We need serious introspection, however, as to why our laws are still failing to adequately protect vulnerable women and children. #GBVFDeclaration

President #Ramaphosa: We have enacted progressive legislation like the Domestic Violence Act, the Sexual Offences and Related Matters Act, the Child Justice Act and the Prevention and Combating of Trafficking in Persons Act, to name but a few. #GBVFDeclaration

President #Ramaphosa: I said at last year’s Presidential Summit that there is no acceptable level of gender-based violence. We don’t want to bring the figures down; we want to eradicate this evil from our society. #GBVFDeclaration

President #Ramaphosa: It exacts a heavy toll on relationships, on families, on communities, on workplaces, on schools and on universities and colleges. It breeds fear and suspicion in a society that is still coming to terms with a divided and violent past. #GBVFDeclaration

President #Ramaphosa: Our women no longer feel safe, in their homes, and on the streets. Rape, abuse and sexual assault is rampant, often committed by those closest to them. Gender-based violence impacts us all. #GBVFDeclaration

President #Ramaphosa: Yet, for so many of this country’s women, these aspirations have not been met. So many of our country’s women face a reality of harassment, of abuse and of violence. Our nation is facing a crisis. #GBVFDeclaration

President #Ramaphosa: Our Constitution and Bill of Rights is one of the most progressive in the world, and holds the right to equality, to freedom, to dignity and security of the person among its key aspirations. #GBVFDeclaration

President #Ramaphosa: We will not allow it to steadily consume our people, to erode our dreams of a stable & peaceful society in which all have equal rights & opportunities, regardless of their race, gender, sexual orientation or the circumstances of their birth. #GBVFDeclaration
President #Ramaphosa: As a nation, today we are making a bold and unequivocal declaration that we will not yield to gender-based violence. #GBVFDeclaration

President #Ramaphosa: They have been united by one common cause – to see an end to gender-based violence. We have here representatives from across society, women’s organisations, faith-based and community formations, and the legal and law enforcement fraternity. #GBVFDeclaration

President #Ramaphosa: Since the Summit we have seen the rise of a mass-based social movement that has embraced both women and men from across racial, cultural, religious, political and socio-economic divides. #GBVFDeclaration
President #Ramaphosa: The Summit, which was attended by over 1,200 women from all walks of life, opened the eyes of our people to the gravity and impact of gender-based violence. #GBVFDeclaration

President #Ramaphosa: The opening of the court, together with the declaration against gender-based violence and femicide, are two of the measures we have put in place since the Presidential Summit convened in November last year. #GBVFDeclaration

President #Ramaphosa: In opening this new sexual offences court at Booysens we are affirming the right of the women and girls of this country to be treated with professionalism and empathy. #GBVFDeclaration

President #Ramaphosa: Right here, today, we are turning the tide. The character of a country can be judged by how that society’s most vulnerable are treated. We have heard the pleas of survivors of gender-based violence to be treated with respect by our criminal justice system.

President #Ramaphosa: It is my pleasure to be here this morning during Human Rights Month, to fulfil the promise our government made to the people of South Africa: that we will take firm, decisive and swift action to eradicate gender-based violence and femicide in our society.
