Heads of State and Government and Heads of delegation from participating countries delivering solidarity statements during the Southern African Development Community Solidarity Conference with the Western Sahara held in Tshwane. #SADCSaharawiSolidarity #BetterAfricaBetterWorldpic.twitter.com/19KF5tYYzg

Family photo of the Heads of State and Government and Heads of delegation from participating countries at the Southern African Development Community (SADC) Solidarity Conference with the Western Sahara held in Tshwane, Gauteng. #SADCSaharawiSolidarity #BetterAfricaBetterWorldpic.twitter.com/SxsXvAyH8R

President @CyrilRamaphosa: It was international solidarity that brought down the barbaric system of apartheid, and it is international solidarity that will see realised the foremost aspiration of the people of Western Sahara: to be independent and free. #SADCSaharawiSolidaritypic.twitter.com/wdzGvhKLWa

President @CyrilRamaphosa: As lovers of peace and freedom – as men and women of conscience – let us step up our international solidarity efforts, in both word and deed, with the people of Western Sahara, with Polisario and with the Saharawi Arab Democratic Republic.pic.twitter.com/L3ldOvuxfM

President @CyrilRamaphosa: So long as the aspirations of the people of Western Sahara are not met, we will fall short of realising the vision of the AU’s #Agenda2063 of a continent at peace with itself. #SADCSaharawiSolidaritypic.twitter.com/Z19NrqYohH

President @CyrilRamaphosa: It is only through the implementation of these decisions that a solution to the Western Sahara question can be achieved. This must be done in the spirit of multilateralism, based on the Charter of the UN and the applicable provisions of the AU.pic.twitter.com/WX4xUUaSj8

President @CyrilRamaphosa: We are here to deliberate on the way in which we can use our respective positions with UN and AU to advocate for the urgent implementation of all the UNSC and AU decisions on Western Sahara, including the holding of a referendum. #SADCSaharawiSolidarity

President @CyrilRamaphosa: We are here to hear from the Saharawi Arab Democratic Republic and Polisario what we can do to aid them in advancing their cause. #SADCSaharawiSolidaritypic.twitter.com/YdX9juPrJc

President @CyrilRamaphosa: The ultimate result has been that the people of Western Sahara have been deprived of the most fundamental right of a people – the right to determine their own destiny. #SADCSaharawiSolidarity

President @CyrilRamaphosa: But despite successive Security Council resolutions and decisions of the Organisation of African Unity and African Union, this critical step has not taken place. #SADCSaharawiSolidaritypic.twitter.com/OkY3cCx8En

President @CyrilRamaphosa: It has been three decades since the United Nations Security Council adopted Resolution 621 of 1998 first calling for a referendum on self-determination for the people of Western Sahara. #SADCSaharawiSolidarity

President @CyrilRamaphosa: The Saharawi people have lived in refugee camps in Algeria since the ‘70s, making this one of the longest humanitarian crises the world has known. In these camps, men, women and children live in desperate conditions. #SADCSaharawiSolidaritypic.twitter.com/0nCd9F1QIU

President @CyrilRamaphosa: We cannot but be moved by the plight of the #Saharawi people. It has been 43 years since Western Sahara was annexed. For 4 decades the people of Western Sahara have had to endure dispossession, displacement, conflict & deprivation of their liberties.pic.twitter.com/P1c5VSWC0d
President @CyrilRamaphosa: It follows on a decision made at the 37th Summit of the SADC Heads of State & Government that took place here in Tshwane in August 2017. #SADCSaharawiSolidarity

President @CyrilRamaphosa: This conference reflects our commitment, as the countries of Africa, supported by our friends in the international community, to call for a just, acceptable and lasting solution to the situation in Western Sahara. #SADCSaharawiSolidarity

President @CyrilRamaphosa: The presence of representatives from the national liberation movements of the region, from the AU and AU Commission, from the SADC and our friends in the international community sends the clearest of messages. #SADCSaharawiSolidaritypic.twitter.com/vjyeIsiuaC

President @CyrilRamaphosa: Gathered here today are men and women of conscience. You stood by South Africa during the struggle for our own liberation and today you affirm your solidarity with the Saharawi people in their quest for self-determination. #SADCSaharawiSolidaritypic.twitter.com/shH3oNHXd8

President @CyrilRamaphosa: In the many times he addressed the international community on the anti-apartheid struggle, Comrade OR, spoke of the role of ‘men and women of conscience’ in giving voice to the struggles of oppressed peoples everywhere. #SADCSaharawiSolidarity

President @CyrilRamaphosa: It is fitting that this conference is taking place in a building named after Oliver Reginald Tambo, a legendary statesman and a committed internationalist who was unwavering in his support for the struggle for self-determination of the Saharawi people.pic.twitter.com/Rk1XYafY55

President @CyrilRamaphosa: On behalf of the people and government of South Africa I would like to welcome you to our country. We are honoured to be hosting this historic act of solidarity with the #Saharawi people. #SADCSaharawiSolidarity

President @CyrilRamaphosa receives Heads of State and Government attending the Southern African Development Community (SADC) Solidarity Conference with Western Sahara held at the OR Tambo Building, @DIRCO_ZA in Tshwane. #SADCSaharawiSolidarity #BetterAfricaBetterWorldpic.twitter.com/1XMwlb9f1q

President @CyrilRamaphosa arrives at @DIRCO_ZA’s OR Tambo Building in Tshwane for the Southern African Development Community (SADC) Solidarity Conference with the the #Saharawi Arab Democratic Republic (SADR). #SADCSaharawiSolidarity #BetterAfricaBetterWorldpic.twitter.com/16CMbUVdqv
President mourns passing away of Princess Irene Buthelezi https://bit.ly/2TVhZfP

“As we imagine a new future for our people, we recall the words of the poet Antjie Krog. She wrote: “Gee vir my ‘n land waar swart en wit hand aan hand vrede en liefde kan bring in my mooi land.” ~ President @CyrilRamaphosa #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/z9MpYwV5WM

President @CyrilRamaphosa inspects the tractors and planters that have been supplied to the farming community in Ebenhaeser as part of the economic recovery and stimulus package as announced by the President in 2018. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/MdH9xnXylV

[PICTURES]: President @CyrilRamaphosa, with @DRDLR_online Minister Maite Nkoane-Mashabane and Western Cape Premier Hellen Zille, handover title deeds to the Chairpersons of the Communal Property Associations of the #Ebenhaeser, #Paternoster and #Beeswater. #DignityThroughLandpic.twitter.com/VADlebGA5h

President @CyrilRamaphosa receives a painting of the historic Ebenhaeser Church made by 16 year old Tamerah Nel a grade 11 pupil at Vredendal Secondary School during the Land handover ceremony in the Western Cape. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/ahNwHpohII
Address by President Cyril Ramaphosa at the Ebenhaeser land claim settlement ceremony https://bit.ly/2CyTQRq

President @CyrilRamaphosa: We have made considerable and demonstrable progress, and will continue to do more. Seeing the children of the Ebenhaeser community running free on the land that was their forebearers’ is no longer a dream deferred, but a promise fulfilled.pic.twitter.com/AF6S6ypPAv

President @CyrilRamaphosa: Each time a land claim is settled, each time we witness the joy of communities who can return to their ancestors’ land, we become all the more optimistic for our country’s future. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/4wr4ZkdFT5

President @CyrilRamaphosa: I am therefore particularly pleased that the Ebenhaeser community wants to use the land for productive purposes. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/5VSokteZns

President @CyrilRamaphosa: It is a priority of government to ensure that we provide the necessary support to communities who have had their land returned so that it is used productively and effectively, and to support our goals of agricultural growth and economic transformation.pic.twitter.com/YoUHBnw3bl
President @CyrilRamaphosa: Having land returned to its rightful owners is just the first step towards sustainable and enduring land reform. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritage

WATCH LIVE: President Cyril Ramaphosa delivers the keynote address during the #Land Handover Ceremony of the 3990 hectares of commercial farmland in the West Coast, Western Cape #DignityThroughLandhttps://twitter.com/CyrilRamaphosa/status/1109397197714608128 …
President @CyrilRamaphosa: With democracy, all our people were afforded equal rights as we laid out our vision for a non-racial, non-sexist, free, egalitarian society. #DignityThroughLand

President @CyrilRamaphosa: In the past, access to land, to wealth, to services, to opportunity, was the realm of the privileged few at the expense of the majority. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritage

President @CyrilRamaphosa: An Inter-Ministerial Committee has been established to oversee the accelerated land reform process, with a Presidential Advisory Panel on hand to assist the committee in its work. Ours is a Constitution founded on the principle of social justice.

President @CyrilRamaphosa: But land reform needs to be accelerated if we are to correct this historical injustice. The slow pace of reform has caused impatience among our people, and justifiably so. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritage

President @CyrilRamaphosa: Despite the numerous challenges we have faced, the land claims process has made a difference to the lives of hundreds of thousands of South Africans denied their birthright. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/HQkOiw7Jhp

President @CyrilRamaphosa: Across the length and breadth of South Africa, #land has been restored to its original owners, be they individuals or community. In other cases, where it was not feasible to return land, individuals or communities were financially compensated.pic.twitter.com/qMHusQJQTQ

President @CyrilRamaphosa: With the passing of the Restitution of Land Rights Act (1994), government set about giving effect to that declaration. Over the last 25 years, we have harnessed the provisions of this law to change the skewed patterns of land ownership in our country.

President @CyrilRamaphosa: Farmworkers and labour tenants on farms are the lifeblood of our country. It is your hands and your labour that puts food on our tables. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/KJFqwRIbNQ

President @CyrilRamaphosa: More than half a century ago, the people of this country declared in the #FreedomCharter that the land shall be shared among those who work it. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/XXbrcvHuM5

President @CyrilRamaphosa: Although human rights are by their nature universal, it is the rights of society’s most vulnerable that we must take particular care to enforce and protect. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritage

President @CyrilRamaphosa: It was successive colonial and apartheid administrations who deprived our people of access to, and ownership of, the land. As the democratic government of a free South Africa, it is our responsibility to undo this bitter legacy. #DignityThroughLandpic.twitter.com/ZG1JKhoKse
President @CyrilRamaphosa: We are reminded of the need to never return to a dark past where the state deprives people of their basic human rights. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritage

President @CyrilRamaphosa: It has been 59 years since the terrible events at #Sharpeville, where 69 unarmed protestors were killed by the apartheid state, and #Langa, where three others were killed. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritage

President @CyrilRamaphosa: Two days ago, our country observed #HumanRightsDay, a time to reflect on how far we have come in advancing human rights in our society. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/gzxWY7CKEJ

President @CyrilRamaphosa: We share a common goal, to improve the lives of all South Africans and uplift their material conditions by giving them access to land. This process has shown just what can be achieved when we work together. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritage
President @CyrilRamaphosa: On behalf of all the people of South Africa I want to acknowledge you and your families. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritage

President @CyrilRamaphosa: The number of claims settled for the West Coast Municipality – a total of 392 out of 422 by February this year – is a result of cooperation between the @DRDLR_online and the Office of the Regional Land Claims Commissioner. #DignityThroughLand

President @CyrilRamaphosa: What we are witnessing here today is a triumph of cooperative governance, because the settlement of these claims would not have been possible without the close collaboration of local, provincial and national government. #DignityThroughLandpic.twitter.com/igISe4z4X2

President @CyrilRamaphosa: Without your daily efforts all the farms around the country would not be able to produce, sell and export the many agricultural goods for which our country is famous around the world. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/6soBQC7Mtz

President @CyrilRamaphosa: It is you who are the future beneficiaries of this land. It is you who will restore it to its former glory and it is you who will be the next generation of farmers, conservation managers, foresters and aqua-culturists. #DignityThroughLandpic.twitter.com/m6i7kwqKT9

President @CyrilRamaphosa: We therefore extend a particular welcome to the youth of the #Ebenhaeser community and the young people of the other communities represented today. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/lpT84hzlSx

President @CyrilRamaphosa: Land is the one thing that endures the passage of time. To borrow the words of Mahatma Gandhi, land is not so much an inheritance from our forefathers, as it is a loan from our children. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritage

President @CyrilRamaphosa: It is in the ownership of land that we find our independence as a people. It is land that we rely on to live, to work and to eat. It is land that holds firmly the roots of our ancestors. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/nshfheZIDo

President @CyrilRamaphosa: The handing over of these title deeds is a historic occasion, because it includes the first ever settled land claim in the Western Cape to descendants of the #Griqua people. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritage
President @CyrilRamaphosa: Ons sê ook baie welkom aan die Vaalplaas en Paternoster-gemeenskappe en verteenwoordigers van Rooiberg en Rooikamp. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritage

President @CyrilRamaphosa: Ons verwelkom ook vandag verteenwoordigers en gemeenskapslede van Beeswater, Vanrhynsdorp en omliggende gebiede wat trots is op hul Griekwa-afkoms. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/wzbUVrSYYw

As the first claim settled in the Western Cape to direct descendants of the indigenous #Griqua community, they also propose to develop a cultural village and ultimately resettle their community to the land that is rich in cultural history. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/LEhBPfO2Nc

The #Beeswater Communal Property Association has indicated their desire to resuscitate livestock and game farming as possible agricultural activities. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/TsYzhIV5p3

The community of #Beeswater was forcibly removed from an undivided portion of the remainder of Farm Vanrhysdorp in 1960. The community was eventually relocated to the Coloured Area of #Vredendal in 1981. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/FppnmKIbOV

The community entered into a lease agreement with the then landowner in 1938-1940 but due to racial laws and practices, did not have the necessary permit to purchase the land. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/dOxG1osyYe

This is a very historic Land Restitution Ceremony as this is the first successful finalisation and settlement of a claim of the descendants of the indigenous Griqua. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/XCLg9qVgGZ

The community of Ebenhaeser in the Western Cape Province, awaiting the arrival of President @CyrilRamaphosa who is handing over title deeds for the 3990 hectares of 178 Vanrhynsdorp #Beeswater commercial farmland. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/hUOeiTCDEG

President @CyrilRamaphosa with @DRDLR_online MinisterNkoana-Mashabane will hand over title deeds for the 3990 hectares of 178 Vanrhynsdorp #Beeswater commercial farmland to the direct descendants of the #Griqua Community that have established themselves on the farm since 1926.pic.twitter.com/osCodtBnNO

Taking place under the theme “Restoring dignity through land reform” the settling and finalising of land claims is part of the Land Reform programme which is part of the transformative principles of our Constitution. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/BEmLFqo2e5

President @CyrilRamaphosa will this morning hand over title deeds to more than 50 households of #Ebenhaeser, Beeswater in the Western Cape province. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/GyNcMup2Hl

Commander-in-Chief President @CyrilRamaphosa has deployed South African National Defence Force (SANDF) to conduct a search and rescue operation in Mozambique and Malawi, with their efforts having resulted in 167 people bring successfully airlifted to safety in Beira, Mozambique.pic.twitter.com/U1IJWG3UGr

The Military Command Council is the highest decision making body in the SANDF comprised of Chiefs of the Army, Navy, Air Force, Military Health Services, Defence Intelligence & Joint Operations, as led by Chief of the SANDF Gen Shoke. The MCC directs the work of the entire SANDF.pic.twitter.com/Y0QlTMhMTp

Commander-in-Chief of the South African National Defence Force President @CyrilRamaphosa meets with the Military Command Council this evening for a briefing on the search and rescue operation underway in Malawi and Mozambique following the devastation caused by #CycloneIdai.pic.twitter.com/8v4ga0x0ik
President #Ramaphosa: Not just for ourselves or our families or our communities, but for the sake of all with which we share this beautiful land. #HumanRightsDay

President #Ramaphosa: We draw strength and courage from them as we confront the challenges of the here and now. Together, let us deepen the culture of human rights and become true human rights activists – committed to dignity, freedom, justice and equality. #HumanRightsDay

President #Ramaphosa: Ri tshimbila kha ṋayo dza Vho Nelson Mandela, Vho Robert Mangaliso Sobukwe, Vho Steve Biko, Vho Mme Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, Vho Mme Albertina Sisulu na vhaṅwe vhaḓivhalea vha nndwa ya mbofholowo. #HumanRightsDaypic.twitter.com/iOYcFShMhG

President #Ramaphosa: The road we have travelled has been a long one. The achievement of a society that respects fundamental human rights was hard won. We fought, we resisted, and ultimately, we prevailed. #HumanRightsDay

President #Ramaphosa: This cannot be the responsibility of government alone. It begins with the individual. It begins when false machismo and toxic masculinity is not praised by other men, but rejected. #HumanRightsDaypic.twitter.com/BlQgq0tljm

President #Ramaphosa: We must intensify our efforts to give effect to the rights promised by our Constitution. This can only be realised if we work together, and reinforce the strong human rights culture upon which our country was founded. #HumanRightsDay

President #Ramaphosa: Schools, clinics and other infrastructure upon which our people depend are being vandalised and destroyed. Around the country, many communities feel under siege from gangsters, criminals & thugs. This is not the South Africa we fought for. #HumanRightsDay

President #Ramaphosa: People with disabilities are being discriminated against at work and in their communities, and have become vulnerable to abuse & mistreatment. Women and girls live in fear of sexual assault, and often do not feel free to walk the streets or be out after darkpic.twitter.com/1uoY3Bj24v

President #Ramaphosa: Children are assaulting and even killing each other in the schoolyard. Men are turning their fists on their mothers, their partners and their children, who look to them for respect and protection. #HumanRightsDay

President #Ramaphosa: We have confronted difficulties before, challenges that seemed insurmountable, but we have prevailed, through working together & never giving up. We will overcome the electricity crisis, just as we will overcome unemployment and poverty, crime & corruption.pic.twitter.com/ZnooAfQJVP

President #Ramaphosa: Restoring a reliable supply of electricity – and ensuring that we have a sustainable model for affordable energy into the future – is now one of our most urgent priorities. #HumanRightsDay

President #Ramaphosa: In 1994, only 36% of the population had access to electricity. Today, 8 out of 10 South Africans have electricity in their homes. Yet, we are currently facing a severe energy crisis that is having a profound impact on the lives of our people and our economy.pic.twitter.com/ajngm4SDhr
President #Ramaphosa: None dare deny that we have made remarkable progress in providing our people with access to electricity. #HumanRightsDay

President #Ramaphosa: Energy, like housing, water and health care, is a human rights issue. It may not be mentioned in the Bill of Rights, but it is fundamental to the dignity, safety, health and well-being of our people. #HumanRightsDay

President #Ramaphosa: It requires that we confront the substantial social and economic challenges we face, a consequence both of the devastating legacy of our past and some of our own missteps over the last 25 years. #HumanRightsDay
President #Ramaphosa: Our commitment to human rights requires that all our efforts are directed at ending inequality, creating jobs and growing our economy. #HumanRightsDay

President #Ramaphosa: It is for that reason that we will move with urgency to sign and ratify the Africa Disability Protocol, in terms of the requirements of our law, so that it may soon become an official legal instrument of the African Union. #HumanRightsDay

President #Ramaphosa: On this day, we must support efforts to raise awareness about down syndrome and confront discrimination, ignorance and prejudice. We must affirm our determination that in the struggle for human rights – we must leave no one behind.

President #Ramaphosa: It is fitting that South Africa marks #HumanRightsDay on the same day that the United Nations celebrates World Down Syndrome Day, because our approach to the needs and interests of persons with disability is at all times guided by our Bill of Rights.

President #Ramaphosa: Working together, we have transformed South Africa from a society driven by a race-based, exclusionary and divisive ideology, to a democracy where all citizens enjoy equal rights before the law. #HumanRightsDay

President #Ramaphosa: Bound by our belief in our Constitution, we are working towards a country that is united, non-racial, non-sexist, prosperous and free. As the government of the people, for the people, by the people, respect for human rights is the bedrock of our actions.

President #Ramaphosa: The regime had no regard for even the most basic of human rights, the right to protest freely. But try as they might, they could not extinguish the torch of liberty carried by the brave men and women who came before us. #HumanRightsDaypic.twitter.com/xElFIJmF2J

President #Ramaphosa: The Sharpeville and Langa massacres came to symbolise the moral superiority of the anti-apartheid cause. Though lacking the guns of their oppressors, they were determined to stand up for what was right, no matter the cost. #HumanRightsDay
President #Ramaphosa: Ka gore re setšhaba se se kopantšwego ka go fapana ga rena.We are a nation united in our diversity. #HumanRightsDay

President #Ramaphosa: Every time an indigenous language is spoken freely and without restraint, every time one is broadcast on our airwaves – re dira se e le segopotšo go motheo wa tumelo yeo e hlagišitšwego go matsenyagae a Molaotheo wa rena. #HumanRightsDay

President #Ramaphosa: As part of our commitment to empower and foster respect for the rights of people with disabilities, a proposal has been submitted to Parliament to elevate South African Sign Language to the status of an official language. #HumanRightsDay

President #Ramaphosa: The Commission for the Promotion and Protection of the Rights of Cultural, Religious and Linguistic Communities is actively involved in resuscitating Isihlubi, Isibhaca, Northern Ndebele and other indigenous languages. #HumanRightsDay

President #Ramaphosa: The Nama language of the Khoisan people is now being taught in primary schools in the Northern Cape, and a language rule book is being finalised by the Pan South African Language Board. #HumanRightsDay

President #Ramaphosa: It is said that when a language dies, a way of understanding the world dies with it. The aim of this year’s celebration therefore is to highlight efforts to conserve languages that are in danger of becoming extinct. #HumanRightsDay

President #Ramaphosa: This coincides with the United Nations declaration of 2019 as the International Year of Indigenous Languages. In according all our languages the respect that they are due, we are affirming the dignity, worth & humanity of every South African. #HumanRightsDay
President #Ramaphosa: We have dedicated this year’s Human Rights Day celebrations to the promotion of indigenous languages as a fundamental part of building a human rights culture. #HumanRightsDay

WATCH LIVE: “The Year of Indigenous Languages: Promoting and Deepening a Human Rights Culture” #HumanRightsDay Keynote Address delivered by President @CyrilRamaphosahttps://twitter.com/CyrilRamaphosa/status/1108667988792664069 …

The objective of 2019 #HumanRightsDay is to amplify efforts to preserve, promote and revitalise endangered languages, affirm our commitment to human rights for all and emphasise that the #BillofRights promotes linguistic diversity and encourages respect for all language rights.pic.twitter.com/E3z0yRNYWm

Since the advent of democratic governance in South Africa 25 years ago, #HumanRightsMonth has been used as a vehicle to foster social cohesion, nation building, national identity, socio-economic development & to combat racism, racial discrimination, xenophobia & all intolerances.pic.twitter.com/ltw9QX2hPW

The Sharpeville Massacre, as the event has become known, signalled the start of armed resistance in South Africa and prompted worldwide condemnation of South Africa's apartheid policies. #HumanRightsDaypic.twitter.com/T8iNmDObqF

On that day, an anti-pass march at the Sharpeville police station came to a brutal end with the mass killing of 69 unarmed protesters. Later that day, in Langa, police baton-charged and fired teargas at protesters, shooting three and injuring several others. #HumanRightsDaypic.twitter.com/wsps8lqNH9

#HumanRightsDay has its origins in the events that unfolded at Sharpeville and at Langa in the Western Cape on 21 March 1960, when apartheid security forces cracked down on peaceful marches that opposed pass laws that had been imposed on black South Africans.pic.twitter.com/TwMG74dUXW

The national event takes place at the George Thabe Sports Ground in Sharpeville, Gauteng under the theme: “The Year of Indigenous Languages: Promoting and Deepening a Human Rights Culture”. #HumanRightsDaypic.twitter.com/zxIco5sS8z
President @CyrilRamaphosa will this morning deliver the keynote address at the 25th commemoration of #HumanRightsDay in Sharpeville, Gautengpic.twitter.com/qLv7GcILsE

[PICTURES]: President @CyrilRamaphosa accompanied by Bishop Lekganyane on a guided tour of the refurbished and extended facilities of the Marobathota High School that includes a science and computer laboratory and a consumer centre.pic.twitter.com/jVtPym7xQj

[PICTURES]: President @CyrilRamaphosa arrives at the Marobathotha High School in Boyne, near the Zion City for the official opening of the school. President Ramaphosa delivered the keynote address at the Zion Christian Church’s handover ceremony.pic.twitter.com/hJs7X9AlKx

President #Ramaphosa: Although the task before us is daunting, we need to harness the energy, expertise & the passion of all stakeholders to provide the infrastructure that enables us to educate our children and care for our people. We are in this together, and we will succeed.

President #Ramaphosa: It is through partnerships like this that we will build the nation that our people need and deserve – a nation where we have defeated poverty and hunger, homelessness and disease, and where all people may live in peace and contentment.pic.twitter.com/Q7LQoXeKLW

President #Ramaphosa: We deeply appreciate the efforts of all those health workers who patiently provide care to everyone who walks through the doors of this clinic. This clinic is a worthy tribute to the life and contribution of Evelyn Lekganyane.

President #Ramaphosa: We feel a similar pride when we think about the outstanding work of the Evelyn Lekganyane Clinic. From its establishment, the clinic has made a vital contribution to the health and well-being of the community.

President #Ramaphosa: Allow me to commend the leadership, the staff, the parents and the learners of Marobathota High School for making this school a site of learning and development, of renewal and progress. You make this community proud and you make our country proud.

President #Ramaphosa: We cannot allow any learner to be injured or killed by another learner, and we cannot allow our schools to become places of fear. They must be places where learners can be safe and cared for.

President #Ramaphosa: We need to work together as school communities to end the scourge of violence in our schools. This starts in our homes, on our streets, in our community centres, in our churches, mosques, synagogues and temples.
President #Ramaphosa: This means we need to support and equip the leadership of the school, the educators and the parents to ensure a conducive and empowering environment.pic.twitter.com/Ty2IDR1lAy

President #Ramaphosa: Our experience tells us - school infrastructure is the foundation, but effective learning requires a comprehensive approach that addresses not only all aspects of the teaching &learning experience, but also the social conditions under which learners live.

President #Ramaphosa: Since the launch of SAFE in August last year, some 234 projects out of 3,900 sanitation projects have been completed. An additional 415 SAFE initiatives and a further 787 provincial sanitation projects are being implemented in the current financial year.

President #Ramaphosa: We are working with the private sector and development partners to eradicate pit latrines and other inappropriate sanitation facilities in all our schools within the next three years.
President #Ramaphosa: We have also launched the Sanitation Appropriate for Education - #SAFEIntiative, which aims to provide decent sanitation to all school-going learners as a matter of priority.

President #Ramaphosa: We set about correcting this through the Accelerated Schools Infrastructure Delivery Initiative - ASIDI. Over 210 state-of-the-art schools have been completed. We also rolled out basic services such as water, libraries, electricity & appropriate sanitation.

President #Ramaphosa: We have had to confront the reality that several years into our democracy, children were still learning under trees, some schools were constructed from inappropriate materials, such as mud, plankie and asbestos.

President #Ramaphosa: Matric results have consistently shown an upward trajectory of above 70% in the last 10 years. This has been achieved through a deliberate programme to undo the legacy of apartheid education mismanagement and poor infrastructure planning.

President #Ramaphosa: Now, 25 years since the advent of democracy, despite the backlogs that still remain, a lot has been achieved. Some 80% of learners attend no fee schools. Some 9 million learners are fed nutritious meals every school day.pic.twitter.com/ZX26AM39Pl

President #Ramaphosa:The low standard of education was paired with inferior school infrastructure, which meant no access to water, sanitation or electricity. By the end of apartheid, 59% of schools had no electricity, 34% no water, 12% no toilets and 82% were without libraries.

President #Ramaphosa: The apartheid legacy of substandard education aimed to ensure that black South Africans were nothing more than a source of unskilled labour for the economy. They were said to be ‘hewers of wood and drawers of water’.

President #Ramaphosa:That is why we have invested significantly in a package of care and support services available to all schools. We are pleased that this school is part of our pro-poor initiatives, such as the no fee school policy and the National School Nutrition Programme.

President #Ramaphosa: Directly linked to the physical infrastructure, we are committed to use schools as vehicles for promoting access to a range of public services among learners in areas such as health, poverty alleviation, psychosocial support, sport and culture.

President #Ramaphosa: We know that poorly designed schools give an impression that learners are a reflection of their school: undervalued, and uncared for. And yet, the learners of our country are our most dear and most valued national asset – and they need to be treated as such.pic.twitter.com/QMDfVILSWd

President #Ramaphosa: A positive school environment is defined as a school having appropriate facilities, well-managed classrooms, available school-based health support, and a clear, fair disciplinary policy.

President #Ramaphosa: Our action plan for basic education says that: “We must ensure that the physical infrastructure and environment of every school inspire learners to want to come to school and learn, and teachers to teach.”

President #Ramaphosa: Today, they are working with government to build a better life for all. The initiatives that we celebrate today contribute directly to critical policy objectives of this administration – improved quality of basic education & improved health outcomes.

President #Ramaphosa: It is a reminder of the essential role that religious leaders have played in building cohesive communities. Throughout our history, communities of faith in South Africa have championed the cause of the poor &marginalised, the oppressed and the dispossessed.
President #Ramaphosa:pic.twitter.com/75otDj1wu8

President #Ramaphosa: Today, we celebrate an outstanding example of collaboration between government and our social partners. We are celebrating the vision and commitment of Bishop Lekganyane and the entire Zion Christian Church to the development of the youth & this community
President #Ramaphosa: It is a great honour to be present at this important handover of the refurbished and extended facilities of the Marobathota High School and Evelyn Lekganyane Clinic.

Deputy President David Mabuza on #NorthWest Province: we are satisfied with the progress that has been recorded on the ground. This is testimony that the intervention we made was necessary to ensure that our people are not adversely impacted in accessing services. #MabuzaQandA

Deputy President David Mabuza on #NorthWest Province: In terms of training, the EPWP created 822 training opportunities in the province during the first two quarters of 2018/19, which is 587 more training opportunities compared to the same period in 2017/2018. #MabuzaQandA
Deputy President David Mabuza on #NorthWest Province: The highest percentage (69%) of work opportunities beneficiaries were women, followed by the youth. #MabuzaQandA

Deputy President David Mabuza on #NorthWest Province: 17 056 more work opportunities were created in the North West province during the first two quarters of 2018/19 compared to the same period in 2017/2018. #MabuzaQandA
Deputy President David Mabuza on #NorthWest Province: which is a 33% increase from the 34 527 work opportunities created during the same period in 2017/2018. #MabuzaQandA

Deputy President David Mabuza on #NorthWest Province: During the first two quarters of the 2018/2019 financial year, the Expanded Public Works Programme created 51 583 work opportunities in the North West province #MabuzaQandA

Deputy President David Mabuza on #NorthWest Province: Training and enterprise development are also implemented in sector specific programmes to enhance #servicedelivery and beneficiary well-being. #MabuzaQandA

Deputy President David Mabuza on #NorthWest Province: We have made progress in stabilising the finances of the Province, through improving controls to prevent unauthorised expenditure which was R384.8m during 2017/18). #MabuzaQandA
Deputy President David Mabuza on #NorthWest Province: Provincial road maintenance programme has been revived, with contractors now on site in 33 roads; #MabuzaQandA
Deputy President David Mabuza on #NorthWest Province: Four out of five operating theatres in Mahikeng Hospital are now functional; #MabuzaQandA
Deputy President David Mabuza on #NorthWest Province: Key vacant executive positions are being filled in service delivery departments such as Roads and Public Works; #MabuzaQandA
Deputy President David Mabuza on #NorthWest Province: Medicine availability in hospitals is at 83% (up from 67% in April 2018); #MabuzaQandA

Deputy President David Mabuza: Our government made relevant interventions aimed at the time at addressing the plight of the affected communities with a view to stabilise the situation and ensure that democratic governance is upheld. #MabuzaQandA
Deputy President David Mabuza: issues of service delivery in the North West Province were raised when various protest actions and destruction of property came to the fore. #MabuzaQandA
Deputy President David Mabuza: as government, we hope that your inputs will go a long way in shaping the success of our #landreform interventions in our country. #MabuzaQandA

Deputy President David Mabuza: State agricultural land parcels will be redistributed to support broadened participation of new entrants into the agricultural sector, and expand agro-based incubation programmes. #MabuzaQandA

Address by President @CyrilRamaphosa at the Land Handover Ceremony, Moretele Recreation Resort, Mamelodi http://bit.ly/2VSJUK5 #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/bzGpU24aTq

The ancestors of the families held informal or unregistered rights to the property and the Malobola family occupied the land in question from the 1800s to 1967 and the Mahlangu family from 1936 to 1960. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/jSqRGwNj7M

President #Ramaphosa: Today, the people who once called places like Kwa Dukathole, Boekenhoutskloof, Franspoort, Hondsrivier, Kafferskraal, Tweefontein and Vygeboschlaagte home are no longer pariahs in the land of their birth, but full and equal citizens of a new united nation.pic.twitter.com/hgUZ7628fL

President #Ramaphosa: As we accelerate the pace of land reform, we are focused also on improving the quality and the impact of our interventions. We are working to ensure that land claims are settled much faster, and that we clear the backlog in the shortest possible time.pic.twitter.com/CX4xOORQ2f
President #Ramaphosa: Land reform is also about building cities and towns that are integrated, where the poor have decent housing in areas close to economic opportunities. #OurLandOurHeritage

President #Ramaphosa: It is about building a South Africans which belongs to all who live in it, and in which all South Africans belong. It is about creating new livelihoods in agriculture and ending rural poverty. #OurLandOurHeritage

President #Ramaphosa: We will never fully heal the wounds of dispossession and degradation, but we are making ever greater strides in redressing the injustices visited on our people in the past. Land reform, however, is ultimately about the future. #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/XtUwjARLw3
President #Ramaphosa: This is an important part of correcting the extremely skewed pattern of land ownership and land use in this country. #OurLandOurHeritage

President #Ramaphosa: We are working to ensure that where it is possible to return the land to claimants, and where they want to return to the land, that we provide the necessary support to enable them to make productive use of the land. #OurLandOurHeritage
President #Ramaphosa: They long to have something that they can pass on to their children after they themselves have been returned to the soil from which they were born. #OurLandOurHeritage
President #Ramaphosa: They still long for the suffering and deprivation of generations to be recognised and to receive some form of recompense. #OurLandOurHeritage

President #Ramaphosa: The human tragedy of these laws is a source of great anguish even today, more than a century after the notorious Natives’ Land Act was enacted and 25 years into our democracy. Families still long to have their ancestral home restored to them.pic.twitter.com/sqbOHCy7WW

President #Ramaphosa: It was a place to live and an asset to pass on to the next generation. The leading intellectuals of the time raised the profound devastation that the land policies of the colonial and apartheid authorities would cause for generations. #OurLandOurHeritage

President #Ramaphosa: We are engaging in this process of redress because the loss of land not only brought about poverty, but also the indignity of living without land in the place of one’s birth. Land was a source of income, a place to graze livestock and raise crops.

President #Ramaphosa: The other restitution settlements are for the Mathabe family from Boekenhoutskloof, the Franspoort community, the Msiza family from Hondsrivier, the Kafferskraal community, the Mahlangu & Ntuli families from Tweefontein, and the Rodman community.pic.twitter.com/JVcyldEK4Y

President #Ramaphosa: In other cases, the land has been extensively developed as either industrial or residential areas. These are the Dukathole community from Driefontein in Ekurhuleni and the Ebenezer Congregational Church in Johannesburg. #OurLandOurHeritage
President #Ramaphosa: In some instances, the claimants had settled elsewhere and are not in a position to start a new settlement #OurLandOurHeritage

President #Ramaphosa: It represents the righting of a grave wrong and provides this community an opportunity to reap the benefits of a valuable asset. In the nine other restitution settlements that we are celebrating today, the claimants chose to receive financial compensation.

President #Ramaphosa: Descendants of these families qualify for restitution of rights to the land as they occupied the farm for continuous periods of more than 10 years. The act of returning the land to these families is therefore both symbolic and material. #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/OKYRjKxaYU

President #Ramaphosa: He arrived there in 1936 with his family and they acquired labour tenancy rights on the land. The family was dispossessed of the land they had occupied in 1960 when they were told to move to places reserved for black people. #OurLandOurHeritage

President #Ramaphosa: They were given 14 days to remove their livestock from the farm. Oral evidence found that Kaflaan Andries Mahlangu was the first person from the Mahlangu family to occupy the piece of land that is now on portion 66 of the farm Klipkop. #OurLandOurHeritage

President #Ramaphosa: A piece of evidence proving the legitimacy of their occupation and their forceful removal was a letter written by the attorneys of a Mr Zwick which stated that all ‘bantu’ people at Klipkoppies were occupying the farm illegally. #OurLandOurHeritage

President #Ramaphosa: The painful stories of these two families echo across the country in a thousand different places, where people were deprived of their birthright, their land and their livelihoods. The Malobola family lived on the farm known as Klipklop from the 1800s.
President #Ramaphosa: It was found that the Malobolo family occupied the land in question from the 1800s to 1967 and the Mahlangu family from 1936 to 1960. #OurLandOurHeritage

President #Ramaphosa: The ancestors of these families held informal or unregistered rights to the property in question and a painstaking process was followed to verify their claims. #OurLandOurHeritage

President #Ramaphosa: Today, we are handing over the title deed to the Klipkop-Nanduna Communal Property Association on behalf of the descendants of the Mahlangu and Malobola families. #OurLandOurHeritagepic.twitter.com/eG9ZhvRGZS

President #Ramaphosa: We have been work closely across a number of government departments and agencies to ensure that more and more of these outstanding claims are addressed speedily. #OurLandOurHeritage

President #Ramaphosa: We are settling land claims, returning the land to those communities and families from whom it was taken, and thereby providing the restitution that our Constitution requires. #OurLandOurHeritage

President #Ramaphosa: We appreciate the patience and the perseverance of claimants, but recognise that much more needs to be done and with greater urgency. Today is part of a process that will cover the length and breadth of this country. #OurLandOurHeritage

President #Ramaphosa: We are today celebrating the settlement of ten land claims in Gauteng that were lodged before 31 December 1998. Many of our people have waited for far too long for this process of land restitution and compensation to be completed. #OurLandOurHeritage

WATCH LIVE: President @CyrilRamaphosa addresses the Gauteng Land Restitution Ceremony at the Moretele Recreation Park, Mamelodi in the City of Tshwane. #DignityThroughLand #OurLandOurHeritagehttps://twitter.com/CyrilRamaphosa/status/1104317794798186497 …

President #Ramaphosa: A Presidential Advisory Panel has also been appointed to provide expert advice to assist the inter-ministerial committee. By restoring the land to our people, we are determined that agricultural production should increase and food security shoud improve.

President #Ramaphosa: We are guided by the rule of law and by the transformative principles of our Constitution. We have also established an inter-ministerial committee, as led by the Deputy President, to oversee the accelerate land reform process. #OurLandOurHeritage

President #Ramaphosa: As a result of these hearings and consultations with a number of experts, Parliament has embarked on a process to amend the Constitution to explicitly set out the circumstances in which land may be expropriated without compensation. #OurLandOurHeritage
President #Ramaphosa: You will recall that Members of Parliament travelled throughout our country to hear what South Africans had to say about the law and the pace of land reform. #OurLandOurHeritage
President #Ramaphosa: We have embarked on a programme of accelerated land reform, which, among other things, has required that we assess the existing legislative framework. #OurLandOurHeritage

President #Ramaphosa: It is important that we approach this task in an integrated and comprehensive manner – covering restitution, redistribution and tenure reform – to ensure that the land can be shared among those who work it and among those who need it. #OurLandOurHeritage
President #Ramaphosa: Land reform is mandated by our Constitution and necessitated by our past. #OurLandOurHeritage

President #Ramaphosa: It is a great honour to address this important ceremony where we celebrate the settlement of land claims. This is a vital part of our national effort to correct the past injustice of land dispossessions. #OurLandOurHeritage

"Through an accelerated programme of land reform, we will work to expand our agricultural output and promote economic inclusion. Our policy and legislative interventions will ensure that more land is made available for agriculture, industrial development and human settlements...”pic.twitter.com/gTm8wT7KJz

President #Ramaphosa: The people of South Africa are looking to the Black Business Council, as they are to all business formations, to provide leadership as we work together to radically transform our economy and build a future in which all may prosper. #BlackBusinessSummitpic.twitter.com/tqq94A4iUS
President #Ramaphosa: Now is the time for engagement, now is the time for dialogue. Now is the time to confront challenges and resolve differences. #BlackBusinessSummit
President #Ramaphosa: The imperative of meaningful black economic empowerment must be embraced by the entire business community, in equal measure and with equal enthusiasm. #BlackBusinessSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Coherence does not mean capitulation or acquiescence by black business to the perpetuation of exclusion. It means raising the bar for all of business to strive for true economic inclusion. #BlackBusinessSummitpic.twitter.com/MEJP6jbnRL

President #Ramaphosa: Coherence does not mean capitulation or acquiescence by black business to the perpetuation of exclusion. It means raising the bar for all of business to strive for true economic inclusion. #BlackBusinessSummitpic.twitter.com/eUTtaupZYK
President #Ramaphosa: Unless business is able to speak with one coherent voice, we will struggle to build that social compact. #BlackBusinessSummit

President #Ramaphosa: South Africa will not achieve the inclusive growth we seek unless we are able to forge a durable social compact that brings together all social partners behind a shared economic programme. #BlackBusinessSummit

President #Ramaphosa: We need to prioritise #unity within organised business. Fragmentation within the business community does not serve the interests of business, nor does it serve the interests of broader society. #BlackBusinessSummitpic.twitter.com/4O7oMMikOP

President #Ramaphosa: We have begun to rebuild public institutions, restore investor confidence, strengthen mechanisms to tackle corruption and rebuild an economy that had been severely impacted by the criminal actions of a few. #BlackBusinessSummitpic.twitter.com/gWdMR1IMRH

President #Ramaphosa: We have strengthened our law enforcement agencies to ensure that all allegations are thoroughly investigated and action taken against those who are implicated. #BlackBusinessSummit

President #Ramaphosa: We have made important progress in establishing the nature and extent of this #corruption, and there is clearly much more work that needs to be done to expose each and every manifestation of state capture. #BlackBusinessSummitpic.twitter.com/mqQzULnIdq

President #Ramaphosa: The details emerging from the #Zondo Commission of Inquiry and other commissions, through investigations by agencies of the state and through the media, reveal a concerted criminal effort that threatened to undermine the foundations of our democratic order.pic.twitter.com/SrnLlgjimE
President #Ramaphosa: As a country, we are having to confront the devastating impact of state capture on our institutions, our economy and our people. #BlackBusinessSummit
President #Ramaphosa: By giving the competition authorities the means to address high levels of economic concentration, we are laying the foundation for a more inclusive future. #BlackBusinessSummit
President #Ramaphosa: Not only does it strengthen existing legislation – it seeks to further diversify our economy by promoting effective participation of small businesses. #BlackBusinessSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Just two weeks ago, I signed into law the Competition Amendment Act, which seeks to remove the constraints to more competition, more innovation, more new businesses and more choice for consumers. #BlackBusinessSummitpic.twitter.com/D0pnvhjuYr

President #Ramaphosa: It is for this reason that we are establishing the Presidential Commission on the #4IR, which will identify relevant policies, strategies and action plans that will position South Africa as a competitive global player. #BlackBusinessSummitpic.twitter.com/PCub0jsFli

President #Ramaphosa: It also means that we need to develop a coherent national strategy that mitigates the risks and seizes the opportunities of the 4th industrial revolution. #BlackBusinessSummit #4IR
President #Ramaphosa: Among other things, this means we need to embrace lifelong learning, enabling working people to skill, re-skill and up-skill throughout their lives. #BlackBusinessSummit

President #Ramaphosa: The technological changes of the 4th industrial revolution, alongside the effects of demographic shifts and climate change, are having a profound and increasingly uncertain impact on production, employment and social relations. #BlackBusinessSummit #4IR

President #Ramaphosa: We are combining our focus on improving the quality of #education outcomes with programmes to get young people working, from the employment tax incentive to the #YouthEmploymentService to government’s various public employment programmes #BlackBusinessSummitpic.twitter.com/okITwwwUJh

President #Ramaphosa: The number of black South Africans enrolled at universities increased from around 330,000 in 1995 to over 800,000 in 2016. Last year, over 78% of learners passed matric, up from around 50% in the 1990s. #BlackBusinessSummitpic.twitter.com/x86orNmmOZ

President #Ramaphosa: #Education provides the means through which young black South Africans can break the cycle of intergenerational poverty and challenge the racial and gender distribution of wealth and opportunity. #BlackBusinessSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Alongside the creation of jobs and support for the emergence of black-owned companies, the most effective form of broad-based black economic empowerment is education and skills development. #BlackBusinessSummitpic.twitter.com/CORQwOu5Cg

President #Ramaphosa: This includes reducing the cost of sourcing coal, reprioritising capital expenditure, driving cost efficient procurement, growing revenue through pricing incentives and improving workforce efficiency. #BlackBusinessSummit
President #Ramaphosa: Eskom has developed a detailed turnaround plan to address its structural, operational and financial challenges. #BlackBusinessSummit
President #Ramaphosa: As indicated during #SONA2019 , we are taking urgent measures to stabilise the generation of electricity and address #Eskom’s dire financial position. #BlackBusinessSummit

President #Ramaphosa: The crisis at #Eskom has now been made painfully apparent to every South African, and there can be no doubt that bold and decisive action is required to restore the performance of the utility. #BlackBusinessSummitpic.twitter.com/4d3X2InfIG

President #Ramaphosa: The development of our industrial capacity – to satisfy both increased local demand and greater exports – is dependent on the uninterrupted supply of electricity. #BlackBusinessSummit

President #Ramaphosa: As these black-owned companies succeed, there is an expectation that they will support the emergence of new black companies, create #employment, contribute their due to the public fiscus, and that they will be good corporate citizens. #BlackBusinessSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Since the programme began in 2016, over 130 black industrialists have been supported. Many of the companies are still constrained by high barriers of entry, limited marketing capacity, saturated markets, high transaction costs and poor market research.pic.twitter.com/o9ZbogGvmW

President #Ramaphosa: The black industrialists programme is one of several instruments we are using to ensure that emerging black business people are able both to benefit from, and contribute to, the growth of our productive economy. #BlackBusinessSummit
President #Ramaphosa: We will simultaneously expand our export capacity through industrial incentives, special economic zones and investment in rail and port infrastructure. #BlackBusinessSummit

President #Ramaphosa: There is huge potential for corporate South Africa, in particular, to nurture the emergence of a new generation of black-owned businesses to meet their supply chain needs. #BlackBusinessSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Through the #JobsSummit agreement, business has also committed to increasing the proportion of goods it procures locally. This will require a coordinated effort to develop supplier networks and support programmes. #BlackBusinessSummit

President #Ramaphosa: In the coming months, government will publish a new #PublicProcurementBill for public comment. This provides an opportunity for government to further leverage public expenditure for growth, development and black economic empowerment. #BlackBusinessSummit

President #Ramaphosa: As we refine our procurement policies, we will ensure that there are set asides for black industrialists, and improved demand and market access as part of the localisation programme. #BlackBusinessSummit

President #Ramaphosa: One of the most important instruments we have is public procurement, which has the potential to stimulate the local economy in terms of aggregate demand, production, innovation, technology transfer, research and development. #BlackBusinessSummitpic.twitter.com/bgEJHUIpEq

President #Ramaphosa: There needs to be a substantial and deliberate shift in the buying patterns of both the state and the private sector towards locally-produced goods. #BlackBusinessSummit #BuyLocal

President #Ramaphosa: In our engagements with social partners in preparation for the #JobsSummit, we agreed on the need to promote growth by increasing local demand for goods and services. BlackBusinessSummit
President #Ramaphosa: It is why we have moved towards policy certainty in areas like mining, energy and telecommunications and are reforming our visa regime. #BlackBusinessSummit

President #Ramaphosa: It is why we have set ourselves the ambitious target of being among the top 50 global performers in the World Bank’s #DoingBusinessReport within the next 3 years. #BlackBusinessSummit

President #Ramaphosa: We must prioritise measures that promote growth, and, in particular, inclusive growth. It is for that reason that we have focused our efforts in recent months in mobilising far greater levels of investment in the productive economy. #BlackBusinessSummit

President #Ramaphosa: It is therefore essential that in the design of our policies and in the development of our programmes, we prioritise those measures that will create jobs and avoid any measures that will constrain job creation. #BlackBusinessSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Employment creation on a massive scale is the most effective, most durable and most impactful form of broad-based black economic empowerment we could undertake. It is the platform on which all other interventions must be built. #BlackBusinessSummitpic.twitter.com/9bNjDM039n

President #Ramaphosa: Creating jobs for the 9 million South Africans who are unemployed is without doubt the greatest contribution we can make to the advancement of radical economic transformation. #BlackBusinessSummit #MoreJobs #MoreDecentJobs
President #Ramaphosa: As we focus on the work that we must do to undertake these tasks, our greatest preoccupation must be the creation of employment. #BlackBusinessSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Growth will not be inclusive for as long as women have fewer opportunities for employment, skills development and advancement; for as long as they are less likely to start a business, access finance or own assets. #BlackBusinessSummitpic.twitter.com/YgleyotD7T

President #Ramaphosa: It requires not only that we remove the barriers that for generations have kept black South Africans from meaningful participation in the economy, but also that we remove the structural, cultural, social and other constraints. #BlackBusinessSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Black economic empowerment cannot be reduced to a set of codes of good practice, or to a commission, or to a procurement policy. Black economic empowerment is the fundamental task of our time. #BlackBusinessSummit

President #Ramaphosa: At the centre of all these efforts, is the advancement of broad-based black economic empowerment. That is what we mean by inclusive growth. That is what we mean by radical economic transformation. #BlackBusinessSummitpic.twitter.com/fbudEUM8WL
President #Ramaphosa: We are restoring public confidence in our institutions and rebuilding the partnerships necessary to chart a new trajectory.

President #Ramaphosa: We meet at a critical moment for our country. We are emerging from a period of great difficulty and uncertainty. We are putting in place the foundation for a sustained economic revival that will create jobs and accelerate growth. #BlackBusinessSummit

President #Ramaphosa: We look to the Black Business Council to provide leadership in our collective effort to build an inclusive economy, a growing economy, a fundamentally transformed economy. #BlackBusinessSummit

President #Ramaphosa: It is always a great privilege to be invited to speak at gatherings of the Black Business Council, because within these walls are assembled the women and men who are the custodians of a proud tradition of courageous business leadership. #BlackBusinessSummit

President @CyrilRamaphosa presenting the ten recommendations of @ILO’s Global Commission Report on the Future of Work at the Zimbali Hotel Fairmont Conference Centre in KwaZulu-Natal. #FutureofWork #MoreDecentJobspic.twitter.com/qdVgm1SBnp

President @CyrilRamaphosa co-chaired @ILO’s #FutureofWork Report which is centred on a human agenda that strengthens the social contract by placing people and the work they do at the centre of economic and social policy and business practice. #MoreDecentJobspic.twitter.com/T5Pv2b4CwA

Address by President Cyril #Ramaphosa at the Launch of the Report of the ILO Global Commission on the #FutureOfWork, Fairmont Zimbali Hotel, KwaDukuza. https://bit.ly/2H9Qyrg pic.twitter.com/KLVsFUMTht

President @CyrilRamaphosa with President Hage Geingob of the Republic of Namibia and SADC Chair and @ILO DG Mr Guy Ryder, at the country launch of the Global Commission on the #FutureofWork Report at the Zimbali Hotel Fairmont Conference Centre in KZN.pic.twitter.com/gRabdqy2mV

President #Ramaphosa: The #FutureofWork report is the fruit of the labour of many people, from governments, to worker formations, business, NGOs, regional, continental and international bodies. We thank you for your inputs, which have been valuable as they have been insightful.pic.twitter.com/CODN6CSj04

President #Ramaphosa: This report is not exhaustive and is really opening the door on what we hope to be a bigger conversation around ensuring the principle of social justice is advanced in the world of work. #FutureofWork

President #Ramaphosa: The third pillar of our human-centred agenda is investment in decent and sustainable work. We must increase long-term investment in areas that support the transformation we want, favour human development and protect the planet. #FutureofWork #MoreDecentJobspic.twitter.com/sgfXfT5txV

President #Ramaphosa: Our second pillar is increasing investment in the institutions of work. This extends to institutions, systems & regulations. We propose establishing a Universal Labour Guarantee that would guarantee fundamental workers’ rights. #FutureofWork #MoreDecentJobs

President #Ramaphosa: This includes more gender-balanced measures around child care & family responsibilities; more transparency in pay; eliminating violence &harassment in the workplace & specific measures to ensure equal opportunities, particularly in the technology sector.

President #Ramaphosa: We also need more support for work transitions, both through different stages of workers’ careers and when they move between types of work. Gender equality must also be made a reality through taking transformative, measurable steps. #FutureofWork #MoreJobs

President #Ramaphosa: When we talk about investing in the capabilities of people, we mean more than simply investing in human capital. We recognise that it is necessary to consider human development more broadly – dealing with factors such as rights, access and opportunities.pic.twitter.com/zX3hXjehDA

President #Ramaphosa: If we are to harness changes for our benefit, we need a new approach. The report proposes 10 recommendations, grouped into 3 pillars: investing in people's capabilities; investing in institutions of the world of work & investing in decent, sustainable work

President #Ramaphosa: It speaks to the need to put people at the heart of economic and social policy and business practices. Our starting point was this: dynamic forces are transforming the world of work. This offers remarkable opportunities, but also challenges. #FutureofWork

President #Ramaphosa: The report’s findings are informed by dialogues between government representatives, employers’ organisations and trade unions in more than 110 of the member states of the ILO. #FutureofWork #MoreDecentJobs

President #Ramaphosa: In drafting the report, we have chosen not to single out technology ahead of all transformative forces. We have instead focused on what needs to be done to create the best future for the greatest number of people in a fundamentally different world of work.pic.twitter.com/I0yik3AWep

President #Ramaphosa: It is the question of how to manage and harness these forces currently transforming our world that has given impetus to the ILO Global Commission on the Future of Work. #FutureofWork #MoreDecentJobs

President #Ramaphosa: The impacts of globalisation, demographic shifts, trade and other forms of protectionism, and climate change are bound to have consequences for future work processes. #FutureofWork #MoreDecentJobs

President #Ramaphosa: Elsewhere, rapid technological advance has had its own consequences for workers, with digitisation and mechanisation of work processes giving rise to increased insecurity. #FutureofWork

President #Ramaphosa: Millions of people around the world are in a working poverty trap. In many societies, working people still labour in antiquated working conditions that have little regard to their rights, with forced indenture and even forms of servitude and bondage common.

President #Ramaphosa: It has been a vital instrument for the good of working people the world over, and brought decency, dignity and pride to the workplace. However, and despite our advances, the world we live in today faces a number of challenges. Inequality is rising.pic.twitter.com/EkmIneHjQx

President #Ramaphosa: To borrow the words that Martin Luther King Jnr used to describe the labour movement in the United States, the ILO has been a force that has transformed misery and despair into hope and progress. #FutureofWork #MoreDecentJobs

President #Ramaphosa: It is a world where men and women in the workplace are equals before the law and protected from prejudice and injustice. It is a human-centred society anchored in the principles of social justice – the vision of @ILO. #FutureofWork #MoreDecentJobs

President #Ramaphosa: We are seeking to build a world where work does not result in the commodification of the human being, but in a higher standard of living, protection of rights, and the possibility for advancement. #FutureofWork #MoreDecentJobs

President #Ramaphosa: Our countries were built by the hands of hard-working men and women. Our collective fortunes depend on the creation of a society where every human being is accorded dignity both through, and in, work. #FutureofWork #MoreDecentJobs

President #Ramaphosa: This history – indeed the entire history of the anti-apartheid struggle – underscores the centrality of workers – of their rights, of their conditions of work, and of their general well-being – to the success and prosperity of any society. #FutureofWork

President #Ramaphosa: In fighting against these injustices in the workplace, in fighting for their rights, the workers of Durban gave hope and encouragement to the broader struggle for national liberation. #FutureofWork #MoreDecentJobs

President #Ramaphosa: It was black workers who bore the brunt of discrimination in the workplace. Working and living conditions were poor, and wages were even poorer. Job reservation kept black workers out of higher-paying jobs. Trade unionism was severely curtailed #FutureofWork

President #Ramaphosa: After years of repression and illegality, a wave of strikes by black workers led to the resurgence of the independent trade union movement in South Africa, and gave new impetus to the struggle against apartheid. #FutureofWork #MoreDecentJobs
President #Ramaphosa: It was here in KwaZulu-Natal, in the nearby city of Durban, that a watershed moment in the struggle for worker’s rights took place in 1973. #FutureofWork #MoreDecentJobs

President #Ramaphosa: This year, South Africa is celebrating 25 years of freedom and democracy – a democracy that was won in no small part through the sustained struggle of workers. #FutureofWork #MoreDecentJobs #Democracy25

President #Ramaphosa: This year is the centenary of the International Labour Organization. It is the 60th year of the ILO’s presence in Africa and the African Regional Labour Administration Centre is holding its 45th Governing Council. #FutureofWork #MoreDecentJobs #ILO100
WATCH: Presentation of the #FutureofWork Report of the ILO Global Commission by President @CyrilRamaphosa #MoreDecentJobshttps://twitter.com/CyrilRamaphosa/status/1101391614134636544 …
The #FutureofWork report further recommends transformative investments, in line with the United Nations 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. #MoreJobs #MoreDecentJobspic.twitter.com/DxfDOMCqRe

The recommendations contained in the report seek to strengthen and revitalize the institutions of work - the building blocks of just societies. They forge pathways to formalization, reduce working poverty and secure a #FutureofWork with dignity, economic security and equality.pic.twitter.com/bW8bPYVRT1

In enabling people to thrive in the digital age, the report goes beyond human capital, to broader dimensions of development & progress in living standards, including the rights and enabling environment that widen people’s opportunities and improve their well-being. #FutureofWorkpic.twitter.com/QF5BHQfoYQ

The report proposes a human-centred agenda for the #FutureofWork that strengthens the social contract by placing people and the work they do at the centre of economic and social policy & business practice. #MoreJobs #MoreDecentJobspic.twitter.com/MbnmyoKOIK

“Our aspiration is for the report to portray the urgency of the changes that the world of work is facing & provide ideas on how to manage and leverage these transformations.” Co-Chair of the Global Commission on the #FutureofWork President @CyrilRamaphosa http://bit.ly/2T7PQ0u pic.twitter.com/vJ2lkPgsPy

The launch of the report takes place alongside the 45th session of the African Regional Labour Administration Council (ARLAC), a gathering of labour ministers and other delegates from 19 African countries under the theme 'Towards Gender Equality in the #FutureofWork’. #MoreJobspic.twitter.com/NvgQLK083K

The Global Commission on the #FutureofWork had been tasked to identify challenges and make recommendations that will sustain and protect the livelihood of workers around the world amid the proliferation of the #4IR, climate change and the changing world. #MoreDecentJobspic.twitter.com/aMbVIiJr4I

Today’s country launch comes after President @CyrilRamaphosa & Swedish Prime Minister Stefan Löfven co-chaired the Global Commission whose report was launched by President Ramaphosa at the @ILO headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland on January 22. #MoreDecentJobs #FutureofWorkpic.twitter.com/qjjEvQ7h4j

President @CyrilRamaphosa is this morning officiating at the South Africa launch of the International Labour Organisation's (ILO) Global Commission on the #FutureofWork #MoreJobs #MoreDecentJobspic.twitter.com/ON1rilES2p
Address by President Cyril Ramaphosa at the official opening of the Vedanta #GamsbergMine, Aggeneys, Northern Cape http://bit.ly/2UeVui4 #InvestinSAMiningpic.twitter.com/mUFCKF9t1c

President #Ramaphosa: We are committed to working with investors to ensure that the industry grows sustainably, is transformed and competitive, and makes a substantial contribution to an inclusive and growing economy. #InvestinSAMining #InvestS #MoreDecentJobspic.twitter.com/7tsgmjhUye

President #Ramaphosa: The operation that we are opening today gives us confidence that the future of mining is bright. It gives us confidence that we can develop an industry that benefits communities as much as it produces returns for shareholders. #InvestinSAMining #InvestSApic.twitter.com/kQv7as1hl2

President #Ramaphosa: They must consult with community leaders and stakeholders to identify specific developmental priorities and develop social and labour plans which speak to the needs of the community. #InvestInSAMining #InvestSA #MoreDecentJobs

President #Ramaphosa: The new Mining Charter enjoins mining companies to work with communities where they operate to address the social and environmental challenges facing such communities. #InvestinSAMining

President #Ramaphosa: We commend Vedanta on the R44 million it spent last year on training and social projects aimed at skills development, health, enterprise development and municipal infrastructure support. This was accompanied by R77.5 million spent on local enterprises.pic.twitter.com/gr0rk2f9PD

President #Ramaphosa: Investing in the workforce, in youth and women, education & training, and partnering with government in improving local infrastructure, are some of the key defining features of a mining company that demonstrates good corporate citizenship. #InvestinSAMiningpic.twitter.com/DSriayjePA

President #Ramaphosa: During #MiningIndaba2019, I outlined ten value-creating principles for a more modern mining industry. For mining to be sustainable in the long-term, it is crucial that companies prioritise the contribution of mining operations to the communities. #InvestSApic.twitter.com/rUE86BL0bi

President #Ramaphosa: Vedanta is well-poised to become a pioneer in the mining industry’s efforts to harness technological progress not only to survive, but also to thrive. #InvestinSAMining #MoreDecentJobs

President #Ramaphosa: We are confident that Vedanta will use technology not to replace human beings with machines but to fundamentally improve efficiency, guarantee safety, produce a skilled workforce and, most importantly, preserve jobs. #InvestinSAMining

President #Ramaphosa: Given that the Fourth Industrial Revolution is set to significantly alter the way the mining sector operates, it is noteworthy that Gamsberg is considered one of the most digitally advanced mines in SA. #4IR #InvestSA #InvestinSAMining #MoreDecentJobs

President #Ramaphosa: This investment will change the economic landscape of this region and contribute to much-needed social development. Government is committed to partner with Vedanta in realising the benefits of this investment for the company, its employees & communities.

President #Ramaphosa: The investments that have already been made here, when taken together with the anticipated investments in further phases, will improve South Africa’s position as a global player in zinc production. #InvestinSAMining

President #Ramaphosa: We need to intensify research and increase investment in mineral beneficiation. The proposed creation of a smelter-refinery complex in Gamsberg will create opportunities for value-adding zinc beneficiation in the Khai-Ma municipality. #InvestinSAMining

President #Ramaphosa: Beneficiation of minerals can play a huge role in this. We must therefore move away from the “pit to port approach” where resources mined here are transported out of the country as raw as they are from along the Sishen-Saldanha route. #InvestinSAMining

President #Ramaphosa: While development in the Northern Cape is hampered by the great distances between economic centres – and mining operations – there is nevertheless great opportunity for mining to be a catalyst for broader economic expansion. #InvestinSAMining #MoreDecentJobs
President #Ramaphosa: It contributes just 2% of South Africa’s GDP and has an expanded unemployment rate of around 39%. Mining offers an opportunity to fundamentally change this. #InvestinSAMining

President #Ramaphosa: This area of the Northern Cape hosts significant deposits of lead-zinc ores associated with copper and silver. It is also home to manganese, iron ore and diamonds. And yet, this province remains underdeveloped. #InvestinSAMining

President #Ramaphosa: We are here to say ‘thank you’ to Vedanta for the enthusiasm with which you have embraced our ambitious investment drive. It is gratifying to see the commitments made at the Investment Conference taking form across our country. #InvestinSAMining #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: Vedanta Resources was one of the companies that heeded our call during the inaugural South Africa Investment Conference in October last year to partner with us as we pursue higher levels of inclusive growth and employment. #InvestSA #InvestinSAMining

President #Ramaphosa: #MiningIndaba2019 demonstrated the high level of interest shown by investors in our country &continent. We are keen to work with the industry to improve the investment climate and improve the ease with which mining companies do business. #InvestinSAMining

President #Ramaphosa: We are confident that we will see more mining projects of this magnitude as many more investors, like Vedanta, see the great potential not only in mining, but also across the South African economy. #InvestinSAMining
President #Ramaphosa: The finalisation of the Mining Charter has brought about far greater certainty and stability, a necessary condition for investment on the scale that we seek. #InvestinSAMining

President #Ramaphosa: We welcome Vedanta as a partner committed to help us achieve our development goals in a manner that is sustainable and inclusive. We also pay tribute to the people and leadership of this region who joined hands with Vedanta to secure a better future for all.

President #Ramaphosa: South Africa has vast undeveloped mineral deposits that we have the opportunity to exploit for the benefit of all our people. We welcome this investment by Vedanta, which signals its confidence in the future of our mining industry. #InvestinSAMining

President #Ramaphosa: The #GamsbergMine is an important step in our journey to revive the industry & confirms our view - with an effective regulatory framework, stakeholder collaboration & sustained investment, mining has the potential to be a sunrise industry. #InvestinSAMining
