President #Ramaphosa: The #PWGD gives us an opportunity to identify catalytic interventions that will change the lives of persons with disabilities meaningfully, regardless of race, age, gender, socio-economic status, type and severity of impairment, or geographical location.pic.twitter.com/loeVL6qEp7

President #Ramaphosa: Last week, I participated in the #NHTLDebate. Participants strongly raised their concerns about the provision of facilities and services to persons with disabilities in areas under traditional authority in particular and rural areas more broadly. #PWGDpic.twitter.com/HLnObbdjRz

President #Ramaphosa: We are working to ensure that persons with disabilities have equitable access to education, health services, employment, social security and all the opportunities that come with the benefits of living in a democracy. #PWGDpic.twitter.com/ReXz54OyCW

President #Ramaphosa: Every state organ must be reporting substantively on the inclusion of people with disability within their respective mandates. We are working with renewed vigour and commitment to ensure that people with disabilities are a part of a cohesive society. #PWGD

President #Ramaphosa: We are committed to ensure that the interests and rights of persons with disabilities are effectively mainstreamed across all departments in the next #MTSF for 2020-2025, accompanied by an integrated information system to track performance against targets.pic.twitter.com/gy2HIk9U6k

President #Ramaphosa: The Disability Report in the 2011 Census, estimates that there are approximately 2.8 million persons with disabilities in South Africa. President Cyril Ramaphosa arriving in Parliament earlier this afternoon to address the annual official Opening of the National House of Traditional Leaders (NHTL) in the Old Assembly Chamber in Parliament, Cape Town. #NHTLOpeningpic.twitter.com/GKzYZtLhm2
Address by President Cyril #Ramaphosa at the Annual Opening of the National House of Traditional Leaders, Parliament, Cape Town. #NHTLOpening https://bit.ly/2NcqlJi pic.twitter.com/FZnKEacHiz
President #Ramaphosa: It continues to be a beacon of hope for millions and a powerful instrument to assist in transforming the lives of people in rural areas for better. #NHTLOpening

President #Ramaphosa: As government, we appreciate the strong working relationship we have developed to address those issues that most affect our people. The institution of traditional leadership is an integral part of our nation’s past, its present and its future. #NHTLOpeningpic.twitter.com/ODngR9ul6w
President #Ramaphosa: Allow me to conclude by thanking the leadership of the National House of Traditional Leaders for the exemplary leadership you continue to provide to society. #NHTLOpening
President #Ramaphosa: In just under 3 months time, on 8 May, South Africans will go to the polls in national and provincial elections. #NHTLOpeningpic.twitter.com/lXAgKENgIQ

President #Ramaphosa: Members may be aware of the task team set up with officials from Traditional Affairs, the National House, the Independent Commission on the Remuneration of Public Office Bearers and the Presidency to consider matters relating to remuneration. #NHTLOpening
President #Ramaphosa: This is a historic piece of legislation, which will, for the first time, give statutory recognition to the Khoi-San. #NHTLOpening

President #Ramaphosa: We welcome the progress that has been made in Parliament with the passage of the Traditional and Khoi-San Leadership Bill, which has been placed on the order paper of the National Assembly. #NHTLOpeningpic.twitter.com/H3XPFmzHhS

President #Ramaphosa: This process should address the issues raised by Prince Buthelezi during the #SONADebate last week around a legal framework for cooperation between government and traditional leaders and section 81 of the Municipal Structures Act. #NHTLOpening

President #Ramaphosa: The Department of Traditional Affairs has also established a task team together with traditional leaders, led by Nkosi Nonkonyana, to make proposals on the powers and functions of traditional leaders and any amendments to legislation. #NHTLOpening

President #Ramaphosa: The fifth task we identified in the #SONA2019 is to strengthen the capacity of the state to address the needs of the people. This means that there needs to be effective coordination across all spheres, departments and institutions. #NHTLOpening

President #Ramaphosa: This means that we need to strengthen democratic institutions, establish suitable checks and balances, and increase transparency and accountability throughout society. Traditional leaders must be an essential part of this effort. #NHTLOpeningpic.twitter.com/esCQnnaqZW

President #Ramaphosa: Our priority must be to uncover all of these networks and expose their activities, bring those responsible to book, recover all stolen funds and take decisive measures to ensure this never happens again. #NHTLOpening

President #Ramaphosa: We have heard of extensive networks of corruption that have diminished public institutions and stolen funds meant for the development of our country, funds destined for the poor and vulnerable. #NHTLOpening
President #Ramaphosa: The evidence that has emerged in recent months about the nature and extent of corruption must be a cause of great concern to all South Africans. #NHTLOpening
President #Ramaphosa: The fourth task we identified in the State of the Nation Address was to step up the fight against corruption and state capture. #NHTLOpening

President #Ramaphosa: The Minister of @NationalCOGTA informed me that in December & January he held meetings with Kings in the Eastern Cape to explore ways of addressing initiation deaths while the Customary Initiation Bill is still being processed. #NHTLOpening
President #Ramaphosa: It is anticipated that once the bill is passed into law, it will assist greatly in bringing to an end the deaths of initiates. #NHTLOpening

President #Ramaphosa: We are happy with the progress on the Customary Initiation Bill and look forward to the finalisation of all the Parliamentary processes so that the Bill can be passed into law. #NHTLOpening

President #Ramaphosa: We look to traditional leaders to work with government and communities to find solutions to the needless death of young males during initiation schools. This ancient rite of passage should never be allowed to become synonymous with death and serious injury.

President #Ramaphosa: We were particularly pleased that a delegation of traditional leaders – led by the Deputy Chairperson of the House, Nkosikazi Nomandla Dorothy Mhlauli, Ahh Nosandi! – attended the Presidential Summit on Gender-Based Violence & Femicide held in November 2018.

President #Ramaphosa: To end the scourge of gender-based violence and femicide requires that we collectively conduct a public education campaign that confronts the persistence of patriarchal values and practices. #NHTLOpening

President #Ramaphosa: We applaud the role traditional leaders play in confronting gender based violence. The National House is a critical partner on issues of gender based violence, femicide, violence perpetrated against the LGBTQI+ community & other vulnerable groups.

President #Ramaphosa: We ask you to support the efforts to improve health facilities in rural areas and encourage communities to demand improved care. The #NHI aims to ensure all South Africans have access to quality health care. #NHTLOpeningpic.twitter.com/10ot3hdeTP

President #Ramaphosa: We have embarked on a broad consultative process to significantly improve the quality of care at public health facilities – many of which are in crisis – as we put in place the pillars of a National Health Insurance. #NHTLOpening

President #Ramaphosa: As we move to initiate 2 million more people on antiretrovirals, it is critical that traditional leaders mobilise rural people to access the services and to remain in treatment to prolong their lives and also to reduce the chances of transmitting #HIV.
President #Ramaphosa: Another area where we have made progress is in improving access to rural health facilities and especially to HIV and TB treatment. #NHTLOpeningpic.twitter.com/mRUD8Fonps

President #Ramaphosa: One of the most important mechanisms to address rural poverty in recent years has been the provision of social security grants, and we commend the Department of Social Development and their partners for continuing to provide this essential social service.
President #Ramaphosa: The third task we identified in the State of the Nation Address, was to improve the conditions of life for all South Africans, especially the poor. #NHTLOpening

President #Ramaphosa: We are also working to ensure that programmes like the Youth Employment Service promote work experience opportunities outside of urban centres. We need to promote access to employment and economic opportunities for people with disabilities in rural areas.
President #Ramaphosa: Because #TVET colleges have a greater reach into rural areas than universities, they offer far more opportunities for skills development for rural youth. #NHTLOpening

President #Ramaphosa: While we improve the quality and accessibility of schooling in rural areas, we are also investing resources and effort into developing #TVET colleges into sites of technical and vocational training excellence. #NHTLOpening

President #Ramaphosa: One of the tasks we share is to ensure that young people living in rural areas receive both the education and skills they need where they live and that they find economic opportunities in rural areas. #NHTLOpening

President #Ramaphosa: To ensure that learners in rural areas are not left behind by the digital revolution, the first phase of our programme to provide digitised text books and work books on tablets will target multigrade, multiphase, farm and selected rural schools from 2020.pic.twitter.com/e9U9Hqkp4F

President #Ramaphosa: Rural schools are benefiting in particular from the Accelerated Schools Infrastructure Delivery Initiative and from the #SAFEinitiative, which is working to replace pit toilets in nearly 4,000 schools with safe and age appropriate sanitation facilities.

President #Ramaphosa: The second task that we identified in #SONA2019 is to improve the education system & develop the skills that we need now and into the future. Education is the key to development and prosperity, and it is essential that no child in the country is left behind.
President #Ramaphosa: We agree that tourism projects in rural communities should form part of the investment books that we are developing to present to potential investors. #NHTLOpening
President #Ramaphosa: The Departments of Arts & Culture and Tourism stand ready to work with traditional authorities to have these sites identified and brought to economic life. #NHTLOpening

President #Ramaphosa: During #SONA2019, we announced our plan to double the number of tourists by 2030. Tourism has great potential for job creation & enterprise development, through food, construction, transport, retail, and the creative and cultural industries. #NHTLOpening

President #Ramaphosa: Issues around mining licences, environmental impact assessments, water use licences, surface lease agreements, social and labour plans and transformation must be enforced to the benefit of the communities in which mining operations takes place.pic.twitter.com/Z0VsxQHVQ9

President #Ramaphosa: While much has changed since the advent of democracy, there is still much to do to ensure that mining brings real and lasting benefits to rural communities. Traditional leaders are well-placed to ensure that the new #MiningCharter is effectively implemented.

President #Ramaphosa: Another industry which has great potential to uplift the standard of living of people in rural areas is mining. Since the earliest days of mining in South Africa, this industry has done great harm to our rural areas. #NHTLOpening

President #Ramaphosa: This is an example of what can be achieved when all government departments involved work closely with traditional authorities, communities and other stakeholders to remove obstacles to implementation. #NHTLOpeningpic.twitter.com/ZsA75vQHx9

President #Ramaphosa: We are determined that real progress should be made in the finalisation of land claims and in the restitution of land to communities. Last year, I had the privilege to witness the return of land to the Mkhwanazi community in KwaZulu-Natal. #NHTLOpeningpic.twitter.com/1rZRuAyIqj

President #Ramaphosa: We accept the broad approach that land returned to communities in such areas be held in custodianship by traditional councils on behalf of the people; this should be balanced against the Constitutional right of individuals to form communal structures.pic.twitter.com/LW9UCPki7G
President #Ramaphosa: Among the range of issues that this IMC needs to deal with are concerns about the Spatial Planning and Land Use Management Act, or SPLUMA. #NHTLOpeningpic.twitter.com/GGH41iPsPh

President #Ramaphosa: We consider further engagement with the Advisory Panel necessary for the development of a comprehensive programme of accelerated land reform that gives effect to the #FreedomCharter’s injunction that the land shall be shared among those who work it.
President #Ramaphosa: The National House, together with Provincial Houses, have been part of the stakeholders engaged by the Presidential Advisory Panel on Land Reform. #NHTLOpening

President #Ramaphosa: Traditional leaders were among the many stakeholders that participated in the work of the Constitutional Review Committee on the issue of the expropriation of land without compensation. #NHTLOpening

President #Ramaphosa: We welcome the work done by the Chairperson of the National House, Ikosi Sipho Mahlangu, Ndzundza, who has travelled to all our provinces to mobilise traditional leaders to support the agricultural revolution. #NHTLOpening

President #Ramaphosa: Since we last addressed this issue in the National House of Traditional Leaders, we are encouraged by the fact that more traditional leaders have identified land that can be designated for agricultural production. #NHTLOpening

President #Ramaphosa: We are committed to work with traditional leaders to significantly expand the amount of arable land available for agricultural production, both for food security and to create jobs opportunities. #NHTLOpening

President #Ramaphosa: These measures are part of the broader effort to unleash an agricultural revolution in South Africa. The epicentre of this revolution will be in the rural areas of our country. #NHTLOpening
President #Ramaphosa: Government has finalised 30 year leases with nearly 900 farmers to enable them to mobilise funding for agricultural development. #NHTLOpening

#Motsoaledi The NHI aims to embed the principle that health care services will be based on clinical need and not the ability to pay. Health care will therefore be free at the point of service. #QualityHealthCare

#Motsoaledi The Summit generated unanimous support for National Health Insurance and for the principles of universal quality health coverage, social solidarity and equity in health access. #QualityHealthCare

#Motsoaledi The Summit adopted the principle of ‘One Country, One Health System’ and welcomed the renewed energy and commitment within government to improve the health system. #QualityHealthCarepic.twitter.com/SdiapXJgC3

#Motsoaledi At a time when we are laying the foundations for increased investment in our economy and we are developing the skills of our people to be active in this economy, it is essential that we build and maintain a healthy nation. #QualityHealthCarepic.twitter.com/Hqs1uCnLN9

#Motsoaledi Realising the magnitude of the challenges in health care, we have established an NHI and quality improvement ‘war room’ in the Presidency, bringing together key departments to address the crisis in public health while preparing for the implementation of the #NHI.
#Motsoaledi By applying the principle of social solidarity and cross-subsidisation, we aim to reduce inequality in access to health care. #QualityHealthCarepic.twitter.com/gDSJhwIxE6

#Motsoaledi The #NHI delivery model will be based on the primary health care approach, which emphasises the importance of providing preventative, promotive, curative, promotive and rehabilitative services. #QualityHealthCare

#Motsoaledi After extensive consultation, the NHI Bill will soon be ready for submission to Parliament. The NHI will enable South Africans to receive free services at the point of care in public and private quality-accredited health facilities. #QualityHealthCare

#Motsoaledi One of the tasks is to improve the conditions of life for all South Africans, especially the poor. The other is to strengthen the capacity of the state to address the needs of the people. #QualityHealthCare

#Motsoaledi While we have made much progress, there is much more we need to do. Our efforts to restore our health system are informed by two of the five national priority tasks outlined in the State of the Nation Address just a few days ago. #SONA2019 #QualityHealthCarepic.twitter.com/ZFzv1zwnMu

#Motsoaledi Five years later, the South African Medical Journal reported a 64% reduction in rotavirus diarrhoea hospitalisations and a 46% reduction in hospitalisation for invasive pneumococcal disease in HIV-negative children older than 16 weeks of age. #QualityHealthCare
#Motsoaledi In 2009, South Africa became the first country in Africa to introduce pneumococcal and rotavirus vaccines. #QualityHealthCarepic.twitter.com/JcnMc0GJMc

#Motsoaledi According to the Medical Research Council’s Rapid Mortality Surveillance Report 2017, which was released a few days ago, average life expectancy in South Africa increased from 61.2 years to 64.2 years in the five years between 2012 and 2017. #QualityHealthCare

#Motsoaledi We need a robust, efficient and caring health system in a country where more than seven million people live with HIV, where we are seeing rising rates of diabetes, hypertension & cancer, and where maternal and neonatal death rates must be reduced. #QualityHealthCare

#Motsoaledi One of the barriers to access is the unsustainably high cost of private care. Many users of this care experience above-inflation increases in medical schemes contributions, and the failure of medical schemes to pay for patient services that have been rendered.

#Motsoaledi Many people have raised concerns about the poor quality of care that people experience in our clinics and hospitals, including inadequate access to medicines & equipment; inadequate numbers of staff; unprofessional conduct; labour unrest, corruption and theft.

#Motsoaledi The Presidential Health Summit 2018 gave us an opportunity to examine our national health system as a patient in its own right and to arrive at a diagnosis that would allow us to intervene and return this system to good health. #QualityHealthCare

The theme for the Summit was: “Strengthening the South African health system towards an integrated and unified health system” - reflecting the commitment in the NDP to a sustainable quality health system that provides equal access & care to all South Africans. #QualityHealthCarepic.twitter.com/HRkfacAIjQ

The objectives of the Presidential Health Summit included advancing the collective efforts to promote quality health care services as an essential foundation for providing health care for all South Africans. #QualityHealthCarepic.twitter.com/QfzIv0JJIt

Deputy President @DDMabuza officiated at the Presidential Health Summit held in October 2018, convening stakeholders from government, civil society, academia & healthcare professionals. #QualityHealthCarepic.twitter.com/nKUFBdatoj

President @CyrilRamaphosa has requested Minister of Health, Dr Aaron Motsoaledi, to officiate today’s launch of the report on the Presidential Health Summit 2018. #QualityHealthCarepic.twitter.com/bSBMinlMOw

President Cyril Ramaphosa has requested Minister of Health Dr Aaron Motsoaledi to officiate the launch today, Tuesday 12 February 2019, of the report on the Presidential Health Summit 2018. https://bit.ly/2N8w2bv

FULL TEXT: State of the Nation Address delivered by President @CyrilRamaphosa https://bit.ly/2taR3ZG pic.twitter.com/t1KVaO295d

President #Ramaphosa: We wish to remind all eligible South Africans who have not yet registered as voters that they still have until the proclamation of the election date to register. #RegisterToVote #SONA2019pic.twitter.com/rR39PgsruH

President #Ramaphosa: I have engaged with the Independent Electoral Commission and also with the Premiers of all provinces, and intend to proclaim the 8th of May 2019 as the date of the election. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: In a few months time, South Africans will go to the polls for the sixth time in our democracy to vote for national & provincial governments. This is an opportunity for our people to exercise their hard-won right to determine the direction of this country.

President #Ramaphosa: We have made progress in examining the size & structure of the state & will complete this work by the end of this administration. We invite you all to make suggestions on how we can better configure government to serve the needs & the interests of the peoplepic.twitter.com/m5De7a3OFe

President #Ramaphosa: we have agreed with the new #NDPP, that there is an urgent need to establish in the office of the NDPP an investigating directorate dealing with serious corruption and associated offences, in accordance with section 7 of the NPA Act. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: Knowing as we do that there are strong linkages between substance abuse, drug trafficking, crime & insecurity in communities – we are focusing on tackling this problem through prevention programmes targeting vulnerable persons especially our youth. #SONA2019
President #Ramaphosa: As government we continue to roll-out interventions to address social ills tearing our communities apart such as alcoholism and substance abuse. #SONA2019
President #Ramaphosa: Ending gender-based violence is an urgent national priority that requires the mobilisation of all South Africans and the involvement of all institutions. #SONA2019
President #Ramaphosa: Government will lead the campaign to include men and boys as active champions in the struggle against gender-based violence. #SONA2019
President #Ramaphosa: We will improve the quality of services in shelters and ensure they also accommodate members of the LGBTQI+ community. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: We are expanding and dedicating more funds to places of support, such as the Thuthuzela Care Centres and Khuseleka Care Centres. We have been working to ensure the better functioning of Sexual Offences Courts. #SONA2019
President #Ramaphosa: This year, we will work with our partners in civil society to implement the decisions of the National Summit on Gender-Based Violence and Femicide. #SONA2019
President #Ramaphosa: Work is underway to implement the decisions of the Summit, including preparing the National Strategic Plan on Gender- Based Violence. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: After extensive consultation, the NHI Bill will soon be ready for submission to Parliament. The NHI will enable South Africans to receive free services at the point of care in public and private quality-accredited health facilities. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: With the assistance of the #NPC, we reached consensus on reforms including the National Social Security Fund, institutional arrangements, regulatory reforms, unemployment benefits, social assistance coverage, & labour market policies for qualifying citizens

President #Ramaphosa: South Africa has one of the most comprehensive and far-reaching social security nets in the world, providing a buffer between poor households and abject poverty. Every month 17.5 million social grants are provided to South Africans. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: We are concerned about developments on some campuses this week, especially reports of violence and intimidation and the tragic death of Mlungisi Madonsela, a student at #DUT. We extend our deepest condolences to his family #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: Stabilising the business processes of the #NSFAS will also be a priority in the coming year so that it is properly capacitated to carry out its critical role in supporting eligible students. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: In line with our Framework for Skills for a Changing World, we are expanding the training of both educators and learners to respond to emerging technologies including the internet of things, robotics and artificial intelligence. #SONA2019pic.twitter.com/2NnkI9V2SH

President #Ramaphosa: Over the next six years, we will provide every school child in South Africa with digital workbooks and textbooks on a tablet device. We will start with those schools that have been historically most disadvantaged and are located in the poorest communities.

President #Ramaphosa: This year, we will migrate responsibility for ECD centres from Social Development to Basic Education, and proceed with the process towards two years of compulsory ECD for all children before they enter grade 1. #SONA2019pic.twitter.com/KtD7updSxm

President #Ramaphosa: With over 700,000 children accessing early childhood education in the last financial year, we have established a firm foundation for a comprehensive ECD programme that is an integral part of the education system. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: Eskom has come up with the 9 point turnaround plan which we support and want to see implemented. In line with this plan, Eskom will need to take urgent steps to significantly reduce its costs. It will need more revenue through an affordable tariff increase.

President #Ramaphosa: We will lead a process with labour, Eskom and other stakeholders to work out the details of a just transition, and proper, credible and sustainable plans that will address the needs of all those who may be affected. #SONA2019
President #Ramaphosa: As we address the challenges that face #Eskom we will ensure that there is meaningful consultation and dialogue with all key stakeholders. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: The consequences may be painful, but they will be even more devastating if we delay. In responding to this crisis, we are informed by the need to minimise any adverse economic cost to the consumer and taxpayer. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: Security of energy supply is an absolute imperative. #Eskom is in crisis and the risks it poses to South Africa are great. It could severely damage our economic and social development ambitions. We need to take bold decisions & decisive action. #SONA2019pic.twitter.com/zW7msWQ7aT
President #Ramaphosa: We are determined to eradicate unsafe and inappropriate sanitation facilities within the next three years. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: Since we launched the initiative, 699 schools have been provided with safe and appropriate sanitation facilities and projects in a further 1,150 schools are either in planning, design or construction stages. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: We recall with deep sadness the tragic deaths of Michael Komape, who drowned in a pit toilet at Mahlodumela Primary School in Limpopo in 2014 & Lumka Mkethwa, from Luna Junior Primary School in the Eastern Cape, who lost her life in March last year. #SONA19pic.twitter.com/9sV1tkU5VA
President #Ramaphosa: The safety of our learners in school is critical for creating a healthy, learning environment. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: We are urgently establishing an inter-governmental rapid response technical team, reinforced by specialist professionals, to intervene in areas which are experiencing severe water problems. #SONA2019
President #Ramaphosa: We are developing a comprehensive integrated nation plan that addresses water shortages, ageing infrastructure and poor project implementation. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: Government has committed to contribute R100 billion into the Infrastructure Fund over a 10 year period and use this to leverage financing from the private sector and development finance institutions. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: More than R1.3 trillion has been invested to build hundreds of schools and two new universities, to build hundreds of thousands of new houses, to electrify more than a million homes, generate new electricity and to expand public transport. #SONA2019
President #Ramaphosa: We are extremely encouraged by the report this morning about the Brulpadda block in the Outeniqua Basin, which some have described as a catalytic find. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: Last night I received a call from Minister Gwede Mantashe when he told me that the oil giant Total would be making a big announcement today about a new “world-class” oil and gas discovery off the coast of South Africa. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: Expected investment in the Oceans Economy over the next five years is estimated at R3.8 billion by government and R65 billion by the private sector. These investments are expected to create over 100,000 direct jobs and more than 250,000 indirect jobs.pic.twitter.com/qi5NWSniA9

President #Ramaphosa: Since the Operation Phakisa on the Oceans Economy in 2014, we have secured investments of nearly R30 billion and created over 7,000 direct jobs. #SONA2019pic.twitter.com/MCK129JjjU

President #Ramaphosa: In addition to direct jobs, this export industry could generate as many as 2 million more jobs in food and agriculture, construction, transport, retail, and the creative and cultural industries by 2030. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: In the past year we had 10 million tourists who came to our country. We intend to raise this to 21 million by 2030, targeting, among others, the largest and fastest growing markets of India and China, as well as strong markets on our continent. #SONA2019pic.twitter.com/hWOHT2WHj4

President #Ramaphosa: As part of the stimulus package in agriculture, we have invested significantly in comprehensive farmer development support to ensure that restituted and communal land is productively utilised. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: As part of accelerating land reform, we have identified land parcels owned by the state for redistribution. Strategically located land will be released to address human settlements needs in urban and peri-urban areas. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: An advisory panel of experts headed by Dr Vuyo Mahlathi, established to advise government on its land reform programme, is expected to table its report by the end of March 2019. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: I wish to commend those who participated in the work of the Constitutional Review Committee in the dialogue that ensued through the length and the breadth of the country. #SONA2019pic.twitter.com/SIarNjXxiV
President #Ramaphosa: Through an accelerated programme of land reform, we will work to expand our agricultural output and promote economic inclusion. #SONA2019pic.twitter.com/13jahZv5zL

President #Ramaphosa: We have launched the #YES4Youth initiative, placing unemployed youth in paid internships in companies across the economy. We call on all companies to participate and contribute not only to building their business but also to building the economy. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: Alongside a focus on exports, we will pursue measures to increase local demand through, increasing the proportion of local goods and services procured both by government and the private sector. Through this we will intensify the #BuySouthAfrican programme.

President #Ramaphosa: The agreement on the establishment of African Continental Free Trade Area offers great opportunities to place South Africa on a path of investment-led trade, and to work with other African countries to develop their own industrial capacity. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: To improve the competitiveness of our exports, we will complete the studies that have begun on reducing the costs of electricity, trade, communications, transport and other costs. #SONA2019
President #Ramaphosa: We will also be looking at establishing special economic zones that are dedicated to producing specific types of products, such as clothing and textiles, for example. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: In line with Jobs Summit commitments, we will focus on the export of manufactured goods and trade in services such as business process outsourcing and the remote delivery of medical services. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: To stimulate growth in the economy, to build more businesses and employ more people, we need to find new and larger markets for our goods and services. We will therefore be focusing greater attention on expanding exports. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: Following our successful Investment Conference, a group of SA business leaders moved by the spirit of #ThumaMina initiated the #PPGI to facilitate focused investment plans of leading companies across 19 sectors of the economy. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: The inaugural SA Investment Conference last October provided great impetus to our drive to mobilise R1.2 trillion in investment over 5 years. The Investment Conference attracted around R300 billion in investment pledges from local & international companies.

President #Ramaphosa: We have so far completed the revitalisation of 10 out of 16 identified industrial parks, in places such as Botshabelo, Phuthaditjhaba, Garankuwa, Isithebe, Komani and Seshego. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: The focus we have placed on revamping industrial parks in townships and rural areas has brought about discernible change, as industrial parks that have been lying idle are becoming productive again. #SONA2019
President #Ramaphosa: Fifthly, we need to strengthen the capacity of the state to address the needs of the people. #SONA2019pic.twitter.com/N64q2YuHKP
President #Ramaphosa: Fourthly, we have no choice but to step up the fight against corruption and state capture. #SONA2019pic.twitter.com/xM7fU4l8EW
President #Ramaphosa: Thirdly, we are duty bound to improve the conditions of life for all South Africans, especially the poor. #SONA2019pic.twitter.com/lbTnYOmTMw
President #Ramaphosa: Secondly, our history demands that we should improve the education system and develop the skills that we need now and into the future. #SONA2019pic.twitter.com/wg5Mc0c7cE
President #Ramaphosa: Firstly, we must accelerate inclusive economic growth and create jobs. #SONA2019pic.twitter.com/t9JVA0uJuo

President #Ramaphosa: While there is a broad range of critical work being done across government, this evening I want to address the five most urgent tasks at this moment in our history. These are tasks that will underpin everything that we do this year. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: The task of building a better South Africa is our collective responsibility as a nation. It is at the centre of the work of every department of government, of every agency, of every public entity. It informs every policy, every programme & every initiative.

President #Ramaphosa: We are undaunted by the considerable difficulties we have yet to overcome. All of us, as South Africans, should face up to the challenges and difficulties that lie ahead. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: We begin this new year encouraged by the progress we have made, working together, in reviving our economy and restoring our country’s democratic institutions. We are determined to stay the course. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: We responded to national concerns and calls by many South Africans by convening a Summit on Gender-Based Violence and Femicide that has provided a firm basis for a coordinated national response to this crisis. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: During the course of the past year as the Presidency, we have paid particular attention to the violence and abuse perpetrated against women and children in our society. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: We have appointed a new National Director of Public Prosecutions, Adv Shamila Batohi, to lead the revival of the NPA and to strengthen our fight against crime and corruption. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: We have therefore acted to stabilise and restore the credibility of institutions like the National Prosecuting Authority, the South African Revenue Service, the State Security Agency and the South African Police Service. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: Our people’s hope is not baseless; it is grounded on the progress that is being made. Over the last year, we have begun to rebuild a durable social compact for fundamental social and economic transformation with key stakeholders as we promised. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: Today, as we reflect on the year that has passed, we can attest to meaningful progress. Our people have embraced the renewal that our country is going through and are much more hopeful about a better tomorrow. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: In ways both large and small, both public and private, South Africans set about building a better nation. Many reached out to other South Africans to lend a hand where others were going through difficulties. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: In our magnificent diversity, and despite our many differences, the people of this country answered the call of Thuma Mina. In their multitudes, South Africans asked not what can be done for them, but what they could do for their country. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: We agreed that, in honour of the centenary of Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela and Albertina Nontsikelelo Sisulu, we would devote our every action, our every effort, our every utterance to the realisation of their vision of a democratic, just and equitable society.

President #Ramaphosa: We resolved to advance the values of our Constitution and to once again place at the centre of our national agenda the needs of the poor, unemployed, marginalised and dispossessed. #SONA2019
President #Ramaphosa: We resolved to cure our country of the corrosive effects of corruption and to restore the integrity of our institutions. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: A year ago, we set out on a path of growth and renewal. Emerging from a period of uncertainty and a loss of confidence and trust, we resolved to break with all that divides us, to embrace all that unites us. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: Have we built a society where the injustices of the past no longer define the lives of the present? We must use this time to reflect on the progress made, the challenges encountered, the setbacks we have suffered, and the mistakes committed. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: We must spend this year, the 25th anniversary of our freedom, asking ourselves whether we have built a society in which all South Africans equally and without exception enjoy their inalienable rights to life, dignity and liberty. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: We will use this time to recall the hardship and the suffering which generations of our people endured – their struggles, their sacrifices and their undying commitment to build a South Africa that belongs to all who live in it. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: We will celebrate the triumph of freedom over subjugation, the triumph of democracy over racial tyranny, the triumph of hope over despair. We will celebrate the irresistible determination of an oppressed people to be free and equal and fulfilled. #SONA2019

President #Ramaphosa: It is a great honour to stand before you today to deliver the 25th annual #SONA2019 in a free and democratic South Africa. This year, as a diverse people and as a united nation, we will celebrate one of the greatest of human achievements.

10 VALUE CREATING PRINCIPLES Companies that include their workers in their shareholding and give recognition to unions must be applauded and emulated, for it is through creating shared value that we can ensure a sustainable industry that benefits all. #InvestinSAMiningpic.twitter.com/3ScDFrRrkn

10 VALUE CREATING PRINCIPLES Companies must prioritise the development of young women, through proactive hiring policies, prioritised training, promotion and mentorship. #InvestinSAMining #MiningIndaba2019pic.twitter.com/hGXmuDzy2D

10 VALUE CREATING PRINCIPLES Companies need to provide internships and job experience opportunities for young people, for that is the only way to prepare our youth for the world of work. #InvestinSAMining #MiningIndaba2019pic.twitter.com/7PsxRhaC0x

10 VALUE CREATING PRINCIPLES As a matter of principle, workers should not be exposed to life-threatening situations or where they could suffer bodily harm. Safe and healthy workers are also much more productive. #InvestinSAMining #MiningIndaba2019pic.twitter.com/ykizDuAMEq

10 VALUE CREATING PRINCIPLES It has been shown that companies that care about the upliftment of workers & communities are more successful. People no longer want to have things happen around them without their knowledge & involvement, they want to be engaged. #InvestinSAMiningpic.twitter.com/ZGMFWi5BUr

10 VALUE CREATING PRINCIPLES Partnerships with training colleges will ensure that companies can draw on a pool of well-trained graduates with relevant skills and experience. #InvestinSAMining #MiningIndaba2019pic.twitter.com/XEMNFbwGAF

10 VALUE CREATING PRINCIPLES “We applaud those companies that are far-sighted enough to set up early childhood education centres, as well as those that are helping to develop hardcore skills that are needed now, such as mining engineering, metallurgy and artisan training.”pic.twitter.com/2L02OzVcuT

10 VALUE CREATING PRINCIPLES Through, for example, building decent houses for workers, companies can ensure workers are much more productive and can demonstrate their commitment to build sustainable working communities. #InvestinSAMining #MiningIndaba2019pic.twitter.com/XIuxsxOnZf

10 VALUE CREATING PRINCIPLES Companies should partner with local governments to improve infrastructure that is critical for the effective functioning of mines - too often companies & municipalities do not coordinate work or even operate at cross purposes. #InvestinSAMiningpic.twitter.com/9pamTzcFer

10 VALUE CREATING PRINCIPLES Not only does beneficiation encourage the expansion of our industrial capacity, create employment and enable the extraction of greater value from our mineral wealth, it also helps create demand and locates markets closer to the site of producation.pic.twitter.com/1IZrbpvI17

President @CyrilRamaphosa addressed the Invest in Africa Mining Indaba at the #CTICC. President Ramaphosa suggested that mining companies strive to realise #10ValueCreatingPrinciples for a more modern, successful and productive mining industry. #InvestinSAMining #MiningIndaba2019pic.twitter.com/Pe89qxFnTD

Ahead of his State of the Nation Address on Thursday, President Cyril Ramaphosa was today joined by the Chairperson of the National Council of Provinces, Ms Thandi Modise, Speaker of Parliament, Ms Baleka Mbete and Senior Managers to check Parliament’ state of readiness.pic.twitter.com/foa1B8JL7A

President #Ramaphosa: We are committed to the mining industry, President of Ghana HE @NAkufoAddo is here to demonstrate this. We’d like all industry players to join us as we grow this industry to where it belongs across the African continent. #InvestinSAMining #MiningIndaba2019pic.twitter.com/eB1m7pU242

President #Ramaphosa: We firmly believe that mining companies have the resources, the capabilities and an interest in more deliberately contributing to development, both where they are located and across society. #InvestinSAMining #MiningIndaba2019

President #Ramaphosa: We are certain that the Mining Leadership Compact will enable all social partners to each do their part in contributing to the sustainable growth, transformation and competitiveness of the industry. #InvestinSAMining #MiningIndaba2019pic.twitter.com/QzhdxdApOg

President #Ramaphosa: We appreciate and applaud the Mining Leadership Compact signed this morning by the South African government, organised business and organised labour. #MiningIndaba2019 #InvestinSAMining

President #Ramaphosa: South Africa’s Minister of Mineral Resources @GwedeMantashe1 provided great detail yesterday on government’s plans for the mining industry, and how we are ensuring that we play our part in creating an enabling environment for investors. #InvestInSAMining

President #Ramaphosa: This measure will be undertaken in a way that promotes economic development & agricultural output, and that does not undermine the principles of our Constitution or the rule of law. Investors need not fear that their investments will be taken away from them.

President #Ramaphosa: We must emphasise that our approach will enhance, rather than undermine, property rights as we seek to address what we have termed the original sin which was committed against black South Africans during colonial and apartheid days. #InvestInSAMining

President #Ramaphosa: We have used the opportunity of our engagement with investors to outline our approach to land reform. Understandably, concern has been raised about the proposal for the expropriation without compensation to be among the mechanisms used to promote land reform

President #Ramaphosa: We are also working with our partners across the continent to develop infrastructure that facilitates the integration of African economies and the development of intra-regional value chains. #AfCFTA #MiningIndaba2019 #InvestInSAMining

President #Ramaphosa: In the coming days, we will be announcing a package of measures to stabilise and improve #Eskom’s financial, operational and structural position and to ensure security of energy supply for the country.

President #Ramaphosa: Eskom’s contribution to the health of our economy is too great for it to be allowed to fail. Is is too important and is too big to fail. And we will not allow it to fail. Restoring and securing energy security for the country is an absolute imperative.

President #Ramaphosa: The other important infrastructure challenge is the security and affordability of energy supply. We have been giving detailed attention to the crisis at Eskom. Eskom is currently facing significant operational, financial & structural challenges.

President #Ramaphosa: We are working in earnest to address the constraints that were raised with us as we implement the Stimulus & Economic Recovery Plan. We are addressing issues that are of concern to companies such as Visa Regulations & reducing the cost of doing business.

President #Ramaphosa: Because of their importance, these actions formed a critical component of the Economic Stimulus and Recovery Plan we announced in September 2018 after our economy went into a technical recession. #InvestinSAMining #MiningIndaba2019

President #Ramaphosa: To this end, we moved to speed up the finalisation of the Mining Charter and to provide greater clarity on the Mineral and Petroleum Resources Development Amendment Bill. #InvestinginSAMining #MiningIndaba2019

President #Ramaphosa: We have emerged from a period of strained relations where the courts became the main platform of engagement between the industry & government. We recognise the critically important role that mining can & must still play in shaping the future of our country.

President #Ramaphosa: It is for this reason that we have prioritised the restoration of a policy and regulatory environment that is stable and predictable. Significant work has been done to remove the uncertainty that held back the development of the industry. #InvestinSAMining

President #Ramaphosa: As government we regard the mining industry as a key player in the future growth & development of our economy, with huge potential for exploration, production & beneficiation. #InvestInSAMining #MiningIndaba2019pic.twitter.com/SlWEZBymd3

President #Ramaphosa: The country’s mineral wealth has attracted large capital investments over the decades, resulting in the development of integrated industrial value chains that generate significant value for the economy. #InvestinginSAMining #MiningIndaba2019

President #Ramaphosa: We have recognised that we will not be able to meaningfully reduce unemployment & poverty without increased investment in critical areas of our economy – especially the productive sectors, of which mining is a vital part. #InvestinSAMining #MiningIndaba2019

President #Ramaphosa: Several companies at the Conference made announcements of investments, which amounted to around $20 billion in total, a clear indication that our economy has a lot to offer, and that opportunities for growth are in abundance. #MiningIndaba2019

President #Ramaphosa: Our message to international investors is that we are taking practical measures to build an economy underpinned by inclusive growth, competitiveness & transformation. This found expression in the inaugural SAInvestment Conference, hosted in October 2018.

President #Ramaphosa: We have recently returned from #WEF19 in Davos and a State visit to India, where we engaged with the investment community on – among other things – South Africa’s ambitious programme to mobilisation far greater levels of investment. #MiningIndaba2019

President #Ramaphosa: We’re pleased to note that a full day has been dedicated to address issues pertaining to Africa’s economic development. This demonstrates a determination to become an integral part of social forces working to address all the social & environmental challenges

President #Ramaphosa: The Mining Indaba offers us a valuable opportunity to engage with investors from across the globe seeking opportunities for new and further investment in Africa’s mining industry. #InvestinSAMining #MiningIndaba2019

President #Ramaphosa: It is fitting that this occasion should coincide with the 25th anniversary of the achievement of democracy in South Africa, given the significant role the mining industry has played in the construction of present day South Africa. #InvestInSAMining
President @CyrilRamaphosa will this afternoon address the #MiningIndaba2019 currently underway at the ICC in Cape Town. #InvestinSAMiningpic.twitter.com/d3XVpgVE2n

The #FutureofWork Report is a culmination of a 15-month examination by the 27-member commission, which is made up of leading figures from business and labour, think tanks, academia, government and non-governmental organizations from around the world. #BetterAfricaBetterWorldpic.twitter.com/kK1bmub1xs

President Ramaphosa as co-Chair of the Global Commission on the #FutureofWork has been tasked with identifying challenges & making recommendations that will sustain and protect the livelihood of workers around the world amid the proliferation of the 4th industrial revolution.pic.twitter.com/i8nUA2qGtk

Among key issues considered by the Commission on the #FutureofWork are new forms of work, institutional ramifications of the changing nature of work, lifelong learning, greater inclusivity, gender equality, and the role of universal social protection in a stable and just future.pic.twitter.com/GvXGepaOeO

President @CyrilRamaphosa and Minister Angie Motshekga on a walk through of the exhibition displayed at the 3rd Annual Basic Education Lekgotla currently underway in at the Birchwood Conference Centre in Ekurhuleni, Gauteng.pic.twitter.com/QMVinQjrdM

The Department of Basic Education has partnered with the Sasol Foundation to bring science & technology equipment via mobile laboratories to schools that do not have these facilities. The UNISA trained facilitators cover physics, chemistry and robotics.pic.twitter.com/hSTed46Oo5

President #Ramaphosa: We need to do more, work harder and establish greater system efficiencies in the first five years of schooling if we are to rise to the international standards prescribed as minimum benchmarks for reading comprehension, mathematics and science.pic.twitter.com/GRXzQQT8zQ

President #Ramaphosa: We must move with greater speed in promoting flexible learning pathways that ease the transition between all educational levels. These include ECD, primary & secondary education, vocational & occupational education & training, and higher education & training
President #Ramaphosa: With visionary leadership, we will succeed and our education system will achieve its intended objectives. More learners will complete their entire period of schooling.

President #Ramaphosa: We need a functional leadership and accountability system that involves the school management teams, the teachers, the representative councils of learners, the school governing bodies and the community members at large.

President #Ramaphosa: We must place strong emphasis on a vibrant learning environment because there is nothing more disastrous than schooling without learning. It is a terrible waste of resources and of human potential and an injustice that deprives children of their rights.

President #Ramaphosa: This creates new global challenges, like the changing nature of work, and can exacerbate existing ones, like poverty & inequality. However, these socioeconomic trends also offer opportunities for wider access to information, innovation & higher productivity.

President #Ramaphosa: Globalisation, technological disruption and digitisation are re-shaping the way people live, work, socialise, share knowledge and participate in increasingly complex, dynamic and diverse societies.

President #Ramaphosa: Working together, we must strive to ensure that our children excel from an early age, especially in the prioritised areas of science, technology, engineering, arts and mathematics, popularly known as STEAM.
President #Ramaphosa: As we mark 25 years of democracy, our actions will continue to be anchored on our recognition of education as a key driver of fair and sustainable development.

President #Ramaphosa: One reason why we are excited about the general upward trend in our Grade 12 results is that we know this is a manifestation of improvements occurring at all levels of the schooling system.

President #Ramaphosa: The class of 2018 did us proud by achieving the highest national pass rate recorded – that of 78.2%. The analysis of the NSC examination results shows that the bulk of the improvements have occurred in historically disadvantaged schools.

President #Ramaphosa: Without quality basic education, our country cannot grow and develop, we cannot redress the injustices of the past, and we cannot build a socially cohesive nation. Despite the challenges, we are making progress.

President #Ramaphosa: We are here to discuss and agree on the steps we will take collectively in the year 2019 & beyond to make basic education a more effective & efficient platform for the creation of an intellectually empowered youth that is ready for higher forms of learning.

President #Ramaphosa: Appreciating that every child is an important national asset, this Lekgotla commits the government and its social partners to take our children on an exciting and meaningful journey of learning.

[IN PICTURES]: President @CyrilRamaphosa launches the Rural Agro-Industries and Finance Initiative (RAFI) at Ncise Village in the OR Tambo District Municipality, Eastern Cape.pic.twitter.com/FkaCqaFjb3
[IN PICTURES]: #ReconciliationDaypic.twitter.com/jaM3YNyDTV
[IN PICTURES]: #ReconciliationDaypic.twitter.com/6EdtaIUF4v

The Day of Reconciliation aims to promote national unity, social cohesion, constitutional democracy, human rights and equality by highlighting and advancing the constitutional values and principles that bind together all South Africans. #ReconciliationDaypic.twitter.com/Xczkne8K76

Through a strong rural focus, the Rural Agri-Industries & Finance Initiative (RAFI) transforms village plots into productive agricultural assets and ensures equitable participation of ordinary citizens in the province.pic.twitter.com/86eZsHlmt9

The pilot project of 430 hectares benefits 150 households and is funded by the district municipality and Argentinian partners. This initiative has secured international investment to enable black farmers to build successful commercial enterprises using a cooperative model.pic.twitter.com/3AH8sSyfOl
President @CyrilRamaphosa launches the Rural Agro-Industries & Finance Initiative (RAFI) at Ncise Village in the OR Tambo District Municipality on #ReconciliationDaypic.twitter.com/Zz3gpoigbj

The Rural Agro-Industries & Financial Initiative aims to achieve a total of 200 000 hectares over 6 years in the Eastern Cape through the investment programme that has been developed with key foreign based investors and a number of local investment and financial houses.pic.twitter.com/yyk0RJSWFH

Nick Snaith is the founder member & Technical Agricultural Director of Rural Agro-Industries & Financial Initiative (RAFI). He is briefing President @CyrilRamaphosa on progress made to date - implementation of the commercial pilot project in 3 districts is at an advanced stage.pic.twitter.com/YJ2ImhWK3N

President @CyrilRamaphosa visited the Rural Agro-Industries and Financial Initiative (RAFI), a flagship project of the Eastern Cape as introduced to him by OR Tambo Municipality Executive Mayor, Ms Nomakhosazana Meth. #ReconciliationDaypic.twitter.com/Kn4s0DcNrC
Address by President Cyril Ramaphosa on the Day of Reconciliation 2018, Walter Sisulu University of Technology, Mthatha https://bit.ly/2rFZxqW

President #Ramaphosa: Far from being a measure that will fuel tensions or set race relations back, accelerated land reform has the potential to improve goodwill between the races in South Africa. #ReconciliationDay

President #Ramaphosa: Land enables people to gain and develop productive assets, and to participate more meaningfully in the economy. Land reform is inextricably tied to nation building. #ReconciliationDay

President #Ramaphosa: This means that we all need to be part of the effort to promote investment, achieve inclusive growth, improve the conditions of the poor and create employment on a massive scale. #ReconciliationDay
President #Ramaphosa: We cannot be a reconciled nation for as long as the majority of our people continue to suffer from the injustices of the past. #ReconciliationDay
President #Ramaphosa: The Day of Reconciliation must therefore be a day on which we reaffirm our commitment to eradicate poverty, hunger, homelessness and unemployment. #ReconciliationDay

President #Ramaphosa: So long as millions of our people are burdened by poverty and underdevelopment, stunting their chances and prospects for a better life, we will not have achieved our goal. #ReconciliationDay
President #Ramaphosa: We also knew that without redress, there can be no equality. We know that without justice there can be no peace. #ReconciliationDay

President #Ramaphosa: And above all, instead of revenge, we chose reconciliation. We knew that if we were to build a new nation, we could not go down the dark and destructive path of vengeance and retribution. #ReconciliationDay

President #Ramaphosa: It reflected the acceptance by all South Africans of the values and the principles that define our democracy. Instead of war, we chose peace. Instead of discord, we chose unity. Instead of domination, we chose compromise. #ReconciliationDaypic.twitter.com/QwE2tybyv2

President #Ramaphosa: With the dawn of democracy, the Day of the Vow to some and Heroes Day to others became the Day of Reconciliation for all of us. It was not only a change of name. #ReconciliationDay

President #Ramaphosa: To others, the killing of over 3,000 Zulu warriors at Ncome represents a dark day when the native people of South Africa were brutally crushed and their land taken by the barrel of a gun. #ReconciliationDay

President #Ramaphosa: To some, the Battle of Blood River – which took place exactly 180 years ago, in 1838 – was a triumph, and a confirmation of God’s special protection of the Voortrekkers. #ReconciliationDay

President #Ramaphosa: On this Day of Reconciliation, we recall the opening words of the Freedom Charter: “We, the People of South Africa, declare for all our country and the world to know, that South Africa belongs to all who live in it, black and white.” #ReconciliationDaypic.twitter.com/AAQCSng3F6

President #Ramaphosa: In observing this day we do not look only to our apartheid past, but to the legacy of centuries of historical injustice. In doing so, we also acknowledge that this day has in the past held different meanings for different South Africans. #ReconciliationDay

President #Ramaphosa: They were activists and fighters; but they were also peacemakers, unifiers and bridge-builders between the races. Mama Sisulu was part of the drafting team of the Freedom Charter that was adopted in Kliptown in 1955. #ReconciliationDay

President #Ramaphosa: Tata Mandela and Mama Sisulu joined the liberation struggle to advance the cause of the oppressed black majority, but they were committed to the ideal of a united nation with equal rights for all. #ReconciliationDay
President #Ramaphosa: The people of this great province should take great pride in counting these two giants of the struggle for our liberation as their own. #ReconciliationDay

President #Ramaphosa: It was here that they were born 100 years ago and here that they spent their formative years, where their spirits were nourished, and where the seeds of their political conscience were sown. #ReconciliationDay

DAY OF RECONCILIATION President #Ramaphosa: It is most fitting that this year we commemorate the Day of Reconciliation in the Eastern Cape, the birthplace of two of South Africa’s greatest leaders, Tata Nelson Mandela and Mama Albertina Nontsikelelo Sisulu. #ReconciliationDay

Address by President @CyrilRamaphosa at the #SALGA National Members Assembly, Inkosi Albert Luthuli International Convention Centre, Ethekwini. #SALGANMA2018 https://bit.ly/2C3TLFD pic.twitter.com/N4RYWQGfpv

Address by President @CyrilRamaphosa at the #SALGA National Members Assembly, Inkosi Albert Luthuli International Convention Centre, Ethekwini. #SALGANMA2018 https://bit.ly/2C3TLFD pic.twitter.com/FxKDpwBm26

President #Ramaphosa: A great deal of effort & resources are being dedicated to building local government capacity, which needs to be intensified. Experience tells us that that capacity cannot be imposed from above; it is most effective when built from within. #SALGANMA2018

President #Ramaphosa: It is far cheaper to invest in infrastructure maintenance than to build new infrastructure, yet we continue to produce grand plans for new projects while so much of what we have is idle or in a state of disrepair. #SALGANMA2018

President #Ramaphosa: Not only do municipalities need to create a hospitable environment for greater investment, but they also need to use their resources better. We also need to make use of neglected infrastructure and ensure that it is effectively maintained. #SALGANMA2018

President #Ramaphosa: Local government is vital to ensuring that these measures succeed not only in stimulating economic activity in the immediate term, but also that they form part of the long-term development plans of these areas. #SALGANMA2018

President #Ramaphosa: Through better data collection and management – and the deployment of big data analysis – government at all levels should be better able to design, plan and manage development. #SALGANMA2018

President #Ramaphosa: About 65% of South Africans live in urban areas, and that this is expected to rise to about 70% by 2030. This poses both great challenges & great opportunities. We know that it’s easier and cheaper to deliver better services in urban settings. #SALGANMA2018

President #Ramaphosa: We seek municipalities – in metros, cities, towns and rural areas – whose central purpose is to enable job creation, sustainable livelihoods and successful human settlements. #SALGANMA2018

President #Ramaphosa: We have made remarkable strides in meeting the basic needs of our people. There are few other countries in the world that, in less than 25 years, could have provided over 4.7 million housing opportunities for the poor. #SALGANMA2018pic.twitter.com/xqWd96EgXZ

President #Ramaphosa: We should recall the spatial absurdity of the apartheid state, which relegated the majority of our people to the margins of cities, towns and farming areas, leaving them without rights, without land, without assets and without opportunities. #SALGANMA2018

President #Ramaphosa: We look to this Assembly to make clear the distinction between the immediate interventions we need to address areas of crisis and the more fundamental measures we must put in place to ensure sustained and sustainable progress. #SALGANMA2018

President #Ramaphosa: As the delegates know only too well, too many of our municipalities do not have the means to respond adequately to the needs of their residents. The drafters of the NDP argue, a clear, long-term and consistent approach is required. #SALGANMA2018

President #Ramaphosa: It is at a local level that the transformation of our country is made visible, where improvements in the quality of life of South Africans is made manifest. Where local government leads, South Africa follows. #SALGANMA2018

President #Ramaphosa: Gathered here are women & men who have been given the responsibility by the people of this country to give effect to the vision of a better life for all. It is through local government that the needs of our people are most directly addressed. #SALGANMA2018

Statement on the appointment of the National Director of Public Prosecutions. http://bit.ly/2G0BKfD #NDPPpic.twitter.com/Ib0TdPZe4q
President #Ramaphosa: Advocate Batohi will commence her duties in February 2019 after serving her notice as Senior Legal Advisor at the ICC. #NDPPpic.twitter.com/ENC1TaS1AF
President #Ramaphosa: I wish Adv Batohi and the entire leadership and staff of the National Prosecuting Authority well in the work that lies ahead. #NDPPpic.twitter.com/spbgobVq4w
President #Ramaphosa: I also wish thank all the candidates who made themselves available for appointment to this important position. #NDPP

President #Ramaphosa: I would like to thank the members of the advisory panel for the diligence and care with which they undertook their task, and to thank Minister Radebe for chairing the panel. #NDPPpic.twitter.com/BcJidUQoS5

President #Ramaphosa: As this administration, we stand ready to provide whatever assistance necessary to the National Prosecuting Authority to ensure that it is able to fulfil its constitutional mandate without let or hindrance, fear or favour. #NDPPpic.twitter.com/g5waium4Fo

President #Ramaphosa: It is our collective responsibility to ensure that the conditions exist for them to effectively serve the cause of justice and to meet the great expectations that the South African people have of them. #NDPPpic.twitter.com/xZhFRiWFkm

President #Ramaphosa: Despite the many challenges the NPA has faced in the past, we know that there are women and men of great ability, experience and commitment within the NPA who are dedicated to doing their job and doing it well. #NDPP
President #Ramaphosa: As the NPA Act requires, she has the experience, conscientiousness and integrity to be entrusted with the responsibilities of this office. #NDPP
President #Ramaphosa: For much of the last decade, she has served as a Senior Legal Advisor to the prosecutor of the International Criminal Court. #NDPP

President #Ramaphosa: She was seconded to the Investigation Task Unit established by President Nelson Mandela in 1995 and later served as the first regional head of the Directorate of Special Operations based in KwaZulu-Natal. #NDPP

President #Ramaphosa: She started her public service as a junior prosecutor in the Chatsworth magistrates’ court in 1986 and steadily rose through the ranks to become the Director of Public Prosecutions in KwaZulu Natal. #NDPP

President #Ramaphosa: I am confident that Adv Batohi possesses all the attributes of a capable NDPP. Throughout her extensive and distinguished career, and in the course of the selection process, she has shown herself to be a fit and proper person. #NDPPpic.twitter.com/3adRwITZkp

President #Ramaphosa: After consideration of their recommendations, I have decided, in terms of section 179 of the Constitution, to appoint Adv Shamila Batohi as the new National Director of Public Prosecutions.pic.twitter.com/WXoUJb3VdP
President #Ramaphosa: Following a process of nominations, shortlisting and interviews that were open to the media, the advisory panel proposed five candidates for the NDPP position.

President #Ramaphosa: While recognising that the Constitution requires that the NDPP is appointed by the President as head of the executive, I sought the assistance of a panel of individuals from the legal fraternity and Chapter 9 institutions in recommending suitable candidates.
President #Ramaphosa: The NDPP needs to be able to take decisions independently and impartially. In appointing the new NDPP, I decided to depart from previous practice. #NDPP

President #Ramaphosa: The NDPP must ensure that the National Prosecuting Authority exercises its functions without fear, favour or prejudice and should not be beholden to any vested interests, whether in politics, in business or elsewhere. #NDPP

President #Ramaphosa: At this moment in our history, as we address matters that South Africans are most concerned about -state capture, corruption and crime, our country needs an NPA that is above reproach in the performance of its mandate and enjoys the confidence of the public.

President #Ramaphosa: The National Director of Public Prosecutions occupies a vital position in our democracy, and makes an essential contribution to upholding the rule of law and ensuring the efficiency and integrity of law enforcement. #NDPP
President #Ramaphosa: In appointing a new NDPP, we are addressing the state of dysfunctionality and deficiencies in the NPA that were identified by the court . #NDPP

President #Ramaphosa: Today, I am announcing the appointment of a new National Director of Public Prosecutions. This follows the order of the Constitutional Court on 13 August 2018 that the President appoint an NDPP within 90 days. #NDPP

PRESIDENT TO ANNOUNCE CHANGES TO THE NATIONAL EXECUTIVE Media representatives are also asked to dress appropriately for this event, in line with the decorum maintained at the Presidency. Issued by the Presidency of the Republic of South Africa

PRESIDENT TO ANNOUNCE CHANGES TO THE NATIONAL EXECUTIVE Media representatives with valid press cards are invited to attend the announcement in the Media Centre, Room 153, in the East Wing of the Union Buildings.
PRESIDENT TO ANNOUNCE CHANGES TO THE NATIONAL EXECUTIVE Media should note that questions will not be taken after the announcement, as this event is ceremonial in nature.

PRESIDENT TO ANNOUNCE CHANGES TO THE NATIONAL EXECUTIVE These changes have been occasioned by the passing away in September 2018 of the Minister of Environmental Affairs, Ms Edna Molewa, and the more recent resignation of the Minister of Home Affairs, Mr Malusi Gigaba.

PRESIDENT TO ANNOUNCE CHANGES TO THE NATIONAL EXECUTIVE President Cyril Ramaphosa will today, Thursday 22 November 2018, announce changes to the National Executive, in a statement to media at the Union Buildings, Pretoria, at 15h00.

President @CyrilRamaphosa leads Heads of State & Government and delegates in attendance at the Africa Investment Forum welcome dinner in celebrating the prospect of producing heightened investment on the continent. #AfricaInvestmentForum #BetterAfricaBetterWorldpic.twitter.com/xTcvo7ncJD
President #Ramaphosa: A strong prosperous Africa, driven by the energies of its citizens is in the interest – and reach - of us all. #AfricaInvestmentForum #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: The convening of the Africa Investment Forum is but one of the many means by which we as African leaders seek to develop our continent, improve the conditions of her people, and enhance her prosperity. #AfricaInvestmentForum #BetterAfricaBetterWorldpic.twitter.com/TnTsKvzaum

President #Ramaphosa: Tomorrow you will hear from leaders from across the continent about the concrete actions we are undertaking in our respective countries to create a business-friendly environment that catalyses investment. #AfricaInvestmentForum #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: This is why the @AfDB_Group should be commended for convening this Forum as a platform of engagement between African governments, the private sector and continental and international financial institutions. #AfricaInvestmentForum #BetterAfricaBetterWorldpic.twitter.com/8eO52RdlLE
President #Ramaphosa: Providing policy certainty and consistency is critical if we are to realise the levels of investment we seek. #AfricaInvestmentForum #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: If we are to unlock capital flows, we have to develop sound policy and regulatory environments, strengthen our financial institutions, improve governance and deal decisively with corruption. #AfricaInvestmentForum #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: By harnessing the potential of technology and by mobilising investment from the private sector, African societies can be at the forefront of innovation and progress. #AfricaInvestmentForum #BetterAfricaBetterWorldpic.twitter.com/wNakavsIWT

President #Ramaphosa: African integration is key to attracting investment and growing our respective economies. It is an imperative if we are to fully harness the potential of our citizens. #AfricaInvestmentForum #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: Importantly, it speaks to strengthening the capacity of continental financial institutions such as the African Development Bank to power Africa’s growth. #AfricaInvestmentForum #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: African integration speaks to the free movement of people, to the deepening of intra-African trade, and to cooperation across borders on infrastructure development. #AfricaInvestmentForum #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: Among the key aspirations of the African Union’s Agenda 2063 is that of a prosperous and integrated continent based on inclusive growth and sustainable development. #AfricaInvestmentForum #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: This Forum, with its strategic focus on leveraging public private partnerships to drive investment on the continent, gives us great cause for optimism. #AfricaInvestmentForum #BetterAfricaBetterWorldpic.twitter.com/FkYKv4cYtT
