President Cyril Ramaphosa Oral Replies in the National Assembly, Cape Town https://bit.ly/2RC9uAF

President #Ramaphosa: It is our diversity that we must promote, as it is this diversity that strengthens us as we deal with the legacy of the past. We must not compromise; we must rid our country of racism and displays of ethnic chauvinism and narrow nationalism #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/vfQl8rswVa

President #Ramaphosa: We all share a constitutional obligation to build a united, non-racial, non-sexist society. As government, we are committed to fulfil our obligation in this regard. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/Sk6hnumv3x

President #Ramaphosa: The task of building a non-racial society cannot be separated from the task of redressing the huge material inequalities in our society. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/fxCTDLL9QH

President #Ramaphosa: The Department of Basic Education is incrementally introducing the African languages programme in schools as part of promoting and increasing multilingualism in schools. #RamaphosaQandA
President #Ramaphosa: The Department of Justice and Constitutional Development conducts community dialogues on racism, racial discrimination, xenophobia and related intolerances. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: Constitutional awareness campaigns through the media, highlighting the constitutional values, continue. Some departments have focused this campaign specifically on vulnerable and marginalised groups. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: We have introduced the Prevention & Combating of Hate Crimes & Hate Speech Bill, which gives effect to our obligations in terms of the Constitution & human rights instruments concerning racism, discrimination, xenophobia & intolerance. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: It is finalising the auditing of teaching and learning material for all forms of discrimination. A teachers’ guide has been developed to provide practical ways for schools to promote the rights and responsibilities of children. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: Government regards schools as a fundamental foundation for advancing social cohesion. It introduced the National Identity Passport of Patriotism in 2014, which contains many of our important symbols that define our national identity. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/06LD2IrhSj

President #Ramaphosa: This is a responsibility that falls on the shoulders of parents, community structures, schools, faith-based organisations, employers, trade unions, civil society and all public bodies. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: While there is much that government can do to reinforce the principles of our Constitution, this is necessarily a task that must be undertaken by all parts of our society. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: The emergence of ethnic chauvinism and narrow nationalism represents a direct challenge to the hopes of our people and the values of our Constitution. We need to respond to these tendencies as a society. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: Nelson Mandela represented the hopes of millions of South Africans who dreamt of a life unshackled from a system that sought to stifle their potential by virtue of their race or ethnicity. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: We are concerned about our debt profile. We have to address this through fiscal prudence and embark on priority expenditure solutions. This is what the next budget will look at. We must generate economic growth to address this challenge. #RamaphosaQandA
President #Ramaphosa: The same conditions that are applicable on all government guaranteed facilities are applicable to the China Development Bank facility. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: As I also indicated in the NCOP, no Eskom assets have been used as security for the loan, and the China Development Bank is not entitled to any direct or indirect ownership of Eskom assets. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: The loan is guaranteed by government under the existing Government Guarantee Framework Agreement. No amendments or conditions were written into the Government Guarantee Framework Agreement for the purposes of this loan. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: As I indicated in the National Council of Provinces in September, there are no specific conditions for the loan that Eskoms received from the China Development Bank. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: We are advocating for the reform of the UN Security Council. Our message is gaining traction and we are getting support across the continent. We will continue to advocate for full representation. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: The UN Security Council is the mandated with the responsibility to maintain international peace & security. South Africa will therefore use its position to work collectively with others to promote a more equitable and inclusive global order. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/Ov8NOqs2rh
President #Ramaphosa: Even the most powerful states cannot achieve security, nor maintain prosperity and health for their people by acting unilaterally or in isolation. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: The current global environment is characterised by various threats to international peace and security, continued poverty and underdevelopment, the displacement of populations, global migration, inequality and climate change. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: We will emphasise the need to work through multilateral institutions to advance post-conflict reconstruction & development, to promote the peaceful resolution of conflict & to champion the cause of children in armed conflict situations. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/DdNemM1gFk

President #Ramaphosa: In addition to country specific conflict situations, serving on the Council will also provide South Africa with an opportunity to place emphasis on the importance of women in peace and security operations. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: South Africa’s presence on the UN Security Council presents an opportunity to work with the other two African countries serving on the Council, Equatorial Guinea and Cote d’Ivoire, to promote peace and stability on the continent. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/Bmt8xNzit9
President #Ramaphosa: While South Africa will engage on all issues on the Council’s agenda, Africa will remain our central priority. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: It will seek to bring together divergent perspectives and seek to resolve impasses which undermine the ability of the Council to act where needed. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/L7oYn7RbtK
President #Ramaphosa: South Africa will use its term on the Security Council to honour former President Nelson Mandela’s legacy by focusing on conflict prevention and mediation. #RamaphosaQandA
President #Ramaphosa: South Africa will become a member of the United Nations Security Council in the non-permanent category for the third time, for the term 2019-2020. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: We must ensure inter-governmental alignment across national, provincial and local government. Public representatives must engage with communities on an ongoing basis to ensure that their needs and concerns are being addressed. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/71879kacUE

President #Ramaphosa: If we are to effectively address the causes of community protests and improve the conditions under which people in these communities live, it is necessary to proceed in a systematic manner. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: The work of the team is supported by a programme management office located at MISA, the Municipal Infrastructure Support Agent. This office draws directly on the MISA technical team of over 50 professional engineers, planners & professionals #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: A set of strategies and action plans are being developed focused on the short, medium and long-term interventions. The inter-ministerial task team has begun a process to ensure that all government expenditure on service delivery is integrated and aligned.

President #Ramaphosa: The inter-ministerial task team has adopted an approach to enhance integrated planning budgeting and implementation of service delivery programmes in 57 municipalities. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/oxawhPGeQ6

President #Ramaphosa: The inter-ministerial task team includes the ministers of Cooperative Governance, Human Settlements, Energy, Water and Sanitation, Transport, Environmental Affairs, Health, Basic Education and Sports and Recreation. #RamaphosaQandA
President #Ramaphosa: It is necessary to addresses the causes of these protests in an integrated and comprehensive manner. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: Many of these protests, both those that are peaceful and those that turn violent, reflect the severe weaknesses in local governance, poor consultation and a perceived distance between communities & their public representatives at all levels. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: There are several reasons for community protests, ranging from local service delivery failures to broader concerns around crime, municipal demarcation or corruption. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: We shouldn’t criminalize our children; we should have more social workers & community workers. The police are a last line for when the wheels come off. We must play a collective role in bringing up children who will not get involved with crimininal activity.pic.twitter.com/mdS7Y91SYa

President #Ramaphosa: We need to embark on initiatives aimed at reducing the temptation for our people to get involved in criminal activity. We must provide services that will restore dignity. A multi-dimensional approach is required to address this challenge. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: Unless we work together as a society to curb violence in schools as a matter of urgency, we will find it difficult to curb crime and violence in our society for many years to come. #RamaphosaQandA
President #Ramaphosa: The strategy will also enhance inter-governmental approaches against criminal elements and respond to factors that contribute to crime. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: Among the tangible initiatives is the national youth crime prevention strategy, which is currently being developed. The strategy aims to integrate government efforts to prevent youth criminality, including in institutions of learning. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: These summits proceed from the understanding that violence in schools is a social problem, which can only be addressed through collaboration between government, stakeholders and communities. #RamaphosaQandA
President #Ramaphosa: School safety also featured prominently in the National Youth Crime Prevention Summit held in June this year. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: To address these, the Department of Basic Education, in collaboration with SAPS, the departments of Social Development and Justice and other stakeholders in education recently convened a School Safety Summit. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: The majority of the pupils that are involved in criminal activities are also affected by social challenges in their communities such as substance abuse, domestic violence and other crimes. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: The police, in collaboration with various stakeholders, undertake social crime prevention programmes that focus on substance abuse, bullying, violence prevention, sexual offences and cyber-related matters. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: School safety committees have been established, comprising of school management, police, school governing bodies and other relevant stakeholders. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/35zZYavC8y

President #Ramaphosa: The South African Police Service has appointed dedicated school safety officers in most areas to serve as liaison officers between the police and the schools. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/lsBu1edYoi
President #Ramaphosa: As a consequence, a number of safety measures have been put in place, including that all schools in the country should be linked to a specific police station. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: The purpose of this protocol is to create a safe, friendly and caring learning environment within schools and to promote multi-stakeholder collaboration in the fight against criminal activities in schools. #RamaphosaQandA
President #Ramaphosa: In response to these challenges in schools, the South African Police Service and the Department of Basic Education have entered into a Protocol on School Safety. #RamaphosaQandA
President #Ramaphosa: Our schools must be places where learners feel safe and secure. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: It is a symptom of some of the social problems confronting young people, which require concerted and consistent action by all stakeholders. School-based violence undermines the environment necessary for effective teaching and learning. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: Opportunities to draw institutional investors, including pension funds, into infrastructure spending is also being explored. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: In addition to this budgeted funding, state owned enterprises will continue to invest in new energy, transport and water infrastructure. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: The plan recognises that infrastructure expansion and maintenance is a critical driver of economic activity and has the potential to create a large number of jobs. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: The economic stimulus and recovery plan announced on 21 September outlined decisive steps to rebuild investor confidence and mobilise investment to unlock the growth potential of the South African economy. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: I have told my children they should not do any business with SOEs but I do know from time to time some of these activities can surface. But the filter I apply as their father is, if there is any illegality, I will take them to jail. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: For the sake of our people and our economy, we need to make a decisive break with these corrupt practices and build a new era of integrity and honesty in all public and private institutions. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/NzxTxWWfpR

President #Ramaphosa: The real tragedy of the VBS saga is that money was stolen from people in our society who could least afford it. It is a tragedy that has repeated itself across several SOEs, in municipalities and with respect to several private companies. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: We take a dim view of those who have been implicated in criminal activity rushing to court to hide their malfeasance and not making any effort to apologise to those who have lost money. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: For much of its existence, VBS was a good bank for ordinary people that gave loans and mortgages to people in rural areas – and now, through greed and deception, that bank has been destroyed. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: Action must be taken against those municipal officials who deposited council funds into VBS, knowing that it was not legal, and whose actions could lead to significant financial losses for these municipalities. #RamaphosaQandA
President #Ramaphosa: We call on the relevant authorities to act swiftly to prosecute those responsible and to recover the funds stolen from the bank’s depositors. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: The report presents a deeply disturbing picture of theft and corruption on a massive scale. It is essential that all those responsible for facilitating this fraud and corruption, and all those who benefited from it, are held to account. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: In response to my request for a comprehensive report on VBS, I received a briefing from Treasury & Reserve Bank officials on the report submitted by Adv Terry Motau to the Prudential Authority in October 2018 just before its public release. #RamaphosaQandA
President #Ramaphosa: I was informed that the South African Reserve Bank, specifically the Prudential Authority, had initiated an investigation into the issue. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: Shortly after becoming President, I received briefings on various matters by different government departments. One of these briefings was from National Treasury, where I was alerted to alleged corruption at the VBS Mutual Bank. #RamaphosaQandA

#GBVSummit: Address by President @CyrilRamaphosa at the Presidential Summit on Gender-Based Violence and Femicide, St Georges Hotel, Tshwane. https://bit.ly/2PAbtIv pic.twitter.com/XBP1hm0oiU

President #Ramaphosa: I am convinced that by working together, by confronting difficult issues, and by mobilising all South Africans, we shall create a society where women and children feel safe and are safe at all times and in all places. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Personally, I pledge to you that government is here, we are listening and will continue to respond to your concerns. We are looking to this Summit to provide clear direction on a comprehensive national response to gender-based violence.

President #Ramaphosa: Let us put aside the issues that divide us and work together for the greater good. I call on all South Africans to become champions of the fight against gender-based violence & femicide. This is a societal problem that requires society wide responses.
President #Ramaphosa: South Africans have consistently shown that we have a great capacity to deal with big, contentious issues through meaningful and respectful dialogue. Let us now do this again.

President #Ramaphosa: The communication commission at this Summit needs to propose how we educate the media, and more importantly, broader society on how to communicate in gender sensitive ways. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Let us pledge here and now to begin to change the way we communicate about gender-based violence and sexual assault. Our language must empower and support the voices of survivors. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: As a society, we must express our deep gratitude to them for leading the way in the struggle against sexual violence and affirm our commitment to support and protect them. #GBVSummit
President #Ramaphosa: The language we use, too often, places the responsibility on the victim to not be raped or hit instead of placing the blame where it belongs: on the perpetrator.

President #Ramaphosa: We find similar or worse victim blaming in statements such as “Why does she stay with him if he beats her?” or “Why did she wear a mini-skirt to the taxi-rank?” or “How drunk was she?” #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: It was extremely distressing to hear ordinary South Africans question why a parent would let a child play by herself after a six year old was recently raped at a well-known restaurant. The degree of victim blaming evident in this statement is appalling.

President #Ramaphosa: One of the specific demands raised by activists was to establish a central, national coordinating structure for gender-based violence. We should discuss here what form this should take, what must its mandate be and who should be on this structure.

President #Ramaphosa: We agree with the demand that we must continuously ensure that lay counsellors at these centres undergo ongoing training to deal with the needs of victims of violence. #GBVSummit
President #Ramaphosa: This is one of our more effective interventions and we must develop concrete proposals on how we can strengthen the operations of these centres.

President #Ramaphosa: The Thuthuzela Care Centres, our unique one-stop, integrated response to incidents of violent sexual acts against women and children, aim to reduce secondary victimisation, improve conviction rates & reduce the cycle time for finalisation of cases.
President #Ramaphosa: We are asking you, who deal with these issues on a regular basis, to work with us in developing effective response and support mechanisms. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: As we work to address this, we need to hear from those who interact with our criminal justice system. Please tell us what is working, where we need to improve, what needs to be scaled up and what must be done away with. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: This is borne out by the numbers of women and children who tell stories of being turned away by the police when they go to report crime, the number of rape & sexual assault cases which are never prosecuted, and the low percentage of successful prosecutions

President #Ramaphosa: A frequent complaint is that the police and the court system are not equipped and capacitated to effectively assist survivors of gender-based violence and sexual assault. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Together with civil society organisations, we have undertaken a review of our Programme of Action on Violence against Women and Children, and plan to launch the revised POA 2019–2023 during the 16 Days of Activism.

President #Ramaphosa: Government has responded to two specific demands raised during the August marches – conducting a review of national plans to end gender-based violence and the development of a National Action Plan on gender-based violence. #GBVSummit
President #Ramaphosa: We should examine the possibility of introducing a national registry for protection orders. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Protection orders can be obtained in terms of the Domestic Violence Act and, once issued, are enforceable throughout the country, but very often survivors have to flee to other parts of the country where it becomes difficult to obtain copies of those orders.
President #Ramaphosa: This failure to implement our laws and policies effectively is doing a complete disservice to survivors of gender-based violence and others affected by violence.

President #Ramaphosa: Despite having progressive laws & being a signatory to many international instruments – such as CEDAW &the UN Declaration of Basic Principles of Justice for Victims of Crime & Abuse of Power – our country does not have an effective, coordinated response.
President #Ramaphosa: This points to the need to target our education programmes at young children in order to make a difference in attitudes from the start. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: However, better results are found where education programmes target boys and young men. Boys and young men who participate in school-wide programmes targeting change in social attitudes tend to show a marked reduction in peer violence.

President #Ramaphosa: Research shows contradictory results about whether the economic and social empowerment of adult men makes a marked difference on whether they continue to perpetrate violence. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Where women become more economically, socially & culturally empowered, they develop greater capacity to extricate themselves from abusive situations. We need to invest more in research that develops evidence-based interventions to end gender-based violence

President #Ramaphosa: Studies that were conducted here in South Africa show that where interventions are linked to the economic and social empowerment of women, intimate partner violence is decreased. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Very often families exert the most pressure on women and children not to press charges against abusers. A critical component of prevention strategies for gender-based violence is the empowerment of women. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Our country has significant substance abuse problems and we need better policies and programmes to prevent substance abuse. Our society is too tolerant of violence against women, often forcing women to withdraw charges against the perpetrators.

President #Ramaphosa: Alcohol and drug abuse is a major risk factor associated with gender-based violence. Researchers suggest that alcohol and drugs either induce violence or are used as excuses for perpetrating violence on women and children. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: The programme to train officials and educators to recognise abused and at risk learners was started in two provinces in 2015 and needs to be mainstreamed by including such training in the pre-service training curriculum. #GBVSummit
President #Ramaphosa: The Department also needs to urgently speed up its programmes aimed at offering psycho-social support to vulnerable learners.

President #Ramaphosa: The Department of Basic Education needs to complete its curriculum transformation programme, especially the auditing of learning materials for latent sexism and racism. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: The effects of trauma on children are quite severe and last well beyond the immediate instances of violence. Children who experience violence are more likely to experience violence or become perpetrators of violence in adulthood. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Most importantly we must ensure that our law enforcement officers are trained to investigate the cases of abuse to get convictions in these cases. There are several intersections between violence experienced by women and violence against children.

President #Ramaphosa: Most importantly we must ensure that our law enforcement officers are trained to investigate the cases of abuse to get convictions in these cases. There are several intersections between violence experienced by women and violence against children.

President #Ramaphosa: A society that does not support notions of authority and control over women, and does not tolerate violence against women, is more likely to reduce gender-based violence. We must name and shame those who perpetrate violence against girls and women.

President #Ramaphosa: We must raise boys and girls with the knowledge and understanding that no person has the right to treat them as inferior or to harm them in any way and that boys and girls are equal in all respects. #GBVSummit
President #Ramaphosa: When we improve the way we raise our children we can go a long way to preventing violence against girls and boys. #GBVSummit
President #Ramaphosa: Social perceptions about the roles of girls and boys, and preconceived notions of how women and men should behave, are often harmful to the development of both sexes. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: This can lead to situations where women may find themselves tolerating the injustices perpetrated against them simply because they may have inadequate economic or emotional resources to walk away from a dangerous relationship. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: It requires that we address societal issues of patriarchy, economic relations and changing the way of thinking about gender relations. Patriarchy means that men feel entitled to exert economic and other forms of power over women. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: There is a danger that society begins to normalise such practices. That is why we need to be vigilant. Condemnation needs to be constant and consistent, perpetrators need to be prosecuted. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Women are often violated by their intimate partners, often in the privacy of their homes. They are slapped, hit, raped, assaulted and emotionally abused and killed because they are with a man who feels entitled to exert power and control over them.
President #Ramaphosa: There is no acceptable level of gender-based violence. We want to eradicate it. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: We cannot, and we will not, rest until we have brought those figures down to zero. We are aiming for a femicide rate of ZERO per 100,000. We want to reach a point where no woman, child or man has to experience the violence, violation and trauma of rape.

President #Ramaphosa: According to the SAPS Crime Statistics report of 2018, femicide increased by 11% over the last two years. Stats SA reports that 138 per 100,000 women were raped last year, the highest rate in the world. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: In South Africa, we know that the problem is even more severe. We are a country with relatively high levels of violence and criminality. Slightly more than 20,000 people were killed in the past year, the majority of the perpetrators and victims were men.

President #Ramaphosa: The World Health Organisation tell us that 35% of women worldwide experienced physical or sexual intimate partner violence or non-partner sexual violence in 2013. This is an alarming figure that underscores the need for global cooperation in overcoming GBV.

President #Ramaphosa: We are here today to listen and learn from the experiences of survivors; to hear their voices and to have the lived experiences of women and children inform our responses to gender-based violence. Gender-based violence is a global phenomenon.

President #Ramaphosa: We are agreed that we need a multi-sectoral approach that responds to the demands of the marchers, and strengthens the broader interventions that address the causes and effects of such violence. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: This promise was made following the activism, borne out of pain and anger, of those who held marches around the country to highlight the scourge of gender-based violence and femicide in this country. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: This promise was made following the activism, borne out of pain and anger, of those who held marches around the country to highlight the scourge of gender-based violence and femicide in this country. #GBVSummit
President #Ramaphosa: In August, I made a commitment that we shall convene this Summit to develop a national plan of action against gender-based violence. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: One moment of violence can have permanent consequences. Most of us know someone who is a survivor of gender-based violence or who has in some other way been affected by this evil. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: When abuse occurs in a situation of trust, whether in the family, the church, in schools or elsewhere, the sense of betrayal is intensified. The physical and psychological effects may recede, but they very rarely disappear. #GBVSummit
President #Ramaphosa: Survivors of sexual violence and abuse – be it physical, psychological or economic – often live with these scars for the rest of their lives. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Gender-based violence is an affront to our shared humanity. The unrelenting murder of women – for no reason other than that they are women – is steadily corroding the soul of our nation. #GBVSummit

President #Ramaphosa: We are gathered here – as South African women and men – to respond to a crisis that is tearing our society apart. It is a crisis that affects every community in our country and that touches the lives of most families in one way or another. #GBVSummit

“We have made enormous progress through our investment envoys who have been traveling the world interacting with potential investors; I’m overwhelmed by the level of interest shown in the South African economy.” President @CyrilRamaphosa during Bloomberg interview #InvestSApic.twitter.com/DrzR290I88

President @CyrilRamaphosa sat for an exclusive interview with Bloomberg on the sidelines of the South Africa Investment Conference 2018 currently taking place at the Sandton Convention Centre in Johannesburg. #InvestSApic.twitter.com/yxQmmIVkvs

President @CyrilRamaphosa delivers keynote address at the South Africa Investment Conference 2018 held at the Sandton Convention Centre in Johannesburg under the theme, “Accelerating Growth by Building Partnerships”. #InvestSApic.twitter.com/a61AO7uRSN

President #Ramaphosa: We invite you to become valued partners in realising the vision – and sharing the benefits – of a new era of renewal, an era of discovery, an era of prosperity and progress and promise. #InvestSApic.twitter.com/pZG7k3CWxD

President #Ramaphosa: We invite you to invest in our mines and factories, farms and game parks, call centres and technology hubs, refineries and solar farms. We invite you to invest in our people, to harness their energy and unleash their latent capabilities. #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: It is a land that has known the pain of division and conflict and deprivation. But, equally, it has experienced the exhilaration of liberation and knows very well the value of partnership and collaboration. #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: As South Africa emerges from a period of great difficulty and uncertainty, as it confronts challenges that are immense – but not insurmountable – we can declare with confidence that South Africa is a land of untold opportunity. #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: South Africa’s strategic position at the tip of Africa, makes it a key investment location, both for opportunities that lie within its borders and as a gateway to the rest of the region.pic.twitter.com/jpIQtrGTlZ

President #Ramaphosa: Together with robust legislation to protect foreign investments, an independent judiciary and the firm rule of law, our Constitution should allay any fears that investors may have of factories being expropriated. #InvestSA
President #Ramaphosa: Our approach reaffirms the constitutional protection of property rights, which, among other things, prohibits the arbitrary deprivation of property. #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: The #JobsSummit agreed on more than 70 focused interventions that will boost domestic demand, increase & broaden exports, create pathways for youth into work and develop sectors such as agriculture, manufacturing, mining & the waste economy. #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: Earlier this month, we convened a Presidential #JobsSummit, which brought together government, business, labour and the community sector to determine a set of practical, achievable interventions that would increase the pace of job creation. #InvestSA
#InvestSA: Opening Address by President @CyrilRamaphosa at the South Africa Investment Conference, Sandton Convention Centre, Johannesburg. https://bit.ly/2EUKEue
President #Ramaphosa: The factory employs 800 workers, of which half are women. We applaud this investment as it confirms South Africa’s manufacturing capability.pic.twitter.com/xSGWZ6ASOQ

President #Ramaphosa: Yesterday I had occasion to open the R1 billion Gibela passenger train manufacturing factory in this province. The investment is a collaboration between Alstom from France and a local consortium made up of black businesses and the community. #InvestSApic.twitter.com/GYHLdciyYS

President #Ramaphosa: We see infrastructure investment as a critical enabler of growth and job creation, and are therefore consolidating government infrastructure spending into a single Infrastructure Fund. #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: As the Minister of Finance indicated when presenting his #MTBPS earlier in the week, we are determined to ensure public spending remains within sustainable levels – and that we generate greater revenue by pursuing growth with a single-minded determination.
President #Ramaphosa: Government also signed off a number of outstanding renewal energy supply agreements, bringing significant further investment into a growing sector of our economy.
President #Ramaphosa: Through the publication of a new Integrated Resource Plan for public comment, we have provided detail on the country’s future energy requirements. #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: The revised Mining Charter has been finalised. This is the outcome of extensive & meaningful consultation between government, community, labour and business and represents evidence of our commitment to solving the challenges in the sector collaboratively.

President #Ramaphosa: As part of this plan, we are taking immediate steps to finalise reforms in key sectors like mining, oil & gas, tourism & telecomms – all of which are sectors that have great potential for growth, but which have been constrained by policy uncertainty.
President #Ramaphosa: Last month, government announced an economic stimulus and recovery plan that aims to restore growth, save existing jobs and create new ones. #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: As a country, we have also had to confront the bitter reality that several public entities have been severely affected by corruption and the phenomenon of state capture. We have resolved to end such corruption and hold those responsible to account. #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: We have replaced the leadership in several state owned enterprises, ensuring that we have people with experience, integrity and the relevant skills who are now leading the development and implementation of sustainable business models. #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: Given the crucial role of these state owned enterprises in the economy, as providers of critical infrastructure and bulk services, it is essential that they be restored as engines of growth and development. #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: As part of the decisive measures that we have had to take, we have had to confront challenges in some of our largest and most strategic SOEs, which have experienced years of poor governance, a decline in financial and operational performance and corruption.pic.twitter.com/weINZk1noh

President #Ramaphosa: We’ve been working with the World Bank to improve the ease of doing business in South Africa & crafting a new FDI strategy for the country. Invest SA is intensifying its facilitation & aftercare service in terms of international best practice. #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: Following thoroughgoing consultations with various role players in our economy, we have been addressing issues of policy uncertainty and regulatory obstacles that have impeded investments in a number of industries. #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: I call upon South African companies to engage with our investment envoys on their investment plans, including capital expenditure programmes, so that we can have a better idea of what the future portends for our country on the economic growth landscape.

President #Ramaphosa: We have emphasised the need for more South African companies to lead the investment charge, demonstrating that they have confidence in this economy and in its ability to deliver decent and reliable returns. #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: In addition to the announcements that will be made at this conference we have received investment pledges from a number of countries. We have appointed task teams to work with these countries to convert these pledges into investments. #InvestSApic.twitter.com/3ukIw1f7f9
President #Ramaphosa: Today, a number of local and international companies will make announcements on investments to expand existing operations in the country or establish new ones. #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: Invest SA, our award-winning investment promotion and facilitation agency, has compiled an investment book of projects that represent great potential. #InvestSApic.twitter.com/4CSttL8kb0

President #Ramaphosa: Over the last half year, as we have prepared for this conference, our four Presidential investment envoys – Phumzile Langeni, Jacko Maree, Mcebisi Jonas and Trevor Manuel – have travelled across the country and around the globe to meet potential investors.
President #Ramaphosa: We did so understanding that no meaningful growth and no significant job creation would be possible without a massive surge in productive investment in the economy. #InvestSA
President #Ramaphosa: In April this year we launched an ambitious and, in the history of our country, unprecedented, drive to raise at least $100 billion in new investment over five years. #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: We have placed economic growth & job creation at the centre of our national agenda. We have prioritised the education of our children and the skilling of our workforce, and we are accelerating the provision of land & other assets to the poor & marginalised.

President #Ramaphosa: This inaugural Conference is an expression of a shared hope and a renewed confidence. It is a bold and unequivocal statement that we are determined to put behind us the period of uncertainty and discord and embrace a future of cooperation and partnership.pic.twitter.com/mdmbKyqrtY

LIVE FEED: President @CyrilRamaphosa addresses the Opening Session of the South Africa Investment Conference in Sandton, Johannesburg. #InvestSA https://www.facebook.com/PresidencyZA/videos/256373088399255/ …pic.twitter.com/mC2QIBLdMq

President #Ramaphosa: Like us, you believe that South Africa is a land of opportunity – a land where the soil is rich and the oceans teem with life, where the beautiful vistas of our country are spectacular and its diverse people are vibrant and resilient. #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: As representatives of the domestic and international investment community, as representatives of business organisations and international financial institutions, you have chosen to walk with us along the path of growth, employment and shared prosperity.

President #Ramaphosa: I am pleased to welcome you all to this inaugural investment conference. We are pleased and humbled that you have responded to the call by the government and the people of South Africa to be part of a new dawn in our country. #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: Working together as South Africans – and in concert with partners across the globe – we can be certain that we will indeed build a better Africa and a better world. #HeadsOfMission #BetterAfricaBetterWorld #InvestSApic.twitter.com/PNlAtQ1qZ5

President #Ramaphosa: They taught us that the race will never be won until all South Africans are able to lead lives of dignity, in peace and in prosperity. Their lives provide ample evidence of the limitless potential of the human spirit to persevere and to prevail.
Address by President Cyril Ramaphosa at the South African Heads of Mission Conference, OR Tambo Building, Tshwane https://bit.ly/2R3crtG

President #Ramaphosa: As we undertake the critical task of renewal and rebuilding, we draw strength from the knowledge that we stand on the shoulders of giants like Tata Mandela and Mama Sisulu. Their examples have shown us that we can triumph over adversity. #HeadsOfMission

President #Ramaphosa: It is up to us to make sure we take full advantage of the opportunities that exist for the benefit of all our people. We have emerged from a difficult decade, which has dampened confidence and slowed our progress. #HeadsOfMissionpic.twitter.com/Lu6ijqDj6E

President #Ramaphosa: We exist in an ever-changing and complex global environment. As a country, as a brand, as a trade partner and as an investment destination, South Africa has what it takes to compete on the world stage.

President #Ramaphosa: We will focus on uniting the diverse countries that constitute the association behind an agenda of peace, stability and sustainable development. #HeadsOfMission #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: South Africa will also be Chairing the Indian Ocean Rim Association, which we view as the pre-eminent regional organisation linking Africa, Middle East, Asia and Australasia. #HeadsOfMission #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: We are also taking the #FOCAC grouping towards a strategic partnership, in which China will be a significant partner in developing African infrastructure and promoting regional integration. #HeadsOfMission

President #Ramaphosa: In addition to reaffirming our shared commitment to multilateralism and the interests of the countries of the global South, we developed an ambitious agenda for cooperation on the 4th Industrial Revolution.
President #Ramaphosa: Earlier this year we successfully hosted the #BRICS countries, establishing the foundation for a decade of greater cooperation, development and progress.

President #Ramaphosa: I will be departing for Berlin later this week to participate in the #G20 Africa Conference, hosted by Chancellor Merkel. We will reflect on the #G20 Africa Partnership, inclusive of the Compact with Africa that seeks to enhance private sector investment.

President #Ramaphosa: South Africa will continue to use its membership of the #G20 to promote inclusive growth and development and support the Argentinian Presidency in their efforts towards consensus building and fair and sustainable development.

President #Ramaphosa: On the multilateral level, this year marks the 10th anniversary of the #G20 being held at summit level. The meeting this year takes place in the context of uncertainty, increased unilateralism and protectionism by some #G20 Members. #MembersOfMission

President #Ramaphosa: Our banking system is solid, well capitalised, well-regulated and internationally respected. There is no doubt that we have a very solid base to work from. #HeadsOfMission #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: Ranked 61/147 in the WEF’s latest Global Competitiveness Report, South Africa offers investors the stability of a well-regulated & developed country, an effective legal environment, cost competitiveness & reliable infrastructure. #HeadsOfMission #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: Our democracy is resilient, we are making progress in addressing the immediate challenges we face, and we are establishing a foundation for lasting growth and fundamental transformation. #HeadsOfMission #InvestSApic.twitter.com/96AGgIZkxl

President #Ramaphosa: Our ability to generate foreign investment in our country depends in large measure on the image of our country abroad, which is one of the core responsibilities of our diplomats. #HeadsOfMission #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: We are investigating and prosecuting cases of corruption. The governance and management of key state owned enterprises is being overhauled to ensure they are held accountable to fulfil their economic and developmental mandates. #HeadsOfMission #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: For example, we have initiated changes to our visa regime to attract more skilled workers and tourists. Processes to restore confidence in our institutions and organisations of governance are underway. #HeadsOfMission #InvestSApic.twitter.com/jxOX9B0bL2

President #Ramaphosa: Over the past few months, we have already achieved a number of milestones in our quest for improved investment, resulting in renewed levels of business confidence. #HeadsOfMission #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: Additional resources from development finance institutions, multilateral development banks and private lenders and investors will also be leveraged through this fund. #HeadsOfMission #InvestSA
President #Ramaphosa: This will be used to address infrastructure gaps in areas such as roads, water infrastructure, schools, human settlements and public transport. #HeadsOfMissions #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: South Africa’s infrastructure is one of the country’s strongest attractions for investors. As part of the work that we must undertake now to stimulate growth, we are consolidating our R400 billion MTEF infrastructure budget into an Infrastructure Fund.

President #Ramaphosa: As part of our investment-friendly approach, we are focusing on addressing structural weaknesses in the economy, rebuilding investor confidence, restoring good governance in public institutions & creating a supportive environment for those who want to invest

President #Ramaphosa: The Summit agreed that the ‘Buy South Africa’ should be significantly upscaled and that we should take advantage of new opportunities in Africa through regional and continental integration. #HeadsOfMission #BuyLocal #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: The Investment Conference follows the successful #JobsSummit held earlier this month, where more than 70 interventions were identified to protect existing jobs and create new ones. #HeadsOfMission #InvestSApic.twitter.com/qT9dNE83qF

President #Ramaphosa: It is our missions abroad that are leading our economic diplomacy, that need to ensure that the outcomes of the conference are conveyed around the world, and that are responsible for assisting the expansion of trade & investment links with partner countries.

President #Ramaphosa: This Heads of Mission Conference therefore takes place at an important moment, for it is you, our diplomats, who must play a pivotal role in driving the message that South Africa is open for business. #HeadsOfMission #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: The Conference will discuss opportunities in sectors like agriculture, minerals, manufacturing, transportation, energy, water, ICT, tourism and film. #HeadsOfMission #InvestSApic.twitter.com/5gB1XPZpQk

President #Ramaphosa: The conference is an integral part of government’s ambitious drive to raise $100 billion in new investment over 5 years, stimulate economic growth and create jobs. #HeadsOfMission #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: In just two days from now, we will open the South Africa Investment Conference in Johannesburg, a critical intervention to showcase opportunities for both domestic and foreign investors. #HeadsOfMission #InvestSA

President #Ramaphosa: We want to regain public and investor trust, and thereby unlock private capital and promote investment. Above all, we want to see our people secure dignified, meaningful employment to ensure that all South Africans benefit from economic growth.

President #Ramaphosa: To address these challenges, government is on an ambitious drive to grow our economy, anchored in cooperation between government, business, labour and civil society. We want to get our economy going following a period of stagnant growth. #HeadsOfMission
President #Ramaphosa: Although we have registered notable progress in the 24 years since democracy, we still grapple with the triple challenge of unemployment, poverty and inequality. #HeadsOfMission

President #Ramaphosa: As we reflect on their respective legacies, we are ever mindful of the sacrifices they and many others made for our liberation. We carry a weighty responsibility to ensure that their sacrifices were not in vain, and to realise their vision for South Africa.

President #Ramaphosa: This year marks the centenaries of two titans of the liberation struggle, Tata Nelson Mandela and Mama Albertina Sisulu. As we reflect on their respective legacies, we are ever mindful of the sacrifices they & many others made for our liberation.

President #Ramaphosa: It was the people of Africa who extended the hand of friendship and solidarity to us during the dark days of apartheid, and today it is African countries who are our valued allies and trade partners. #HeadsOfMission

President #Ramaphosa: In accepting the Nobel Peace Prize in 1961, Inkosi Albert Luthuli said: “I accept this also as an honour not only to South Africa, but for the whole continent of Africa, to this continent, Mother Africa!” #HeadsOfMission

President #Ramaphosa: At the same time, we wholly identify with the aspirations of Agenda 2063 of the African Union and its vision of “an integrated, prosperous and peaceful Africa, driven by its own citizens and representing a dynamic force in the international arena”.

President #Ramaphosa: In all our efforts, we are guided by the National Development Plan 2030, which provides a roadmap for unleashing the energies of our citizens, growing an inclusive economy, building capabilities and enhancing the ability of the state. #HeadsOfMission

President #Ramaphosa: In the midst of global uncertainty, we are fortunate to have at the helm of our diplomatic service an experienced and capable corps of people who can be relied upon to steadfastly promote our progressive international agenda. #HeadsOfMission

President #Ramaphosa: We strive to advance our national interest in a global landscape that is in a constant state of flux, where political, social and economic forces beyond our control have a direct bearing on our efforts. #HeadsOfMission

Statement by President @CyrilRamaphosa on position of Finance Minister. http://bit.ly/2yoCNPp pic.twitter.com/4fXVnrfsA1

President @CyrilRamaphosa looks on as new Minister of Finance Mr Tito Mboweni takes his oath of office. Mr Tito Mboweni takes over this role from Mr Nhlanhla Nene with immediate effect.pic.twitter.com/HAB0QmSnTe

Dr Cassius Lubisi, Director-General in The Presidency requests President @CyrilRamaphosa to proceed with the swearing in ceremony of the new Minister of Finance, Mr Tito Mboweni.pic.twitter.com/1gQ7ln4RQS
President #Ramaphosa: Once more, I wish to thank Mr Nene for his tireless service to the country, and wish Mr Mboweni well in his new role.pic.twitter.com/s4blwG7CM9

President #Ramaphosa: Throughout this process, we need to be guided by the values & principles of our Constitution, mindful of the importance of due process, committed to good governance & determined that the Commission of Inquiry will succeed in fulfilling its critical mandate.

President #Ramaphosa: For the country to move forward, we need to establish the full extent of state capture, identify those responsible for facilitating it, and take decisive steps to prevent it happening again.pic.twitter.com/wMZLo0ubl6

President #Ramaphosa: It is incumbent upon any person who may have knowledge of any of the matters within the Commission’s mandate to provide that information to the Commission, to do so honestly and to do so fully.
President #Ramaphosa: In this process, no person should be above scrutiny, and all relevant and credible accusations of wrongdoing should be thoroughly investigated.

President #Ramaphosa: Allow me to conclude with a few remarks about the Commission of Inquiry into State Capture. It is critical that the Commission has the means and opportunity to effectively fufil its mandate.

President #Ramaphosa: This moment calls for strong, capable and steady leadership that will unlock new opportunities as we grow and transform our economy. I am confident that Mr Mboweni will provide that leadership.

President #Ramaphosa: Mr Mboweni takes on this responsibility at a critical moment for our economy, as we intensify cooperation among all social partners to increase investment, accelerate growth and create jobs on a substantial scale.
President #Ramaphosa: In the wake of Mr Nene’s resignation, I have decided to appoint Mr Tito Mboweni as Minister of Finance with immediate effect.pic.twitter.com/MowoxsnboA
President #Ramaphosa: I wish to take this opportunity to thank him for his service to the nation.pic.twitter.com/uXkxbGf7vQ

President #Ramaphosa: It is a measure of his character and his commitment to the national interest that he has taken this decision to resign in the wake of errors of judgment, even though he has not been implicated in acts of wrongdoing.
President #Ramaphosa: Under difficult circumstances and often under great pressure, he consistently defended the cause of proper financial management and clean governance.
President #Ramaphosa: During his tenure as Minister of Finance, Mr Nene served the people and government of South Africa with diligence and ability.
President #Ramaphosa: After due consideration of the evidence presented by Minister Nene at the Commission, and in the interests of good governance, I have decided to accept his resignation.

President #Ramaphosa: He has indicated that there is risk that the developments around his testimony will detract from the important task of serving the people of South Africa, particularly as we work to re-establish public trust in government.

President #Ramaphosa: As a consequence of these developments, Minister Nene submitted a letter of resignation this morning in which he requested that I relieve him of the position of the Minister of Finance.

President #Ramaphosa: Over the course of the last few days there has been much discussion among South Africans on matters that arose in the course of the testimony of Minister Nhlanhla Nene at the Commission of Inquiry into State Capture.

President @CyrilRamaphosa, Minister Cwele, Deputy Minister Ndabeni-Abrahams, Mr Comfort Ngidi (SAPO Board Chairperson), Mr Mark Barnes (SAPO CEO) during a photo session at the unveiling of the Presidential Postal Stamp at Tuynhuys in Cape Town.pic.twitter.com/Q57aYjcPRu

President @CyrilRamaphosa accepts the framed Presidential Commemorative Stamp. President Ramaphosa is joined by @DTPSZA Minister Siyabonga Cwele, Deputy Minister Stella Ndabeni-Abrahams, SAPO Board Chairperson Mr Comfort Ngidi and CEO Mr Mark Barnes #WorldPostDaypic.twitter.com/a2Vi4zB5Th
President #Ramaphosa: When you paste this stamp onto a postal item and send it into the world or the country, it will indeed be the realisation of #ThumaMina.
President #Ramaphosa: Now we have arrived at the moment where postal becomes personal and where I am honoured to officially unveil the Presidential Commemorative Stamp.

President #Ramaphosa: I am confident that they will be pleasantly inspired by what they discover and that their enterprises will, as a result, flourish around our countryside in the same way the Post Office has become a pervasive feature of our national life.

President #Ramaphosa: It is my wish that new entrants to our economy – and especially young entrepreneurs – will explore the full range of business and civic solutions offered by the South African Post Office.pic.twitter.com/E9rqMlcNrF

President #Ramaphosa: As we deepen economic transformation and create new value streams in our economy, our postal services are poised to bring new goods and services to the nation, create new jobs, create new wealth and help us build an inclusive knowledge society.
President #Ramaphosa: It is for this reason that we must increase internet connectivity in all post offices across the country to ensure that everyone, particularly the youth, benefit.

President #Ramaphosa: The South African Post Office is presented with the task – in a time of rapid technological change – of giving all South Africans the benefit of participating in the digital society.

President #Ramaphosa: The services offered by the South African Post Office manifest our tireless effort to improve the quality of life of all citizens and free the potential of each person in line with the precepts of our Constitution.
President #Ramaphosa: The South African Post Office occupies a special place in our endeavours to build a united, cohesive and proud South African nation.

President #Ramaphosa: Post offices remain an important part of our nation’s economic & social landscape in urban centres & far-flung villages. More than 5 million social grant recipients recently became part of the beneficiaries of the diverse services offered by post offices

President #Ramaphosa: Postal services have been an important catalyst for economic growth and should remain so into our digitised future. The opening up of new opportunities with online commerce present our postal sector with new opportunities.

President #Ramaphosa: Postal services have been pivotal in the every day lives of people and businesses, and have made a significant contribution to global social and economic development. More than simply facilitating commerce, postal services brought people closer together.

President #Ramaphosa: It is a great honour & pleasure to accept this Commemorative Stamp on #WorldPostDay. When World Post Day was declared at the 1969 Universal Postal Congress in Tokyo, it was to signal that the world was then shifting towards a globalised citizenship.

Today marks #WorldPostDay - the anniversary of the establishment of the Universal Postal Union in 1874 in Bern, Switzerland - celebrated on 9th October each year. This year World Post Day is observed under the theme: “The post delivering good to the world.”

The Post Office honours all South African Presidents with a stamp. Heads of State and former Heads of State are the only living people who can feature on stamps. President Ramaphosa is the 5th President of the Republic to be honoured in this manner since the advent of democracy.pic.twitter.com/JVjAXDIrBl

President @CyrilRamaphosa hands over the National Flag to the Next of Kin during the burial service of the late Minister of Environmental Affairs, Dr Edna Molewa a at the Zaandfontein Cemetery in Tshwane, Gauteng. #EdnaMolewaFuneralpic.twitter.com/Q7Y4aqRX1p

General Masondo hands over the National Flag to the Commander-in-Chief, His Excellency President @CyrilRamaphosa during the burial service of the late Minister of Environmental Affairs, Dr Edna Molewa at the Zaandfontein Cemetery in Tshwane, Gauteng. #EdnaMolewaFuneralpic.twitter.com/taRWpzR94A
#EdnaMolewaFuneral: President @CyrilRamaphosa during the Official Funeral of Former Minister of Environmental Affairs, Edna Molewa.pic.twitter.com/aNJDC7KcWo
#EdnaMolewaFuneral: Eulogy by President @CyrilRamaphosa at the Official Funeral of Former Minister of Environmental Affairs, Ms Edna Molewa. http://bit.ly/2PhzK2u pic.twitter.com/1McwIPjQFY

President #Ramaphosa: Her legacy lives on in the people of this great land, as they strive together, sparing neither strength nor courage, to build the free, equal and just society to which she dedicated her very being. May her soul rest in peace. #EdnaMolewaFuneral

President #Ramaphosa: It is in the rich African soil, it is in our clear blue skies, it is in the abundance of our oceans, in the unique plants and the bountiful wildlife that we cherish and respect and preserve. #EdnaMolewaFuneralpic.twitter.com/pgaQbvulSD

President #Ramaphosa: Receive her, your sister and comrade; a leader who understood too well the dictum that we must become the change we want to see in the world. She has left this mortal world, but her work and her legacy is all around us. #EdnaMolewaFuneral

President #Ramaphosa: She joins the pantheon of exemplary women leaders and icons to which this country has given birth. We evoke your spirits - boMama Lilian Ngoyi, Albertina Sisulu, Charlotte Maxeke, Helen Joseph, Ruth Mompati, Dorothy Nyembe and Winnie Madikizela-Mandela.

President #Ramaphosa: Her legacy is deep, impactful and enduring, as it is assured. It is because of leaders like her that we will be able to bequeath to our children and grandchildren that which is the greatest gift of all – our natural world. #EdnaMolewaFuneralpic.twitter.com/ZPVNuaGD3O

President #Ramaphosa: She never waivered in her commitment to the upliftment of our people & to the protection of their rights. We must draw lessons from her life, wholly embracing the concept of cadreship & putting the interests of the collective above those of the individual.

President #Ramaphosa: And yet, while we should welcome the fact that rhino poaching figures on the decline, we know that there is yet much more to be done. The fight against poaching is not over, and we who remain must take it up with as much determination and passion as she did.

President #Ramaphosa: Minister Molewa will be forever remembered by South Africans for her efforts to conserve the country’s wildlife, in particular our rhino. She had promised us that rhino would not go extinct on her watch, and this has been proven to be both prescient & true.

President #Ramaphosa: Dr Molewa was always a champion of women’s issues, and it is remarkable to note that no other country has a wildland fire-fighting capacity that has more than 10% of its fire-fighters being women. #EdnaMolewaFuneral

President #Ramaphosa: It is testament to her hard work that the environmental programmes of the Expanded Public Works Programme continue to be among the most successful we have today, particularly the Working for Water programme, which Dr Molewa was particularly passionate about.

President #Ramaphosa: She was a daughter of the South African soil, with deep love for nature, for her country and for the African region. She led from the front and could often be found out in the field herself, in the trademark SANParks ranger uniform. #EdnaMolewaFuneral

President #Ramaphosa: She was determined to provide dignity to waste-pickers by providing them with opportunities and tools of trade. South Africa pioneered the Recycling Enterprise Support Programme under her leadership #EdnaMolewaFuneral

President #Ramaphosa: As part of the global effort to strike a balance between economic development and ocean health, she was preparing to launch a Source to Sea initiative, an international movement to address the sources of marine and river pollution at source.

President #Ramaphosa: She was a key figure in international environmental governance and was a leading voice in the development of and the subsequent adoption of the UN Agenda 2030 for Sustainable Development and the Sustainable Development Goals. #EdnaMolewaFuneral

President #Ramaphosa: She will be remembered for her unwavering belief in constitutionalism, in democratic values, in the unity of all South Africans, and in the central role of government in forging a society based on freedom, justice and human rights for all. #EdnaMolewaFuneralpic.twitter.com/Stok1KmTed

President #Ramaphosa: Dr Edna Molewa’s life was one of sacrifice, selflessness & service – dedicated to the founding values of the organisation to which she dedicated her life, the African National Congress & dedicated to realising the objectives of our democratic Constitution.

President #Ramaphosa: It is a sad day, as we mourn the untimely passing of our dear sister, colleague and comrade. On behalf of the Government of the Republic of South Africa and on behalf of the nation, I offer my deep condolences to the family. #EdnaMolewaFuneral

Launched in 2004, the Expanded Public Works Programme (EPWP) is a nationwide government initiative covering all spheres of government and SOEs. EPWP provides an important avenue for labour absorption and income transfers to poor households in the short to medium-term. #JobsSummitpic.twitter.com/gjubGVp1yg

President @CyrilRamaphosa visits the Unemployment Insurance Fund (UIF) stand. The UIF provides programmes aimed at providing protection to workers when they become unemployed. #JobsSummitpic.twitter.com/xVeSdeEYzx

“These commitments include clear statements on the time scale for implementation and envisaged employment impact. A monitoring and evaluation framework that ensures accountability amongst partners and to the wider community will support this implementation.“ #JobsSummitpic.twitter.com/33EM6jrVGs
Address by President @CyrilRamaphosa at the opening of the Presidential #JobsSummit Gallagher Estate, Johannesburg. https://bit.ly/2zSATbF

President @CyrilRamaphosa addresses the 2018 Presidential Job Summit in Midrand, Gauteng. #JobsSummithttps://www.pscp.tv/w/boYbkjFyYVFab3lnemVNS3p8MWxEeExYbldQcVB4bczfoCR7Mx5o-Pg8l1iUHjuRTlex9sV-Hg__ACVcBWSW …
President #Ramaphosa: This is part of a series of initiatives supported through the framework agreement to ensure that graduates are absorbed into the economy. #JobsSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Mechanisms are being put in place to enable companies to form partnerships with nearby TVET colleges, where the colleges offer the theoretical component of the programme and companies offer the practical and workplace components. #JobsSummit
President #Ramaphosa: A specific area of focus is the development of the technical skills that are required in the industrial economy.

President #Ramaphosa: One of the country’s greatest potential strengths is our young population, whose capabilities and talents the social partners are committed to develop as a matter of priority. #JobSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Social partners have agreed to maximise the collaboration between public and private sector hubs & incubators. Government will continue to advocate, educate, assist & monitor the implementation of the 30% set aside for SMMEs by all spheres of government.

President #Ramaphosa: If we are to succeed in creating the number of jobs we need, it is essential that small, medium and micro enterprises like these take their rightful place in the economic life of our nation.

President #Ramaphosa: This innovative and welcome initiative will create around 100 jobs initially and aims to contribute to the re-industrialisation of a province which suffers from widespread poverty and unemployment. #JobSummit
President #Ramaphosa: Organised labour, through one of its member unions, plans to open a union-owned clothing factory in the Eastern Cape within the next two years.

President #Ramaphosa: Through our programme of land reform, we will expand the area of land under cultivation, increase the number of people productively working the land & provide rural dwellers with ownership & tenure rights needed to unlock the economic potential of their landpic.twitter.com/FAkCAHY7ad
President #Ramaphosa: The social partners have agreed on strategic interventions in economic sectors that have great potential for growth and even more potential for employment creation. #JobsSummit

President #Ramaphosa: The financial sector, as part of its transformation code, will invest R100bn over 5 years in black-owned industrial enterprises. Government will work with the financial sector to develop facilities for financing at preferential rates & extended terms.
President #Ramaphosa: Through this framework agreement, we will be mobilising finance on a far greater scale, ensuring that it is focused on building our manufacturing capacity. #JobsSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Social partners have agreed to unblock impediments to expanding exports – such as inefficiencies at ports and poor knowledge of potential markets – and to ensure greater support to companies seeking export opportunities. #JobsSummit

President #Ramaphosa: We will seize the opportunities presented by regional integration and the establishment of an African Continental Free Trade Area to produce more goods for other African markets. #JobsSummit #AfCFTA

President #Ramaphosa: From this #JobsSummit, we will embark on an export drive that prioritises manufactured and processed goods, ensuring that we derive the full employment benefit of our mineral and agricultural resources.

President #Ramaphosa: They will be the first to be invited to join a ‘Buy SA Circle’, which recognises companies that are leaders in buying local and have demonstrated in practice their commitment to supporting South African enterprise. #JobsSummit

President #Ramaphosa: These include companies such as Adcock Ingram, Anglogold Ashanti, Clientele, Coca Cola SA, Edcon, First Rand, Lixil, Mondi, Nandos, Nestle, AB InBev, Sappi, Sasol, Standard Bank and Tsogo Sun. #JobsSummitpic.twitter.com/xmJmDRxPCY
President #Ramaphosa: As part of this agreement, a number of companies have made specific commitments to local procurement initiatives as part of their operational strategies. #JobsSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Government has undertaken to simplify and speed up the process for the designation of products for local procurement, and organised labour, in partnership with Proudly SA, will proactively identify opportunities for new designations.

President #Ramaphosa: The framework agreement goes into detail on measures to promote local procurement both within the public and private sectors – even to the point of outlining interventions in specific sectors and companies. #JobsSummit

President #Ramaphosa: The most direct way for South Africans and South African companies to create jobs is to buy only South African products. This is a message that must reverberate across the country and that must find expression in concrete action. #JobsSummit #BuyLocal

President #Ramaphosa: If we do not buy the food that comes out of South African soil, there will be no farms and no farmworkers. If we do not buy the goods made by South African hands, there will be no factories and no workers. #JobsSummit #BuyLocalpic.twitter.com/iRm0PDhOpS

President #Ramaphosa: For the economy to grow and for jobs to be created, it is essential that there is a substantial increase in domestic demand. This means that South African companies, government and consumers must buy local. #JobSummit

President #Ramaphosa: There is agreement that all possible alternatives and opportunities need to be explored before retrenchment is considered, including executive salary sacrifices and the foregoing of dividends.
President #Ramaphosa: Business and government have agreed to establish rapid response teams of experts to assist businesses in crisis. #JobsSummitpic.twitter.com/cQy22ERPrM

President #Ramaphosa: To address this challenge, we have agreed that the training layoff scheme, which was introduced in response to the 2008 global financial crisis, should be immediately revived and improved. #JobsSummit
President #Ramaphosa: All social partners have committed themselves to concrete steps to avoid retrenchments and support struggling companies. #JobsSummit
President #Ramaphosa: As a critical starting point, social partners agreed that in the current economic environment the #JobsSummit must focus on both creating new jobs and retaining existing one.

President #Ramaphosa: This Jobs Summit is not a once-off event, but the first phase of an extensive process in which all social partners will work closely together to improve growth, protect existing jobs and create new jobs.pic.twitter.com/mGYDvDk3AU
President #Ramaphosa: This Presidential #JobsSummit is just the start of a process of engagement and collaboration that will intensify in the coming months.

President #Ramaphosa: Now this framework agreement gives us the opportunity to once again develop trust and forge cooperation. Through this framework agreement we are demonstrating that we are capable of developing a new social compact for jobs, growth and transformation.

President #Ramaphosa: It was by working together that we managed to overcome apartheid, that we brought an end to an intractable conflict that had raged for generations, and were able to write a democratic Constitution that guarantees the equal rights of all. #JobsSummitpic.twitter.com/v9DkAO6BZM

President #Ramaphosa: One of the great difficulties we have faced in recent years is that cooperation between communities, labour, business and government has weakened, making it difficult to advance the collective interest. #JobsSummit

President #Ramaphosa: It is the product of intensive engagement among the social partners over several months, in a spirit of cooperation, consensus building to address a problem that affects all of us. #JobsSummit
President #Ramaphosa: The social partners have agreed that this Presidential Jobs Summit will emerge with a framework agreement that is both ambitious and realisable. #JobsSummit

President #Ramaphosa: I wish to commend all social partners for the hard work that has gone into making this Jobs Summit possible and to thank everyone who has contributed to organising this summit. #JobsSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Since the announcement of the Jobs Summit in the State of the Nation Address in February, all social partners have been engaged in intensive discussions to craft an agreement to begin to address this crisis. #JobsSummit #SONA2018pic.twitter.com/mMEpPHSKe6
President #Ramaphosa: We need to acknowledge that we will not be able to reach that target unless we do something extraordinary. #JobsSummitpic.twitter.com/8Xsf8A2sFA

President #Ramaphosa: In the National Development Plan, we said that if we were to effectively and sustainably tackle this triple challenge, we should aim to reduce unemployment to at least 6% by 2030.
President #Ramaphosa: We have therefore gathered here at this Jobs Summit to respond to these economic challenges, which manifest themselves through unemployment, poverty and inequality. #JobSummit
President #Ramaphosa: The jobs that have been created over the past few years have not kept pace with the growth of the population or the expansion of the workforce. #JobSummit

President #Ramaphosa: As we speak, rising international oil prices combined with investor concerns about emerging economies are pushing up the price of petrol and other fuels, making life harder and more expensive for all South Africans, but particularly the poor. #JobSummit
President #Ramaphosa: Many people, especially young people, lack the skills and work experience needed to find a job and participate meaningfully in the economy.

President #Ramaphosa: While progress has been made in lifting millions of people out of dire poverty, many of our people still face great hardship. The apartheid spatial landscape makes economic opportunities scarce, increases the cost of living and diminishes quality of life.

President #Ramaphosa: State capture and corruption has undermined investor confidence and public trust, eroded key institutions of the state and diverted resources intended to support development. #JobSummit
President #Ramaphosa: Our economic performance has also been undermined by state capture and corruption in both public institutions and private companies. #JobSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Significant levels of public investment in infrastructure, which kept the economy afloat following the 2008 global financial crisis, has been tapering off as consumption spending and debt servicing has consumed a greater portion of our budget. #JobSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Policy uncertainty and inconsistency, onerous regulations and declining business and consumer confidence have curtailed investment in the productive sectors of the economy. #JobSummit

President #Ramaphosa: As a result, the decline of the mining industry and manufacturing has cost the country millions of jobs and much economic capacity. Low levels of growth in recent years has undermined our efforts to overcome the economic legacy of apartheid. #JobSummit
President #Ramaphosa: The structure of the economy, which was built on the extraction of minerals, where ownership and control are highly concentrated, remains largely untransformed. #JobSummit

President #Ramaphosa: The extreme unemployment in the country is the product of an economy that for several decades has been starved of any meaningful investment in its human capital, where most people have been denied the opportunity to own assets or develop skills. #JobSummit

President #Ramaphosa: It has a devastating effect on families and communities, eroding people’s dignity and contributing to social problems like poor health, poor education outcomes, substance abuse and crime. #JobSummit

President #Ramaphosa: Unemployment is the greatest challenge facing our country at this moment in its history. Unemployment diminishes our ability to eradicate poverty, tackle inequality and improve the lives of the working class and poor. #JobSummit

President #Ramaphosa: We gather here today to answer the call of the people of South Africa for decent work. We have gathered here, as social partners, having agreed on a broad range of measures to create and protect jobs. #JobSummit
