President #Ramaphosa: It is for this reason that, earlier this year, we launched an ambitious investment drive to raise $100 billion in new investment over five years. #InvestInSA #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: Greater capital inflows generate greater trade flows, and with it the opportunity for a country like South Africa to derive greater value from its mineral, agricultural and other resources. #InvestInSA #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: Foreign direct investment is critical to this effort, because it strengthens productive capacity through transfer of technology & knowledge, the creation of job opportunities, improvements in human capital & enhanced production processes. #InvestInSA #UNGA
President #Ramaphosa: This is a necessary condition for the growth of our economy and the creation of jobs on a scale that will significantly reduce current levels of unemployment. #InvestInSA
President #Ramaphosa: During #SONA2018, I announced that a central priority for my government is to encourage significant new investment in our economy. #InvestInSA
President #Ramaphosa: And it is through such engagements that investors can gain greater insight into government’s plans and prospects. #InvestInSA

President #Ramaphosa: Thank you very much for this opportunity to have a discussion on the South African investment experience, such engagements enable the South African government to understand what motivates, energises and worries investors. #InvestInSA

President @CyrilRamaphosa addresses the United Nations High-Level Meeting on the Fight to end Tuberculosis at the United Nations Headquarters in New York. #UNGA #EndTB #UNHLMTBpic.twitter.com/5xAe6aiaya

President #Ramaphosa: Please be assured of our commitment to ensuring that we do everything possible to end Tuberculosis as a public health threat by 2030, if not earlier. #UNGA #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: As South Africa, we look forward to the meeting of the UN General Assembly of 2030 where it should be declared that indeed, we have ended the Tuberculosis epidemic. #UNGA #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: The achievement of universal health coverage is essential because those who are most affected by TB are those who have the greatest difficulty accessing health care. #UNGA #BetterAfricaBetterWorld
President #Ramaphosa: Ultimately, all our efforts to end Tuberculosis will not succeed unless we are able to implement universal health coverage. #UNGA #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: We must adhere to the 2001 WTO Doha Declaration on the TRIPS Agreement and Public Health, which recognises that intellectual property rights should be interpreted in a manner that supports public health and promotes access to medicines for all. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: It is only with new tools that we can achieve the dramatic reduction in the incidence of TB needed to ensure total elimination of this disease by 2030 or earlier. To succeed, we need to ensure that drugs are affordable. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: Investing in research and development is critical if we are to develop new diagnostics, vaccines and medicines – and find innovative ways to deal with the social determinants of Tuberculosis and its transmission. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: We would like to see the Declaration emanating from this High-Level Meeting embracing the “Key Asks” and setting in motion the bold response needed to end the global Tuberculosis epidemic. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: South Africa supports the “Key Asks” identified through a consultative process led by the World Health Organization, Stop TB Partnership, civil society and other interested parties. #UNGA
President #Ramaphosa: This is important as the BRICS countries contribute 40% of all drug susceptible TB and 50% of all drug resistant TB globally.

President #Ramaphosa: South Africa is a member of the BRICS TB Research Network, which is a collaboration among BRICS countries on research and development to produce new TB diagnostics, vaccines and medicines. #UNGA
President #Ramaphosa: In South Africa, 60% of people living with HIV are co-infected with TB. This means that any strategy that does not address both the TB and HIV epidemics will not succeed. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: The decline is attributed to strengthened response in the form of rapid roll-out of new diagnostics & drugs. South Africa’s antiretroviral programme has significantly contributed to better TB outcomes including successful treatment & reduced mortality. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: In South Africa, TB is the biggest cause of mortality in the general population, especially among men. There were 322,000 new TB infections in South Africa in 2017, which is a significant decline from the 2015 estimate of 438 000. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: Tuberculosis is not just a medical condition. It has many social determinants, including poverty, unemployment, poor nutrition, overcrowding and social stigma that fuel the spread of diseases. This means that the poor carry a disproportionate disease burden.

President #Ramaphosa: In 2004, he said: “The world has made defeating AIDS a top priority. This is a blessing. But TB remains ignored. Today we are calling on the world to recognise that we can't fight AIDS unless we do much more to fight TB as well”. #UNGA
President #Ramaphosa: President Mandela was a survivor of tuberculosis, which he contracted while in prison, and was firmly committed to the campaign against the disease. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: This first ever UN High-Level Meeting on Tuberculosis is a historic opportunity that we must embrace if we are to effectively respond to a disease that has killed more people than smallpox, malaria, the plague, influenza, HIV and AIDS and Ebola combined.
The commitment from Heads of State & Government at the UN High-Level Meeting on Tuberculosis will drive action across all sectors and stakeholders to end TB #UNGApic.twitter.com/uVrHyK8rX6

President #Ramaphosa: This is not the generation that will stand expectant at the gates of hope. This is the generation that will change the world. This is their time, and this is their age. Let their greatness blossom. #UNGApic.twitter.com/PvaCSBCXse
President #Ramaphosa: Allow me to conclude by once more drawing on the wisdom of Nelson Mandela, when he said: “Sometimes it falls on a generation to be great.” #UNGApic.twitter.com/khmrCwSD3L

President #Ramaphosa: We are determined through our international relations to be a force for progress and peace and global equality, and will continue to advance the interests of the African continent and the Global South. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: We are working to correct the injustices of our past & to build a society that is free, inclusive and sustainable. We are pursuing an economic path that draws on the resources & capabilities of all our people to eradicate poverty, unemployment & inequality.
President #Ramaphosa: From the ashes of a system that was described by the UN General Assembly as a crime against humanity, we are building a new democratic nation, united in its diversity. #UNGA
President #Ramaphosa: The youth of Africa are poised to transform their continent. As the people of South Africa, we are committed to be part of this transformation. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: With effective investment in education, improved health care, good governance and greater economic integration, Africa has the potential to develop its productive capacity on a scale and at a rate that will lift tens of millions out of poverty. #UNGA
President #Ramaphosa: As the continent with the youngest population in the world, Africa has the potential to be the next great frontier for global growth. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: We are working to silence the guns in Africa by 2020, to bring an end to conflicts that have cost the lives of millions of our people, displaced many more and stunted economic growth and human development. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: We have reached agreement on the establishment of an African Continental Free Trade Area, which will fundamentally transform African economies, giving rise to a new industrial age on the continent. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: We continue to vigorously implement our commitments contained in the AU Agenda 2063, which is our collective plan to rid our continent of underdevelopment, poverty & conflict & improve democratic governance, the rule of law & the promotion of human rights.
President #Ramaphosa: As Africans, we have made significant strides in addressing the challenges that have confronted our continent over many decades. #UNGApic.twitter.com/lw3NyQvEGG

President #Ramaphosa: Our task as global leaders is to pursue the policies that are required to turn intent into implementation and mobilise the resources needed to turn implementation into impact. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: Together, they represent our common commitment to tackle poverty, underdevelopment and environmental degradation. They represent our common commitment to tackle diseases like Aids, tuberculosis, malaria, diabetes and cancer. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: This responsibility is manifest in the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, the Paris Agreement on Climate Change and the Addis Ababa Action Agenda on the financing of development, among others. #UNGA
President #Ramaphosa: It is therefore essential that we take collective responsibility for the development of all nations and for the improvement of the lives of all people. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: The history of the global economy informs us that no country can prosper at the expense of all others, and that no people can hope to live in comfort and security for as long as millions of others languish in poverty. #UNGApic.twitter.com/2Omj1dcehJ

President #Ramaphosa: We must resist any and all efforts to undermine the multilateral approach to international trade, which is essential to the promotion of stability and predictability in the global economy. #UNGA2018
President #Ramaphosa: Reform of the United Nations, and particularly its Security Council, is a priority if we are to give full effect to the values and principles enshrined in the UN Charter. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: Institutions like the United Nations, World Bank, IMF and the WTO need to be reshaped and enhanced so that they may more effectively meet the challenges of the contemporary world and better serve the interests of the poor and marginalised. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: The call to leave no one behind requires that we strengthen the institutions of global governance and make them more responsive to the needs of young people, particularly in the developing world. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: We need a deliberate programme to ensure that the digital revolution – which carries such great potential for both disruption and empowerment – is effectively harnessed to promote social justice and human progress. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: It is therefore vital that we deploy every means at our disposal to address youth unemployment and ensure universal access to educational opportunities that are appropriate to the changing world of work. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: One of the greatest challenges to the achievement of global prosperity and development is the continued exclusion of millions of women and young people from meaningful economic participation. #UNGA
President #Ramaphosa: We must similarly intensify our efforts to secure the right of the people of Western Sahara to self-determination and full national sovereignty. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: The fact that the people of Palestine have endured occupation and suffering for nearly as long as the United Nations has existed, makes their plight no less pressing, nor their suffering any less acceptable. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: Our resolve to end ongoing conflicts & our determination to root out terrorism must be matched by action and by the appropriate deployment of resources. We must act with the same urgency to resolve some of the world’s most protracted & intractable disputes.

President #Ramaphosa: We must accept our shared responsibility – & our shared interest – in ending conflict and, using the outcomes of the Nelson Mandela Peace Summit, to empower the UN to be a more effective instrument for mediation, peace keeping & post-conflict reconstruction.

President #Ramaphosa: Not only must we stop the death, destruction and human suffering that is visited daily on millions of people, but we must act with purpose to prevent the loss of another entire generation to its aftermath. #UNGA
President #Ramaphosa: As we speak, young lives are being lost and futures are being destroyed. There is an urgency to the measures we must take to end conflict and war. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: It is young people who are fighting the wars that we started. It is women who are bearing the brunt and hardships of the wars that continue to destroy their families and lives. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: We are living in the Age of Youth. This places a responsibility on us, as leaders, not only to put the interests of young people at the centre of our efforts, but to empower women & young people to be more prominent in directing the course of global affairs.

President #Ramaphosa: We are a young world, where more than half the global population is under the age of 30 years. This is even more pronounced on our continent, Africa, where two-thirds of its people were not yet born when Nelson Mandela was released from prison. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: It is within our hands, as the leaders assembled here today, to forge a more representative, equal and fair United Nations that is empowered and equipped to lead the struggle to end poverty, unemployment and inequality in the world. #UNGA
President #Ramaphosa: They want an end to the greed, ignorance and conceit that is driving the destruction of our only home, the earth. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: They are men and women with dreams and aspirations that transcend the hardships of the present, who want to contribute to a new global civilization defined by care, justice and solidarity. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: To the poor, vulnerable and marginalised, the UN today is a beacon of promise in a landscape of doubt. To billions across the world, the UN is the most powerful instrument we possess to achieve a more equal, more humane and more inclusive world. #UNGA
President #Ramaphosa: During the dark days of colonialism and apartheid, we drew strength, inspiration and encouragement from the UN and its Charter in our quest for self-determination. #UNGA
President #Ramaphosa: Throughout its seven decades, the UN has been a source of hope for the oppressed, exploited and poor. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: To succeed in giving effect to this commitment, the UN must become what billions of people across the world want it to be – a representative and truly democratic global parliament of the people. #UNGA
President #Ramaphosa: This reflects a new and sincere commitment by the world’s leaders to comprehensively advance peace and security and resolve all conflicts and wars. #UNGA
President #Ramaphosa: We applaud the Political Declaration of the Summit, which recognises the period from 2019 to 2028 as the Nelson Mandela Decade of Peace. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: Allow me to express the deep gratitude of the government and the people of South Africa to the international community for convening the Peace Summit to honour the memory of Nelson Mandela and advance his legacy. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: More importantly, we are called upon to ask – as we did yesterday during the Nelson Mandela Peace Summit – what the United Nations and the assembled global leadership must do to secure lasting peace, reconciliation and stability across the globe. #UNGA
President #Ramaphosa: We are bound to ask what contribution the United Nations has made to a more peaceful, more prosperous and more equal world. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: As we mark the centenary of the birth of this great global leader, we are bound to ask whether the United Nations has met the needs and the expectations of the millions who stand at the gates of hope. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: It is nearly a quarter of a century since the founding father of our democracy, President Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela stood at this podium to declare that:pic.twitter.com/4Gk17TrrJA
President #Ramaphosa: I have the honour to address this august body, the United Nations General Assembly for the first time as President of the Republic of South Africa. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: We remain committed to multilateralism as the most sustainable and effective approach to the management of international relations – and will continue to advocate for the interests of developing countries to be placed at the top of the international agenda.pic.twitter.com/6UE0Swofuc

President #Ramaphosa: In line with the philosophy and practice of the Mandela years, South Africa continues to seek warm fraternal relations and strong economic ties with all the countries of the world regardless of size, influence or alignment. #UNGA #CFR

President #Ramaphosa: South Africa will take up a non-permanent seat on the UN Security Council from next year - December 2020. We will dedicate our tenure to continuing the legacy of Mandela, whose values of peace, reconciliation & respect continue to inspire Africa & the worldpic.twitter.com/gZebqPJtSK

President #Ramaphosa: South Africa will continue to play its part in conflict resolution in these areas, and in combating threats to regional and international peace and security. #UNGA #CFR #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: We are still confronting challenges in places like South Sudan, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Central African Republic, Lesotho and areas of the Great Lakes, the Sahel and the Lake Chad Basin. #UNGA #CFR #BetterAfricaBetterWorld
President #Ramaphosa: Despite the progress, however, there are still areas where instability and conflict continue to cause great misery and hardship. #UNGA #CFR #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: This dream – of a single African market for goods and services – has been made possible by sustained economic growth and greater political stability. #UNGA #CFR #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: We are working together with our fellow African countries to establish a Continental Free Trade Area, which would fundamentally transform Africa’s economies and consolidate the continent’s position in the global trading system. #UNGA #AfCFTA #CFR

President #Ramaphosa: As South Africa, we are determined to use every means at our disposal, including our participation in global forums, to advance the African Union’s Agenda 2063 and to consolidate regional integration. #UNGA #CFR #BetterAfricaBetterWorldpic.twitter.com/RKKnpQub14

President #Ramaphosa: To do so, we need to build meaningful partnerships between UN member states, international organisations, civil society organisations and the private sector. #UNGA #CFR #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: For the global development agenda to succeed we must ensure full implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development & its means of implementation, the Climate Change Paris Agreement & the Addis Ababa Action Agenda on financing for development.

President #Ramaphosa: This should include reform of the UN Security Council, which is limited in its ability to respond to current security challenges by virtue of its structure, composition and relative lack of accountability. #UNGA #CFR #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: We need to strengthen the rules-based international trading system & move with speed to transform other multilateral institutions & global governance structures to be in line with the current realities of the 21st century. #UNGA #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: We can do that by paying particular attention to preventive diplomacy, which should be supported through closer coordination and partnership between the United Nations and regional organisations such as the African Union. #UNGA #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: There is an opportunity for the world leaders, international organisations and civil society to work together to restore the primacy and relevance of multilateralism. #UNGA #CFR #BetterAfricaBetterWorld
President #Ramaphosa: However, they do require a return to a cooperative and inclusive approach to international relations. The idea that might is right is wrong. #UNGA #CFR

President #Ramaphosa: While globalisation has brought many opportunities and much progress, it has also contributed to growing inequality among states and within states. These challenges are by no means insurmountable. #UNGA #CFR

President #Ramaphosa: There appears to be little prospect of the resolution of intractable conflicts in the Middle East & in Africa, nor has the international community managed to effectively address growing political intolerance, acts of terrorism and right-wing extremism. #UNFA
President #Ramaphosa: The rise of trade protectionism threatens the multilateral trading system we agreed in Marrakech in 1994 and Doha in 2001. #UNGA #CFR

President #Ramaphosa: There is a growing challenge to important multilateral arrangements, characterised by the withdrawal from commitments made in the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, on climate change, financing for development and in nuclear non-proliferation. #UNGA

“Peace, stability and the rule of law are critical for economies to thrive and for businesses to achieve sustainable returns for shareholders,” President Ramaphosa at the United Nations Private Sector Forum Lunch, UN General Assembly, New York, USA. https://bit.ly/2OK1Ov9 pic.twitter.com/zEierwddnX

President #Ramaphosa: This view is reinforced by a number of disturbing global developments. The resurgence of geopolitical rivalry, which has not been experienced since the Cold War era, has huge implications for international peace and security. #UNGA #CFR

President #Ramaphosa: At this moment in global history, as we seek to navigate the challenges confronting the political, security and economic architecture, we are convinced of the value of Mandela’s approach to consensus-building and the peaceful resolution of conflict. #UNGA

President @CyrilRamaphosa delivers keynote remarks at the United Nations Private Sector Forum under the theme: “Building & Investing in peace for All”at the United Nations Headquarters in New York #UNGA⁠ ⁠ #UNPSF #LeadersForumpic.twitter.com/2sfyLtMqZb

President #Ramaphosa: For our part, we are committed to work together with the UN and the members of the Global Compact to ensure that we build a strong and lasting partnership that will deliver not only peace – but also prosperity – to all the people of the world. #UNGA #UNPSF

President #Ramaphosa: We have this morning through the Political Declaration adopted by the Summit declared the next 10 years to be the Nelson Mandela International Decade for Peace. We should seize the opportunity of this decade to rally behind a common agenda for peace #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: This centenary of President Mandela offers all of us an opportunity to reflect on progress and challenges, and the work we still need to do to advance peace. #UNGA #UNPSF #LeadersForum

President #Ramaphosa: This requires the involvement of political leaders, business leaders, unions and other social formations – supported wherever possible by international organisations like the UN or continental bodies like the African Union. #UNGA #UNPSF #LeadersForum

President #Ramaphosa: To ensure that this becomes a virtuous circle – rather than a vicious cycle – requires a social compact which clearly delineates the respective responsibilities and expectations of all partners. #UNGA #UNPSF #LeadersForum
President #Ramaphosa: Investment is necessary to promote economic progress and stability, while stability is an important condition for investment. #UNGA #UNPSF #LeadersForum

President #Ramaphosa: As countries emerge from conflict, they face the challenge of rebuilding the state, including infrastructure, establishing resilient public institutions & restoring the economy to health. This is where the private sector can play a critical role #UNGA #UNPSF

President #Ramaphosa: Peace, stability and the rule of law are critical for economies to thrive and for businesses to achieve sustainable returns for shareholders. The private sector therefore has a direct interest in the preservation or restoration of peace. #UNGA #UNPSF
President #Ramaphosa: The Peacebuilding Commission’s efforts can only succeed with the support of political leadership and their partners, like those in the private sector. #UNGA #UNPSF #LeadersForum

President #Ramaphosa: We appreciate the vision of the members of the Global Compact who have taken it upon themselves to consider the role that the private sector can play in building and investing in peace. #UNGA #UNPSF #LeadersForum

“In Nelson Mandela, we have proof of what cooperation among peoples and nations can achieve. We have a living symbol of hope for all humanity.” ~Boutros Boutros Ghali, 1994 #UNGA #Mandela100 #BetterAfricaBetterWorldpic.twitter.com/P7UVLTL5Cr
President #Ramaphosa: We hope we will prove ourselves worthy as the bearers of the legacy of Nelson Mandela. #UNGA #Mandela100pic.twitter.com/twTqZdJBs0

President #Ramaphosa: We hope we will rediscover the strength of will to save successive generations from war, and to overcome the hatred of our past and the narrow interests that blind us to the vision of a common future that is peaceful and prosperous. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: It is our deepest hope that this summit, in the name of one of our greatest exemplars of humanity, serves as a new dawn for the United Nations. We hope the Summit will give expression to the Secretary-General’s call for a “surge in diplomacy”. #UNGApic.twitter.com/k57E4cUlus

President #Ramaphosa: It is an opportunity to pledge to each other and to our people our determination to seek peaceful solutions to our political differences; and to building peace in those countries emerging from the destruction of war, violence and the perpetuation of hate.

President #Ramaphosa: It provides a moment for us as heads of state and government to recommit ourselves to achieve the social and economic development necessary for the prevention of conflict. #UNGApic.twitter.com/F80G6NBl85

President #Ramaphosa: Today we are gathered as world leaders, representing the hopes of billions for a peaceful, prosperous world. It is the desire for such a world that prompted this Peace Summit, to take stock of how the UN has performed in the pursuit of peace. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: We must ensure that the United Nations – in its form, operation and orientation – is able to maintain international peace and security, protect human rights and achieve sustainable development for all. #UNGA
President #Ramaphosa: We are called upon to ensure that women are afforded a special role in peace negotiations, political transition and in ensuring durable security. #UNGA
President #Ramaphosa: We are called upon to act decisively to end the exposure of women and children to untold suffering including displacement, torture, rape, mutilation and murder. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: Through this Peace Summit, the current generation of global leadership is given an opportunity not only to reflect on peace in the world, but to take those measures necessary to end the wars that continue to take millions of innocent lives. #UNGApic.twitter.com/D7osbFuRWJ

President #Ramaphosa: These reveal that the current threats to international peace & security result more from conflicts within states and the effect that these have across nations that have become increasingly interdependent, rather than the traditional conflicts between states.

President #Ramaphosa: We are confronted by intra-state armed conflicts in Syria, South Sudan and Yemen; the protracted turmoil in Somalia and other parts of the African continent; and struggles for self-determination in Western Sahara and Palestine. #UNGA
President #Ramaphosa: While we have managed to avoid another world war, we continue to grapple with the haunting spectre of modern atrocities such as the genocides in Rwanda and Srebrenica. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: Over the past seven decades, millions of people worldwide have been killed, maimed, displaced and starved as a result of war and conflicts. Of these, women and children continue to bear a disproportionate burden. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: It was this capacity that led to the establishment of the United Nations, which served as an important platform for the anti-apartheid movement, and which continues to be a platform for other struggles against oppression, war and global injustice. #UNGApic.twitter.com/Jt9J1q9wJp

President #Ramaphosa: The story of South Africa’s transition from apartheid to democracy, and the role played by leaders such as Nelson Mandela, is well known. It is a story about humanity’s great capacity for goodness and hope. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: He would come to represent the hopes of millions of South Africans who dreamt of a life unshackled from a system that would limit their potential and stifle their possibilities based merely on the shade of their skin. #UNGA
President #Ramaphosa: One such leader was born in the small village of Mvezo in the eastern parts of South Africa in 1918. #UNGA
President #Ramaphosa: For these noble ideas to be realised, however, they needed to find expression in the actions of those who took up the mantle of leadership at the most trying of times. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: It is from this collective trauma that the United Nations was born. Countries sought to reimagine a world where nations would cooperate rather than clash, & where friendly relations would lead to social progress, development & a better life for all. #UNGA

President #Ramaphosa: The signing of the UN Charter over 70 years ago took place in a world very different from our own. It was a world still reeling from the clash of great powers in the 2nd World War that cost the lives of close to 5% of the world’s population at the time.

President #Ramaphosa: On behalf of the Mandela family and the people of South Africa, allow me to express our humble appreciation to the United Nations convening this special summit in honor of the founding President of our democracy, Nelson Rolihahla Mandela #UNGA #Mandela100

The statue is fitted with former President Nelson Mandela’s prison shoes that he wore during his days as political prisoner 46664 on Robben Island in Cape Town, where he served a jail term of 27 years. #UNGA #Mandela100 #BetterAfricaBetterWorldpic.twitter.com/2J55r5DKXr

The statue is modeled after the day Nelson Mandela delivered his first speech to the United Nations Special Committee on Apartheid on 22 June 1990. He urged the United Nations to maintain sanctions against South Africa until apartheid was abolished. #UNGA #Mandela100pic.twitter.com/N1HEVpmDDM

At 1.8 meters tall, the Nelson Mandela Statue is the only life size statue at the United Nations Headquarters, signifying the tole he played in unifying the world under the banner of peace and conflict resolution. #UNGA #Mandela100 #BetterAfricaBetterWorldpic.twitter.com/XxDstyMqCg

President #Ramaphosa: We trust that this statue will remain a constant reminder to the international community of the dedication of Nelson Mandela to the mission of the UN and a constant affirmation of South Africa’s commitment to contribute to a better world for all. #UNGApic.twitter.com/lRpBnqql5I

President #Ramaphosa: President Mandela firmly believed that the United Nations was the most valuable and effective instrument for the advancement of peace, development and equality that humanity had conceived. #UNGA #Mandela100 #BetterAfricaBetterWorldpic.twitter.com/WWjjkq1ktT

President #Ramaphosa: We recall with great appreciation & gratitude the leading role of the United Nations in championing the struggle of the South African people against apartheid & in calling for the release of Nelson Mandela and other political prisoners. #UNGA #Mandela100

President #Ramaphosa: It gives me great pleasure to present to you and the United Nations, on behalf of the government and the people of South Africa, this life-size statue of President Nelson Mandela. #UNGA #Mandela100 #BetterAfricaBetterWorldpic.twitter.com/GsVTLjz7NH

President #Ramaphosa: The values by which he lived and to which he dedicated his life are universal. We are honoured and grateful that the Nelson Mandela Peace Summit has been convened in his memory. #UNGA #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: For those of us gathered here at the United Nations, Nelson Mandela will forever hold a special place in our hearts because of his dedication to the service of humanity & the promotion of peace throughout the world #UNGA #Mandela100 #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: The people of our country, united in their diversity, revere Nelson Mandela as the founding father of our democratic nation – whose life, sacrifices and extraordinary contribution to freedom continues to inspire successive generations. #UNGA #Mandela100

President #Ramaphosa: For the government and people of South Africa, the enthusiasm with which the international community has embraced the celebration of the centenary of the birth of Nelson Mandela is truly humbling. #UNGA #BetterAfricaBetterWorld #Mandela100pic.twitter.com/67yZRwMJjB

President #Ramaphosa: Together, we are taking bold and concrete measures to ensure a clear and sustained improvement in the lives of all South Africans. #StimulusPackagepic.twitter.com/o5LuvNnxdy

President #Ramaphosa: Now, we have it within us to come together and forge a new path of growth, jobs & transformation. We are confident that the elements of our economic stimulus & recovery package will play a decisive role in reversing the recent contraction of the our economy.

President #Ramaphosa: As South Africans, we have confronted challenges far greater than this before. By working together, we managed to end a seemingly intractable conflict and set our country on the path to a peaceful transition to democracy.

President #Ramaphosa: We are certain that these interventions will help to put the economy on a far firmer footing as current investors and potential investors convene in Johannesburg for the Investment Conference at the end of October. #StimulusPackagepic.twitter.com/RLsJlMtaNM
President #Ramaphosa: We are certain that the measures we have outlined here will complement the deliberations at the forthcoming Jobs Summit. #StimulusPackagepic.twitter.com/fpo3MIzrc0
Statement by President Cyril Ramaphosa on economic stimulus and recovery plan https://bit.ly/2xskYzf

President #Ramaphosa: We continue to draw on the guidance and support of bodies like the NPC, which will soon release its own guidance on focal areas to stimulate the economy, and Government will continue to coordinate its work with formations like the CEO Initiative.

President #Ramaphosa: We have held consultations with leaders from business and labour on this plan. We are encouraged by the support they have pledged for the measures outlined and many have undertaken to provide resources and expertise to ensure its success.

President #Ramaphosa: Igniting economic activity requires partnership and collaboration. It must be a national effort in which all of us work together to restore our economy to growth in the immediate term & prepare the ground for sustainable, inclusive growth into our future.pic.twitter.com/XrfUFRORuj
President #Ramaphosa: This spending will cover, among other things, sewerage purification and reticulation, refuse sites, electricity reticulation and water reservoirs. #PresidentRamaphosa

President #Ramaphosa: We also need short term municipal investments to address the challenges that our people face. We have identified 57 priority pilot municipalities in order to unlock infrastructure spending in the short term. #StimulusPackage

President #Ramaphosa: In support of the stimulus efforts, the IDC will be targeting to increase its approvals to R20 billion over 12 months, an increase of 20% on the previous year. This funding will target the productive sectors of the economy.

President #Ramaphosa: As part of the reprioritisation of spending, additional infrastructure funding will be directed towards provincial and national roads, human settlements, water infrastructure, schools, student accommodation and public transport.

President #Ramaphosa: The team will identify and quantify ‘shovel ready’ public sector projects, such as roads and dams, and engage the private sector to manage delivery. The role of the PICC will be strengthened to ensure improved coordination across the three spheres.

President #Ramaphosa: To ensure these funds are used effectively, we are establishing a dedicated Infrastructure Execution Team in the Presidency that has extensive project management and engineering expertise to assist with project design and oversee implementation.

President #Ramaphosa: The contribution from the fiscus towards the Infrastructure Fund would be in excess of R400 billion, which we’ll use to leverage resources from developmental finance institutions, multilateral development banks & private lenders & investors. #StimulusPackagepic.twitter.com/VEz9ITKD0l

Deputy President David Mabuza embarks on a guided tour of different training workstations showcasing innovation, partnerships, entrepreneurship and transfer of skills to learners at the Orbit TVET College. (2/2)pic.twitter.com/pxeLducWQD

Deputy President David Mabuza embarks on a guided tour of different training workstations showcasing innovation, partnerships, entrepreneurship and transfer of skills to learners at the Orbit TVET College. (1/2)pic.twitter.com/ODhBJW3MYY

President #Ramaphosa: With a view to unlocking the potential to create more jobs on a large scale we have decided to set up a South Africa Infrastructure Fund, which will fundamentally transform our approach to the rollout, building and implementation of infrastructure projects.pic.twitter.com/h1Fd9euv2g

President #Ramaphosa: The stimulus and recovery plan prioritises infrastructure spending as a critical driver of economic activity. Infrastructure expansion and maintenance has the potential to create jobs on a large scale, attract investment.
President #Ramaphosa: In total, the plan will result in reprioritised expenditure and new project level funding of around R50 billion. #StimulusPackagepic.twitter.com/Z74pCssQWe

President #Ramaphosa: To address some of the shortages in our hospitals, funding is being made available immediately to buy beds & linen, while the Minister of Health and the National Health Council will immediately fill 2,200 critical medical posts, including nurses and interns.

President #Ramaphosa: Arising from the priorities identified at the meeting of the President’s Coordinating Council earlier this week, additional funds will be directed to addressing the dire state of sanitation facilities in many public schools.pic.twitter.com/pbD0HHImCL

President #Ramaphosa: In the third instance, we will also be re-directing resources towards addressing immediate challenges in health and education, which are critical to the health, wellbeing and productivity of our people.
President #Ramaphosa: A township and rural entrepreneurship fund is being established to provide finance to either scale up existing projects or provide start-up capital for new projects.

President #Ramaphosa: We have prioritised the revitalisation of three regional and 26 township industrial parks as catalysts for broader economic and industrial development in townships and rural areas.

President #Ramaphosa: Further details of the mandate and composition of the panel will be made available in a separate statement. In the second instance, reprioritised funding will also be re-directed towards igniting economic activity in townships and rural areas.

President #Ramaphosa: The 10-person panel is to advise government on the implementation of a fair and equitable land reform process that redresses the injustices of the past, increases agricultural output, promotes economic growth and protects food security. #StimulusPackage

President #Ramaphosa: As part of the work to develop agriculture and ensure effective land reform, I have appointed an advisory panel on land reform that will guide the Inter-Ministerial Committee (IMC) on Land Reform chaired by Deputy President David Mabuza.

President #Ramaphosa: A significant portion of the funding will go towards export-oriented crops that are highly labour intensive. Government will finalise the signing of 30 years leases to enable farmers to mobilise funding for agricultural development.

President #Ramaphosa: Blended finance will be mobilised from the Land Bank, Industrial Development Corporation and commercial banks. The Land Bank is currently concluding transactions that will create employment opportunities in the agricultural sector over the next 3 to 5 years.

President #Ramaphosa: The interventions we have identified will include a package of support measures for black commercial farmers so as to, increase their entry into food value chains through access to infrastructure like abattoirs and feedlots.

President #Ramaphosa: Re-prioritised funding will be directed towards investments in agriculture and economic activity in townships and rural areas. Agriculture has massive potential for job creation in the immediate and long term.pic.twitter.com/uI9xXLOpyk

President #Ramaphosa: The reprioritisation of spending we are outlining as part of this stimulus and recovery plan will take place within the current fiscal framework and in line with the normal budgetary process.

President #Ramaphosa: Our government has limited fiscal space to increase spending or borrowing, it is imperative that we make sure that the resources that we do have are used to the greatest effect. #StimulusPackagepic.twitter.com/k5njA32iX5

President #Ramaphosa: The central element of the economic stimulus & recovery plan is the reprioritisation of spending towards activities that have the greatest impact on growth and job creation, with a particular emphasis on township and rural economies, women and youth.pic.twitter.com/D16iEjFgDw

President #Ramaphosa: Other measures we will implement include expanding procurement from small business and cooperatives, as well as using trade measures – within WTO rules – to protect poultry and other sensitive sectors and a vigorous crackdown on illegal imports.
President #Ramaphosa: Lower data costs will also provide relief for poor households and increase the overall competitiveness of the South African economy. #StimulusPackage

President #Ramaphosa: Within the next few weeks, government will initiate the process for allocation of high-demand radio spectrum to enable licensing. This will unlock value in the telecommunications sector, increase competition, promote investment & reduce data costs.

President #Ramaphosa: To reduce the cost of doing business, to boost exports and to make South African industry more competitive, government has begun a review of various administered prices, starting with electricity, port and rail tariffs.
President #Ramaphosa: Separate legislation for the regulation of the oil and gas industry will be drafted through the government’s legislative process. #StimulusPackage

President #Ramaphosa: Parliament will be requested in terms of its Rules not to proceed with the Mineral and Petroleum Resources Development Act Amendment Bill, which has contributed to a lot of uncertainty in the sector. #StimulusPackage

President #Ramaphosa: This will revitalise the mining industry and provide certainty to investors while charting a sustainable path towards a transformed and inclusive industry. #StimulusPackagepic.twitter.com/Jx4QWNoH9t
President #Ramaphosa: Following extensive consultation that involved industry players, communities, labour and government, Cabinet approved the revised Mining Charter.

President #Ramaphosa: It is imperative that South Africa restores investment and exploration levels in the mining sector as mining and mineral beneficiation activities have significant potential to drive long term growth, exports and job growth. #StimulusPackage

President #Ramaphosa: It is imperative that South Africa restores investment and exploration levels in the mining sector as mining and mineral beneficiation activities have significant potential to drive long term growth, exports and job growth. #StimulusPackagepic.twitter.com/gLqc5ltEjT

President #Ramaphosa: These measures have the potential to boost tourism and make business travel a lot more conducive. Tourism continues to be a great job creator and through these measures we are confident that many more tourists will visit South Africa.

President #Ramaphosa: Within the next few months, amendments will be made to regulations on the travel of minors, list of countries requiring visas to enter South Africa, an e-visas pilot will be implemented, and visa requirements for highly skilled foreigners will be revised.

President #Ramaphosa: We are decisively and rapidly accelerating the implementation of key economic reforms that will unlock greater investment in important growth sectors. These reforms include immediate changes approved by Cabinet to South Africa's visa regime.

President #Ramaphosa: It is generally agreed that in order for our economy to grow at a rate that will lead to job creation on a meaningful scale, we need to significantly increase levels of investment. #StimulusPackage
President #Ramaphosa: The measures we are announcing give priority to those areas of economic activity that will have the greatest impact on youth, women and small businesses.

President #Ramaphosa: ...restore investor confidence, prevent further job losses and create new jobs, and address some urgent challenges that affect the conditions faced by vulnerable groups among our people. #StimulusPackage

President #Ramaphosa: The stimulus and recovery plan we are outlining consists of a range of measures, both financial and non-financial, that will be implemented immediately to ignite economic activity...

President #Ramaphosa: It is in response to these factors, many of which are outside our control, that we are announcing today, following its adoption by Cabinet, an economic stimulus and recovery plan. #StimulusPackagepic.twitter.com/HqfIwIkqwz

President #Ramaphosa: In recent months, the structural weaknesses in our economy have been made worse by global factors such as a rising oil price, weakening sentiment towards emerging markets and deteriorating trade relations between the US and other major economies.

President #Ramaphosa: For several years our economy has not grown at the pace needed to create enough jobs or lift our people out of poverty. Public finances have been constrained, limiting the ability of government to expand its investment in economic and social development.

President #Ramaphosa: Yet, as is evident from the contraction of our economy in the first two quarters of the year, our economic difficulties are severe and will take an extraordinary effort – and some time – to overcome. #StimulusPackage

President #Ramaphosa: Since then, we have taken decisive steps to rebuild investor confidence, end corruption and state capture, restore good governance at state owned enterprises and strengthen critical public institutions. #StimulusPackage
President #Ramaphosa: During #SONA2018 in February, we announced a range of measures that we would initiate to set the country on a new path of growth, employment and transformation.

President #Ramaphosa: So let us march forth, as Steve Biko called on us to do, with courage and determination to bestow upon South Africa the greatest gift possible – a more human face. I thank you.

President #Ramaphosa: Steve Biko was a selfless revolutionary whose epoch defining ideas contributed significantly in making South Africa what it is today. His thoughts continue to guide us in our quest for a true humanity. #BIKOLecture

President #Ramaphosa: Bantu Steve Biko led people, not parties. His revolution was one of the mind, not one of membership. The alumni of his movement are spread across many formations and are found in many parts of society and different geographies. #BIKOLecture

President #Ramaphosa: The Black Consciousness Movement gave rise to an enduring consciousness among oppressed South Africans who found political homes in different organisations but shared a common commitment to end a crime against humanity. #BIKOLecture
President #Ramaphosa: He bequeathed to our nation a cohort of leaders who were politicised in the South African Student Organisation and sharpened their revolutionary skills in struggle. #BIKOLecture
President #Ramaphosa: We must draw on the example of Steve Biko, who belonged to a special generation of young and fearless patriots who kept the flames of liberation burning. #BIKOLecture

President #Ramaphosa: Every citizen needs to respect the rights and property of others, respect the law and be respected by the law. We must rise above the differences of colour, faith, creed and affiliation to pursue a common mission.

President #Ramaphosa: But ultimately, we will not succeed unless we forge a new morality. We need leaders who serve with diligence and commitment, seeking neither advantage nor undue rewards for themselves.

President #Ramaphosa: We have begun the work, but there is much more to do. Commissions of inquiry, disciplinary hearings, criminal prosecution and lengthy prison sentences are necessary instruments to tackle this scourge. #BIKOLecture

President #Ramaphosa: Astounded as we are by the devastating audacity of one family and their associates, we should not be blinded to the corruption that has taken in hold in many institutions across government. This requires firm, decisive and united action.
President #Ramaphosa: We now know of business people whose reckless and fraudulent actions eroded the savings of many ordinary people. #BIKOLecture

President #Ramaphosa: We now know of powerful individuals who used positions of authority to plunder the resources of the state, threatening our economic sustainability and further impoverishing our people.

President #Ramaphosa: Now in the 25th year of our democracy, we must acknowledge with shame and regret that we have failed to live up to the standards of the selfless leaders that came before us. #BIKOLecture

President #Ramaphosa: As we emerge from the corruption of apartheid, we are called upon to forge a new morality, which places the interests of the people above the narrow interests of the individual. #BIKOLecture
President #Ramaphosa: Our quest for a true humanity requires that we have leaders of integrity and a society that values honesty and hard work. #BIKOLecture

President #Ramaphosa: We must build a society that is defined by compassion, selflessness and generosity. We must give effect to the expression: ‘From each according to their ability, to each according to their needs.’ #BIKOLecturepic.twitter.com/kO5Pyb80q7

President #Ramaphosa: Inequality severely constrains our ability as a country to realise our potential, it limits growth, perpetuates hardship and promotes instability. We must therefore become a society defined by solidarity, not competition. #BIKOLecture

President #Ramaphosa: It requires a recognition by those who are the beneficiaries of decades of racial privilege that they have both a responsibility and a vested interest in ending privilege and effecting redress.
President #Ramaphosa: It requires the involvement of all within society – with those who have most being prepared to make the greatest contribution.

President #Ramaphosa: We are therefore called upon to embark on an extensive programme of fundamental redistribution that closes the gap between those who have and those who have not, between white and black, and between men and women.
President #Ramaphosa: These efforts have met with some success, but have not done nearly enough to reduce inequality or overcome exclusion.

President #Ramaphosa: We have enacted legislation and implemented policies to improve the representation of blacks, women and people with disability in the economy, to encourage the development of black and women entrepreneurs, and to increase black ownership of the economy.

President #Ramaphosa: Since democracy, we've directed resources towards meeting the needs of the poor, providing assets in the form of land & houses, equalising spending on education, health and social grants and investing in infrastructure in previously neglected areas.

President Ramaphosa: And yet, our Constitution – which is readily embraced by all South Africans – enjoins us not only to recognise the injustices of the past, but also to ensure equitable redress of historical iniquity.

President #Ramaphosa: For the last three centuries, the history of our country has been defined by the deprivation of the many to enable the enrichment of the few. Today, our people continue to live that history. Millions live without work, without land, security or opportunity.

President #Ramaphosa: We must be a society where the burning of a school, the trashing of a library, is a great affront to our sense of moral purpose. Our quest for a true humanity must be root in a genuine sense of solidarity. #BIKOLecture

President #Ramaphosa: It requires teachers, principals, administrators, elected representatives and political formations who place at the centre of their efforts the promotion of educational excellence. #BIKOLecture

President #Ramaphosa: It requires a shift in social mindset, where few things are valued more than knowledge and learning – where parents, relatives, friends and neighbours take a keen interest in the development of the young mind.

President #Ramaphosa: The faultlines of race, gender, class and geography are nowhere more distinct than in access to a decent education. Unless we correct this as a matter of priority, we will not reduce inequality and we will not end poverty. #BIKOLecture
President #Ramaphosa: Despite the progress made over the last two decades, inequality in education remains one of the greatest obstacles to the achievement of a just and prosperous future.

President #Ramaphosa: It is for this reason too that we continue to give attention to the physical state of our schools, the availability of resources and the quality of learning, teaching and leadership. #BIKOLecture

President #Ramaphosa: This is the reason why we have invested so extensively in early childhood development and why we have made higher education free to the children of the poor and working class. #BIKOLecture

President #Ramaphosa: If we are to end the transmission of poverty from generation to generation, we must ensure that every child receives from their earliest years until adulthood a comprehensive quality education. #BIKOLecture
President #Ramaphosa: This means, in the first instance, that we must educate the black child and the girl child. #BIKOLecture

President #Ramaphosa: We should not and cannot, accept that poverty is an inevitable feature of the human condition. Because the face of poverty in South Africa is that of an African woman, our task is to address the racial & gender dimensions of economic exclusion #BIKOLecturepic.twitter.com/mbr9xM21zz

President #Ramaphosa: When poverty is so widespread, when it is so deeply embedded in the structure of society, when it has existed for as long as any of us can remember, then there is a real danger that we learn to live with it. #BIKOLecture

President #Ramaphosa: Our quest for a true humanity requires that we end poverty. No society can be free for as long as any member is denied the basic requirements of life – food, shelter, water, security, work. #BIKOLecture
President #Ramaphosa: The assertion by women of their own power and agency is the foundation on which we must work together to eradicate all forms and manifestations of patriarchy.
President #Ramaphosa: As black consciousness is a necessary part of the response to racism, so too is the self-affirmation of women necessary for the achievement of gender equality.
President #Ramaphosa: The struggle against patriarchy is therefore a struggle against the social norms, the attitudes and the thoughts that embolden men and enfeeble women.

President #Ramaphosa: Women bear the brunt of centuries of discrimination and oppression, imposed in this case not by a colonial power, but by the traditions, practices and institutions of the societies into which they were born.
President #Ramaphosa: Throughout history, there are few relationships more unequal than those between men and women.

President #Ramaphosa: It is our responsibility therefore to both confront deeply embedded feelings of inferiority and superiority and work to overcome the economic and social inequality that underpins them. This is not confined to race. #BIKOLecture
President #Ramaphosa: While naked racism is an aberration, the material manifestation of racism – white wealth and black poverty – is the norm.
President #Ramaphosa: It is a measure of the progress we have made, and of the impact of leaders like Steve Biko and Oliver Tambo, that society reacts with revulsion to these racist outburst.

President #Ramaphosa: Even today, we observe, in ways both subtle and crude, the residue of white entitlement and black submission. Thanks to the advent of social media, the prejudice that lurks below the surface is, from time to time, given virulent expression. #BIKOLecture
President #Ramaphosa: Even as we have defeated apartheid, even as we have built a democratic state, the psychological and physical vestiges of institutionalised racism persist. #BIKOLecture

President #Rampahosa: While some regard black consciousness as a historical artefact, the ideas that Steve Biko propounded are timeless and universal. They are no less powerful and no less relevant today. #BIKOLecture
President #Ramaphosa: His answer, black consciousness, was for the black person to see themselves as being complete in themselves.

President #Ramaphosa: Biko taught us the revolutionary value of the confidence of black people in their own humanity. He spoke of the debilitating effect of centuries of colonialism on the psyche of black people, making them complicit in perpetuating a sense of inferiority.

President #Ramaphosa: Now, in another time, under different circumstances, as we confront new and sometimes unexpected challenges, we are driven by this goal. To succeed, we must start – as Steve Biko did – with affirming our own sense of self.

President #Ramaphosa: It is found within seminal documents like the African Claims and the Freedom Charter, in the writings of Pixley ka Seme, Sol Plaatje, Alex la Guma, Bessie Head, Steve Biko and others. #BIKOLecture
President #Ramaphosa: It was present at the formation of the liberation movements, during the campaigns of defiance, the strikes and the stayaways, the armed resistance.

President #Ramaphosa: It is that quest – for a true humanity – that must lie at the core of our every endeavour. For decades, this quest has been a constant companion to the struggles of our people for freedom, dignity and respect. #BIKOLecture

President #Ramaphosa: What Steve Biko lived for was to restore the true humanity of all people, black and white, and to build a society in which there would no majority, nor minority. There would just be people, free, fulfilled and at peace. #BIKOLecture

President #Ramaphosa: The philosophy of Steve Biko was fundamentally the antithesis of this lie; it was about establishing the principles on which a new and more humane society would be established. #BIKOLecture

President #Ramaphosa: He understood the system of apartheid was predicated on the deliberate lie of black inferiority. He knew too that this lie was perpetuated by those who sought to preserve white economic privilege at the direct expense & to the exclusion of the black majority

President #Ramaphosa: It was a life dedicated to the pursuit of freedom, equality and truth. It was the life of a great, but humble, revolutionary who fiercely rejected the false hierarchy of races. He spoke with a burning eloquence of the essential humanity of all people.

President #Ramaphosa: The murder of Steve Biko reverbarated across the world, reinforcing the characterisation of apartheid as a crime against humanity. In the week that we commemorate a cruel death, we also honour and celebrate a remarkable life. #BIKOLecture

President #Ramaphosa: In its fear and its desperation, in its brutality and callous disregard for life, the apartheid state inflicted a devastating loss on the Biko family and on our nation. #BIKOLecture

President #Ramaphosa: It is an honour for me to be delivering this lecture during the centenary of the birth of Nelson Mandela. Earlier this week, we commemorated the 41st anniversary of the death in detention of Steven Bantu Biko. #BIKOLecture

Address by President Cyril Ramaphosa to Members of the Diplomatic Corps, OR Tambo Building, Pretoria https://bit.ly/2QsOsov
“Sukumani sakhe isizwe! Saam werk! Let us build today what we broke yesterday. With those few words, I wish you a successful summit.” #DPNedlacSummit
“Let us inspire hope, let us withstand the labour pains of yesterday and today so that a thriving new dawn my rise tomorrow.” #DPNedlacSummit

“We will turn our focus towards the institutionalisation of initiatives such as Sukuma Sakhe and Nthirisano at a national level to ensure that we build on the successes at provincial levels.” #DPNedlacSummit

“I have convened the Ministers COGTA, Small Business Development and Public Works to create work-streams and an anti-poverty inter-ministerial committee. Our focus is to graduate people out of Public Works programmes into enterprises and sustainable businesses.” #DPNedlacSummit

“I am advised that The Department of Labour has tabled the much anticipated National Minimum Wage (NMW) Bill and the Basic Conditions of Employment Amendment Bill to NEDLAC on 05 May 2017.” #DPNedlacSummit
Without your support and commitment, we cannot be able to defeat the corruption both in public and private sectors as well as price collusion. #DPNedlacSummit

In the similar vein, we expect all NEDLAC partners to follow in good-turn. We must join hands in improving the lives of our people. Together we must build resilient institutions that would make our country to grow to higher levels. #DPNedlacSummit

Most importantly, we have to graduate our people out of poverty by creating opportunities 4 young people & women. The other category in this regard that require attention and innovative responses, is the youth not in employment, not in education & not in training. #DPNedlacSummit
Our inequality levels are far too high. The wage differentials, the historical disadvantages and low levels of education and skills, demand of us all to care more about the poor. #DPNedlacSummit
For our part as government, we have made significant progress in the past eleven months to identify and take key actions to mitigate the risk factors. #DPNedlacSummit
Working together with government, we all need to assist our National Treasury in the development of appropriate stimulus measures to cushion the poor and re-start the economy. #DPNedlacSummit
In this environment, South Africans are standing cap-in-hand, facing us as NEDLAC social partners to coordinate all-round efforts to answer to their needs. #DPNedlacSummit
This is a place where we can bring an end to exploitation and other forms of modern-day slavery. #DPNedlacSummit

Here we will breed a system that gives workers a living wage. A system that creates jobs. A system that gives our people dignity. A system that helps them provide for themselves and live by the work of their hands. #DPNedlacSummit

It is a system that cares little for race, creed, colour, wealth or class status. So long as we all put shoulders to the wheel, with all palms holding fast to a single ideal, we can achieve more. #DPNedlacSummit
NEDLAC in its architecture envisions a country of opportunity. It envisions the cultivation of economic opportunities by working together as a people. #DPNedlacSummit
As we work together going forward, you will have my unwavering commitment to bringing together Government, Labour, Business and Community organizations for this common-cause. #DPNedlacSummit

As this is my first engagement with you since our appointment to this position, I join you in your critical to work with all of you in partnership for a common objective to create a developed and prosperous nation. #DPNedlacSummit

Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: In addition, President Ramaphosa appointed me to be his Special Envoy to South Sudan essentially to assist the Sudan Peoples’ Liberation Movement (SPLM) to unite and reconcile in order to lead the reconstruction programme of South Sudan.

Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: Subsequently President Ramaphosa convened a meeting of the High Level Ad Hoc Committee of Heads of State and Government on the fringes of the June 2018 AU Summit in Mauritania to assess the peace and security developments in South Sudan.

Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: On 5 August 2018, the Parties have appended signatures to the Agreement on Outstanding Issues of Governance. This has been hailed as a momentous achievement in the efforts to finding lasting peace in South Sudan.

Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: These talks were facilitated under the High-Level Revitalisation Forum (HLRF) of the Agreement on Resolution of Conflict in South Sudan (ARCSS) led by the Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD).

Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: In August 2018, the South Sudan Parties, including the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement/Army-In Government, the Sudan People’s Liberation Movement/Army-In Opposition and the South Sudan Opposition Alliance participated at the peace talks.
Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: This has assisted in arresting the decline in the Industrial Park’s infrastructure so as to encourage further investment.
Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: 2/2 to address challenges of key industrial development infrastructure such as electricity, bulk water supply and sewage system.
Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: 1/2 In the last two years alone, government has invested approximately R511m in revitalizing the basic infrastructure of 10 Industrial Parks across South Africa
Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: These cover townships and underdeveloped areas such Botshabelo, Seshego, Garankuwa, Nkowankowa, Isithebe, to name but a few.

Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: I am advised by the Department of Trade and Industry that, to date, a total of 65 854 jobs have been created within these State Owned Industrial Parks across the country.

Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: The programme has identified 11 state-owned industrial parks to be revitalised and this is implemented through national government partnerships with the provinces, their agencies and municipalities.

Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: Additionally, in order to bring about full scale industrialisation and inclusive growth, government initiated a structured programme for the revitalisation of industrial parks located in old industrial areas across the country.

Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: The Special Economic Zone Programme was specifically developed to promote the creation of a regionally diversified industrial economy by establishing new industrial hubs in underdeveloped regions of the country.
Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: we have made significant progress in directing strategic investments towards targeted areas in order to support economic growth and job creation.

Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: We have also made interventions like the Expanded Public Works Programme, which provide income relief, skills development and opportunities to get into long-term gainful employment and creation of own enterprises.
Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: We have also introduced various government incentives to support entrepreneurship under the Department of Small Business Development.
Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: Government realises that the National Minimum Wage Bill is one of the greatest contributors to poverty alleviation and reduction of income inequality.

Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: The upcoming Jobs Summit will also ensure that we continue on the path of addressing our country’s poverty and income distributions. It will elevate the efforts focused on inclusive growth and correcting the issue of wage differentials.

Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: In the longer term, the sustainability of our efforts against poverty and inequality will depend on an economy that grows at sustainable levels to create sufficient employment for the majority of our people.
Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: In previously underdeveloped and underserviced areas, we have built transport infrastructure networks to connect communities and provide economic mobility.
Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: We are making progress in expanding quality healthcare including the implementation of the National Health Insurance.

Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: Similarly, government has put in place programmes that aim at improving access of the poor to other social services through the provision of improved sanitation, electricity, water, and access to health services.
Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: South Africa has one of the largest social assistance programs in the world, covering more than 17 million beneficiaries.

Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: We have implemented school nutrition programmes to ensure that no child goes to school hungry. We have introduced free higher education for students from poor households.
Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: We introduced no-fee schools for the poor. We implemented adult basic education to raise the levels of literacy amongst our adult population.
Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: We have opened access to education for all. We rolled-out early childhood education to promote holistic development that instils the culture of lifelong learning.
Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: Apartheid spatial planning was a chief enabler of a system that was essentially designed to keep the black majority landless, unskilled and malnourished.

Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: Apartheid stripped people of their dignity, land, livelihood and overall means of production. It distorted the supply and demand patterns of the economy along racial lines.
Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: 2/2 lack of access to quality education and healthcare, as well as years of underdevelopment in former homelands and townships.

Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: 1/2 Let me state at the outset that the root causes of poverty and inequality have to do with the unfair and unequal distribution of economic opportunities engendered by the history of land dispossession

Deputy President David Mabuza responds to Questions for Oral Reply in the National Assembly, Parliament, Cape Town 12 September 2018. The Deputy President is briefing the House on efforts by Government to address poverty and inequality. #MabuzaQandApic.twitter.com/8jatXMHP8g

Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: Deputy President David Mabuza responds to Questions for Oral Reply in the National Assembly, Parliament, Cape Town 12 September 2018. The Deputy President briefed the House on efforts by Government to address poverty and inequality.

Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: As Deputy President, I am part of the Presidential Infrastructure Coordinating Committee which is seized with finding solutions and better ways of accelerating infrastructure development.
Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: In the execution of their line functions, Ministers have undertaken outreach visits in the provinces and municipalities to assess the delivery of services.

Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: 2/2 , together with my Cabinet Colleagues, Premiers and Mayors, we are providing support to existing initiatives that will strengthen various instruments of service delivery.
Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: 1/2 In light of the responsibilities assigned to me by the President to promote social cohesion initiatives and lead the Government’s anti-poverty programmes

Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: Our focus on rural development is also contributing to job creation, local economic development and investment. To this end, construction has been the 2nd largest generator of new jobs in this administration.
Deputy President David #MabuzaQandA: Since the development of the national infrastructure plan, government has made significant progress in terms of delivery of social infrastructure.

President #Ramaphosa: We are informed by research that associates investment in ICTs with such economic benefits as higher productivity, lower costs, new economic opportunities, job creation, innovation and increased trade. #ITUinSA18

President #Ramaphosa: Earlier this year, we announced plans to establish a Digital Industrial Revolution Commission to ensure we are in a position to seize the opportunities of the rapid advances in information and communication technology. #ITUinSA2018

President #Ramaphosa: This work builds on the strides we have made to increase penetration of 3G and 4G which stands at over 90% and 70% respectively. About 87% of households have access to mobile phones which means that mobility will continue to drive growth and innovation.

President #Ramaphosa: Government is working with industry to search for interventions to maximize the value of digital innovations. Key interventions include the accelerated rollout of broadband in areas that are generally seen as being economically not viable. #ITUinSA18

President #Ramaphosa: Our economies are increasingly dependent on ICTs, and this has been recognized across the sectors of the economy such as finance, transport, mining and other key industries that dominated the previous industrial revolutions. #ITUinSA18

President #Ramaphosa: As we move deeper into the digital economy, it is becoming more and more necessary that we work together to maximize the value of the new, heightened technological innovations. #ITUinSA18

President #Ramaphosa: South Africa is hosting this ITU Telecom World 2018 not only to showcase our inventions and capabilities, but to also benchmark and collaborate with others in the development of innovations to boost digital economy. #ITUinSA18

President #Ramaphosa: This is particularly critical in the developing world where countries still have not overcome the joblessness of the past revolutions. We have to deal with the 4th Industrial revolution while we also attend to the outstanding issues from the past. #ITUinSA18

President #Ramaphosa: This event comes at a time when all nations states are considering ways to maximize the value of the 4th Industrial Revolution while as a necessity mitigating its socio-economic threats such as job losses. #ITUinSA18

President @CyrilRamaphosa and ITU Secretary General Houlin Zhao cut the ribbon to mark the official opening of the conference exhibition. The exhibition provides international exposure and opportunities for innovative local SMEs operating in the ICT sector. #ITUinSA18pic.twitter.com/GtmbhN7maN

ITU Telecom World is a platform for government and industry leaders to explore challenges, partnerships, solutions, and identify investment opportunities and best practices for socio-economic development through the use of ICTs #ITUinSA18pic.twitter.com/Z09V7Ad075
