President #Ramaphosa: Our objectives extend beyond the peoples of Africa and China. Together, we are working to build a community of shared future for all humankind. This requires leadership, vision and partnership #FOCAC2018 #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: This is a forward-looking partnership, concerned not only with the challenges of the present, but preparing for the opportunities of the future.We should be using FOCAC as an instrument for youth development & to invest in building their capabilities

President #Ramaphosa: As we strengthen political and economic ties, we need to place greater emphasis on people-to-people cooperation. We need, through such cooperation, to nurture and empower the youth of China and Africa. #FOCAC2018 #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: We should be using platforms such as FOCAC to reaffirm our shared commitment to multilateralism, a fair and transparent system of international trade and a global economic architecture that promotes the interests of the developing world #FOCAC2018

President #Ramaphosa: The economic value of FOCAC – to both Africa and China – is particularly important in the context of an increasingly uncertain global environment #FOCAC2018 #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: It is important also that we promote investment-led trade between Africa & China, which addresses the nature and quality of investment in Africa.We should seek inward investment that enables industrial development & the export of more value-added products.

President #Ramaphosa: It is through platforms like FOCAC that we should work to balance the structure of trade between Africa and China. As we look to expand Chinese investment in Africa, we need to encourage more local partnerships between Chinese and African entrepreneurs.

President #Ramaphosa: Much of what is exported from Africa are raw materials and primary products; much of what is imported from China are finished goods. We export to China what we extract from the earth; China exports to us what it makes in its factories #FOCAC2018

President #Ramaphosa: We appreciate the decision to provide $60bn new funding to African countries and to invest in initiatives in areas such as industrial development, infrastructure, human resource development, health care, the green economy, and peace & security #FOCAC2018

President #Ramaphosa: Building on these remarkable achievements, we welcome the announcement today by President Xi of new FOCAC initiatives that will have a significant and lasting impact on peace, stability and sustainable development on the African continent #FOCAC2018

President #Ramaphosa: The agricultural modernisation plan has promoted greater agricultural productivity and the infrastructure plan has boosted African connectivity and integration #FOCAC2018 #BetterAfricaBetterWorld
President #Ramaphosa: The China-Africa industrialisation plan has driven development in many parts of Africa & contributed to economic transformation #FOCAC2018 #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: We are greatly encouraged by their assessment that the ten cooperation plans announced in 2015 have been fully implemented, for it shows a partnership that is hard at work to advance the mutual interests of Africa and China. #FOCAC2018

President #Ramaphosa: Importantly, it is an Africa whose development is people-driven, relying on the capability and potential of its people. We look to China as a valuable and committed partner in advancing the @_AfricanUnion Agenda 2063 #FOCAC2018

President #Ramaphosa: Our vision is for an Africa where the guns have been silenced, and where all its people live in peace and security. It is an Africa with a strong cultural identity, common heritage, shared values and ethics #FOCAC2018 #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: We are working to build an Africa that is defined by good governance, democracy, respect for human rights, justice and the rule of law. It is an Africa where the guns have been silenced, and where all its people live in peace and security #FOCAC2018

President #Ramaphosa: The relationship that we have forged through FOCAC is premised on the fundamental & inalienable right of the African people to determine their own future, premised on the African Union’s Agenda 2063, a vision that has been crafted in Africa, by Africans.

President #Ramaphosa: In the values that it promotes, in the manner that it operates and in the impact that it has on African countries, FOCAC refutes the view that a new colonialism is taking hold in Africa, as our detractors would have us believe #FOCAC2018

President #Ramaphosa: Since its launch in 2000, FOCAC has grown both in extent and scope. It serves as an effective platform for south-south cooperation focused on the tangible improvement of the quality of lives of all the people of Africa #FOCAC2018 #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: We recall the visit of Chinese Premier Zhou Enlai to Africa in the 1960s, where he articulated the key principles underpinning our comprehensive strategic and cooperative partnership - equality, trust, mutual respect and mutual benefit #FOCAC2018
President #Ramaphosa: Africa and China enjoy a rich history characterised by friendship and solidarity from times immemorial #FOCAC2018 #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: We are also cognisant of challenges relating to our regulatory framework. We are in the process of regularizing our visa regime and making it easier to conduct business in South Africa #SAinChina #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: Our land reform program will be undertaken in a manner that does not harm our economy, agricultural production or food security #SAinChina #ChinaStateVisit #BetterAfricaBetterWorld
President #Ramaphosa: In my engagement with President Xi, we agreed that SA must use the resolution of the land question to drive transformation, development and stability

President #Ramaphosa: We are also heartened by support received from important multilateral organizations including the World Bank & the IMF. South Africans will emerge united following the resolution of the land question as we did in the period following demise of apartheid

President #Ramaphosa: Our country is also currently engaging on land reform. The fear that had been propagating around the land question is subsiding. South Africans realize that this "original sin" continues to be a wound that must be healed

President #Ramaphosa: Challenges related to corruption and the governance of our state owned enterprises are receiving the urgent attention of our government #SAinChina #ChinaStateVisit #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: As we meet with potential investors, we are aware that some of the critical signals they will look for from us are policy certainty and policy consistency. We have not done well on this over the last couple of year, we are focusing on it now

President #Ramaphosa: As SA government & business our message to the rest of the world is simple and straightforward. South Africa is open for business. We seek to raise $100bn to drive economic growth & job creation in our country. Half of this must come from within our borders

President #Ramaphosa: Thank you for attending this business breakfast. I had left it important that as SA government and business we should get together before meeting the rest of the world. All of us are very proud to be here flying high the SA flag

President #Ramaphosa: I am confident that through engagements of this nature – by working together in pursuit of common goals – we will succeed in building business partnerships that contribute to inclusive growth and shared prosperity for all. I thank you.

President #Ramaphosa: We are committed to enhancing investor confidence and positioning South Africa as one of the leading emerging market investment destinations. We are committed to improving the investment climate and the ease of doing business in South Africa.
President #Ramaphosa: That is why the government is aiming to generate at least half of all new investment over the next five years from outside our borders. #UKinSA #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: We see foreign direct investment as a critical driver of economic growth. It contributes to the expansion of a country’s productive capacity through the transfer of technology, knowledge, job opportunities, human capital & production processes.

President #Ramaphosa: Through my four investment envoys and the efforts of a dedicated division of the Department of Trade and Industry, Invest SA, we are scaling up our investment promotion, facilitation and aftercare services. #UKinSA #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: In recent months, we have finalised long-outstanding renewable energy independent power producer projects, released the Integrated Resource Plan on energy for public comment and held stakeholder engagements towards the finalisation of the Mining Charter.

President #Ramaphosa: Our government is working earnestly to restore South Africa’s sovereign ratings to investment grade status by, among other things, bringing policy certainty in areas such as mining, telecommunications and energy.

President #Ramaphosa: These include measures to correct governance failures at certain key state owned enterprises, ensure those involved in graft are held to account and strengthen law enforcement agencies.

President #Ramaphosa: We are determined that whatever measures we take to effect land reform do not undermine the economy. Government has taken steps to tackle the problem of corruption within both public and private institutions. #UKinSA

President #Ramaphosa: This is an opportunity to strengthen the property rights of all our people, to provide certainty to investors & to our people, & to achieve consensus on a land reform programme that will contribute to economic growth, job creation & the reduction of poverty.
President #Ramaphosa: There is a vibrant and healthy debate underway within society on the circumstances under which land reform should take place.

President #Ramaphosa: We have embarked on a programme of accelerated land reform to ensure that land is equitably shared among all South Africans, the agricultural sector is transformed, urban spatial distortions corrected & the economic potential of the land is unlocked.

President #Ramaphosa: Minister Davies and his team at the Department of Trade and Industry stand ready to assist investors where clarity is required and to develop implementation strategies for multinationals through the equity equivalent programme. #UKinSA
President #Ramaphosa: We have recognised that these policies may prove difficult for foreign multinational companies to navigate.

President #Ramaphosa: That is why broad-based black economic empowerment is a key government policy aimed at addressing the racial and gender imbalances of the past while unlocking the human potential of our people.

President #Ramaphosa: Our approach is informed by the understanding that we cannot achieve sustained economic growth or enduring social stability without ensuring more South Africans are able to participate in the productive economy. #UKinSA #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: We are improving the investment environment by, among other things, ensuring policy certainty and consistency, improving the performance of state owned enterprises and consolidating fiscal debt. #UKinSA #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: They would know that the South African government is working alongside its social partners in business, labour and civil society to build a new and inclusive growth path for South Africa. #UKinSA

President #Ramaphosa: This means that there are many British business leaders who have a good understanding of the South African market and recognise its potential, and who are also able to identify constraints to growth and development.

President #Ramaphosa: We are encouraged by the fact that the UK is one of the largest foreign investors in the South African economy with more than 650 British firms present in the market. #UKinSA #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

President #Ramaphosa: We are looking forward to welcoming British investors to this Conference, both those who have long been invested in South Africa looking to expand their operations and those who would be investing here for the first time.

President #Ramaphosa: This drive will culminate in an Investment Conference on 25-27 October, which will bring together investors both from within South Africa and from other parts of the world. #UKinSA #BetterAfricaBetterWorld
President #Ramaphosa: Earlier this year, we announced an ambitious investment drive that aims to generate at least $100 billion in new investment over the next five years.

President #Ramaphosa: This is taking place alongside a process of political and economic renewal, which aims to restore the credibility of our public institutions, tackle corruption and wastage and strengthen the capacity of the state. #UKinSA

President #Ramaphosa: After several years of poor growth, limited investment and constrained public finances, the South African economy is starting to show signs of revival. #UKinSA #BetterAfricaBetterWorld
President #Ramaphosa: It is my pleasure to welcome you here today. I would like to extend a word of thanks to Mr Jacques Celliers and FNB for hosting us in this venue today. #UKinSA

President #Ramaphosa: Let us build a social compact for access to quality health care for all. Let us build the #NHI. I thank you.

President #Ramaphosa: It is my hope that this consultative meeting will facilitate the necessary partnerships between different sectors of our society towards the NHI. Without all sectors of society working together, we will not be able to build a healthy and successful society.
President #Ramaphosa: Our collective approach to health care as a society must be more preventative rather than curative.

President #Ramaphosa: I urge all of us gathered here to do our best to encourage South Africans to adopt more healthy lifestyles and avoid placing themselves at risk of contracting diseases. We must emphasise that primary health care begins with individuals at a household level.pic.twitter.com/Auhzu9ELJj

President #Ramaphosa: I wish to conclude by urging all our health professionals and general workers in the health sector to understand that the provision of quality health care – and thus the success of the #NHI – is literally in their hands.
President #Ramaphosa: We are determined to work together to overcome our two-tiered health system, which is the major barrier to achieve a universal health system.

President #Ramaphosa: We have decided to cover the whole country on an incremental basis. This means from 2019, once the bill is passed, we will start to incrementally implement the NHI and by 2025 everyone will be covered.

President #Ramaphosa: The NHI can and will be a success. We are a country that is spending R420 billion or 8.5 percent of domestic funding on health care. This is more than any other middle-income country, and it is very close to advanced economies such as the UK and Canada.pic.twitter.com/b3l2gp07Ns

President #Ramaphosa: We need to build on the strengths of the public health system, which has helped improve life expectancy of our people, successfully turned the tide in our battle against HIV & AIDS and rolled out massive health infrastructure we now have across the country.

President #Ramaphosa: Providing universal and quality health care for all is not only a matter of moral principle. It is also a financially responsible decision that will save a lot of money while keeping our people healthier.

President #Ramaphosa: We must put behind us the era of quality health care being the exclusive preserve of those among us with deep pockets. The #NHI is therefore also fundamentally about social justice.
President #Ramaphosa: We envisage a transformed health system that will not just have better health outcomes, but one that will also save money for individuals, households and the country as a whole.

President #Ramaphosa: We need to ensure these resources are used efficiently and fairly to scale-up the supply of quality health services for everyone, with enough trained and motivated health workers, and to transform the health system to address the needs of all our people.
President #Ramaphosa: This is a view with which we agree and we are determined to prove it. Achieving universal health coverage is not just about spending more money.

President #Ramaphosa: When the NHI was brought to the table ten years ago, some were quick to dismiss it as an “unaffordable dream”. But Nobel Laureate Amartya Sen vehemently disagreed. He argued that when properly designed and managed, the #NHI is affordable.

President #Ramaphosa: We must be clear that the resources needed to provide quality health care services represent investment rather than consumption, particularly if you consider the benefits of a healthy population and a productive workforce.

President #Ramaphosa: Our doctors must not be put in the brutal position of having to fight among themselves, seeking to convince one another on who must be operated on first, and by implication, who must be allowed to perish. We must change this situation.
President #Ramaphosa: The massive backlog of operations in our hospitals owing to the dysfunctionality of our operating theatres must also be dealt with.

President #Ramaphosa: We must accept the quality of service cannot be improved by a fatigued & demoralised workforce. The challenges related to the shortage of medical equipment as well as theatre & intensive care unit beds in our public hospitals also require urgent attention.

President #Ramaphosa: Our health professionals, who constitute the backbone of the public health care system, have often indicated that they are overworked and exploited as a result of staff shortages occasioned by the exodus of their colleagues to the private sector.

President #Ramaphosa: In dealing with the challenges raised in that report, we need to use this meeting to exchange ideas on how we can address the severe shortage of essential employees, such as doctors and nurses, and support staff such as radiographers, porters and others.

President #Ramaphosa: The Office of Health Standards Compliance tabled a shocking report to the Portfolio Committee on Health in Parliament, which indicated that health facilities inspected met less than 50% of the required quality health standards. This is totally unacceptable.

President #Ramaphosa: Our people should be able to access a comprehensive range of health services, including prevention, treatment, rehabilitation and others. These services – no matter who is providing them – should be of good quality. #NHI

President #Ramaphosa: The National Health Insurance is meant to ensure that all our people, black and white, rich and poor, receive the quality health services they need without the imposition on them of financial hardship.pic.twitter.com/IAJiilQxiC
President #Ramaphosa: This is especially important in our country with a racialised two-tier health system sustained on the basis of uneven distribution of resources.

President #Ramaphosa: It is therefore the duty of a democratic and progressive government to create policies that ensure that every South African can access quality health care – and not just the rich.pic.twitter.com/W6SE2Hf4bf
President #Ramaphosa: It inconceivable that anyone could argue against the need for every South African to have access to health services on the basis of need and not on their ability to pay. #NHI
Minister in The Presidency, Dr Nkosazana Dlamini Zuma will today make the Keynote tribute at the Memorial Service for the former United Nations Secretary-General, Mr Kofi Annan

President #Ramaphosa: The SDG target on health spells out that we have to: “Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential healthcare services, access to safe, effective, quality & affordable essential medicines & vaccines.”
President #Ramaphosa: The global community marked the end of the Millennium Development Goals era with the adoption of the Sustainable Development Goals in 2015. #NHI

President #Ramaphosa: We also did a lot to dramatically improve the social and political determinants of health care – including the near universal provision of clean water to millions of the poor, decent education and the provision of social grants to poor households.

President #Ramaphosa: We abolished the apartheid structures of the health care system, rolled out primary health care facilities to areas where they were needed most, and waged an effective battle against HIV and AIDS.

President #Ramaphosa: Finally, this meeting is providing us with an opportunity to broaden consensus around the core principles that will define the #NHI. We have achieved a lot in ensuring access to health care for our people since the dawn of democracy in 1994.

President #Ramaphosa: More importantly, we wish to emerge out of this meeting having collectively considered and exchanged ideas about the proposed reforms in the legislative and regulatory framework of our health care system. #NHI

President #Ramaphosa: We have convened this important National Health Insurance consultative meeting with you, as representatives of various stakeholders in our health care system, to engage in dialogue on the current health situation in our country. #NHI

President #Ramaphosa: We must stop casting aspersions or spreading rumours. Where there is suspected corruption, it must be raised on an evidence basis.pic.twitter.com/JaOcV1OQqQ
President #Ramaphosa: “Without transformation, there can be no stability...” #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/jWj4vHsr2d

President #Ramaphosa: South Africa’s ground-breaking renewable energy programme is firmly rooted in the National Development Plan, is guided by the Integrated Resource Plan and has been part of ANC policy for over a decade. It is not new and it is not being rushed.pic.twitter.com/Gd83dLUJ2o

President #Ramaphosa: Renewable IPPs have created over 35,000 job years for youth, women and citizens from local communities and have invested around R766 million on education, health, social welfare and enterprise development projects in these communities.

President #Ramaphosa: The benefits of the Renewable Energy IPP Programme will continue to grow. By March 2018, a total of 64 projects were in operation and under construction representing a total investment of R142 billion.

President #Ramaphosa: International research forecasts that new photovoltaic prices will fall to 20c per kilowatt hour by 2030 compared to the average Eskom’s prices that will rise to over 100c per kilowatt hour, as a result of the capital & generation cost of Medupi & Kusile.
President #Ramaphosa: Increasing renewable capacity is a cost effective means of reducing carbon emissions.

President #Ramaphosa: As a country we need to build new reliable power plants to grow our economy. The energy planning process for securing new generating capacity is not only directed at immediate short-term issues but rather towards medium to long-term objectives.

President #Ramaphosa: The 27 projects do not negatively affect Eskom’s current capacity but will supplement and support stable supply as and when Eskom commences with the decommissioning of its aged fleet, as projected in the IRP.
President #Ramaphosa: In line with the IRP projections, the majority of the 27 projects will start generating power and be paid for their output as from late 2020.
President #Ramaphosa: The commissioning dates of these projects correspond with demand and supply projections of the Integrated Resource Plan.

President #Ramaphosa: The 27 projects from bid windows 3.5 and 4 of the Renewable Energy IPP Programme were all procured during 2014 in accordance with long standing government energy policy and statutory mandate.
President #Ramaphosa: The three year delay was the result of a delay in the finalisation of the Power Purchase Agreements that needed to be signed by Eskom.
President #Ramaphosa: The successful bidders for the 27 Independent Power Producers agreements that the Minister of Energy signed on 4 April this year had already been selected and announced in 2015.
President #Ramaphosa: “The one thing we will keep in mind is how best we can advance the interests of our people.” #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/Fe1LZymJjl
President #Ramaphosa: “The intention of the proposed amendment on land is to strengthen the property rights of all South Africans.” #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/cCrLM6G8IJ
President #Ramaphosa: For its part, government will continue to pursue a comprehensive approach to land and agrarian reform that ensures transformation, development and stability.
President #Ramaphosa: It will provide certainty to those who own land, to those who need land and to those who are considering investing in our economy.

President #Ramaphosa: It gives greater force to the requirement in the Bill of Rights, which says: “The state must take reasonable legislative & other measures within its available resources to foster conditions which enable citizens to gain access to land on an equitable basis.”
President #Ramaphosa: The intention of the proposed amendment is to strengthen the property rights of all South Africans and to reinforce the transformative nature of our Constitution.

President #Ramaphosa: Section 25 (8) of the Property Clause explicitly states: “No provision of this section may impede the state from taking legislative and other measures to achieve land, water and related reform, in order to redress the results of past racial discrimination”.

President #Ramaphosa: The late Andre van der Walt, one of South Africa’s leading constitutional property scholars, has argued that Section 25 (3) makes non-compensation permissible in appropriate circumstances.

President #Ramaphosa: It lists among the relevant circumstances to be considered in deciding on such a balance, such things as the history of the acquisition of the property, its current use, and the extent of direct state investment in the property. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: In dealing with just and equitable compensation in the case of expropriation, for example, Section 25 calls for an equitable balance between the public interest and those affected.

President #Ramaphosa: The acceleration of land redistribution is necessary not only to redress a grave historical injustice, but also to bring more producers into the agricultural sector and to make more land available for cultivation.
President #Ramaphosa: This should take place within a broad and comprehensive land redistribution and agricultural development programme. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: I’ve appointed an Inter-Ministerial Committee on Land Reform, led by the Deputy President, which has been tasked with coordinating measures to accelerate the redistribution of land, the extension of security of tenure & the provision of agricultural support.

President #Ramaphosa: As I indicated during #SONA2018, government is determined that land reform should be implemented in a way that increases agricultural production, improves food security & ensures that the land is returned to those from whom it was taken under colonialism.
President #Ramaphosa: Once Parliament has adopted a position on the matter, it will become government’s responsibility to implement.

President #Ramaphosa: Much like the pronouncements of other political parties – including the pronouncements by the Honourable Leader of the Opposion – this position will guide the contribution of its Members in the Parliamentary process.
President #Ramaphosa: This announcement does not undermine nor does it preempt the outcome of the public consultation process.

President #Ramaphosa: It is based on an understanding that the Constitution, as it currently stands, allows for expropriation without compensation in certain circumstances. The proposal is intended to make explicit what is currently implicit in the Constitution.
President #Ramaphosa: The proposal is informed, among other things, by the views of our people in public hearings and by the members of the ANC.

President #Ramaphosa: On 31st July, in my capacity as President of the African National Congress, I announced that the ANC would propose an amendment to the Constitution that would provide clarity on circumstances under which expropriation without compensation could be effected.pic.twitter.com/lg9G0wTK9l

President #Ramaphosa: “Based on all the available evidence, it emerged as the one revenue raising measure that would have the least negative impact on economic growth, which is essential for job creation and the reduction of poverty.” #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/bdlYXCRQDq

President #Ramaphosa: Taking the recommendations, public comments and evaluation of the recommendations by Treasury & SARS, the Finance Minister will determine which recommendations to implement by including them in current/future tax legislation for consideration of Parliament.

President #Ramaphosa: The report also highlights some programmes on the expenditure side that would assist poorer households, such as strengthening the National School Nutrition Programme and increasing the Child Support Grant and Old Age Pension Grant.
President #Ramaphosa: The process of public consultation will assist in evaluating the recommendations further to ascertain if they have the potential to significantly benefit poor households.
President #Ramaphosa: It should for instance be ensured that a price of a zero-rated product is reduced from what it was with VAT included.

President #Ramaphosa: The Panel recommended that National Treasury conducts further work on each of the proposed additional items to ensure there is no room created for VAT fraud by producers or retailers & that the benefit of zero-rating on these items indeed goes to consumers.

President #Ramaphosa: The report recommends the following additional items be included in the basket of zero rated goods: white bread, bread flour and cake flour, sanitary products, school uniforms, nappies, including cloth and adult nappies.
President #Ramaphosa: The Panel’s report was submitted to the Minister of Finance on 6 August 2018, and subsequently released for public comment.

President #Ramaphosa: However, as we implement the VAT increase it is essential that this does not place an undue burden on the poor. Government therefore set up an Independent Panel of Experts to review the current list of zero-rated VAT items.

President #Ramaphosa: Based on all the available evidence, it emerged as the one revenue raising measure that would have the least negative impact on economic growth, which is essential for job creation and the reduction of poverty.
President #Ramaphosa: It was these considerations that informed government’s decision to increase VAT by 1 percent from 1 April 2018.

President #Ramaphosa: Underlying all the tax proposals that government has made since 1994, is the need to promote the growth of an inclusive economy, to redistribute resources to meet the needs of the poor, and to ensure sustainable management of public finances. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: All the agreements that we enter into are based on ethics, good corporate governance and are meant to advance the interests of our people. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/8MYzCXq02A
President #Ramaphosa: #BRICS countries are forging ahead with initiatives to expand trade and investment. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/rOk6krTM2A
President #Ramaphosa: BRICS is not just a talkshop. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/AVlmH4G1v1

President #Ramaphosa: We always act to promote our country’s interest in everything we do. When we deal with various countries, it is to protect our national interest. China has not displayed imperialist tendencies. We are wide awake and we know an imperialist when we see one.

President #Ramaphosa: Individual #BRICS countries are important and influential globally, but it is when these countries stand together in the alliance formed through #BRICS that we are in a better position to advance a fairer global trade agenda.

President #Ramaphosa: This provides the necessary policy space for developing countries to pursue their development objectives, including industrialisation, to promote their effective integration into the global economy. #RamaphosaQandA
President #Ramaphosa: They support provisions for special and differential treatment, including in agriculture.

President #Ramaphosa: The #BRICS countries are in agreement that development must remain integral to the WTO’s work and that developing countries should secure a share in the growth of world trade that matches their needs for economic development. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: The #BRICS countries constitute an important global voice in support of a rules based, transparent and inclusive multilateral trading system that promotes a predictable trade environment and the centrality of the WTO.
President #Ramaphosa: The BRICS countries have reaffirmed their commitment to work together to shape a multilateral trading system that supports industrialisation and economic diversification.
President #Ramaphosa: One such initiative, is the China International Import Expo in Shanghai in November 2018, which South Africa will use to expand the basket of products it exports to China.

President #Ramaphosa: Against the backdrop of unilateral measures taken by some developed countries to protect their domestic industries, #BRICS countries are forging ahead with initiatives to expand intra-BRICS trade and investment. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: Trade between South Africa and its BRICS partners has grown from $28 billion to $35 billion over the last decade. Combined, the BRICS countries account for 15% of South Africa’s exports, and 25% of the country’s imports.

President #Ramaphosa: With a combined GDP of approximately $15 trillion, #BRICS countries account for around 20% of gross global product, over 40% of the world population, & have collectively contributed more than half of world economic growth during the last 10 years.
President #Ramaphosa: The #BRICS partnership offers South Africa significant opportunities to expand and diversify our trade, to attract investment and to develop our economic infrastructure.
President #Ramaphosa: “Working together, we must fight for every job and for every cent of investment.”pic.twitter.com/kSQYGI1bl8

President #Ramaphosa: We need investment for our economy to grow and for us to create jobs. We are focused on local corporates to invest in our economy. Many have demonstrated this commitment. We have a multiplicity of sectors in our economy that can create jobs. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: we are well aware that private sector actors set up various systems to defraud money from the public sector. We are going to stop these. We are cleaning up government. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: We are becoming more aware of how we can tighten up our processes to ensure that when money is allocated it is used for the purposes it was earmarked for. We are going to curb wastage and corruption as assisted by the Auditor-General.
President #Ramaphosa: We shouldn’t hold back and be afraid to give young people a chance. I call on companies to open up opportunities for young people to get to work.

President #Ramaphosa: If work experience was a requirement for many of us here to get into job positions, many of us wouldn’t have been able to access the opportunities that we have. Young people must be given opportunities regardless of lack of work experience.
President #Ramaphosa: Working together, we must fight for every job and for every cent of investment. Now is the moment to unite and work together.

President #Ramaphosa: As social partners, as a country, we must respond to the current economic difficulties with the same determination that we have confronted the seemingly intractable problems of our past.
President #Ramaphosa: We are promoting the growth of labour intensive sectors like agriculture, services and tourism. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: We are developing the productive base of the economy, by enhancing current industrial policy measures, leveraging local procurement, sharpening the Industrial Policy Action Plan, promoting export competitiveness & taking advantage of regional opportunities.

President #Ramaphosa: We are doing this through stronger competition regulation, revitalising key state-owned entities, promoting agrarian reform, better spatial planning, improved public transport systems, development finance and industrial incentives.
President #Ramaphosa: We are reducing barriers to entry, especially for emerging black businesses. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: We are working to build human capabilities through access to high quality early childhood development, access to higher education to produce skills needed for the future, youth employment interventions and improving outcomes in education and health.
President #Ramaphosa: Beyond these measures, we must undertake a fundamental re-engineering of the economy.

President #Ramaphosa: With many companies contemplating retrenchments, we need to work together as social partners - in much the same way as we did in response to the 2008 financial crisis – to mitigate the effects of the current economic climate on jobs.

President #Ramaphosa: We are improving governance across the public sector and have moved with speed to tackle state capture and corruption. We are also taking measures to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of government at all levels. #RamaphosaQandA
President #Ramaphosa: We will also soon be making announcements on the allocation of broadband spectrum, the Electronic Communications Amendment Bill and the single transport economic regulator.

President #Ramaphosa: We are addressing chief constraints to greater investment & growth. Government is making progress on addressing policy & regulatory issues like visa requirements for skilled individuals, finalisation of the Mining Charter & the draft Integrated Resource Plan

President #Ramaphosa: This package reprioritises funds towards initiatives that are labour intensive, addresses infrastructual needs and boosts local economies. Government will vigourously implemement confidence-building measures to unlock private sector resources.
President #Ramaphosa: In the coming days, Cabinet will announce the details of a stimulus package to reignite growth and to establish the foundation for a sustained economic recovery.
President #Ramaphosa: They too see that the platform is burning, and instead of throwing up their hands in despair, are determined to be part of the solution.
President #Ramaphosa: We have been approached by business leaders across the economy insisting that they will play their part, working together with government, to grow the economy and create jobs.

President #Ramaphosa: There has been an enthusiastic response from South African businesses and international investors to our plans for an Investment Conference, which will be held in Johannesburg from the 25th to 27th October.
President #Ramaphosa: We have prioritised the task of significantly raising levels of investment in the economy, since that is essential for growth and job creation.

President #Ramaphosa: That is why this government is working together with its social partners to address both the immediate economic challenges and, through far-reaching reforms, place the economy on a new path of inclusive growth and job creation.
President #Ramaphosa: Put simply, we have not been creating enough jobs to meet the growing need for work.

President #Ramaphosa: In other words, employment has doubled between 1994 & 2018. Despite an absolute increase in the number of people employed, South Africa’s unemployment rate has remained stubbornly high, as the population has grown and more people have entered the workforce.

President #Ramaphosa: Following the dawn of democracy, we were able to create jobs on a scale not before seen in this country. In 1994, 8.8 million South Africans were employed. The latest employment data show that 16.3 million people are in employment.

President #Ramaphosa: The historical reliance on raw commodity exports and the deliberate underdevelopment and economic marginalisation of the majority of our people resulted in structural unemployment that has been a prominent feature of our economy since the early 1980s.

President #Ramaphosa: We must treat unemployment as a burning platform – a challenge that requires extraordinary measures and exceptional efforts to address. To succeed, it is essential that we understand the causes of the massive unemployment in our country. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/ExN5Zf3pZ7

President #Ramaphosa: Creating employment, particularly for young people, is the most urgent & critical priority for our country at this moment in our history. The most recent unemployment figures are a clear signal that we cannot continue at the current pace of economic growth.
President #Ramaphosa: We encourage local government entities to look at the places where hostels are located and transform them into more decent and better accommodation. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: I am totally opposed to the eviction and mass movement of people from areas where they have lived. My family was forcibly removed in 1962. Those wounds remain deep in our memory. Seeing that happening today is against what we should stand for as a nation.

President #Ramaphosa: Through such a compact, through the transformation of our urban spaces, by strengthening property rights for all, we can ensure that the poor and working class live in decent communities located near to economic opportunities. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: Elements of this approach are already found in the funding and fiscal framework of the Department of Human Settlements, which uses government grants, subsidies and investments to leverage private sector funding to make housing finance more accessible.

President #Ramaphosa: This should form part of the broader social compact envisaged in the National Development Plan, and which, in many different ways and on many different fronts, we are working to build. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: To build the cities and towns that we want, it is critical that government, the private sector and the NGOs work together to create a sustainable growth model of compact, connected and coordinated urban areas by integrating and aligning investments.

President #Ramaphosa: We need to develop a continuum of use and ownership tenure rights. We are committed to using expropriation, where appropriate, to achieve social and economic spatial transformation in towns and cities.

President #Ramaphosa: While extending title deeds to a greater number of households is a priority, we should also secure less expensive and less complicated forms of tenure for households in informal settlements, in rental arrangements and in areas of communal land tenure.

President #Ramaphosa: We need to use every inch of underutilised land for our people to live on and to farm. We have a responsibility – imposed on us by the Constitution – to ensure that all South Africans have security of tenure.

President #Ramaphosa: Much of this land is owned publicly by national departments, provincial governments, municipalities and state-owned companies. Some of this land is privately held for purely speculative purposes.

President #Ramaphosa: To accelerate spatial transformation, Cabinet resolved at its recent lekgotla on the rapid release of well-located, but under-utilised land to develop affordable, mixed-income human settlement.
President #Ramaphosa: At the same, through a significant investment in the township economy, we are working to bring economic activity to where most of our people live.
President #Ramaphosa: We are focused on developing integrated human settlements located close to work and amenities, rather than just meeting housing targets.

President #Ramaphosa: Through instruments like the Spatial Planning and Land Use Management Act and the Integrated Urban Development Framework, we are approaching spatial planning guided by principles of social equity and economic efficiency.
President #Ramaphosa: The radical transformation of our urban spaces is, therefore, both a social and economic imperative.
President #Ramaphosa: We need to eradicate the economic inefficiencies of transporting a workforce from dormitory townships into centres. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: But the progressive transformation of our urban spaces is not just about radically addressing social poverty and racial inequities. We must make our cities generators of wealth and reservoirs of productivity. #RamaphosaQAndA

President #Ramaphosa: According to StatsSA, more than two-thirds of households in the lowest income quintile spend more than 20% of their monthly household income per capita on public transport. #RamaphosaQandA

President #Ramaphosa: Among other things, this places enormous pressure on family life. Working parents leave home early and return well after young children are, or should be, asleep. These long commuting times impact disproportionately on the household income of the poor.

President #Ramaphosa: It is unacceptable that the working class and poor, who are overwhelmingly black, are located far from work opportunities and amenities. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/nphKtRrpL9

President #Ramaphosa: The urban spatial patterns that we inherited from apartheid, and which persist to this day, contribute to the reproduction of poverty and inequality – and must be fundamentally changed.

President #Ramaphosa: Allow me to extend the warmest wishes to the Muslim community on the celebration of Eid-ul-Adha today. More than 2,500 Muslims have travelled to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia to join an estimated 2 million Muslims from around the world for the Hajj pilgrimage.

President @CyrilRamaphosa will also speak on government’s signing of the Independent Power Producers agreements as well as how South Africa, as a BRICS member state, intends to build a fairer global trade regime to forge strong, sustainable & inclusive growth. #RamaphosaQandApic.twitter.com/p96zEoSpd2

President @CyrilRamaphosa will also respond to questions on the high unemployment figures recently released by @StatsSA, as well as government’s plans on the review of the list of zero-rated items to mitigate the impact of the increase in VAT from 14 to 15% earlier this year.pic.twitter.com/CyZxE0qHrO

President @CyrilRamaphosa will brief Parliament on government’s approach to the national discussion on proposals by the governing party that the Constitution be amended to indicate the conditions under which land could be expropriated without compensation. #RamaphosaQnApic.twitter.com/n6lBnKWG8g

President @CyrilRamaphosa will this afternoon account to the nation on the work of government when he responds to Questions for Oral Reply in the National Assembly at 15h00 in Parliament, Cape Town. #RamaphosaQnApic.twitter.com/T9b24Y1tOZ
President Ramaphosa wishes Muslims happy Eid-ul-Adha https://bit.ly/2BASwQ6
President Ramaphosa to respond to Questions for Oral Reply in the National Assembly https://bit.ly/2ORjDZ0

President Ramaphosa, with the President of AFASA, Dr Vuyo Mahlati and Minister of Agriculture, Forestry & Fisheries, Mr Senzeni Zokwana, presenting the Presidential Awards to agri-pioneers who have made outstanding contributions to agricultural transformation & rural developmentpic.twitter.com/uX50l9s68a
Remarks by President Cyril Ramaphosa at the AFASA Agribusiness Transformation Conference Gala Dinner and Presidential Awards https://bit.ly/2MqHBh0
President #Ramaphosa: By working together, by harnessing the energies and capabilities of our people, we will be able to reap a harvest that provides nourishment and sustenance for all. I thank you.
President #Ramaphosa: Through these awards, through the activities of AFASA, we are sowing the seeds of hope, of progress and of shared prosperity.

President #Ramaphosa: They send a powerful and compelling message about the future of farming in this country, about the confidence and capabilities of a new generation of emerging black farmers, of the long road we have travelled, and the distance we still need to go.
President #Ramaphosa: These awards serve a broader purpose than recognising outstanding individual contributions.

President #Ramaphosa: It is important, in particular, to recognise the advances made by women in farming – as landowners, farmers, farm managers, producers and suppliers of farming equipment, and as owners and managers of markets.

President #Ramaphosa: As I conclude, let me commend and congratulate all the farmers nominated for the AFASA awards. This demonstrates the enthusiasm, innovation and tenacity that drive farmers and agribusiness people across various value chains and areas of human endeavour.

President #Ramaphosa: Black & white farmers must together, working with government, build a better future not just in the agrarian economy but in all of society. We’re convinced that ensuring an equitable distribution of land is at the heart of creating a united & cohesive nation
President #Ramaphosa: We must work together as a nation to make our land reform programme a success. This is the time for South Africans to find each other, not fight each other.

President #Ramaphosa: Through accelerated land redistribution, and with the necessary support from the state, more and more black farmers will emerge, unlocking the economic potential both of land and of people.

President #Ramaphosa: In all this, we are guided by the need to increase agricultural production, unlock the economic potential of our land, stimulate economic growth, create jobs and ensure food security.

President #Ramaphosa: It is through our engagements with groupings like AFASA that we must define what other measures we must take to create a conducive and favourable environment for black farmers to thrive.

President #Ramaphosa: We should consider re-opening agricultural colleges and the use of subsidies and incentives for emerging and small-scale farmers. We should ensure that government uses its procurement power to open up markets for emerging farmers.
President #Ramaphosa: It means that we must expand the basket of agricultural support services available to both established and emerging farmers.
President #Ramaphosa: It has revealed that we need a comprehensive approach to land and agrarian reform that extends far beyond the debate on the property clause in our Constitution.
President #Ramaphosa: Most importantly, it has required that we consider the full extent of land reform and the measures that we must undertake to resolve the land question in our country.
President #Ramaphosa: It has required that we confront the injustices of the past, acknowledge our weaknesses and shortcomings, and seek a sustainable path towards a just and inclusive future.
President #Ramaphosa: The proposal to use expropriation without compensation as one of the mechanisms to effect land redistribution has ignited a vigorous and welcome debate.
President #Ramaphosa: Not since the advent of democracy nearly 25 years ago, has our country been so engaged in a public conversation around land reform.

President #Ramaphosa: We have embarked on a programme of accelerated land reform that aims to redistribute more land, at a faster pace, to black South Africans; that will ensure tenure security for the insecure; and change the distorted patterns of development.
President #Ramaphosa: This is necessary to correct a past wrong. It is also necessary to ensure a fair and prosperous future for all.

President #Ramaphosa: This is the reality that we need to confront and overcome together. The country’s land must be shared among those who wish to work it, and those who wish to work it must be given the support and encouragement to be successful.
President #Ramaphosa: This is in addition to the challenges they face when the forces of nature and forces of the market conspire to cut production and undermine profitability.
President #Ramaphosa: And yet the ability of black farmers to work the land successfully is constrained by the accumulated disadvantages of centuries of dispossession and deprivation.

President #Ramaphosa: It is demonstrating that black South Africans are able to make a success of owning & managing land & that they are able to farm successfully, ensure food security & sustain livelihoods. They are redefining what is meant in South Africa by the word ‘farmer’.
President #Ramaphosa: At the same time, AFASA is challenging some of the preconceptions about black farmers and changing attitudes throughout society.

President #Ramaphosa: This gives us hope that in the near future, the old will know of famine only when they piece together distant memories, while the young will know of it only from reading history.

President #Ramaphosa: They give us confidence that our villages and small towns can become sustainable economic centres. At a time of rapid urbanisation, AFASA works to maintain our people’s connection with the land.

President #Ramaphosa: Gathered here this evening are the farmers who help feed the nation. These sons and daughters of the soil are patriots of the plough and heroines of the harvester. They are essential to the economic life of rural communities.

President #Ramaphosa: In doing so, it is sending a clear message to young South Africans that there is a future in farming, that it is a part of our economy whose potential we have only just begun to explore.

President #Ramaphosa: Through its lobbying and advocacy work, AFASA is helping to re-shape agriculture, bridging the divide between policy and reality, between legislation and the live experience of emerging black farmers.

President #Ramaphosa: It is AFASA’s mission to correct that great injustice. We are here at this gala dinner and awards ceremony to recognise and celebrate the great contribution that AFASA has made towards the transformation of the agricultural sector.

President #Ramaphosa: By denying them the right to employ their skills and capabilities, by depriving them of their assets, the apartheid state denied African farmers the opportunity to work the land for the benefit of all the people of this country.

President #Ramaphosa: Since its formation more than seven years ago, AFASA has been shining a light on the challenges faced by those who historically, and solely on the basis of their skin colour, were systematically placed on the margins of agriculture and agribusiness.
President #Ramaphosa: It is a great honour and privilege to address this gala dinner and awards ceremony organised by the African Farmers’ Association of South Africa.

President Cyril Ramaphosa addressing the launch the Sanitation Appropriate for Education (SAFE) Initiative at the Sheraton Hotel, Pretoria. The SAFE initiative responds to the significant sanitation challenges facing some of the country’s poorest schools.pic.twitter.com/yCF33KSbIv
President Ramaphosa launches SAFE Sanitation for schools https://bit.ly/2MHewKd
Address by President Cyril Ramaphosa at the launch of the ‘SAFE’ School Sanitation Initiative, Sheraton Hotel, Tshwane https://bit.ly/2B8RxXd
President #Ramaphosa: This is something we must do, for our children, for their future and for our country. I thank you.

President #Ramaphosa: Thank you to everyone who has joined us here this morning for your commitment to being part of this initiative. Your involvement gives us confidence that, however great the challenge, however dire the need, by working together in partnership, we will succeedpic.twitter.com/GJF3wqIAOA

President #Ramaphosa: Allow me, in conclusion, to extend my appreciation to those organisations that have joined government in launching this initiative – @UNICEF, the @NelsonMandela Foundation and the National Education Collaboration Trust.

President #Ramaphosa: Let us build a social compact that recognises our shared responsibility to build a new society founded on the principles of justice, respect, dignity and equality. Let us act in solidarity with the children of this country.pic.twitter.com/aCQiTKO56a
President #Ramaphosa: Let us build a social compact that is greater than the sum of its parts, which harnesses the resources and capabilities of each social partner to achieve our common goals.

President #Ramaphosa: We seek sustainable and affordable solutions that have community support. We seek partners that will not rest until every school and every learner has decent, safe and appropriate sanitation. #SAFESchools

President #Ramaphosa: In whatever way we each choose to assist, there is an urgent need to collectively develop infrastructure that will bring dignity to those who lack safe and adequate sanitation and, thereby, improve public health.

President #Ramaphosa: Secondly, companies can adopt a group of schools as model schools for joint sanitation-water-energy off-grid solutions. And thirdly, companies can be part of building a base for the industrialisation of these new technologies for local and global markets.

President #Ramaphosa: Firstly, through direct contributions to the #SAFEInitiative, companies can support the construction of models of new technology toilets as a core component of the plan for each school.

President #Ramaphosa: We are calling on the private sector to be an integral part of this effort to realise the basic human rights of our children and secure their future. There are several ways to get involved. #SAFESchoolspic.twitter.com/tZLgJ9dosg

President #Ramaphosa: This has broader social and economic implications, encouraging the deployment of new sanitation technology in public and other facilities, and potentially establishing an industry in South Africa for the development and production of such systems.

President #Ramaphosa: By finding innovative solutions to a challenging problem, we will not only be making our schools safer and the lives of learners better, but we will be opening new possibilities for environmentally sustainable sanitation. #SAFESchools

President #Ramaphosa: The SAFE Initiative could be a catalyst for a new revolution in sanitation, demonstrating that these new systems can be effectively implemented at scale.pic.twitter.com/6fTW8tF5J4
President #Ramaphosa: These are not low-technology solutions. Instead, they use the benefit of the best science in the world to achieve high tech, low maintenance, value-adding solutions.

President #Ramaphosa: This is why the Water Research Commission has partnered with local and international organisations to realise a new approach to sanitation. The new toilet systems are localised, usually off-grid, potentially energy producing and use minimal water, if any.
President #Ramaphosa: Current models of sanitation are expensive, require large-scale networked infrastructure, have a high energy budget and use much more water than we have.
President #Ramaphosa: In our quest to ensure universal access to safe and dignified sanitation, we need to employ the sanitation solutions of tomorrow – not yesterday.
President #Ramaphosa: Despite this progress, we are painfully aware that we have not done enough, and we are not moving nearly as fast as we need to.
President #Ramaphosa: In instances where reticulated water connections are not available, government has provided appropriate alternative sanitation technologies in a further 9,600 public schools.

President #Ramaphosa: The percentage of households with access to improved sanitation increased from 62% in 2002 to 80% in 2015. Since the advent of democracy, over 11,000 schools have been provided with flush toilets linked either to a municipal connection or a septic tank.

President #Ramaphosa: Aware of the importance of adequate sanitation in preventing diseases and ensuring economic and social benefits, South Africa is committed to attaining the targets of sanitation for all by 2030. We have made significant progress in addressing the backlogs.

President #Ramaphosa: Through the Sustainable Development Goals, global leaders have agreed that by 2030 we must have achieved “access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all”. #SAFESchools

President #Ramaphosa: We will also be contributing to the broader goal of decent sanitation for all our people. The UNDP estimates that, globally, there are more than 2.4 billion people who did not have access to basic sanitation like toilets and latrines.
President #Ramaphosa: We cannot expose our learners and educators to an environment that is not conducive to teaching and learning and still expect excellent educational outcomes.

President #Ramaphosa: With today’s launch, we are calling on all South Africans, corporates, NGOs and international partners to be part of this ambitious, but necessary, effort to give effect to the fundamental human rights of our learners.
President #Ramaphosa: Just as it takes a village to raise a child, so too does it take an entire society to educate a child.
President #Ramaphosa: Through the SAFE initiative, we can all help to restore the dignity of learners in mostly rural and township schools by providing age-appropriate sanitation facilities.
President #Ramaphosa: It is our responsibility – as government, business, civil society, parents, teachers and communities – to act with purpose, urgency and unity.
President #Ramaphosa: We have heard the cries of anguished families, we have felt the outrage of a society that cannot bear to witness to another needless death. #SAFESchools

President #Ramaphosa: The utterly tragic and devastating deaths of children so young and so innocent remind us of the human consequences of service delivery delayed. They remind us that we must focus all our attention not on what we have achieved, but on what we haven’t.

President #Ramaphosa: It was in such a school, Mahlodumela Primary School in Limpopo, where 5 year old Michael Komape drowned in a pit toilet in 2014. And it was in such a school, Luna Junior Primary School in the Eastern Cape, where Lumka Mkethwa lost her life in March this yearpic.twitter.com/BSphg7cUqg

President #Ramaphosa: There are nearly 4,000 schools across the country that only have pit latrines or other inappropriate sanitation facilities. These are the schools that serve the children of the poor.
President #Ramaphosa: It seeks to contribute to building a cohesive society in which schools are the heartbeat of wholesome communities. We are gathered here to answer an emergency.

President #Ramaphosa: Schools should be centres for building communities and for strengthening partnerships between a government of the people and the people themselves. The SAFE initiative reaches beyond the bricks and mortar of water and sanitation.
President #Ramaphosa: Schools should be places where children can be safe, supported, nurtured and empowered. #SAFESchoolspic.twitter.com/cCQOIx05rE

President #Ramaphosa: The Sanitation Appropriate for Education – or SAFE – initiative will spare generations of young South Africans the indignity, discomfort and danger of using pit latrines and other unsafe facilities in our schools.
President #Ramaphosa: This is an initiative that will save lives and restore the dignity of tens of thousands of our nation’s children, as our Constitution demands.
President #Ramaphosa: We are here to ask you to be part of a bold social initiative to ensure that every school in the country has safe and appropriate sanitation facilities. #SAFESchools
President #Ramaphosa: We are gathered here today to seek collective action to give all the children of this country what most of us take for granted. #SAFESchools

The initiative follows the President’s call for eradication of unsafe schools & ablution facilities, and for an audit and plans to deal with all unsafe facilities.pic.twitter.com/FSWbYKGkXx

President #Ramaphosa: As a bloc, we should use this opportunity to ensure that we fully appreciate and exploit the opportunities presented by this wondrous new age of technology in building a brighter shared future for humanity. I thank you.pic.twitter.com/48Jv67KFPQ

President #Ramaphosa: As we enter the second Golden Decade of #BRICS, we need to look to the future and place ourselves at the forefront of the extraordinary changes that are taking place. Our officials must engage in robust discussions to develop concrete actions.

President #Ramaphosa: Excellencies, as the #BRICS Forum, we can neither ignore, nor take for granted, the reality that is the 4th Industrial Revolution and the impact that it will have on the global economy.pic.twitter.com/vY5yozAH9D

President #Ramaphosa: Under the partnership, and in support of the manufacturing sector, a new industrial revolution advisory group comprised of policy makers and experts from all BRICS countries will be established.

President #Ramaphosa: It aims to translate the vision of the second decade of BRICS cooperation into reality through deepened cooperation on industrialisation, innovation, inclusiveness and investment.
President #Ramaphosa: It is against this backdrop that BRICS Ministers of Industry resolved to establish the #BRICS Partnership on the New Industrial Revolution.
President #Ramaphosa: Equally important are policies that support and stimulate local industries, especially small, medium and micro enterprises.
President #Ramaphosa: Such investment improves the supply of relevant skills, expands the capacity for research and development, and contributes to an environment that nurtures innovation.

President #Ramaphosa: Governments should formulate and institute policies that are supportive of these processes. Such policies should provide a favourable environment for foreign investment in the development of new sectors and technologies.

President #Ramaphosa: While this must start even before a child enters primary school and continue right through to our universities and colleges, there is an urgent need in developing and emerging economies to re-skill a significant portion of the current workforce.

President #Ramaphosa: Without adequate training, only a few emerging economies will possess these skills in sufficient numbers, while others will see their prospects stifled by automation. There is a need to develop more agile and applied education models.
President #Ramaphosa: The World Economic Forum predicts that the three most important skills for an employee by 2020 will be complex problem-solving, critical thinking and creativity.
President #Ramaphosa: To succeed, however, we need to equip our people with the necessary skills to thrive in such a society and in such an economy.
President #Ramaphosa: They can expand economic participation by ensuring that knowledge and information is more broadly disseminated across the population.
President #Ramaphosa: It demonstrates that, properly harnessed, new technologies can ensure more efficient processes and more reliable systems of service delivery.

President #Ramaphosa: The rapid adoption of mobile telecommunications in Africa and other parts of the developing world, for example, demonstrates how innovation can ignite sudden bursts of development.
President #Ramaphosa: The technologies of the 4th Industrial Revolution provide developing and emerging economies with the opportunity to leapfrog the technologies of the preceding revolutions.

President #Ramaphosa: We must ensure that mastery of the 4th Industrial Revolution does not become the exclusive preserve of just a handful of countries. We must promote inclusivity, diversity and cooperation.
President #Ramaphosa: We should not allow technology to shape our societies. We must instead ensure that the needs of our societies shape the technologies that we develop.

President #Ramaphosa: This means that our response needs to be comprehensive and integrated. As #BRICS countries, we should not become mere adopters of new technologies. Rather, we need to combine our resources and expertise to become innovators.

President #Ramaphosa: According to Professor Klaus Schwab of the World Economic Forum, the 4th Industrial Revolution “is characterised by a fusion of technologies that is blurring the lines between the physical, digital, and biological spheres”.
President #Ramaphosa: There is no area of economic activity that is immune from technological disruption.

President #Ramaphosa: We proceed from the understanding that this is not simply a digital revolution, but a fundamental shift in the way people live, work and relate. It is a phenomenon that cuts across all industries and technologies.

President #Ramaphosa: This places a great responsibility on all of us. Through our collective effort, by working together, I am certain that we will be able to confront the challenges and seize the opportunities that this new age of development presents.

President #Ramaphosa: However, unless it is approached in a collaborative manner, underpinned by a developmental agenda, rapid technological change could serve to entrench existing disparities within and between countries. It could also create new faultlines in our societies.
President #Ramaphosa: It has the potential to solve many of the social problems we face, by better equipping us to combat disease, hunger and environmental degradation.
President #Ramaphosa: This surge in innovation has the potential to dramatically improve productivity and to place entire countries on a new trajectory of prosperity. #BRICS2018
President #Ramaphosa: Quantum leaps in technology and innovation present enormous opportunities for growth, development and human progress.

President #Ramaphosa: It is therefore appropriate that at this moment in the evolution of #BRICS, we should focus on collaboration for inclusive growth and shared prosperity in the 4th industrial revolution.

President #Ramaphosa: From its formation, the BRICS partnership has had its sights firmly set on the future. It is itself the product of a rapidly changing world, which has seen the emergence of new economies, realignment of old alliances & shifts in the balance of global power.

President #Ramaphosa: We look to you to be ready to realise the vast potential that exists for investment and trade, and to be our partners in building inclusive economies that create shared prosperity. I wish you every success in your deliberations. I thank you.pic.twitter.com/WG6MdxDa8J
President #Ramaphosa: We look to you, our distinguished business community, to be at the centre of our collective efforts to forge a new economic path. #BRICSBF2018
President #Ramaphosa: Addressing the demands of both the present and the future requires the same unity of purpose that brought BRICS into existence and which has sustained it over the last decade.
President #Ramaphosa: While trade among the #BRICS partners has expanded exponentially over the last 10 years, we need to advance to a new level of industrial cooperation.
President #Ramaphosa: Our task is to give practical expression to an economic partnership that will catapult the industrialisation of our respective economies beyond the digital age. #BRICSBF2018
President #Ramaphosa: There is much we can do together to develop appropriate regulatory frameworks, infrastructure and skills to support and enable the 4th Industrial Revolution. #BRICSBF2018
President #Ramaphosa: It is imperative that we collectively navigate the risks and leverage the opportunities that arise from the new digital age.

President #Ramaphosa: We are embracing new technologies and approaches that are merging the physical, digital and biological worlds. We are committed to walking this path together with our #BRICS partners.
President #Ramaphosa: South Africa is determined to derive greater value from its abundant natural resources and to steadily advance up the value chain into knowledge-based sectors.

President #Ramaphosa: A wide range of investment opportunities are available in areas such as renewable energy, recycling, biofuels, water infrastructure, mining and minerals beneficiation, agriculture & agro-processing, aquaculture, tourism, manufacturing, fuel cell production.

President #Ramaphosa: We have been steadily improving the ease of doing business in the country, providing dedicated support to investors through Invest SA and developing an attractive package of incentives. We are working to diversify our economy.
President #Ramaphosa: Our partners in BRICS are familiar with our world class transport and telecommunication infrastructure, a supportive operating environment and a sophisticated banking system.

President #Ramaphosa: We are seeking to reinforce the strong bonds that we developed with our BRICS partners by expanding investment into the country. We are building on the vast investment potential that South Africa possesses. #BRICSBF2018

President #Ramaphosa: We have embarked on an investment drive that has taken us to meet with investors in various parts of the world and which will culminate in an Investment Conference later in the year.

President #Ramaphosa: As South Africa, we have acknowledged that to effectively deal with poverty, unemployment and inequality, we need to significantly increase the level of investment in our economy to lift growth and create jobs.pic.twitter.com/UMSZFFl7vk

President #Ramaphosa: This Business Forum provides a platform to harness the benefits of globalisation and to also confront the challenges it presents, all within an ever-changing global political economy.
President #Ramaphosa: This presents opportunities for #BRICS countries, some of whom have extensive experience in infrastructure development and are world leaders in education and skills development.
President #Ramaphosa: The value of this free trade area will only be fully realised through massive investment in infrastructure and skills development.

President #Ramaphosa: More opportunities are presented by the agreement to establish the African Continental Free Trade Area, which provides access to a market of over 1 billion people and a combined GDP of over $3 trillion.

President #Ramaphosa: This growth will be supported by increasing foreign direct investment flows, public investment in infrastructure and higher agricultural production. In addition, Africa’s working age population is expected to double to 1 billion in the next 25 years.
President #Ramaphosa: In the past decade Africa has grown at a rate of 2 to 3 percentage points faster than the global GDP, with regional growth predicted to remain stable above 5 percent in 2018.

President #Ramaphosa: As South Africa, we are determined that our engagements within BRICS and other multilateral platforms should advance the integration and development of the African continent. There is great potential for investment in Africa.

President #Ramaphosa: I am pleased that these are some of the areas under discussion in this Business Forum. I look forward to the concrete proposals made by yourselves for the consideration of the Summit. Equally important are your deliberations on BRICS-Africa cooperation.pic.twitter.com/ooOAm0FRQn

President #Ramaphosa: We also require a strategic roadmap regarding the opportunities presented by the fourth industrial revolution and the measures required to mitigate its disruptive effect on industry.
President #Ramaphosa: Linked to the trade agenda, we need to increase investment between BRICS countries, particularly in the productive sectors of our economy.

President #Ramaphosa: There is also much scope to expand the value of trade between BRICS countries. As a country that is primarily an exporter of commodities to its BRICS partners, South Africa supports a shift towards complementary and value-added trade. #BRICSBF2018

President #Ramaphosa: The BRICS countries are increasingly recognised as an influential formation in reinforcing the principles of transparency, inclusiveness and compatibility within the multilateral trading system.pic.twitter.com/RHLMqD1ukz
President #Ramaphosa: These developments call for thorough discussion on the role of trade in promoting sustainable development and inclusive growth.

President #Ramaphosa: We are concerned by the rise in unilateral measures that are incompatible with World Trade Organization rules and are worried about the impact of these measures, especially on developing countries.
President #Ramaphosa: We are meeting here at a time when the multilateral trading system is facing unprecedented challenges.

President #Ramaphosa: Since its formation, the bank has disbursed loans totaling $5.1 billion, with approvals amounting to $1.7 billion this year alone. As we enter the second decade of BRICS cooperation, we are determined to expand the Bank’s role in socio-economic development.
President #Ramaphosa: One of the most important achievements of the first decade of BRICS was the establishment of the New Development Bank, which fills a critical gap in project funding.

President #Ramaphosa: Intra-BRICS cooperation has been gaining momentum in areas such as finance, agriculture, trade, combating transnational crime, science and technology, health, education, security and academic dialogue.

President #Ramaphosa: This year also marks a decade of BRICS collaboration, during which we have successfully shaped an ambitious agenda for development that recognises the great potential our countries possess for collective action.pic.twitter.com/ks4LKRzK7i

President #Ramaphosa: We invoke his name here because the work we are here to do requires of us to build on the foundations Madiba laid for the advancement of democracy, world peace, human solidarity, international cooperation and mutual respect.

President #Ramaphosa: We welcome you to our shores just a week after the world marked the centenary of the birth of the father of our nation and a global icon, President Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela. #Mandela100
