President #Ramaphosa: I wish to thank President Xi once again for hnouring us with a State Visit in this historic year and wish him and his delegation a wonderful stay in our country.pic.twitter.com/xoxvfjpAkV
President #Ramaphosa: We have agreed that we must work as partners to improve the lives of our peoples by elevating our business, commercial and trade ties.

President #Ramaphosa: Both countries continue to advance the centrality of the UN and other multilateral fora in resolving issues of global concern. The dynamism of the partnership between China and South Africa derives from a common desire to develop our bilateral relationship.pic.twitter.com/uZEmRAvzCF

President #Ramaphosa: President Xi & I have agreed to continue supporting each other in international fora, including the UN. In 2019, South Africa will commence its two-year non-permanent seat on the UN Security Council. #ChinaInSA

President #Ramaphosa: From tomorrow South Africa will be hosting the 10th BRICS Summit and in September we will be going to China for a reciprocal State Visit and the Summit of the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation (FOCAC).pic.twitter.com/FEbdhprCPZ

President #Ramaphosa: We also discussed upcoming international events in which our two countries have common interest. We have a number of multilateral platforms through which we pursue our shared objectives as leading members of the Global South. #ChinaInSA

President #Ramaphosa: President Xi Jinping has indicated that China is ready to invest and work with South Africa in various sectors, such as infrastructure development, ocean economy, green economy, science and technology, agriculture, environment and finance. #ChinaInSA

President #Ramaphosa: We have signed several Agreements and Memorandums of Understanding that are intended to further deepen our relations, including investment commitments to the value of US$14 billion. #ChinaInSApic.twitter.com/FZpiyzyv14

President #Ramaphosa: During this State Visit, we were able to go through a number of issues affecting the two countries, including the strengthening of our Comprehensive Strategic Partnership which is a platform to engage on matters of mutual interest. #ChinaInSA

President #Ramaphosa: This State Visit forms part of several other activities that we will jointly undertake during the course of this year under the umbrella of the celebration of the 20th anniversary of diplomatic relations. #ChinaInSA

President #Ramaphosa: President Xi and I noted that relations between South Africa and China have developed and expanded considerably since diplomatic relations were established in 1998, just four years after the first democratic elections in South Africa. #ChinaInSA

President #Ramaphosa: The purpose of our meeting has been to review and strengthen our long lasting friendship, which has its roots in the bonds of solidarity that developed between our peoples during our struggle for liberation.

President #Ramaphosa: Thank you for joining us today at the conclusion of a successful meeting with His Excellency, President Xi Jinping. We have had wide ranging discussions with President Xi and his delegation, covering bilateral relations and cooperation and other matters.

President #Ramaphosa Your country has strong relations with our Continent & has a record of treating African countries as equals. We therefore appeal to China to join Africa in its battle for equality & use every effort to move the negotiations on Security Council reform forward.
President #Ramaphosa: South Africa is deeply concerned by the slow pace of UN reform. Our view is that the beginning a text-based negotiation would enable progress in the negotiations in New York.

President #Ramaphosa: We are looking forward to working with you in the Security Council. South Africa reaffirms the centrality of the United Nations Charter and the primacy of the UN Security Council on issues of international peace and security.
President #Ramaphosa: I would like to extend appreciation for your support for South Africa’s candidature to serve as a non-permanent member of the UN Security Council for the term 2019 and 2020.

President #Ramaphosa: As the outgoing co-Chair of the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation (FOCAC), I look forward to attending the 3rd FOCAC Summit to be held in China in September 2018, as well as to honour Your Excellency’s invitation for a State Visit just prior to the Summit.
President #Ramaphosa: This milestone is significant as it is intended to be a physical research centre focused on research and development and vaccine innovation. #ChinaInSA

President #Ramaphosa: I would like to express my sincere appreciation to China for the establishment of a Vaccine Research Centre for Collaboration with BRICS vaccine innovation and development partners.

President #Ramaphosa: South Africa wishes to use the opportunity presented by its 2018 chairship of #BRICS to reiterate its commitment to further strengthening relations with and among its BRICS partners, the African continent and the Global South.
President #Ramaphosa: I would like to extend an invitation to Chinese investors to participate in both the Investment Conference and the Jobs Summit.

President #Ramaphosa: announced in my State of the Nation Address in February this year, that I intend hosting an Investment Conference and a Job Summit later in the year. Since the announcement, several countries have shown interest in attending.
President #Ramaphosa: South Africa is China’s number one trading partner in Africa. Total trade between South Africa and China amounted to R319 billion in 2017.

President #Ramaphosa: Thank you for the invitation sent to South Africa to participate at the China International Import Expo scheduled to take place from 5-10 November 2018 in Shanghai. The Department of Trade and Industry will represent South Africa at the Expo.

President #Ramaphosa: This year South Africa & China commemorate the 20th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations. Our diplomatic achievements coincide with the centenary celebrations of two of our great leaders, President Nelson Mandela & Mrs Albertina Sisulu.

President #Ramaphosa: China is South Africa’s friend and a reliable partner. I would like to see our two countries focusing on the implementation of decisions and agreements we have signed. This will elevate South Africa-China bilateral relations.

President #Ramaphosa: I would also like to thank you for delegating State Councillor YANG Jiechi to meet with me in March this year. You were the first President to send a Special Envoy to South Africa to congratulate me as the President.

President #Ramaphosa: President Xi Jinping, allow me to thank you for agreeing to the State Visit prior to the #BRICS Summit. I would like to congratulate you on your re-election as the President of the People’s Republic of China. #ChinaInSApic.twitter.com/9gm0ZJOUiU

DP #Mabuza: I am confident that these summits are bringing together the best minds and leaders to re-write our terrible history into a tolerable tale. We must stand by the courage of our convictions to chart a path for what is rightfully ours. I thank you.pic.twitter.com/nLraUSEkvu

DP #Mabuza: The role of finance institutions in fostering transformation as envisioned under the programme of radical economic transformation, must be seriously looked at as it cited by many small and medium enterprises as a hindrance to their growth.

DP #Mabuza: These inclusive development interventions are intended to be practical programmes for decentralization of economic activities, narrowing inequality, creating jobs, youth employment, skills development as well as capacity building.
DP #Mabuza: The revitalisation of township and rural economies is no longer about convenience but rather, a significant developmental imperative.

DP #Mabuza: But all these efforts will mean nothing unless we bring these economic activities closer to where the majority of our people live. We must build factories and agro-processing centres into rural areas and within our townships.

DP #Mabuza: We will also be strengthening our hand in ensuring that SMMEs are paid within 30-days. We cannot claim to support small business public procurement but strangle small businesses of life giving cash.

DP #Mabuza: Our public procurement strategies will focus on SMME development, especially in sectors such as the metal fabrication, capital equipment and transport equipment, electronics and other medium as well as heavy commercial vehicles and the pharmaceutical sector.
DP #Mabuza: We encourage you to engage with the Department of Trade and Industry to take advantage of the numerous support measures that can assist township and rural economic players.

DP #Mabuza: We are also building on our trade and comparative advantages within the manufacturing and other Industrial Policy Action Plan priority sectors. This is the space that township economies must capture & build competitiveness in order to gain significant market share.
DP #Mabuza: We are bringing about this Radical Economic Transformation by focusing on value-adding sectors that combine high employment with technological progress and other growth multipliers.
DP #Mabuza: Through the Industrial Policy Action Plan, we are determined to build a cohort of Black Industrialist who will emerge from the SMME sector into mainstream economic activity.

DP #Mabuza: We want the SMME sector to be more competitive and enable them to undo the invasive damage caused by large corporates that crowd out small business through large shopping and retail malls.

DP #Mabuza: For our part as government we are hard at work to stimulate job creation & locate the SMME sector as central to achieving these outcomes. We have adopted & invested in strategies to finance small business sector to create varying degrees of labour absorbing growth.

DP #Mabuza: This is where I believe we can reach an economic stage of convergence. This is where we can leap-frog our own growth potential. We must build a cohort of young people who are fascinated with new ideas, innovation and technological progress.

DP #Mabuza: The costs for starting a business are increasingly decreasing and the architecture is becoming easily global and accessible. Herein lies the opportunity for inter-connectivity of our townships and rural economies both technologically and geography.

DP #Mabuza: Herein lies the beauty of our time. We live in a time where technology is more open-sourced. Where it is becoming cheaper to enter the digital economy and the barriers are only as restrictive as far as your creativity and imagination can stretch.pic.twitter.com/JW9BiU0AFe

DP #Mabuza: We must encourage our people to be enterprising, to see beyond townships of old and into the future as industrialists, as people who will claim the African century, as people who see themselves as job creators and not job-seekers.

DP #Mabuza: Out of our townships, we must build the stuff to drive the 4th Industrial revolution. These opportunities will depend on the extent to which we can empower ourselves by harnessing and preserving our natural endowments and resources.

DP #Mabuza: Just as we have demonstrated through the Meerkat, as part of the SKA, we must learn to profess science as a fusion of necessity, innovation and education-driven advancement.pic.twitter.com/1Spr7LJbsz

DP #Mabuza: For those of us who are in Presidential B-BBEE Advisory Council, we must see young people on the path to success. We can assist in making them excellent traders, entrepreneurs & industrialists who not only put food on the table, but who are also globally competitive.

DP #Mabuza: Our rural areas & townships can also be better served if our young people are trained & encouraged to express themselves and innovate. In our youth, we have bounds of energy, ideas and potential for unlocking prevailing socio-economic challenges.
DP #Mabuza: For our part as government we are acutely aware that we cannot achieve any of these ideals so long as our people, the majority of who are youth, have no opportunities.

DP #Mabuza: Think of how many cars are there in our townships or in government fleet that are serviced & repaired outside of the very township establishments. Yet as we do that, we have many small workshops & auto-body shops that could be supported to grow and become competitive.

DP #Mabuza: To ensure that these enterprises are competitive, agencies & departments responsible for economy & industry need to offer support and enforce the implementation of programmes that support enterprise & supplier development & enable access to procurement opportunities.

DP #Mabuza: In considering and determining procurement in construction work, we must consider prescribing as part of the briefing to bigger companies that they should identify and engage local enterprises within communities in which any construction project is implemented.

DP #Mabuza: These barriers must not deter us. We must consider reviewing service level agreements and tender documentation for Consultants & Contractors in order to incorporate principles of an enterprise development model that localizes the manufacturing & supply of materials.
DP #Mabuza: In most cases, these regulatory requirements like certification of products in line with dictates of standards bodies, may be present obstacles to the success of such initiatives.

DP #Mabuza: It is common course that township and rural economies are predominantly small and medium enterprises. These may not necessarily have the same capacity and sophistication demanded by mainstream economy.
DP #Mabuza: Of course, there are structural challenges with suppliers that government must attend to and provide mechanisms on how they are sub-contracted by main service providers.

DP #Mabuza: These initiatives must seek to promote community driven initiatives in all government led built environment initiatives, which in their implementation will boost townships and rural economies.

DP #Mabuza: There is a need for new innovative approaches to development, in line with contemporary policy directives, so as to upscale service delivery given the current backlogs and prevailing socio-economic conditions in human settlements.

DP #Mabuza: Some of this work is in the construction and built environment that would transform the sector by supporting construction materials production at every locality in support of infrastructure development and construction of human settlements.

DP #Mabuza: In our concerted effort to revitalise the township and rural economies, we must consolidate, integrate and accelerate pockets of work done across government that would meaningfully support supplier mobilization per economic sector.

DP #Mabuza: We cannot make meaningful progress in this regard, if we do not link procurement to government strategy as a conscious agenda for the revitalization of township and rural economy.pic.twitter.com/GcQ43GfOSE
DP #Mabuza: By so doing, we will deal with existing obstacles to meaningful and sustainable participation of black people on procurement opportunities provided by government and the private sector.

DP #Mabuza: And so we must treat it with seriousness and determination. Among the measures we must practically implement without wasting time is the issue of localization and ring-fencing of certain economic sectors to achieve real economic transformation.

DP #Mabuza: Much has been written about the history of black business & the challenging legacies of apartheid. But an economy exists amongst our townships and rural areas. It may be small, simple & informal, but it can make a significant difference in the lives of our people.
DP #Mabuza: Today as we seek to answer the questions about what it is we must do to help township economies, we must perhaps aim for the most obvious and most simple solutions.

DP #Mabuza: It is possible and within our power to build the Rural and Township Economy in a manner that takes us to the level envisioned by those who came before us & struggled to end economic exclusion to build a non-racial, non-sexist, democratic and prosperous South Africa.

DP #Mabuza: However, we must come to a point where we agree that poverty, high unemployment, and deepening crisis of inequality is not good for all of us and is actually a major threat to the sustainability and stability of democracy that we enjoy as a country.
DP #Mabuza: We have no illusion that as a country we are going through serious challenges that are as a result of contradictions we have as a nation.
DP #Mabuza: It is not slogans that would resolve the reality we are faced with, but practical actions that would stimulate economic growth and lead to opportinties for gainful employment.
DP #Mabuza: The extent and depth of this crisis, mean that our challenge is to find workable and practical solutions that would take us out of the current quagmire.

DP #Mabuza: This means our people are not just lazy with no desire to uplift themselves and pull themselves through their bootstraps. What it means, is that they need support that will give life to their ideas & contribute to the building of our economy and creation of jobs.

DP #Mabuza: In every engagement that government has with aspiring entrepreneurs & those in the informal economy, which in the main are women & young people, the issue that is frequently raised is that of lack of business funding or sufficient support from financial institutions.

DP #Mabuza: The question for us today is how to unlock the repository of its value, how to unearth its inherent potential in a manner that addresses the aspirations of the black majority, whilst eliminating fears shaped by white privilege.

DP #Mabuza: Perhaps, as a start, we can begin by acknowledging that an economy existed, and still exists, amongst the economic marginalised and excluded majority of our people in rural areas and townships.
DP #Mabuza: It is not racial ideology but a conscious programme of black economic empowerment whose outcome will lead to concrete social cohesion.

DP #Mabuza: This is the defining feature of what must be understood as the reversal of the breaking down of thriving system of black economic programme steeped in well-designed programme of empowerment.

DP #Mabuza: Thus when we today speak of land restitution, when we speak of economic restitution and wealth creation, we speak of Radical Economic Transformation not for sloganeering, but as policy action that will bring the unemployment, poverty and inequality to its knees.pic.twitter.com/THCw8KF6vx

DP #Mabuza: In it and its manifestation, we must locate the systematic displacement of women, black people in general, and Africans in particular, from the centres economic activity within its correct context.

DP #Mabuza: For history is only valuable to the extent that it is tells us where we come from as a reference point. However, it is no place to dwell to an extent that blinds us to the action we must take to arrive at the tomorrow we that we desire.

DP #Mabuza: In advancing the cause of what it is we must do together to wrestle our country from the pitfalls of history, the challenge of the moment is to right the wrongs of the past that have breed the current crisis of poverty and inequality.

DP #Mabuza: This history simply provides us with the context of why we maybe be here today. It may help explain how we have arrived at this point and what pointers do we have on the next course of action. However, it may also prove limiting.

DP #Mabuza: For in reality and consequence, the Native Land Act was not a singular event in history. It was in essence, to all intents and purposes, the consolidation of legislative process of dispossession and dehumanisation.

DP #Mabuza: By singling out one part of the many Native Land Acts, it is denuded of its full-economic meaning to set the tragedy as a common, and trite refrain, that our people seek land, when they in fact seek full economic participation.

DP #Mabuza: Today, 105 years later, we have taken the liberty, and latitude, to quote this in its fullest form, to demonstrate its weight and its impact on the life of those it effectively marginalised.

DP #Mabuza: It was on 16 June 1913, when then Governor-General of South Africa signed into law sixteen pieces of legislation, which according to Solomon Plaatjie, were so voluminous & bulky & were “beyond the capability of any mortal human being to read & digest in just 4 days.”

DP #Mabuza: We get to talk of the Township and Rural Economy not as a characterisation of a particular sector of the economy, but as an inherent acknowledgement of the contradictions and configuration of our country’s political economic history.

DP #Mabuza: Through this 2nd Provincial B-BBEE Township and Rural Economies Summit, we are provided with an opportunity to engage, shape policy processes and outcomes that should lead us to the successful realisation of radical economic transformation.

DP #Mabuza: This legacy expresses itself in the racialized patterns of poverty, unemployment and inequality. This is generally evidenced in land and spatial disparities, infrastructure and service backlogs.

DP #Mabuza: Despite the economic advances of the past 24 years of freedom and democracy, the legacy of colonialism and apartheid is still deeply entrenched in our society and the manifest in the economic structure of South Africa.
DP #Mabuza: This is about the quest for inclusive economic development, redress and the reconfiguration of economic landscape from its current status quo.

DP #Mabuza: Thank you for inviting me to take part in this special engagement on an important and topical aspect on the transformation of our economy. The issue of Township and Rural economies, forms part of our call for radical economic transformation.

“To those who say that Madiba sold out, I want to emphatically say that Madiba did not sell out. He did not have it in his make up to sell out. He always acted in the interest of our people,” President Cyril Ramaphosa https://bit.ly/2zOGGBb pic.twitter.com/d6Ky7Hcq7C

President @CyrilRamaphosa addressing members of the community in Mvezo in the Eastern Cape Province as part of the Centenary Celebrations of Nelson Mandela. #MandelaDay #Mandela100pic.twitter.com/K1mxPYaDJV

President #Ramaphosa The free, equal and prosperous society to which he dedicated his life is still being built. We must carry on, inspired by his memory and fortified by his extraordinary life. The struggle continues. A luta continua. I thank you.
President #Ramaphosa We dare not relent in our efforts to build a non-sexist society, to end all forms of violence against women and create opportunities for all.

President #Ramaphosa The journey that began here in Mvezo a century ago has not ended. Madiba has run his race. His mortal remains have been returned to the soil from whence they came. But his journey is not complete.pic.twitter.com/G5EzSSu7dn

President #Ramaphosa He did so as part of a generation of courageous, principled and committed women and men. He did so under the harshest of circumstances, transmitted from the darkest of pasts. But in doing so, he enabled the most brilliant of futures.pic.twitter.com/U6kjLe9hQf

President #Ramaphosa Karl Marx wrote: "Men make their own history, but they do not make it as they please; they do not make it under self-selected circumstances, but under circumstances existing already, given & transmitted from the past." Nelson Mandela made his own history.

President #Ramaphosa Madiba was never a sellout. He was a true blue blooded revolutionary. It is armchair revolutionaries, sitting contemplating the sun, who have the audacity to think of him as a sellout. #MandelaDaypic.twitter.com/VJ5qNuF2mL
President #Ramaphosa Madiba bequeathed us a legacy of fearlessness. He instilled in us the courage to confront difficult issues. History imposed on him a heavy responsibility.

President #Ramaphosa That must be our central and over-riding task in this year of the centenary of the birth of Nelson Mandela – to grow our economy, to stimulate investment and to create jobs. #Mandela100

President #Ramaphosa The most effective way to advance broad-based black economic empowerment is to create jobs and develop skills. Madiba understood that employment provides the most direct route out of poverty.

President #Ramaphosa This will unlock great opportunities in our economy and to those who remain fearful we say fear not. We will do this in the quintessential South African way - through engagement, dialogue and finally agreement.
President #Ramaphosa We are continuing with our programme to accelerate land reform using as one of the mechanisms - expropriation of land without compensation.pic.twitter.com/215tu30BQI

President #Ramaphosa We are now firmly on the path of radical economic transformation to resolve this historic injustice. We are working to transform our economy and make it more inclusive in its ownership, control and management.

President #Ramaphosa As we celebrate the centenary of Nelson Mandela, we are acutely aware that the free and equal nation for which he fought will not be achieved for as long as economic inequality between black and white, and men and women, persists. #Mandela100
President #Ramaphosa We have a duty to build a state that is founded on Madiba’s values – of integrity, service and selflessness.
President #Ramaphosa We have a duty to strengthen these institutions, to properly resource and capacitate them and to vigorously resist each and every attempt to capture them for narrow interests.
President #Ramaphosa If these institutions are undermined, if they are weakened or if they are hollowed out by corruption, then our ability to achieve genuine social justice is severely limited.
President #Ramaphosa The democratic institutions that were established during his Presidency remain central to our efforts to fundamentally and radically transform our society.
President #Ramaphosa As the first President of the democratic South Africa, Madiba had the responsibility to establish a new state that would diligently serve all the people of this country.

President #Ramaphosa Madiba would have been pleased with the fact that we are now providing free higher education to children from poor and working class backgrounds. He would have urged all young people to be focused, dedicated and hard working at school.

President #Ramaphosa We have a moral duty to ensure that no child is denied the right to education; and that once they are in school, we must create a conducive environment for our children to succeed and fully realise their potential.

President #Ramaphosa Madiba would welcome the great progress we have made in massively expanding access to education for the black child. He was no doubt speaking from personal experience when he said: “Education is the most powerful weapon we can use to change the world.”
President #Ramaphosa This is an essential part of his legacy that we must never endanger, whether through negligence or wrongdoing or disinterest, for it directly affects the poorest of the poor.

President #Ramaphosa It is for this reason that everywhere we go, elderly social grant recipients say in appreciation: “Siyabulela iMali kaMandela. Ri kho livhuwa tshelede ya Vho-Mandela.” #MandelaDay

President #Ramaphosa He'd be glad to see that we are still committed to his dream of assisting the elderly, people with disabilities & children with a basic income in the form of social grants. Madiba knew the difference these social grants would make in the lives of our people.

President #Ramaphosa We are celebrating the centenary of Nelson Mandela in the 24th year of our democracy. As the founding President of our democratic state, he laid the foundation for the great progress we have made since 1994 in improving access to basic services.
President #Ramaphosa We dare not relent in our efforts to build a non-sexist society, to end all forms of violence against women, and to ensure equal opportunity for all.

President #Ramaphosa Madiba fought for the education of the girl child, for the economic empowerment of women and for true equality in all areas of life. In remembering Madiba, we must recognise that the struggle for gender equality still has much further to go.
President #Ramaphosa He was among those who challenged sexist attitudes and practices within the liberation movement and asserted the need for women to assume their rightful place in the struggle.

President #Ramaphosa There is no place for racism, for tribalism or for ethnic chauvinism in the South Africa of Nelson Mandela. Born into a traditional setting, raised in a patriarchal society, Madiba became a leading champion of gender equality.

President #Ramaphosa We are all called upon to stand up and speak out when the values for which Madiba lived and for which which so many fought are being denigrated by those who have no interest in progress.
President #Ramaphosa He would certainly be have been concerned by what appears to be the resurgence of racism and ethno-nationalism both in our country and elsewhere in the world.
President #Ramaphosa Nelson Mandela was loyal and true to the non-racial character and politics of the ANC. It was not a concession. It was a matter of principle.
President #Ramaphosa He felt a personal responsibility to mobilise the broadest possible range of forces in support of the struggle for democracy and for social and economic change.

President #Ramaphosa Consistent with the politics of his movement – which fought for a South Africa that belonged to all who lived in it – Madiba was at his most effective in reaching out to others and forging a unity of purpose among disparate people.

President #Ramaphosa It contains an important lesson, that all of us have a responsibility to continually seek knowledge and understanding, of our society and of our world. It contains an important lesson about tolerance and the value of inclusiveness.

President #Ramaphosa This moment in the evolution of his political thought is instructive, because it demonstrates the extent to which even the greatest leader is shaped by the circumstances of struggle, by the movement and by those around them. #MandelaDaypic.twitter.com/XDUsKOWBoe
President #Ramaphosa He understood the class content of the national struggle and the national content of the class struggle.
President #Ramaphosa Through hours of intensive engagement with comrades like Walter Sisulu & Moses Kotane, he came to appreciate the contribution of communists in the National Democratic Revolution.

President #Ramaphosa He was the first to acknowledge his mistakes. He allowed himself to be persuaded by sound argument and clear evidence. A defining moment in his political development was when he was able to overcome his hostility towards the Communist Party of South Africa.

President #Ramaphosa His steadfast commitment to principle remained throughout his life, regardless of the pressure that was placed on him. Yet, although he was firm in his convictions, even stubborn at times, he had an enormous capacity for introspection and reflection.

President #Ramaphosa He sacrificed his career as a lawyer. He sacrificed his freedom. Even as he faced the prospect of a death sentence, he defiantly asserted the moral superiority of the ideals of freedom, justice and equality. #Mandela100

President #Ramaphosa It turned him into a constant target of harassment, a fugitive, an absent husband and father, and a treason trialist. But he was a prisoner of his own convictions and principles. He selflessly continued his work despite the hardships.

President #Ramaphosa It was this theme – of voluntary and selfless service – that characterised his lifelong contribution to the South African people. At great risk to his own person, he undertook whatever task he was given.

President #Ramaphosa It says much about Madiba’s character, his contribution and his commitment that at the young age of 34 he was appointed Volunteer-in-Chief to lead the campaign for the defiance of the apartheid machinery and its unjust laws.

President #Ramaphosa It required women and men of courage to step forward to take upon themselves the most difficult tasks of the revolution. These were tasks that brought no reward, no recognition, no praise but only suffering. #MandelaDay

President #Ramaphosa Madiba was foremost among those who understood that militancy alone could not secure change. It required work and effort. It required tireless organisation, mobilisation and raising level of consciousness amongst our people about their condition.

President #Ramaphosa It was with a clear strategic purpose that they formed the ANC Youth League in 1944 and set about transforming the African National Congress into a mass based militant movement. In doing so, they changed the course of our struggle. #MandelaDay

President #Ramaphosa Nelson Mandela belonged to a remarkable generation of young people who rallied against the profound injustices and the daily indignities of their time. They thought their elders were too cautious, their methods too tentative. But they were not reckless.

President #Ramaphosa It was not a journey of one brave man. It was a journey of a multitude of women and men, known and unknown, who confronted the tyranny of injustice in pursuit of the dream of freedom.pic.twitter.com/IPbKgGvjft

President #Ramaphosa We have returned here to the start of a journey that over the course of a century bore witness to the hardship and suffering of a subjugated people, their courageous struggle to be free, the great sacrifices they made and the setbacks they endured.

President #Ramaphosa We have come to say thank you for giving Nelson Mandela to our nation, to Africa and indeed the whole world. Siyabulela. We salute the people of Mvezo, Qunu and eMqhekezweni. #MandelaDay #Mandela100

President #Ramaphosa: We've returned here to the place where one of the most extraordinary lives of modern times began. We've returned here to pay tribute to those who gave him life, taught him honesty, kindness & imbued in him an essential dignity & an abiding sense of justice.

“Today we recommit to renewal of the legacy of Tata Madiba & Mama Albertina. Eulogy by President Cyril Ramaphosa at the Official Funeral of the late Ambassador Billy Modise, Marks Park, Johannesburg. https://bit.ly/2KugZXn pic.twitter.com/OGBPKHMeyc

President #Ramaphosa We say farewell to an extraordinary human being, devastated by our loss, fortified by what we have been given, and moved by a deep and abiding affection. Tsamaya ka Khotso cde Billy. May your soul rest in peace. I thank you.

President #Ramaphosa You did this so that he could say goodbye to the organisation that he loved so much and served for his entire life. As I saw him lying peacefully in his hospital bed how I wished it were possible to bottle his recipe for life.

President #Ramaphosa You shared your son, your bother, your husband and your father with a grateful nation. Sis Yoliswa you allowed me a sacred moment to see him and be with him in hospital on the last day of his life.
President #Ramaphosa On behalf of the people of South Africa, we extend our deepest condolences to Yoliswa and the Modise family, to his comrades, his colleagues and his friends.
President #Ramaphosa Today, as we lay to rest a great revolutionary, we vow to continue his struggle – to pick up his spear where it has fallen.

President #Ramaphosa It is a struggle for decent education and relevant skills, for affordable health care, a living wage, decent jobs, land, houses, water and electricity. It is a struggle for unity, non-racialism and non-sexism; for dignity, respect and peace.

President #Ramaphosa The struggle to which Billy Modise dedicated his life continues. It is a struggle against hunger and homelessness, against violence and abuse, against severe inequality and chronic unemployment.

President #Ramaphosa His commitment to this cause was matched by his determination that women and men should be free and equal in all areas of life. He fought for a society where gender would never again be a determinant of status, wealth or opportunity.

President #Ramaphosa He was firmly convinced that non-racialism was the only viable, morally defensible response to the divisive and destructive policies of apartheid. It was both a principle to which one must hold fast and an objective which one must strive to achieve.
President #Ramaphosa He understood that no progress could be made without the unity of the oppressed and that no advances could be sustained without the unity of the South African people.
President #Ramaphosa Through engagement and persuasion – and no small degree of charm – he rallied disparate people behind a common cause.
President #Ramaphosa Cde Billy Modise brought diverse people together, convinced that their common humanity was more powerful and more compelling than any force that could divide them.

President #Ramaphosa Wherever he went in the world, from Lund to Lusaka, from the United Nations to the Union Buildings, he forged strong bonds of friendship. He made it his life’s work to ensure that South Africa built the foundation for a long-term partnership with Scandinavia.
President #Ramaphosa Throughout his life, Uncle Billy was a unifier. The desire for unity was an essential part of his nature as much as it was a product of his political consciousness.

President #Ramaphosa We are charged to forge a new society in which relations between people are characterised by respect, solidarity and equality – and where those who are given the responsibility to lead do so honestly and selflessly.
President #Ramaphosa It was an act of love, for the movement, for the country and for its people. We are bound to act as the stalwarts did, with purpose and conviction, to unite, rebuild and renew.

President #Ramaphosa It was a signal that we had strayed from the path of Chief Albert Luthuli, Oliver Tambo and Nelson Mandela. There was no bitterness in this act, nor pride, nor conceit. He generously gave us his knowledge, his expertise, his skills.

President #Ramaphosa It was a devastating signal of the extent to which the clamour for political office and access to public resources had disfigured the great movement that had nurtured and sustained him over a lifetime of struggle.

President #Ramaphosa It is a betrayal of those who fought so valiantly for our freedom. It was this understanding that explains Uncle Billy’s decision to count himself among those stalwarts who spoke out against the erosion of the values and principles of the ANC.

President #Ramaphosa It was founded on an understanding that the wealth of this country belongs to all its people and that to appropriate even the slightest portion for the enrichment of a few is a grave betrayal of the people’s trust.

President #Ramaphosa Like so many of his generation, he sought and received no reward. This was not simply a product of circumstance – it was a conscious political decision to always place the interests of the people above one’s own.

President #Ramaphosa He belonged to a generation of leaders who joined the struggle at great personal risk to themselves, a generation that was called upon to make great sacrifices and who suffered terrible hardship for their beliefs.

President #Ramaphosa His attention to detail, his meticulous planning, his respect for rules and procedures was a manifestation of a deeply-held believe that it is the responsibility of every revolutionary to apply themselves to the greatest extent of their ability.

President #Ramaphosa For him, the conduct of a cadre, a leader, a public servant was material to the purpose they were expected to serve. Respect, discipline and honesty were important attributes in a revolutionary.

President #Ramaphosa Billy Modise was a man of honesty and decency. There was an essential integrity to his being. The revolutionary politics that he first learnt in the Fort Hare branch of the ANC Youth League could not be extricated from his sense of revolutionary morality.

President #Ramaphosa His humanity and his internationalism imposed a responsibility on us that as we build our nation we should also support all those people who are engaged in a struggle to build theirs.

President #Ramaphosa It requires that we do not accept the detention of Palestinian children any more than we accept that there are still children in this country who have not seen the inside of a classroom.

President #Ramaphosa His spirit of solidarity required that we do not accept the suffering of the Saharawi people in refugee camps any more than we accept families living in appalling conditions on the fringes of our cities.
President #Ramaphosa He felt the same anguish whether a child died from tear gas in Gaza or in a pit toilet in Bizana. His principles compelled him and us to act to prevent such tragedy.
President #Ramaphosa He taught us that human solidarity is universal. It mattered not where injustice and suffering were to be found – it was equally and always a concern to him.

President #Ramaphosa More than a diplomat, Billy Modise was an internationalist. He inscribed his name in our movement’s foreign policy positions. He had firm principles. He expounded them clearly. He acted upon them decisively.

President #Ramaphosa It united the peoples of the world in declaring apartheid to be a crime against humanity and reinforced their resolve to struggle alongside the people of South Africa until they had won their freedom.

President #Ramaphosa It was a message that found resonance even among people who were far removed in both time and space from the troubles and the struggles of the South African people. It was a message of human solidarity which defied borders and traversed oceans.
President #Ramaphosa Measured in his delivery, clear in his articulation, passionate in his conviction, Billy Modise carried the message of our liberation struggle across the world.
President #Ramaphosa It sought a society freed from the iniquity of apartheid dispossession and subjugation, in which every person could realise their potential.
President #Ramaphosa He was drawn to the revolutionary politics of the Congress movement because it sought a fundamentally different order of social and economic relations.

President #Ramaphosa From his earliest experiences of the indignity and injustice of racial discrimination, Uncle Billy was driven throughout his life by a profound concern for the plight of the oppressed, vulnerable, poor and exploited.

President #Ramaphosa We saw in him the qualities that we seek in ourselves, and we found in him the human being that each of us so dearly want to become. He taught us that no life could be complete if it was not lived in the service of others.

President #Ramaphosa Some of us in the then leadership of the trade union movement saw this big heart when he guided us as trade unionists in our dealings with the Swedish trade union movement. He helped us navigate the dynamics of the politics of our movement.

President #Ramaphosa His intellect, his energy, and his enthusiasm are what made him who he was. He was bright, logical and systematic in his thinking. He was always willing to share his ideas and thoughts. Many of us found him to be a splendid person with a big heart.
President #Ramaphosa His warmth, his gentle manner, his humour and his humility drew us towards him. Yet his humility and humour had a purpose beyond what we could comprehend.
President #Ramaphosa We are drawn to this place as we were drawn to Uncle Billy because he was an easily approachable human being with such a cheerful and invigorating presence.

President #Ramaphosa There are few among us who so thoroughly represent the essence of what it means to be human. But most of all, many of us will remember him as one of nature’s greatest gentlemen. He was kind and warm towards everyone no matter their background.
President #Ramaphosa But there are few of them who have so entirely earned our affection as Ambassador Billy Modise, Esteemed Member of the Order of Luthuli.

President #Ramaphosa There are many among us who are due great honour and respect. Many have fought worthy struggles and achieved great victories. There are those whom we admire, for their wisdom, their courage and their compassion.
President #Ramaphosa We gather here to bid a fond farewell to Uncle Billy Modise as we remember Mama Albertina Sisulu & Tata Nelson Mandela who would have both turned 100 this year.
President #Ramaphosa We have lost a great South African, a great freedom fighter, above all many of us have lost a dear brother and a friend.

The late Ambassador Modise served as former Chief of State Protocol. Prior to this position, he worked for the UNand later the ANC appointed him as Chief Representative in Sweden. He also served as the first black High Commissioner of South Africa to Sweden from 1995 - 1999.pic.twitter.com/61Rxzz8DCa

President #Ramaphosa This is the South Africa that you must build. It is time for young women to take their rightful place in the life of the nation. This is your time to shine; your time to lead us. As President, I look forward to being replaced by one of you bright young womenpic.twitter.com/vtEe0ck660

President #Ramaphosa We are going to continue having these dialogues so that we can benefit from your wisdom. I would like to see a South Africa that leads the world in the way that it empowers and treats its women.

President #Ramaphosa We want to ensure that as young women you are positioned in a better place than they have been in the past. I want to invite you to work together with us. Our women ministers know their stuff and they give us guidance. We want to lead from the front.

President #Ramaphosa I am pleased to have been given this rare opportunity of being amongst you and listen to all the issues raised this evening from various walks of life. We want to walk this journey with you and focus on your empowerment.

President #Ramaphosa We must at setting up a Council located at a high level to raise the issue of gender based violence. The killing and raping of women is putting us to shame on global and we must address it in a way that empowers young men to raise their level of consciousness

President #Ramaphosa We have become gender sensitive and we want to do good by the women of our country - we must address the issue of gender based violence, we must address it as hard as we fighting corruption.

President #Ramaphosa We have women leaders in key government portfolios and we have become a government that is very sensitive to issues of women. Where we are lacking, we want you to engage us so that we may be able to address the issues that you raise.

President #Ramaphosa You said you want a Ministry of Women in the Presidency. The Ministry of Women is in the Union Buildings. Whenever I leave my office, I meet with Minister Bathabile Dlamini and she asks me: "President, what are you doing today for the Women of our country?"

President #Ramaphosa We invite you as young women to be brave and courageous like the many great women that have come before you and seize the opportunities that have been made available to you. Continue to be brave and unafraid and do not hold yourselves back.
President #Ramaphosa At an economic level we are focused on creating jobs for young people in our country. We are doing everything we can to open up opportunities and create jobs for young people.

President #Ramaphosa We should recognize that out government listens and gives an ear to what young people are saying. Similarly tonight, as you have articulated various issues, I can assure you that we are listening and we are taking notes.

President #Ramaphosa We must open pathways for young women to ensure that they stay in school and finish their studies. If they stumble, they must be given another opportunity so that they continue to move forward. We must never keep young women down.

President #Ramaphosa Men must take the backseat and listen in order for them to become active partners in bringing about solutions. Women must lead in bringing about solutions as they are innovative and creative. They must be given the opportunity to put these ideas forward.
President #Ramaphosa I would like to see this dialogue continue in August, it must be inter-generational and inclusive of men. Women's issues must be articulated in the presence of men.

President #Ramaphosa We need a movement that is going to ensure that men are taught to respect and honour women from a very young age. The criminal justice system must respond proactively & appropriately in rape and murder cases of women.

President #Ramaphosa Men have tended to do abominable things against girls and women of our country. This is a shame we bear with us as men. I urge our men to raise their level of consciousness and not look at women as objects, but look at women with great honour and respect.

President #Ramaphosa Women have a critical role to play in the makeup of a nation. Women take up the full responsibility for the building of the nation. Men must honour the women of our country as women bear the brunt of all social ills.

President #Ramaphosa Your gender, race or class must never determine your position in life or be the reason to hold you back. All constraints must be removed to free you to have a full identity. We want you to have a South Africa that will fully supported your endeavours.

President #Ramaphosa The South Africa you want must give you the skills and education that you deserve as young women. As you get the education you deserve we must ensure that you are safe and you have adequate resources. We must ensure that the education you get is decolonized.
President #Ramaphosa We are heeding what you are saying. The future belongs to you, you must shape the future you wish to see. We must listen to you and give you a South Africa that you want.

President #Ramaphosa The campaign you initiated as young women for sanitary pads has been widely accepted. Resources are being put in place to ensure that free sanitary pads are provided to young women. I am saying this to demonstrate that we are listening.

President #Ramaphosa Looking at you I am reminded of the women of 1956, who contributed to the struggle for liberation; women who had foresight and were able to see the future South Africa. You expressed views about the South Africa you wish to see in your dreams.

President #Ramaphosa You stood up for your rights as women and as young people. I appreciate you for following in the footsteps of great women of our country like uMama Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, uMama Albertina Sisulu, whose centenary we celebrate this year

President #Ramaphosa I rise to appreciate you as the young women and men who have braved this winter night to participate in this dialogue and expressing top-of-mind issues that affect young women in our country. Thank you for being forthright & courageous.

President #Ramaphosa Laat ons saam die toekoms van hierdie land beplan en bepaal. Laat ons saam die vrede van hierdie verskeurde, tragiese, verdeelde Suid‐Afrika soek. Ons is almal Suid-Afrikaners, wat hierdie land saam moet bou. Baie dankie.pic.twitter.com/6rdQMYMyre

President #Ramaphosa Let us seek peace together in this torn, tragic, divided South Africa. As we honour those who have come before us, as we pay tribute to those that lost their lives in defence of our liberty, let us heed the words of Beyers Naudé.
President #Ramaphosa ...say to them: let us plan and determine the future of this country together.

President #Ramaphosa Step outside and meet with black people, as they offer themselves in all sincerity to you. Grab the hand of friendship that is still being extended, even at this late hour, to you as Afrikaners and as white rulers of this country...

President #Ramaphosa “...that can destroy the Afrikaners as well. Break free from this ideological system that is enslaving and suffocating your whole life. Do not seek security in weapons, in an exclusive identity or in clinging to false loyalties…”

President #Ramaphosa Oom Bey said: “So, should you ask me what message Steve Biko’s life has for the Afrikaners that we should heed today, I would say it was this: break free from the prison of your subservience to an ideology that is leading our country towards disaster and...”

President #Ramaphosa It is appropriate to recall these words, delivered over 40 years ago, because they capture in many ways the journey of the Broederbond into the Afrikanerbond, the journey of our country from apartheid to democracy.
President #Ramaphosa Speaking in the days following the death in detention of Steve Biko in 1977, Oom Bey reflected on Biko’s message to fellow South Africans.
President #Ramaphosa Allow me to conclude by borrowing the words of Beyers Naudé, one of the finest South Africans ever to have been a member of the Broederbond.
President #Ramaphosa If there is anything that our history has taught us, it is that the advancement of some cannot be achieved or sustained without the advancement of all.
President #Ramaphosa But as we look ahead to the next 100 years, we must be firm in our resolve that the Afrikanerbond be an instrument of unity, progress and equality.
President #Ramaphosa As we reflect on the last 100 years, we must acknowledge that for millions of South Africans, the Broederbond was an instrument of misery and hardship.

President #Ramaphosa They are as integral to the South African nation as any other community. Their language, their culture, their needs and their aspirations are no less important – and no more important – than those of their compatriots.

President #Ramaphosa As we mark the 100th anniversary of the Afrikanerbond, it is inevitable that we reflect on the place and role of the Afrikaner in our history and in our democracy. Afrikaners are by name and by definition Africans.

President #Ramaphosa “If well handled, land reform will help bind the nation together & produce benefits for all. If badly managed, it will simply redistribute resentment, damage the economy & destroy social peace. If not undertaken, the country will remain divided at its heart.”
President #Ramaphosa Let us remember that: “The question is not whether or not to have land reform. Have it we must, and in a deep and meaningful way…

President #Ramaphosa They have taken the initiative and – with differing degrees of success –have developed different models for local land reform and agricultural development. We commend their efforts and call on others to follow their lead.

President #Ramaphosa Already, we know of several established white farmers who have found ways of sharing the land with farmworkers, labour tenants and neighbouring communities. They have not waited for government to arrive or act.

President #Ramaphosa It is an opportunity to build a more just, more equitable society that makes full and effective use of all the resources it has – its land, its mineral wealth, its oceans and, most importantly, its people.
President #Ramaphosa We call on all South Africans – including the members of the Afrikanerbond – to see the acceleration of land reform not as a threat, but as an opportunity.
President #Ramaphosa We do so by providing land close to urban centres for housing for the poor. We do so by providing emerging farmers with finance, training and other support.

President #Ramaphosa We do so by returning land that was forcibly taken from African, coloured and Indian South Africans. We do so by securing the rights of labour tenants to the land they have occupied for generations.pic.twitter.com/OU2Rb4Ty1J
President #Ramaphosa We also need to acknowledge that the taking of land and removal of the majority of South Africans from their land was the source of the poverty and inequality we see.
President #Ramaphosa It is our responsibility to unlock the economic value of the land. It is our collective responsibility to deal with and reduce poverty and inequality.

President #Ramaphosa By restricting the ownership and use of land to a small minority over many decades, the apartheid government made sure that the country would never realise the full potential of this valuable resource.

President #Ramaphosa By the same measure, all those who need land, whether to build a house or to run a business, should be equally able to have title to land in well-located parts of our towns and cities.

President #Ramaphosa The land should never have been and will not be reserved for one group of South Africans. Our aim must be to ensure that all those who work the land – and who want to work the land – should be equally able to have such land.

President #Ramaphosa In approaching this issue, we are guided by the Freedom Charter, which said: ‘The land shall be shared among those who work it’. I want to emphasise this point, that the land shall be shared.pic.twitter.com/DTViDI1CTs
President #Ramaphosa It provides us with an opportunity to move together with purpose and determination to address one of the most contentious issues in our country’s history.

President #Ramaphosa Among the measures that government should use where appropriate is the expropriation of land without compensation. This has generated significant debate and much interest in the question of land in South Africa.

President #Ramaphosa Hierdie is dieselfde benadering wat ons sal volg met die oplossing van die grond-vraagstuk. The ANC took a resolution at its 54th National Conference in December to accelerate the process of land reform.

President #Ramaphosa We remain committed to affirmative action that is meaningful and improves the lives of all our people. We remain committed in its implementation to dialogue, consultation and inclusiveness.pic.twitter.com/e7i9qNgaNK

President #Ramaphosa We have a responsibility, as a society, to address these concerns. If we do not engage on these matters and seek to find consensus, we undermine efforts to build a united society in which all feel at home.

President #Ramaphosa It is a concern that is to be found in many other areas where we have taken measures to end white privilege and correct past injustices, whether it be employment equity, black economic empowerment or preferential procurement.

President #Ramaphosa This process, as it has unfolded over the last 24 years, has caused anxiety and even dissent in some sections of the Afrikaans community. We know that this is a matter that concerns the Afrikanerbond.

President #Ramaphosa This proved to be a barrier to access and, had steps not been taken to change language policies at many such institutions, would have undermined our commitment to equal access to educational opportunities.
President #Ramaphosa We have had to confront the reality that many of the better resourced public schools and around a quarter of our universities were Afrikaans-medium institutions.
President #Ramaphosa As we have undertaken this task, we have had to confront the many impediments to equal access to education, including issues of poverty, distance, social norms and language.

President #Ramaphosa It was therefore imperative that the democratic government take urgent and far-reaching measures to establish an education system that benefits all South Africans equally. We have made great progress, but we have much further to go.

President #Ramaphosa As we know, this had a devastating effect on the social and economic capabilities of generations of black South Africans, a deficiency that continues to severely limit the development of our economy and the transformation of our society.
President #Ramaphosa As a democratic state, we inherited a severely unequal education system which directed the bulk of resource towards white institutions.

President #Ramaphosa Hierdie is ‘n realiteit wat die Afrikanerbond lank reeds erken en ons vertrou dat dit sy programme en aksies in die toekoms sal rig. Hierdie is ‘n vertrekpunt wat ons benadering tot onderwys moet toelig.

President #Ramaphosa It should do so informed by a determination to correct the injustices of the past, but based also on an understanding that a stable, prosperous and free South Africa is dependent on a more equal distribution of economic and social resources.pic.twitter.com/CrTtiOBNbw

President #Ramaphosa It should do so informed by a determination to correct the injustices of the past, but based also on an understanding that a stable, prosperous and free South Africa is dependent on a more equal distribution of economic and social resources.
President #Ramaphosa Now, as we work to build an inclusive society, we look to the Afrikanerbond to play its part in unleashing the economic potential of all the people of this country.

President #Ramaphosa While this contributed in no small measure to the highly unequal distribution of wealth, skills and opportunity in our society, the Broederbond was responsible for unleashing the economic potential of the Afrikaner people.
President #Ramaphosa One of the singular achievements of the Broederbond was the economic empowerment of the Afrikaner.

President #Ramaphosa Hierdie is ‘n inisiatief waarvan die Afrikanerbond ‘n integrale deel van moet wees. Die Afrikanerbond kan ‘n bydrae maak tot die groei en transformasie van die ekonomie en daardeur sy Credo verwesentlik.

President #Ramaphosa We are hard at work to deepen our efforts to stabilise state owned enterprises and set them on a path of recovery, to reduce the cost of doing business and to maintain our investment in economic and social infrastructure.

President #Ramaphosa As the first quarter GDP figures indicate, there is a pressing need to push forward with urgency to resolve policy issues in key industries like mining & telecommunications, to promote industrialisation more intensively & to advance productive land reform.

President #Ramaphosa It lies behind our determination as this government to undertake an ambitious investment drive to stimulate growth in the productive sectors of our economy. Part of this investment drive are concrete steps to remove all the impediments to greater investment.

President #Ramaphosa It informs our focus on transformation, changing patterns of ownership, management and control to benefit black and women South Africans. It informs our focus on education and skills development, on employment equity and preferential procurement.

President #Ramaphosa It is this demand that stands at the centre of the economic policy of every administration since 1994, to lift the majority of South Africans out of poverty by building an inclusive economy that creates jobs.
President #Ramaphosa This means that we must strive together to realise the demand of the Freedom Charter that the people shall share in the country’s wealth.
President #Ramaphosa If we are to achieve this, we need to heed the injunction in our Constitution not only to recognise the injustices of our past but to also work together to redress them.

President #Ramaphosa More importantly, we owe it to our children to forge a nation in which all may have security, all may have shelter and comfort and where all may enjoy an improving quality of life.

President #Ramaphosa That is the South Africa that all of us, together, have a responsibility to build. We owe it to the memory of Nelson Mandela and Albertina Sisulu to forge a new nation that is united in its diversity.
President #Ramaphosa They believed that South Africa belonged to all its people equally and that none should be discriminated against on the basis of language, faith, culture, creed or origin.
President #Ramaphosa They both believed deeply that Afrikaners were an essential and integral part of the South African nation.

President #Ramaphosa It is just as important – perhaps even more so – for understanding our future. Nelson Mandela and Albertina Sisulu were among the most consistent proponents of a united, non-racial, non-sexist society in which all would have equal rights and opportunities.

President #Ramaphosa The fact that we mark the centenary of the Afrikanerbond in the same year as we celebrate the centenary of the births of Nelson Mandela and Albertina Sisulu is important not only in understanding our past.
President #Ramaphosa It was the same Broederbond that would reconcile itself to the new democratic dispensation and would embrace the values and principles contained in our new Constitution.

President #Ramaphosa It was the same Broederbond that was behind a process of reform in the National Party and in sections of white society that contributed to the release of Mandela, the unbanning of liberation movements and the negotiated transition to democracy.
President #Ramaphosa It is therefore significant that it was the same Broederbond that began in the 1980s to cast doubt on the sustainability and even the morality of the system of apartheid.
President #Ramaphosa And it was against a government led by members of the Broederbond that Nelson Mandela, Albertina Sisulu and others mobilised a powerful movement of defiance and resistance.
President #Ramaphosa It was a government led by prominent members of the Broederbond who imprisoned Nelson Mandela and banned, detained and harassed Albertina Sisulu.

President #Ramaphosa This was the antithesis of the apartheid policies championed by the Broederbond from at least the 1930s and implemented with great zeal after the National Party came to power in 1948.
President #Ramaphosa They sought to build a society founded on the fundamental principle contained in the Freedom Charter that ‘South Africa belongs to all who live in it, black and white’.
President #Ramaphosa Their lives – the values for which they stood and the freedoms for which they fought – stood in sharp contrast to the goals and ethos of the Broederbond.

President #Ramaphosa We have dedicated this year to the celebration of the centenary of his birth and to the celebration of the centenary of Albertina Nontsikelelo Sisulu, another giant of the struggle for freedom and democracy.
President #Ramaphosa This young boy was called Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela and he would become the first President of the Republic of South Africa never to have been a member of the Broederbond.

President #Ramaphosa There is great symbolism in the celebration of this centenary. Little more than a month after the Afrikaner Broederbond was founded in June 1918 at a home in Malvern, Johannesburg, a son was born to a chief of the abaThembu in the tiny village of Mvezo.

President #Ramaphosa Daarom sal ons: Die fundamentele regte van elke indiwidu en elke groep in hierdie land met vasberadenheid verdedig; Ons beywer vir die uitskakeling van diskriminasie op elke terrein waar dit voorkom…

President #Ramaphosa As the Credo itself says: Ngakho-ke thina: Sizovikela amalungelo alowo nalowo kanye nawaleso naleso sigaba sabantu bakuleli ngokusabela ngokushesha; Sizolwela ukuqeda ukucwaswa uma kwenzeka emphakathini wethu…
President #Ramaphosa It reflects a determination to forge an Afrikaner identity that is rooted in a commitment to enhance the quality of life and human dignity of all people in South Africa.

President #Ramaphosa Today, the Afrikaner Bond is an organisation that is much changed. It is not only known by a different name, but its credo reflects a desire to build an inclusive, just and truly democratic society.

President #Ramaphosa This is a historic reality that we must acknowledge and reflect on. We cannot not deny our history, for it lives on in the present. We cannot change our divided past, but we can together shape our common future.

President #Ramaphosa It is a tragedy that the desire of the Afrikaner people for self-determination, preservation of their language & culture & the affirmation of their identity should have formed the basis for the perpetuation of the discriminatory practices of the colonial era.

President #Ramaphosa Yet, it is one of the greatest tragedies of South Africa in the 20th century that in pursuing the rights & freedoms that all peoples yearn for & deserve, the Afrikaner Broederbond would inevitably deny the majority of South Africans the same rights & freedoms
President #Ramaphosa It was born out of the suppression of Afrikaans as a language and the frustration of the economic and political aspirations of the citizens of the former Boer republics.

President #Ramaphosa It was a movement born out of the subjugation of the Afrikaner people by the British, the pain and resentment caused by the destruction of Boer farms and the imprisonment in concentration camps of Boer women and children.
#Ramaphosa For nearly 50 years, the Afrikaner Broederbond stood at the centre of the political and economic life of South Africa.
#Ramaphosa This seminal document was a precursor to the Freedom Charter, the ANC’s Constitutional Guidelines and the country’s democratic Constitution.
#Ramaphosa It is 75 years since the adoption of the Africans’ Claims in South Africa document, which set out the demands of black South Africans for equal rights and self-determination.

#Ramaphosa As the Broderbond was being formed 100 years ago the Bantu Women’s League, a forerunner of the ANC Women’s League was the first organisation in the country to take up the struggle of South African women.

#Ramaphosa This year is also 105 years since the 1913 Land Act and 95 years since the Native Urban Areas Act, two pieces of legislation that were central to the deprivation of black South Africans of their land, assets & livelihoods. The effects of these laws continue to be felt.
#Ramaphosa The rebellion, which was quashed by the colonial authorities, was one of the earliest instances of organised multi-racial resistance to tyranny and injustice in South Africa.
#Ramaphosa The one obscure event that we should remember as a nation is what happened 210 years ago when slaves rebelled in 1808 in the Cape seeking a free state and freedom for all slaves.

#Ramaphosa 2018 is an important year in the life of our country in more ways than many. It is a year in which we commemorate a number of key historical events that have shaped the future of our country.
#Ramaphosa Hierdie is ‘n beduidende geleentheid, wat ons as Suid-Afrikaners moet erken en waardeer.
#Ramaphosa Goeie naand! Dit is vir my ‘n groot voorreg dat u my uitgenooi het vir die geskiedkundige 100 jarige viering van die bestaan van die Afrikanerbond.
President Cyril Ramaphosa arrives in Paarl, Western Cape for this evening’s Centenary Celebrations of the Afrikanerbond.pic.twitter.com/uD1udukc5i

The Afrikanerbond was established in 1918, the same year our struggle icons Tata Nelson Mandela and Mama Albertina Sisulu were born, to fight against subjugation of the Afrikaner people by the British.

President is expected to raise expropriation of land without compensation as a means to accelerate land redistsribution, conditions of farm workers, crime & the role each South African is expected to play towards a united, non-racial, non-sexist democratic & prosperous society

President #Ramaphosa “We have restored confidence and trust in the hearts and minds of South Africans in the direction that the country is taking...”pic.twitter.com/INfiGFTy5z

President #Ramaphosa Thuma Mina is a campaign for all of us to take action & work for our communities. Our volunteers are in all corners of the country listening to our people and intervening to resolve their problems. We must contribute in changing people’s lives for the better.

President #Ramaphosa We are all South Africans. The ANC is the instrument that assists us to deliver on the needs and aspirations of our people as elected. The ANC must come up with policies that will ensure improvement in their lives. It is therefore the political centre.
President #Ramaphosa We support that the Auditor-General be given powers to intervene timeously when presented with evidence of wrongdoing and corruption in our institutions
President #Ramaphosa Through the Commission of Enquiry, Justice Zondo will be investigating state capture and this process will assist us get to the bottom of corruption.

President #Ramaphosa We are working on the issue of municipalities that are not functioning optimally. We are paying much attention on the issues raised in the report of the Auditor-General about our municipalities
President #Ramaphosa Our municipalities must work for the people. I'm going to be conducting unannounced visits to see how our communities are being serviced.

President #Ramaphosa That our people still live in shacks does not sit well with us. The ANC led government has built over 4 million homes and that has never happened in any other country on the continent. We are still going to continue building houses for our people.pic.twitter.com/PUWreZHVvK
President #Ramaphosa The policy on land expropriation without compensation will be implementedpic.twitter.com/DDKyPmtq7j
President #Ramaphosa on Afriforum and their position on apartheid not being a crime against humanitypic.twitter.com/cXU3Gaqq2l

President #Ramaphosa People like to see value of our currency, but we need to do the right things to ensure that our economy is going in the right direction. When we do right things we will see growth in our economypic.twitter.com/U8ayQA4U2m

President #Ramaphosa We are competing with other countries to attract investment. We have set investment targets and we are determined to work hard to reach them. We want to attract R1.2 trillion over the next 5 years. This will help us create jobs and improve people’s livespic.twitter.com/46ZShdwdKR

President #Ramaphosa We need to ensure that when compared to other countries, South Africa is attractive to maximize on investment opportunities. Our policies need to promote stability and provide certainty to potential investors.
President #Ramaphosa on creating jobs and fixing the economypic.twitter.com/0SyU8MHGJ9
